headline: SERG101
content_plain:
SERG101 Aguero's tonderful for Pep By PHIL THOMAS SERGIO AGUERO made it a
century of goals for Pep Guardiola as Manchester City dished out a clinical
lesson in finishing. Aguero struck twice to rack up 101 goals under the Spaniard
and take his tally to half a dozen after just four games this season. And that
saw him equal a Premier League best haul for August  level with former City
striker Edin Dzeko, who did it in 2011, and Blackburn hotshot Chris Sutton from
1997. Manager Guardiola purred: "Sergio has scored goals with Argentina, in Turn
to Page 3 Manchester City..............4 Brighton..............................0
TON OF FUN ... Aguero hails his second goal while (below) he scores his first to
make it 100 goals under boss Pep Guardiola MAN CITY GOALS UNDER PEP (all
competitions) Sergio Aguero 101 Raheem Sterling 64 Gabriel Jesus 46 Leroy Sane
39 David Silva 28 Kevin De Bruyne 26 Bernardo Silva 23 Ilkay Gundogan 17 Riyad
Mahrez 12 Fernandinho 9 DREAM TEAM RATINGS SERG From Page 1 England with all the
managers he's had, with the national team. "He's a special talent and I love
that from day one he has tried to do it. "We changed many things, how we wanted
him to play, but from day one I have been delighted with his commitment. "There
are no complaints. Of course we need his goals, everyone knows it but even days
he doesn't, with commitment like this there can be nothing to say. I'm so happy
for him and the team." Pep  who along with his players wore black armbands in
tribute to former Barcelona team-mate Luis Enrique's nineyear- old daughter,
Xana, who died from bone cancer this week  was also keen to praise Brighton for
trying to play football against the champions. He added: "The result was 4-0 but
the performance wasn't because they did really well. "Few teams come here and
play with that courage. "The difference was, as I have said many times, the
players we have got up front. "Managers like Graham Potter are very good for
football. "The credit is to Brighton. When I said they were good some people
didn't believe me. "They created some problems that usually we don't have."
Seagulls chief Potter agreed with Guardiola's appraisal and said: "The result
isn't something we enjoy but the performance was one of real courage. "Whatever
you do here it's very difficult. We just wanted to try to be ourselves and test
ourselves against the very best. "It's only our fourth game together and we
thought it was a chance to learn and develop. We can take a lot from the
performance." POTTER ... proud of his team

headline: Gerrard is ready for war
content_plain:
By COLIN DUNCAN STEVEN GERRARD has told his players not to pat themselves on the
back.

He knows today's Old Firm derby at Ibrox stands as Gers' biggest test of the
season so far.

The Gers qualified for the Europa League group stages by beating Legia Warsaw,
sparking wild scenes at Ibrox.

And he knows the Hoops remain the benchmark by which Gers must be judged if the
celebrations for Euro progress are to be matched by a domestic party this
season.

Gerrard said: "The hardest part is getting over the line.

"It is tough to win, but I do get a different feeling in terms of this group.

"We spoke at the end of last season and the beginning of this season about being
hungry.

"We spoke about finding a better level of consistency and, so far, the evidence
has been there that we are more consistent.

"But we are not in a position where we should be patting ourselves on the back.

"Sure, we deserve credit for qualifying two years in a row for the Europa League
group stage  but there is a long way to go.

"The next step and the next challenge is, 'Can we win something?' That's the
hardest part.

"The mentality has changed. It's a group of players with more confidence and
belief.

"We've got better players in the door now." Gerrard added: "We have experienced
beating Celtic on a couple of occasions and going close to beating them, even at
Celtic Park in the second away fixture last season.

"Having said that, we still know Celtic come as a fantastic team with really
good players.

"They are in a good place themselves, they are playing with confidence and
scoring heavily.

"It is set up for a fantastic match.

"Just because we have more belief and confidence about ourselves doesn't mean
our respect for Celtic changes.

"We still know they are the team to beat, the team to catch.

"But if we find a performance close to our maximum, any team that comes to Ibrox
is going to find it tough to beat us."

headline: MO IS GOOD TO GO
content_plain:
IT would be an El of an Old Firm baptism of fire but Celtic's new loan star
insists he is ready to answer Neil Lennon's call at Ibrox today.

Mohamed Elyounoussi only joined the Hoops from Southampton on Friday but could
make his debut against Rangers.

The £16million man has not played a competitive game in four months after
falling out of favour at St Mary's. Yet Norwegian Elyounoussi would have no
fears about being pitched straight in against Steven Gerrard's men.

He said: "If the gaffer needs me I am ready.

"I have played derbies before but I don't think there is anything like this in
Europe.

"I feel OK, I feel fit and I have been training hard.

"Obviously I haven't played for a long time but I feel good.

"I would like to play, of course. I have come here to make an impact and help
the team to win games.

"Obviously it is a big game so either way it's something I'm really looking
forward to, whether watching or taking part.

"In Norway it was a rivalry between Molde and Rosenborg, more than a real derby.

"It was a bit friendly, no real fight or hooligans! In Basel, it was more about
the football as well.

"From what I have heard there's a lot of history behind everything the two clubs
do in Glasgow, so I've not experienced anything like that."

Elyounoussi is already known to the Celtic fans after scoring home and away in
the Europa League for Molde in 2015.

But he confirmed he could also have been pulling on the Hoops after Ronny Deila
made a move in January 2016.

Celtic could not agree a fee with Molde and Elyounoussi admits he was gutted
when the transfer did not materialise. He said: "I had a good experience against
Celtic for Molde  a goal and an assist in both games  but now I get the chance
to do it for Celtic rather than against them.

"I also knew about Celtic's interest back then.

"From what I've heard, I was a bit too expensive.

"I can't confirm that but it's what I heard. I remember at that time I really
wanted to come to Celtic, especially after playing at the stadium. The
atmosphere was amazing that night  until we scored.

"It was my wish to come to Celtic at that time. I would have signed if I could.
But it's better late than never, for sure."

Elyounoussi reckons the current Celtic side are miles ahead of that struggling
Deila team from 2015-16.

The ace added: "I felt like Celtic was the right choice. The club, size of club
and the way they play football too.

"They play attacking, aggressive football. I watched games and I just liked it
instantly and wanted to be a part of it.

"I have come here to win games, to win titles and for myself to get better as a
player.

"I know Kristoffer Ajer, Fraser Forster and other players who have been here
like Stuart Armstrong. They have said good things about the club.

"I'm here to become a better player and try to help the team to win titles.
That's all I want.

"I like the pressure of history and going for the title.

"I can compare it to my time at Basel when they had won the league seven times
in a row.

"The pressure was huge from the fans every year, to win the league, the Cup and
do well in Europe.

"I liked that pressure and the challenge, so that's why I am here at Celtic  I
want to win more titles."

Lennon has challenged Elyounoussi to rediscover the form that saw Southampton
pay Basel £16m for him last summer.

The Norwegian flitted in and out of the team as injury and a change of manager
took its toll.

He said: "It was all small details. It didn't start great because I was injured
and it took some time.

"It was my first game and I got injured when I'd never had one in my career. I
got back in, then the manager got sacked, a new manager came in  a lot of
things went on and it was hard to get momentum.

"But I look back and try to learn from it."

headline: RAN 'EM RAGGED
subheadline: Numbers stack up as legend slays Seagulls
content_plain:
MAN CITY.........4 De Bruyne 2; Aguero 42, 55; B Silva 79 BRIGHTON..........0 By
PHIL THOMAS HOME comforts, seventh heaven and a century of smiles ... Sergio
Aguero is leaving City fans spoilt for choice this season.

Another double from the champions' deadliest marksman brought up 101 goals in
134 games under Pep Guardiola.

Not bad for a guy whose workrate the gaffer doubted so much at first that he
went out and spent £28.6million on Gabriel Jesus.

A double which made it 99 goals at the Etihad  a record just Wayne Rooney and
Thierry Henry, at Old Trafford and Highbury respectively, can better for Prem
goals at one venue.

A double which made it six in just four matches before the end of August for the
Argentine. And just for good measure, a double which means Aguero's last seven
shots on target have all ended in the back of the net.

All of which ensured a fixture that on paper always looked like one of the
biggest mismatches you'll see all year, did indeed end up as just that.

To be fair to those who questioned Brighton's 33-1 odds  though there were not
many who were not Seagulls fans  it did take just 69 seconds to see why.

That is how long it took before City were ahead. That is how long before an
uphill task became an Everest-sized one, as the first real attack brought the
ultimate reward.

Indeed, you could have added a nought to Brighton's price and there still would
not have been many takers.

The worrying thing for them in that blink-of-an-eye opening was how easily they
were sliced open.

There was not a hint of onetouch, pinball-passing incision about it, either.
Just a ball down the line from Oleksandr Zinchenko, a pull back from David Silva
and Kevin De Bruyne nonchalantly strolling into the box to sidefoot home from
eight yards.

Maybe if Shane Duffy was playing it might have been cleared? The Ireland man was
surprisingly left on Brighton's bench just days before the Euro 2020 qualifier
against Switzerland and though one or two whispers of a minor knock did the
rounds on social media, this was not confirmed.

Back to City. Riyad Mahrez fired straight at keeper Mat Ryan after jinking
impishly inside, De Bruyne drilled a low fizzer a couple of feet wide and Aguero
pulled another just too far left.

Oh, and in between times, Kyle Walker took out the frustration of his England
axing in a thundering 50-50 with Dale Stephens that had 50,000-plus wincing.

Not half as much as they were ten minutes from the break when Aymeric Laporte
flew into a challenge  more like an assault  to stop Adam Webster.

It certainly did that, earning a justifiable yellow card.

More worrying was the sight of Laporte leaving on a stretcher in agony, his
right knee banged horribly in the collision.

With John Stones sidelined and no new centre-back brought in ,Pep will be
praying the Frenchman is not too seriously injured. But the way Laporte
immediately flung his arm into the air for treatment and the anguish on his face
made it look like we are talking months rather than weeks.

That brief Brighton foray was also a reminder that, for all the City dominance,
a one-goal cushion still meant where there is life there is hope. But not for
long.

Not after Aguero pounced for the first time in the afternoon.

And if the opener was a pretty basic affair, this one had the Guardiola stamp
running through it from start to finish.

It began with Zinchenko to Nicolas Otamendi on halfway and continued with Walker
rolling a ball forwards from midfield.

Mahrez then backheeled telepathically to the right, De Bruyne delivered
radar-like at full pace and Aguero stepped back across before smashing into the
roof of the net.

From that moment it became damage limitation, even if Fernandinho did have to
head one 50th-minute goalbound shot from Leandro Trossard to safety after a
Zinchenko rush of blood.

Another shake-from-the-slumbers warning for City? It may well have been because
a couple of minutes later it was 3-0. Zinchenko, spending more time in the
opposition half than his own, fed Silva and when he teed up Aguero, the curled
edge-ofthe-box strike could not have been more clinical.

De Bruyne went close to a stunning fourth when he volleyed wide but they did not
have long to wait for it. And in Bernardo Silva's case, just 17 seconds after
stepping from the bench to replace namesake David.

His first burst into the box was on to Aguero's set-up, which he despatched
across Ryan into the far corner.

Two-horse race? If City keep up this sort of form, even that will be a tad
optimistic.

headline: Jor king of the Palace
content_plain:
CRYSTAL PALACE....1 Ayew 73 ASTON VILLA...........0 JORDAN AYEW broke Crystal
Palace's home duck to sink his old club.

The Ghana striker's stunning secondhalf strike was the Eagles' first goal at
Selhurst Park this season, after firing blanks in both of their previous games
on their own patch.

It was a sweet moment for Ayew, who scored seven goals in 30 Premier League
games for Villa in the 2015-16 relegation campaign.

But the visitors, who were reduced to ten men on 54 minutes, were left fuming
after ref Kevin Friend disallowed sub Henri Lansbury's late 'goal' and booked
their skipper Jack Grealish for diving.

Whether Grealish intentionally went to ground after playing in Lansbury will be
debated long and hard.

The angry captain had to be held back from confronting Friend by his team-mates
as Palace celebrated only their third win in nine home games.

It must have been show-and-tell day at Selhurst as on the half-hour mark, Palace
Ultras 'The Holmesdale Fanatics' unveiled three banners with messages slamming
Bury owner Steve Dale, the EFL and the FA for the Shakers' sad midweek demise.

The Palace players were just as creative on the park in the first half, only for
their finishing touch to let them down.

James McArthur should have put them ahead on 22 minutes but he blazed Jeffrey
Schlupp's cross over the bar from eight yards.

MATCH C PALACE 5/10......Shots on/7................Blocked
53%.............384..................13....................

Villa keeper Tom Heaton then plucked the ball out of the air after Schlupp's
shot zipped off the turf and up towards the roof of the net  before Ayew was
just inches away 2/0..........Yellow/from sliding in McArthur's cross. Just
before the break Heaton superbly tipped Luka Milivojevic's free-kick around a
post before palming Cheikhou Kouyate's header over the bar.

Villa had four players booked in the first half and it was no surprise when one
of them, Trezeguet, was sent off for a second yellow card after a foul on
Wilfried Zaha.

With a man advantage, Palace pressed in search of the breakthrough and
Milivojevic's 25-yard curler produced a superb stop from Heaton.

Just as the natives started to get a bit restless, up stepped Ayew to break the
deadlock with a stunning strike.

The frontman appeared to be in a cul-de-sac after running into the channel to
collect Schlupp's pass.

But he turned inside England newboy Tyrone Mings and Grealish before steering
his shot past Heaton.

You could almost taste Palace's relief. But their celebrations were almost
spoilt when Lansbury fired a shot into the bottom corner near the end.

Ref Friend disallowed the goal and booked Grealish for diving in the build-up,
even though the Villa captain did not appeal for a foul as he hit the deck under
a challenge from Gary Cahill.

STATS Villa fan Prince William  not at the game  would not have been happy.

headline: Callum's fuming over Youri tackle
content_plain:
CALLUM WILSON accused VAR of letting Youri Tielemans off the hook with a tackle
that almost broke his ankle.

The Foxes midfielder went over the top of the ball in an attempt to retain
possession and inadvertently brought his studs down on Wilson's ankle, which
buckled alarmingly.

England and Bournemouth striker Wilson was furious ref Peter Bankes failed to
reach for his red and stunned when VAR failed to overrule him.

Wilson said: "If that's not clear and obvious, then I don't over the top and on
to my shin. He almost broke my ankle  it warranted a card."

Cherries chief Eddie Howe said: "It looked a bad one. It was a dangerous and
reckless challenge.

"I don't know what VAR is thinking in terms of why it hasn't acted."

Foxes boss Brendan Rodgers added: "When you slow them down they look worse than
they are."

headline: VARD 2 BEAT
content_plain:
LEICESTER........3 Vardy 12, 73; Tielemans 41 B'mouth..........1 C Wilson 15 By
GRAEME BRYCE VINTAGE Jamie Vardy magic left Leicester third in the table and
unbeaten ahead of the international break.

He grabbed a double as the Foxes underlined their credentials as serious
contenders to break up the top six this season.

Brendan Rodgers' side have won two and drawn two of their opening four games and
the elated boss gathered his players near the centre circle for a celebratory
huddle.

Bournemouth, meanwhile, were left in a muddle.

They dropped down to 15th as their defence imploded with a performance so
alarming that it will raise questions as to why midweek England call-up Tyrone
Mings was allowed to leave for Aston Villa during the summer.

At both ends of the park some of the defending bordered on farcical, if you were
being kind.

Take Leicester's opener after 12 minutes. If there is one thing everyone knows
about the Foxes it is that they have a useful striker. Name of Vardy  you may
have heard of him.

Legend has it he is so quick he can switch off his bedroom light and be tucked
up under the covers before it's dark.

Now fast forward to match day when he pumps himself up by swigging down a
minimum three cans of a well-known energy drink. Suddenly he is a whippet  with
wings!

So how could Bournemouth's dozy defenders fail to fathom it was a bad idea to
leave Vardy acres of space to run into behind them? Come to think of it, why did
Chris Mepham and Steve Cook fail to cut out the danger at source when they
watched Ben Chilwell's hoofed pass travel fully 50 yards towards them? Somehow,
neither thought to apply the simple header required to defend their line and
suddenly Vardy was off haring past them.

Naturally, he arrived at the ball first. One bounce off the turf and then a
sublime lob with the outside of his right boot sent it sailing over Aaron
Ramsdale's head from 25 yards and into the corner of the net.

However, three minutes later Leicester were at it as they gifted the Cherries a
speedy equaliser.

Adam Smith found Harry Wilson with a throw and the winger moved the ball on to
Ryan Fraser.

The Scotland international ran at Ricardo Pereira, looked up and threaded a cute
ball behind Jonny Evans to Callum Wilson.

Caglar Soyuncu watched it happen  but somehow did not think to match the
striker's bread-and-butter run into the channel.

And that gave him the space he needed to dink the ball beyond Kasper Schmeichel
and in off the post for his first goal of the season.

Leicester responded as James Maddison flashed a header just wide from a Marc
Albrighton cross, before Soyuncu almost made amends for his howler by curling a
shot just over.

And the Foxes retook the lead just before half-time.

You guessed it, the Cherries' defence was caught napping when Vardy turned
provider, brushing past a powder-puff challenge from Cook to roll the ball
across the face of goal.

Youri Tielemans nipped in to flick it home off the inside of the far post.

After the break, VAR roared into action when Belgium midfielder Tielemans was
guilty of a horrific challenge on Callum Wilson, which saw him rake his studs
down the striker's ankle.

In fairness to Tielemans he had looked to be protecting the ball  and VAR
agreed that it was not a malicious challenge  although he was still a lucky boy
to stay on the park.

Ironically, he could not even be yellow-carded, as VAR can only check for
red-card offences.

Callum Wilson's day was going from the sublime to the ridiculous and he was
booked for a dive in the box before Leicester put the game beyond his team with
a third.

Maddison tried a clever stepover in the box to set up Vardy  but Mepham read
the danger and intercepted.

In keeping with the day, though, he then dallied and Maddison poked the ball
away from his toes to Tielemans, who slipped a pass to Vardy on his left.

And te hitman, 32, applied the finish, drilling the ball home from close range.

Job done and Bournemouth undone.

How boss Eddie Howe must surely now regret selling Mings to Villa.

headline: I'M confused as to why [...]
content_plain:
I'M confused as to why Fabian Schar's goal was allowed to stand.

I've said before Law 12 concerning handling the ball is an ass  but we want
consistency from VAR.

How was Isaac Hayden's use of the arm in the build-up to Schar's strike any
different from goals ruled out in other games? Four weeks into the season and
already we have inconsistency in decision-making by VAR on accidental handball
when a goal is scored.

headline: It's a Brucie (VAR) bonus
content_plain:
NEWCASTLE............1 Schar 41 Watford.................1 Hughes 2 By DAVID
COVERDALE STEVE BRUCE was bemoaning bad luck all week after an injury crisis and
penalty shootout defeat.

Well, yesterday, the Newcastle boss was given a huge helping HAND to pick up his
first point at St James' Park.

Toon, beaten by Leicester on spot-kicks in Wednesday's Carabao Cup tie, were
down to Watford after 78 SECONDS.

Yet they levelled through Fabian Schar after an accidental handball by Isaac
Hayden  which VAR missed.

Under new laws, the goal should not have stood, like Gabriel Jesus' 'winner' for
Manchester City against Tottenham two weeks ago.

That was ruled out because Aymeric Laporte handled in the build-up.

So this was a Brucie bonus for Toon, even though they should have made it
back-to-back league wins following Sunday's shock victory at Tottenham.

The point lifts Newcastle out of the bottom three ahead of a tricky trip to
Liverpool in a fortnight's time.

Asked about their lucky break, boss Bruce said: "I haven't seen it but we are
going to have many VAR issues. I am not sure I am a big lover of it."

Winless Watford remain rock bottom  but are at least now off the mark.

Boss Javi Gracia was under fire following six league losses in a row, three of
which came at the end of last term.

And the Spaniard had a good moan at officials at the end, but even he was not
certain if VAR got the call wrong.

MATCH He said: "Maybe when the ball is falling it touched his hand. But I didn't
see it."

You fear for Gracia's men in their next two games against Arsenal and City.

NEWCASTLE 5/3.......Shots on/5................Blocked
49%.............466..................6.....................2/0..........Yellow/Yet
they got off to the perfect start here when Tom Cleverley was given time to fire
off a 25-yard shot. It was blocked by Paul Dummett before taking a ricochet off
his teammate Jamaal Lascelles.

And the loose ball fell to Will Hughes to steer past Martin Dubravka for
Watford's second-fastest Prem goal.

Miguel Almiron should have levelled when Christian Kabasele misjudged Christian
Atsu's cross. But the Paraguayan, who has still not scored since his January
arrival, failed to control the bouncing ball.

Toon fans were restless, with one fan shouting, 'Where are your tactics,
Brucie?' Yet the hosts got their lucky equaliser four minutes before the break.

Emil Krafth crossed and, after an aerial battle between Craig Dawson and Hayden,
it fell to Schar to net.

Replays showed Hayden handled but VAR, for some reason, did not rule it out.

Schar could have had a second after half-time but headed off target from six
yards before Almiron scuffed another glorious chance.

Still, it was the visiting fans who were now getting impatient as they chanted
for Gracia to make a change.

And when he did make one after 71 minutes he almost had instant Success, as sub
Isaac Success went close with a header.

start of the 2008-09 campaign  11 years ago.

headline: CONKED OUT
content_plain:
SOUTHAMPTON....1 Vestergaard 58 Man United.........1 James 10 By DAN KING IT is
the first day of autumn and Manchester United are out of the title race.

Not that they were ever in it, of course.

But with seven points dropped in the first four games, the reality of the
challenge facing boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has been laid bare while most of the
conkers are still on the trees.

It does not really matter that United probably deserved to beat ten-man
Southampton.

They created plenty of chances to score after Kevin Danso's sending off 17
minutes from time left Saints clinging on for a point.

In the end, though, United were just not good enough.

They failed to build on Daniel James' early goal, allowed the home side back
into the game before half-time and then conceded an equaliser to centrehalf
Jannik Vestergaard (left). A tactical switch which moved the infuriating Paul
Pogba into an advanced position, that he felt more worthy of his talents, might
have paid dividends on another day.

United did not have much luck, but how much do you deserve when you are asking a
17-year-old striker to save the day with eight minutes to go? Mason Greenwood
may go on to be a big player for United and his effort produced the best of a
number of decent saves by home keeper Angus Gunn.

But Solskjaer's side overall look short on quality and ideas, as well as goals.

That 4-0 romp against Chelsea just three weekends ago feels like an awfully long
time ago. Offloading your two most senior strikers  RomLukaku and Alexis
Sanchez to InMilan  without signing a replacemmelu nter ment egy, uled already
looked an interesting strateeven before a thigh injury ruAnthony Martial out of
this game.

nalatic, Not having a designated No 1 penty-taker was also proving problemawith
spot-kicks missed in consecutgames.

tive ving ning wed But one new United policy  givthe ball to £18million summer
signJames at every opportunity  showsigns of paying off early on.

ave e to with The Welshman, 21, seemed to hrescued a point for United at home
Crystal Palace seven days earlier wan excellent late goal.

secmier That was not the case but his sond strike in 11 minutes of PremLeague
football was another beauty. SOUTHAMPTON had pressed hard their attacking third
but were slow close James down when he collectedsimple pass from Scott
McTominay.

y. in w to d a. how firr of He still had a bit to do, but hwell he did it,
cutting inside and ing a fierce shot into the top corner Gunn's net after just
ten minutes. 'James, James will tear you apart again,' sang the away fans, which
is quite a tribute.

The chant, to the tune of the Joy Division hit 'Love Will Tear Us Apart', is
most associated with United legend Ryan Giggs, the most decorated player in
English football history.

James will not win anywhere near as much however long he stays at Old Trafford,
but he is the main reason to be cheerful so far this season.

Moments later the Southampton keeper easily gathered a tamer effort from the
Wales international.

But Gunn had to be alert to beat out a snapshot from James midway through the
half.

In that spell James was very much the focal point, more so than England
centre-forward Marcus Rashford, but United's overall performance was also
promising.

The energy level was mostly high and Solskjaer's side showed purpose and
ambition whenever they had the ball, looking dangerous from almost every attack.
At the other end, the visiting defence was rarely troubled after Sofiane Boufal
had sent an eighth-minute shot just wide of David De Gea's right-hand post.

Southampton huffed and puffed but United's wall, with ten men retreating behind
the ball when necessary, was made of brick.

The home team were missing the in-form Nathan Redmond through injury and without
him they seemed to lack the guile to find a way through or around it.

United's only concern at that stage was how Pogba had seemed to start losing
interest, as well as possession, in the latter stages of the opening 45 minutes.

A big part of the reason Southampton gained the upper hand was Pogba's
carelessness with the ball.

Sure enough, within ten minutes of the restart Che Adams had fluffed Saints'
best chance of the game.

They need not have worried, the equaliser soon arrived.

De Gea had just kept out a Danny Ings header from a James Ward-Prowse cross.

But the United keeper was helpless when Danso swung the ball back in and 6ft 6in
Vestergaard outjumped Victor Lindelof to nod home on 58 minutes.

The industrious Shane Long was then thrown on for his first league action of the
season as Saints looked to cause United more hassle.

But following a free-kick the Tipperary man conceded, Danso was shown a second
yellow for a challenge on McTominay, giving United  with Jesse Lingard on and
Pogba pushed up  17 minutes to avert an early-season crisis.

Gunn saved from James and Rashford, Lingard went close and then Greenwood forced
the Saints No 1 into his best stop of the game.

The Saints survived four minutes of stoppage time pretty easily.

After three wins in his last 13 Premier League games, how long will even
fan-favourite Solskjaer last if things don't improve soon?

headline: JANNIK VESTERGAARD scored his first [...]
content_plain:
JANNIK VESTERGAARD scored his first Prem goal for Southampton, becoming the
third Danish player to score for the Saints in PL, along with Ronnie Ekelund and
Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg.

headline: DANIEL JAMES has scored three [...]
content_plain:
DANIEL JAMES has scored three goals in four Prem games for Man Utd  as many as
Chile striker Alexis Sanchez managed for the club in 32 PL matches.

headline: SOUTHAMPTON have failed to win [...]
content_plain:
SOUTHAMPTON have failed to win in their last nine home Prem games v Man Utd (W0
D4 L5). But this was the first time they have avoided defeat in consecutive home
games against them since Jan 1998.

headline: Shinnie's stunner
content_plain:
Luton Town.........................2 Huddersfield
Town................1Xxxxxxxx........... ..................x
Xxxxxxxx.............................x ANDREW SHINNIE'S wonder-goal fired Luton
to their first home league win of the season.

The Scottish midfielder struck on 66 minutes and to add insult to injury,
Huddersfield went home cursing after being denied an 80th-minute penalty.

And it looked nailed on as Sonny Bradley pulled back Elias Kachunga.

Luton's all-action attacking display made them well worth their third win in a
week after seeing off Barnsley in the league and Cardiff in the cup.

It is their first home victory in the Championship since February 2007.

Hatters chief Graeme Jones said: "If you look around world football, three wins
in seven days doesn't happen very often. You have to be totally committed and
focused on each game.

Today was a show of character  the boys have been magnificent."

Karlan Grant put the visitors ahead two minutes after the break when he
converted Terence Kongolo's low cross.

Luton levelled when James Collins won and converted a 57th-minute penalty, after
Christopher Schindler was adjudged to have fouled him, before Shinnie's stunning
20-yarder.

The Terriers are 18 games without a win or clean sheet and caretaker boss Mark
Hudson raged at the penalty call, saying: "Schindler barely touches him. Collins
actually apologises."

headline: MATH'S GENIUS
content_plain:
West Brom ..... ..................3Blackburn
Rovers...................................2Xxxxxxxx...........................
..x Xxxxxxxx.............................x SLAVEN BILIC hailed brilliant
Brazilian Matheus Pereira after he lit up The Hawthorns in his first
Championship start.

The midfielder, on loan from Sporting Lisbon, set up first-half goals for Matt
Phillips and Jake Livermore and showed top-notch quality on the ball.

Victory catapulted unbeaten West Brom into the top four.

And former West Ham boss Bilic said of Pereira: "I knew him from Germany last
season when he was on loan at FC Nuremberg.

"He's confident on the ball, he's happy to be in the pockets, he sees everything
 and he doesn't mind defending either.

"He's not a showman, he wants to penetrate. We expected this from him and he
gelled straight away."

But Rovers needed just 23 seconds to break the deadlock. Kyle Bartley tried to
play out of defence but the ball broke to Bradley Dack and he curled home a
15-yarder.

Pereira turned the game around, setting up two goals in nine minutes.

Grady Diangana made it 3-1 but the visitors responded in first-half injury time.
Baggies keeper Sam Johnstone failed to hold a header from Ireland's Darragh
Lenihan, with Bradley Johnson gobbling up the loose ball.

headline: A Fry was just the job
content_plain:
BRISTOL CITY.........................2
MIDDLESBROugh.........................2Xxxxxxxx........................... x
Xxxxxxxx........................... x JONATHAN WOODGATE labelled Middlesbrough
captain Dael Fry "a big lighthouse" on his longawaited return to the side.

On an afternoon of defensive blunders, Fry shone like a beacon in his first game
for six months after a serious hamstring injury.

Boro boss Woodgate called his side's display their "best performance all
season".

And saluting Fry, who was 22 last Friday, he said: "Dael was absolutely
outstanding and deserved the captain's armband.

"I was proud when I captained Middlesbrough and he will be, too.

"That was his first game in six months against a team that has been unbeaten in
five games.

"He's not the loudest but he leads by example and in time will be the full-time
captain of this club."

Woodgate will have nightmares over Bristol City's goals as both Kasey Palmer and
Tommy Rowe headed home when unmarked.

Boro's Ashley Fletcher poked a shot against a post while the Robins' Nathan
Baker also hit an upright.

Delightful work on the wing from Niclas Eliasson left Paddy McNair for dead and
his cross saw Palmer lose his marker to head City ahead.

But Boro found their rhythm after the break and equalised when McNair's cross
was diverted into his own net by Taylor Moore.

Britt Assombalonga put the visitors in front with his 100th league goal and
Woodgate admitted: "I did think we were on our way to win."

Yet they fell asleep nine minutes from time and Rowe stooped to head home Callum
O'Dowda's cross after the Ireland midfield man had come off the bench.

Robins head coach Lee Johnson said: "I didn't enjoy it at all. I didn't expect
it to be that open.

"We should have gone in 3-1 up. We had some very good chances but we didn't
communicate, which may be my fault as I played too many young players and not
enough leaders."

headline: TOP STARS
content_plain:
Leeds.........................0 Swansea....................1
Xxxxxxxx.............................x Xxxxxxxx.............................x
SUPERSUB Wayne Routledge plundered a dramatic last-gasp winner to send Swansea
top of the Championship.

The winger, on for Yan Dhanda, fired home from close range after the Leeds
defence had failed to clear Matt Grimes' 90th-minute ball into the box.

It was a strike that kept City's impressive unbeaten start to the season going
and came after they had taken a real pounding from the home side.

Even Swans boss Steve Cooper was honest enough to admit: "I don't know about it
being the perfect performance, but it was certainly the perfect result for us
away from home.

"We had to work very hard for it, that's for sure.

"But we defended properly and showed no fear."

Leeds, who welcomed back skipper Liam Cooper after two weeks out with an ankle
injury, had won their previous ten home meetings with Swansea.

And victory No 11 looked on the cards as the Swans did well to survive a
battering in the opening 20 minutes.

The first chance came after only four minutes when Ezgjan Alioski cleverly
created space for himself before firing a rising drive from the edge of the box
inches over.

And it was the Macedonian who went close again when, from a Stuart Dallas feed
four minutes later, he let fly with a blistering drive which drew a smart save
from Freddie Woodman.

Then, on 11 minutes, Patrick Bamford scuffed a close-range shot after a
beautiful Pablo Hernandez corner.

Bamford was also out of luck when he arrowed a header inches wide from a
16th-minute Dallas corner.

And, on the stroke of halftime, Cooper was unfortunate to plant a header against
the bar from another well-flighted Hernandez corner.

There was no let-up from Leeds after the break either and between Bamford,
Hernandez and substitute Eddie Nketiah, they should have found the net before
Routledge struck.

Boss Marcelo Bielsa said: "We had 12 or more goalscoring opportunities, 70 per
cent of the ball and good refereeing, so I'm not going to blame bad luck. The
performance was very positive from each player."

headline: Phillip's shame at loss
content_plain:
Xxxxxxxx........................... x Xxxxxxxx........................... x
Brentford............3Derby .................. 0PHILLIP COCU admitted he was
ashamed after a battering by the Bees.

Bryan Mbeumo and an Ollie Watkins double in the first half bagged Brentford a
first home league win in their last season at Griffin Park.

But ex-Barcelona star Cocu was left stunned by the worst 45 minutes his
struggling side have played under him.

The 1,600 Rams fans chanted "what the f****** hell was that" after an abject
performance.

Cocu said: "The fans were disappointed and they've every right to be.

"We should be ashamed of that first half  and we can never play like that
again.

"It is the worst we've played since I've been here, I didn't expect it.

"We were at 75 per cent when we should be at our maximum."

The hosts started well and they made it count with two goals in as many minutes.

Mbeumo netted on the rebound after Ireland's Richard Keogh cleared a Watkins
drive off the line after 17 minutes.

And Mbeumo returned the compliment when he broke swiftly down the right and
pulled the ball low across the area for unmarked Watkins to sidefoot home from
ten yards. Watkins got his second on the stroke of half-time.

The forward steered home a rebound from close range after his first effort was
blocked.

Brentford boss Thomas Frank said: "Derby couldn't cope with our intensity."

headline: Wigan.....................0Barnsley.................0PAUL [...]
content_plain:
Wigan.....................0Barnsley.................0Xxxxxxxx...............x
Xxxxxxxx........................... x PAUL COOK helped break up a melee after
Barnsley's Ben WIlliams got a straight red card late on for an X-rated lunge on
Wigan's Lee Evans.

The row could have got out of hand had the former Sligo boss not played
peacemaker.

Wigan's attack was less aggressive and manager Cook admitted: "We were excellent
defensively but going forward we must be more of a threat."

Mamadou Thiam, Conor Chaplin and Luke Thomas all had chances for Barnsley.
Gaffer Daniel Stendel said: "I give credit to Wigan's keeper."

headline: Wahey, Jude
content_plain:
Birmingham.........2 Stoke........................1Xxxxxxxx...............x
Xxxxxxxx........................... x JUDE BELLINGHAM bagged Birmingham's winner
on his home debut  at the age of just 16!

After coming on as a first-half sub for crocked Jefferson Montero, the teen
sensation completed a late comeback to pile pressure on Stoke boss Nathan Jones.

Blues boss Pep Clotet said: "I do hope he gives this club as many happy days as
possible. As soon as the option was there he took it.

"It's such a memorable day for him. It's difficult to say how far he can go when
you have huge talent at such a young age. My priority is to protect him."

Stoke led on 58 minutes through defender Liam Lindsay but Lukas Jutkiewicz
headed in Maxime Colin's pinpoint cross to equalise and Bellingham's effort from
the edge of the area deflected in off of Lindsay.

Winless Stoke stay bottom and boss Jones said: "Nothing's going for us. This
can't continue but I'm confident we can turn this around."

headline: Sheffield Wed........1 QPR.......................... 2 [...]
content_plain:
Xxxxxxxx........................... x Xxxxxxxx........................... x
Sheffield Wed........1 QPR.......................... 2 JORDAN HUGILL scored his
fourth and fifth goals on loan from West Ham to ruin Lee Bullen's perfect
Hillsborough record  after escaping a second yellow card for diving.

Steven Fletcher's first-half penalty fired Wednesday in front after Grant Hall
fouled Fernando Forestieri.

But Hugill beat Keiren Westwood twice, the second time from Ryan Manning's neat
delivery. QPR chief Mark Warburton said: "I knew getting Jordan would work for
us as we have the quality to create chances."

headline: GROS POINT
content_plain:
Millwall.....................1 Hull City...................1
Xxxxxxxx.............................x Xxxxxxxx.............................x
KAMIL GROSICKI thwarted Millwall with a freakish goal to bamboozle fellow Pole
Bartosz Bialkowski.

The Hull winger's arcing 35-yard free-kick on 18 minutes looped and then dropped
behind the Lions keeper and into the net.

It wiped out Jed Wallace's tenth-minute penalty, which was awarded after Jordy
de Wijs fouled Matt Smith.

The Tigers had striker Josh Magennis sent off in added time after a second
caution for a foul on Ryan Leonard. It meant they finished with nine men, having
been down to ten since the 78th minute when third substitute Jon Toral limped
off. Hull boss Grant McCann smiled: "Kamil will say he meant it. He did one like
it in training on Friday.

"This was a big point for us. Millwall is a tough place to come and we answered
a lot of questions."

Millwall gaffer Neil Harris said: "It wouldn't surprise me if Grosicki meant to
score. He's shown that ability."

headline:
Nott'm Forest.....1Preston................1Xxxxxxxx........... x
Xxxxxxxx................ x [...]
content_plain:
Nott'm Forest.....1Preston................1Xxxxxxxx........... x
Xxxxxxxx........................... x ALBERT ADOMAH bagged a fine Forest
leveller just two minutes after coming on at the City Ground.

The winger latched on to a stunning defence-splitter from fellow sub Joao
Carvalho and slammed home on 79 minutes.

Forest boss Sabri Lamouchi said: "It was a great finish from Albert.

"It wasn't easy against Preston, they're a very good team. It was a good draw
for us in the end."

Billy Bodin had blasted Preston in front with a super back-post finish 40
minutes into a first half the visitors dominated.

North End chief Alex Neil sighed: "It feels as if two points slipped away."

headline: Lee: No slowing
content_plain:
Reading..............0Charlton............. 2Xxxxxxxx........... x
Xxxxxxxx........................... x By GEOFF KNOX LEE BOWYER warned Charlton's
promotion rivals: "We'll keep surprising teams."

A second-half curler from Jonathan Leko and another outrageous walking spot-kick
from Lyle Taylor lifted the new boys into the automatic promotion places.

Boss Bowyer has the lowest playing budget in the division this term. But his
rag-tag red and white army, unbeaten in the league, keep marching on.

Bowyer said: "Our game-plan worked, our defence again stood strong and the
keeper did his job when called upon.

"The midfield lads have worked really, really hard to do the dirty side of the
game and the front two caused problems all day."

Jose Gomes defended his substitutions despite his Royals falling apart by the
end.

He said: "If you play games on the PlayStation, change the players and you lose,
you can repeat the game. Here, we can't."

headline: CHAMPIONSHIP FASTEST & LATEST GOALS [...]
content_plain:
CHAMPIONSHIP FASTEST & LATEST GOALS FASTEST - Bradley Dack (Blackburn) 28s
LATEST - Wayne Routledge (Swansea) 89m 12s

headline: BRENTFORD'S Ollie Watkins has scored [...]
content_plain:
BRENTFORD'S Ollie Watkins has scored four goals in his last five league games,
more than he managed in his previous 25 games for the club (3).

headline: SWANSEA beat Leeds in a [...]
content_plain:
SWANSEA beat Leeds in a league game at Elland Road for only the second time 
and their first since a 2-1 win in the second tier in September 1949.

headline: Chris cross words cut Blades to bits
content_plain:
CHRIS WILDER revealed his half-time hairdryer shock tactic worked a treat in
earning Sheffield United a point.

The Blades boss (below) went for keeper Dean Henderson and striker Callum
Robinson over their firsthalf performances.

And it prompted the perfect response as 22-year-old Henderson pulled off a
brilliant save and Ireland star Robinson scored the first goal to put United on
their way to a battling draw.

Wilder said: "I smashed Dean at half-time because he should have done better and
was kicking it all over the place. He's a young man learning his trade and we
feel he should have done better for the goal.

"And that is the character of the group  the two individuals. Dean kept us in
the game with an unbelievable save and for Callum to score just after half-time
shows what he is about.

"To come roaring back hopefully gives us an enormous amount of confidence and
belief going forward."

Henderson's instinctive save denied Tammy Abraham a hat-trick and acted as a
turning point in the game.

Chelsea defender Kurt Zouma's last-minute own goal put the seal on a gutsy
fightback.

Delighted Wilder said: "We deserved something from our second-half performance.

"The players need to believe more. I understand their apprehension but we
deserve to be in this division  the coaching staff believe in the players more
than they do at times."

headline: Rookie errors
subheadline: LAMPS' LADS ENOUGH TO TURN HIM TO DRINK
content_plain:
Chelsea..........2 Abraham 19, 42 Sheff Utd.......2 Robinson 46; Zouma (og) 89
By ANDREW DILLON FRANK LAMPARD watched the youngest Chelsea team in Premier
League history blow a two-goal lead at Stamford Bridge.

And even worse, last night the baby-faced Blues would struggle to buy a beer in
a supermarket to drown their sorrows.

A starting XI with an average age of 24 years and 158 days fell foul of the
under-25 rule in many ways.

Not only would they need ID to get booze but they also look worryingly immature
at times.

The team which trudged off the pitch at the final whistle included pint-sized
midfielder Billy Gilmour, 18, who even if he did have proof of age would
struggle to see over the counter.

Two goals from in-form Tammy Abraham gave them a cushion from which to go on and
build a solid victory. Yet once Sheffield United pulled a goal back less than a
minute into the second half, Chelsea crumbled.

Perhaps it is because the team is so young hat the boys out there in blue have
such short attention spans.

Boss Lampard's bold policy of giving the kids a chance is to be applauded but it
came at a hefty price yesterday.

He was denied a first home win since taking over as boss in the summer.

And for the second game in a row at home he has looked on as his rookies wobbled
after getting themselves in the driving seat.

Bizarrely it was two of the wiser heads who contributed to their downfall.

Skipper Cesar Azpilicueta allowed himself to be mugged on the edge of his box as
Ireland pair Enda Stevens and scorer Callum Robinson combined to haul the Blades
back into it.

Then Kurt Zouma's outstretched boot scored the calamitous own goal which totally
transformed the mood.

Even with Chelsea 2-1 up and clinging on, the punters were loving the
electricity in the air as a team of home-grown players were rocking and rolling
in a game full of ebbs and flows.

When Lampard brought on Gilmour  born in the same June week in 2001 that his
manager signed for Chelsea  for his debut alongside Michy Batshuayi, it looked
like another brave masterstroke.

Today it looks like a huge blunder from a man who is himself a rookie in terms
of management  this being only his second season as a coach.

The decision to drop Denmark star Andreas Christensen and replace him with
Fikayo Tomori was a surprise one.

Replacing a 23-year-old with somebody two years younger was enough to nudge the
average age of the starting XI down to a record in the modern game.

Without a shot on target in the first half from the visitors, there was little
Tomori  who was on loan at Derby under Lampard last term  could do in order to
impress and stake a claim to keep his place.

But his clean sheet was gone just 50 seconds into the second half when the
Blades hit back with a goal to remind everyone that Lampard's fledgling Chelsea
are a long way from a polished team  and one Mick McCarthy would love to see
repeated at the Aviva Stadium against Switzerland this Thursday.

Taking the return pass from his own throw on the left flank, Stevens drifted
through the Chelsea defence, stopping en route to nutmeg Azpilicueta. Then from
the by-line he cut the ball back to where striker Robinson stood unopposed and
he proceeded to hook the ball into the corner of the net from eight yards out
for his first Prem goal.

Lampard must be concerned at the lack of mental strength to chuck away a game
against a spirited team but one which should have been rolled over.

Abraham grabbed the first goal on 19 minutes after it had been pawed clear by
Blades keeper Dean Henderson.

His second was another example of his striking instincts, capitalising on a
horrendous mix-up between Jack O'Connell and George Baldock to fire in.

Henderson made a great save to deny Abraham a hat-trick and Kepa Arrizabalaga
saved a longrange bullet from Ollie Norwood. But amid chaos in the Chelsea back
four, Zouma stumbled as he tried to defend a cross into the box and the
Frenchman poked the ball into his own net.

headline: SEBSATION
content_plain:
WEST HAM.......2 Haller 24; Yarmolenko 56 NORWICH...........0 By MARK IRWIN IT
does not take a lot to gain legendary status at West Ham these days and
Sebastien Haller is already well on his way to becoming an east London icon.

The £42million Frenchman is only the fourth player in the club's history to
score three goals in his first three Premier League games.

He follows Trevor Sinclair, Ian Wright and Demba Ba.

And if he can keep up this form for the rest of the season, they will probably
build a statue of him at the London Stadium.

Haller's 24th-minute strike came hot on the heels of last week's winning double
at Watford.

Andriy Yarmolenko's first goal since last September confirmed Norwich's 19th
consecutive trip to London without a Prem victory.

Yet Haller might want to think twice about going to Norfolk any time soon after
his reckless late challenge forced defender Christoph Zimmermann off.

MATCH WEST HAM's record signing revealed this week he rejected a move to Norwich
after visiting the city in 2016  and the Canaries' loss is proving to be West
Ham's gain after Haller's flying start to life in England.

470 .................... Passes .................... 391..........Completed 3
.................. Blocked 8 ....................... Corners
....................... 16...............Fouls 2/0.............Yellow/Yet it was
not all sweetness and light for the Hammers and manager Manuel Pellegrini was
far from impressed early on.

There was a real lack of intensity as his players allowed Norwich to dominate
possession and establish a toe-hold on the game.

Todd Cantwell was able to slalom through three half-hearted challenges during
one particularly slack passage of play.

In fact West Ham were so poor they were forced to resort to gamesmanship when
Yarmolenko was guilty of a shameful dive under Cantwell's challenge in the box.

Ref Paul Tierney failed to take any action, which allowed the winger to go down
easily again RATINGS with barely any contact from fullback Max Aarons.

But Norwich were unable to take advantage of their early control and conceded
the initiative.

Felipe Anderson's charge on goal demanded a heroic last-ditch challenge from
Zimmermann.

But that was to be the towering German's last meaningful contribution to the
game before being taken out by Haller's lunge, which again went unpunished by
Tierney.

And Zimmermann was still feeling the effects of that challenge when Haller found
space in the penalty area to fire West Ham ahead from Arthur Masuaku's inviting
cross.

Even that breakthrough goal could not settle Hammers nerves and they were lucky
not to concede a 31st-minute equaliser following more unconvincing defending.

STAts ................... .484 passes..........417 shots .................. 2
....................... 2 conceded...............10 red cards.............1/0
Unfortunately for Norwich, Cantwell was millimetres too short to make a clean
connection with Aarons' cross and headed a glorious opportunity over from a yard
out.

Any thoughts of a second-half comeback were dismissed when Yarmolenko put the
game beyond doubt in the 56th minute.

The lively Ukrainian certainly did not look like someone still finding his way
back after ten months on the sidelines with a torn Achilles.

He pounced on Cantwell's loose control to tee up Mark Noble and when the ball
came back to him off Ben Godfrey, he smashed home beyond keeper Tim Krul's dive.

Daniel Farke will be concerned at how quickly his Canaries players then allowed
their heads to drop, with only Krul saving them from a real beating late on.

headline: SHEFFIELD UNITED have won five [...]
content_plain:
SHEFFIELD UNITED have won five points from their four Premier League games this
season. Only in 1993-94 (6) have the Blades had a better start in the division.

headline: TAMMY ABRAHAM is the first [...]
content_plain:
TAMMY ABRAHAM is the first Englishman to score at least two goals in consecutive

headline: TRICKS OF THE TRADE
subheadline: Keith Barry is back with a mesmerising new show
content_plain:
THE KEITH BARRY EXPERIENCE RTE One, 9.35pm, Wednesday DON'T try this at home.

There is only one magic man who can pull off a death-defying escape from a
straight jacket while suspended upside down, 100ft in the air, from a crane.

And that's Ireland's own mentalist, hypnotist and amazing magician Keith Barry!
But hair-raisingly he almost didn't pull it off.

Keith recalled how it almost all went terribly wrong saying: "I actually passed
out halfway through it because my head is wrapped in cling film, and not only
can you not breathe but you can't see either.

"And I'm upside down in a straitjacket which restricts your breathing."

You can see how it pans out on his new show.

This September Keith Barry has something special up this sleeve for telly
viewers.

A live studio audience and some very well known faces from the world of
entertainment and music will be taking part in sometimes hilarious, and often
terrifying, magic stunts that will bamboozle and flummox the viewing public.

It promises to be the water cooler show of the year where you should expect the
unexpected.

Guests include Laura Whitmore, Baz and Nancy Ashmawy, Julian Benson, Eamon
Dunphy and Soulé.

CELEB GUESTS....Keith with Ken Doherty and Julian Benson

headline: HISTORY AWAITS
content_plain:
ALMOST tired of the rocking road of Dublin, one, two, three, four  FIVE?
Today's the day when  barring the draw  either Jim Gavin's men will go where
no team has ever gone before or Kerry will deny them, just as they were denied
five successive Sam Maguire titles by Offaly in 1982.

One more win for Stephen Cluxton and Co and talk of the Drive for Five can be
parked forever. It will just be 'the five'. Most doubt they can be stopped.
Former Dubs captain and Sun-Sport columnist Collie Moran warned: "If Kerry give
Dublin the kind of space they afforded Tyrone the Dubs will destroy them."

But Kingdom top scorer Seán O'Shea insists: "It is a one-off game. It's not
history for us."

Still, if it proves to be the oneoff defeat Dublin suffer in this five-year
spell, that's going in the record books too. History awaits!

Big-Match Special  Pages 2-8

headline: HEAVYWEIGHTS
subheadline: The starters are ready for the main course
content_plain:
IN the Drive For Five, Dublin have their very own Super 8. Eight players have
started each of the All-Ireland finals Dublin have contested during this
historymaking unbeaten run since 2015. Stephen Cluxton, Jonny Cooper, Philly
McMahon, James McCarthy, Cian O'Sullivan, Brian Fenton, Ciarán Kilkenny and Dean
Rock all started the finals in 2015, the 2016 drawn game, the 2016 replay, 2017
and 2018.

A total of 11 players have actually featured in each of those finals  with John
Small, Michael Fitzsimons and Kevin McManamon playing but coming off the bench
in one or more.

Jim Gavin has used a total of 30 players across that quintet of deciders.

And one of the strengths of this Dublin set-up has been the ability to
continually bring through fresh talent and develop new leaders on the field to
replace those at the latter end of their careers.

Former Dublin captain Paul Griffin said: "You are looking at five in a row.

"But there has been such a wellmanaged turnover over the five years.

"So there is a core group you are looking at that are potentially going for
their seventh medal, they have been there for them all.

"But there's a lot of them for which this is maybe only their second or third.

"That makes it different for those guys in that they are not carrying the
baggage from previous years.

They are still coming out, attacking every medal like it's the first to go in
their collection.

"It's not necessarily like it's the same group that has played all five so that
probably makes it slightly easier for them as a panel."

For example, this will only be Brian Howard's second All-Ireland final, having
made his senior breakthrough last year.

It is only Con O'Callaghan's third senior decider, the same for Niall Scully.

Eoin Murchan came from almost nowhere last year to become a Dublin regular.

He lined out in last year's final, but has started just one match this summer 
the dead rubber against Tyrone in Omagh.

If Murchan is a defensive player who has lost out from last year, David Byrne is
one who has stepped back up.

He featured in the 2016 finals  starting the drawn game and being brought on as
a sub in the replay  but did not play in the 2017 or 2018 deciders.

A broken bone in his foot hampered Byrne last summer and he did not even make
the match-day squad for the showpiece.

But during this year's campaign, he has played in all of Dublin's Championship
matches so far  starting in six of their seven encounters.

Of the Super 8, McMahon and O'Sullivan were the only ones not named in
tomorrow's starting XV, although Dublin's officially-named team is merely to be
viewed as a guide, never to be taken as fact.

But whether there will be mass retirements should Dublin make history tomorrow
remains to be seen.

Griffin added: "I don't know. It's difficult.

"If you are successful and you are winning, physically then it gets harder to
step away.

"They have got lives outside of football, career-wise, family-wise, a lot of
things will crop up.

"I think a lot of them, they take that time over the winter to have those
conversations.

"Jim has always given them space to see what they want to do.

It will be hard for them all.

"The five, because it's the first time it will have been done, it's a potential
capstone  you'll have absolutely made history.

"They've been the best team from a Dublin perspective, hands down, but they do
become very much the top of that conversation of what is the best team ever,
based on what they've done.

"Do fellas have the same drive and bite to get back again? "Hopefully that's a
conversation they'll be looking to have off the back of another All-Ireland."

headline: Fires not foul play
content_plain:
GARDAI say no foul play is suspected in two separate blazes in Drogheda.
Emergency services attended the scene of the first fire in Constitution Hill the
Co Louth town at 8pm on Friday night.

At 4.30am yesterday morning, there was another blaze at a property at Bessexwell
Lane, There were no reported injuries. Gardai are investigating

headline: BLOOD, SWEAT AND TEARS
subheadline: Seán hopes it's a far cry from 2002
content_plain:
SEÁN O'SHEA left Croke Park in tears after his first All-Ireland final.

He was only four and father Seán Sr had to carry him out of the Cusack Stand
after Armagh defeated his beloved Kerry 1-12 to 0-14.

The deadly free-taker does not remember much about the day when Oisín
McConville's goal helped seal a historic first-ever title for the Orchard.

But he hopes the memories of today's decider against Dublin are both happy and
plentiful  and that any crying after his first senior All-Ireland final as a
player will mean there have been tears of joy.

O'Shea, 21, said: "As a young fella supporting Kerry, you go up to the game with
your family and you dream of playing.

"The first final I was at was 2002 against Armagh. I don't remember much about
it because I was very young, but I was in the Cusack Stand with my parents.

"My only recollection is leaving the pitch and my father had to carry me out
because I was in tears. I was only four.

"He coached me all the way up from Under-6 and I got most of the interest from
him."

At such a young age, football already meant so much to the younger Seán.

Fast-forward four years and the memories were a lot happier. Kerry eased past
Mayo 4-15 to 3-5 with goals from serial winners Declan O'Sullivan, Kieran
Donaghy, Colm Cooper and Eoin Brosnan.

Today, O'Shea will be one of the men that four- and eight-year-old Kerry lads
will be looking at in awe and in hope  and whether they pretend to be Seán
O'Shea in their back gardens or not, he hopes they do not go away sobbing.

He added: "My next final was in 2006 against Mayo  that's the first one I
properly remember. I would have looked up to a lot of them.

"I was a big fan of Declan O'Sullivan always, the way he played and took to the
field. He had everything.

"He was one of the key men for that team, the way he carried himself around the
pitch and with the stuff he did when he got the ball. He was a real leader.

"Watching the 'Gooch' as well, you'd want to emulate them in the back garden
after watching them play."

O'Shea progressed well after he mimicked those legends back home in Kenmare. He
won minor All-Ireland crowns in 2015 and 2016 before making his senior
Championship debut last summer.

He only turned 21 in mid-July this year but his calmness on the ball and
composure from frees make him look like he has been on the senior team for
years.

This summer he is Peter Keane's top scorer with 1-38, including 27 frees and two
45s  a serious return for any young player in his second senior season.

But practice makes perfect. He explained: "Since playing Under-12 and Under-14,
I remember taking them, it comes naturally enough.

"Especially when I was younger, 15 or 16, when things weren't as busy and
training wasn't as tough. I probably had a lot more time to go to the pitch with
my friends and bring a bag of balls.

"We might stay there two or three hours practising. It's all about the amount of
practice.

"You just can't go out on the day and hope that things go well for you. What you
put into it is what you get out of it.

"You never get a kick in a game that you haven't taken in training and that's
where the confidence comes from."

O'Shea has never before faced Dublin in Championship football.

As Jim Gavin's Sky Blues go for the five in a row, the bulk of the Kerry squad
just want their first All-Ireland medal  but for O'Shea it is just a one-off
game.

History might be on the line for the opposition, who are overwhelming
favourites, but then the history books show that no county has won Sam Maguire
more times than Kerry's 37  and if they make it 38 today, it will be one of
their greatest feats.

O'Shea added: "Once you start playing football that's what you dream of. We know
the size of the challenge that is ahead of us.

"The main thing for us is the game, it is a one-off game. It's not history for
us. We know the traditions that are in Kerry about winning All-Irelands and
stuff.

"Dublin are the team going for five in a row. We just want to go up and do our
best and hopefully win one All-Ireland because a lot of our fellas wouldn't have
one.

"They are a fantastic team. They have won four All-Irelands in a row and there
is a reason for that. They've been the best team in the country for the last
good while.

"There is a massive challenge ahead and we know we have to be on top of our
game.

"But we will go up and give it a rattle and hopefully that will be enough for
us."

KERRY have made one change from their semi-final victory over Tyrone with Gavin
White replacing Shane Enright in the half-forward line.

There is no room for Tommy Walsh despite his impressive outing off the bench
against the Red Hands.

headline: JONNY 5 IS ALIVE
subheadline: GAME THE Cooper happy to B here after early-summer foot problems
content_plain:
JONNY COOPER found himself on the B team at Dublin training earlier this summer
 chasing around after Con O'Callaghan and Paul Mannion.

But more than anything, he was chasing down a jersey which had been pretty much
his own throughout this glorious unbeaten era for Dublin's footballers.

Prior to this summer, Cooper had missed just two Championship games in the last
four years.

The first was the 2017 Leinster final against Kildare.

And the second was the deadrubber Super 8s outing against Roscommon in 2018 
when manager Jim Gavin made wholesale changes to his team.

Apart from those matches, Cooper started every match in Dublin's four-in-row
success.

But this summer he has missed three games  a niggling foot problem ruling the
Na Fianna defender out for the entire Leinster SFC campaign.

Over a matter of just a few weeks Cooper missed more Championship matches than
he had over the previous four years.

He recalled: "You have to have patience but at the same time you're losing time
very quickly, very rapidly, particularly as selections go on.

"I stayed smart and just hoped the lads would keep winning games and that I'd
get an opportunity to get back in the squad.

"I don't know how many weeks it was, six or eight weeks, maybe more, so that was
a long period of time, particularly at that part of the season.

"If it was earlier in the season I could have maybe got away with building up
more slowly."

Cooper, 29, featured prominently for Dublin throughout the league  starting
their first six games but not featuring in their last outing against Cavan, also
a dead-rubber clash for which Gavin made numerous changes.

But by the time the Leinster SFC started, Cooper's name was off the team-sheet.

As Dublin breezed to their ninth straight Delaney Cup, he was in the shadows
getting himself right and preparing for the battle to get back in the frame for
a starting spot in the All-Ireland series.

Cooper said: "You just start from the bottom and just try to claw your way back.

"Obviously I was doing stuff when the lads were training, on and off the pitch,
just trying to maintain some level of ball work and skills, as much as I could.

"But yeah, on the training field, in terms of marking and spatial awareness and
that stuff, I was just trying to tick those boxes along the way."

And so during the internal training matches, Cooper found himself on the B team.

He added: "I think you get what you deserve. I didn't deserve in this case to be
on the first team.

"You're a competitor and you have to manage your individual emotions and
expectations.

"Also then you have 14 guys beside you who maybe feel similar but you have to
get that performance for that team to win, but also put your own best foot
forward.

So it's a tricky one in terms of trying to funnel your own energy into the team
as opposed to yourself.

"Jim Gavin will spot that as well, if you're selfish around things and a little
bit tunnel-visioned.

"But it's a good learning, I definitely found a lot of learning in it in terms
of coming at it from a different angle or perspective.

"It was different. But I really enjoyed it in a strange way as well, it brought
me back to around the time of Pat Gilroy, in my head.

"I've said it many times, that gave me a real good value in terms of trying to
get on the team and what I thought it would be like.

"In a strange way it was kind of like that again, trying to prove myself to
myself and hopefully the management then pick me.

"In a strange way I think I got a lot from it as well.

"And you realise that things could have went the other way for me as well and I
could have been sitting on the bench or not even on the squad."

He was back in the match-day squad for Dublin's Super 8s opener against Cork.

And in the 67th minute he was introduced off the bench for his first appearance
of the summer, replacing fellow stalwart Cian O'Sullivan.

Cooper has started every game since  including the nothing match against
Tyrone.

He said: "It's just trying to get the balance of not doing too much but also
obviously playing as much as I could, getting 40-odd minutes in Omagh.

"And then some of the Super 8s gave me some of the stuff in the legs, to get up
to that level."

That level, he reckons, will go up a few notches today when Kerry, who beat them
in Tralee in the NFL this tear, stand as the last bump in the road to Dublin
completing their Drive for Five.

He said: "Obviously we played them in the league earlier in the year but apart
from that we haven't come across them too much this year. They have a lot of
very talented players."

And he expects, as a defender, to be given his toughest challenge of the year by
the Kerry forwards.

Cooper added: "That's the beauty of it, it's cutting edge, you're walking a
tight-rope and there's no real safety net.

"As nice as it to win a game by 10 points or whatever it is, it's also really
nice  I find anyway  to be right on the edge of something, be right up against
a person who has a left and a right, who runs left and right and backwards and
can go high or low, and you're really facing that full array skill-set.

But at this stage of his career  Cooper made his Championship debut in 2013 

Barring a late change, Cian O'Sullivan  who has started in each of Dublin's
last six All-Ireland finals  will be on the bench.
