headline: Dublin v Kerry was give and take - they'd give us a beating and we'd take it
subheadline: game  the OUR COLU M Collie UMNISTS ARE THE TALK OF SPORT MORAN
content_plain:
IT used to drive us mad.

Whenever we played Kerry, you'd have the players from the 70s rolled out talking
about the great rivalry between the two counties.

Waxing lyrically about the special relationship that existed between Dublin and
Kerry.

But actually it wasn't a special relationship.

In our dressing room it felt like a one-way relationship.

Yeah, there was give and take all right. They'd give us a beating and we'd take
it.

In late November 1999, early in my Dublin career, we played Kerry in a league
game at Parnell Park, running out narrow winners, 1-8 to 0-9. And while the
games between us after that were always generally close enough, we never beat
them again. They always seemed to find a way.

In Championship, Dublin went between 1977 and 2011 without beating Kerry.

But since Dublin broke the spell in 2011, it is Kerry now who are on the
receiving end of this special relationship.

The Kingdom haven't beaten Dublin in the Championship since 2009. I've been
thinking a lot about '09 this week.

Because when I read and hear former Kingdom players coming out with lines about
Kerry 'having a free shot, that there's no expectancy on them, that all of the
pressure is on Dublin', well, call me sceptical.

I have the scars on my back from Kerry ambushes.

You see, 2009 was meant to be our time to turn the tables.

Because of injury, I had been forced to retire earlier that year but Pat Gilroy
had asked me to remain part of the backroom set-up.

In the build-up to our quarter-final against Kerry, I remember being in the
manager's room, as we called it, with Pat and Mickey Whelan going through the
scouts' report on their march through e back door. Only they hadn't much marched
as stumbled. Having lost to Cork by eight ints in a Munster semi-final play,
Kerry then put together nconvincing wins over Longrd, Sligo and Antrim. The
report was damning. nd it was the truth  they'd en terrible in all their games.
That was the summer Tomás Ó Sé and Colm Cooper got opped during the qualifiers r
going drinking.

the so H po rep un forT An beeT Ó dro forK the wa woM the we the tea Kerry
seemed to be all over e place, and the end verdict as that a good club team ould
probably beat them. Many of Kerry's heroes of e early and mid-noughties ere
still hanging on. But eir legs were gone and the am was on borrowed time.

So it was our time to finally put one over on them.

Our assessment to the players wouldn't have been quite as blunt. We'd have
watered it down somewhat to ensure there'd be no complacency.

But on that day, it was us who were blown away. While the Dublin players looked
rooted to the spot, Kerry  the team whose legs had gone  were full of running.

I was maor foirne and in the first 20 minutes I was constantly on giving
instructions and switches to the players. It felt like I was doing more running
than them. We were trying to put out fires everywhere. At one point I looked up,
saw the scoreboard and said to myself, 'I'm wasting my time here, the game is
over'. Afterwards, Pat used the phrase 'startled earwigs' to describe Dublin's
performance.

We'd been on the end of a Kerry ambush.

So 2009 has been on my mind a lot this week as the talk in the build-up to
today's game has leaned strongly on how it's Dublin's to lose. That Kerry aren't
ready.

The first thing that should be said is that this will be the best set of
forwards Dublin have come up against in the last four of five years  better
than anything Mayo or Tyrone have brought.

But when you delve through the stats, there are some red flags for Kerry 
particularly their lack of green flags. Kerry have averaged one goal per game 
only once have they actually managed to score two in any Championship match this
summer, against Meath.

They'll need at least two and probably three if they're to beat Dublin because
the figures show you'll almost certainly need to hit over 20 points to overcome
the champions.

It has to be a concern for Kerry that they only managed one goal against teams
like Clare and Cork, who aren't exactly defensively rock-solid.

Kerry also only scored one goal against Mayo. They owned the ball in that game
and were completely dominant.

Dublin have been averaging two goals per game  they hit Cork for five and last
time out netted three against Mayo.

Then you look at the damage Cathal McShane and Mattie Donnelly were able to do
against the Kerry defence.

The sweeper role with Paul Murphy didn't work and defensively they just didn't
seem on the same page.

If Kerry give Dublin the kind of space they afforded Tyrone then the Dubs will
destroy them.

The big hope for Kerry will be that David Clifford continues his incredible
season where everything he does ends up as a score.

It reminds me of Bernard Brogan in 2010  a season when nearly everything he
touched turned to gold.

No matter who Dublin put on him, I think they just need to accept Clifford is
going to do some damage today.

The way his team-mates run into the scoring zone and then give a short hand-pass
to him almost makes it impossible to defend against.

So I wouldn't be surprised if Dublin haven't spent a huge amount of time
concentrating on Clifford, but rather accept he'll do damage and instead give a
lot of attention to stopping those around him and cutting off the supply further
out the field.

Tommy Walsh is a possible x-factor for Kerry but you'd imagine Dublin have been
preparing for that scenario too.

Which brings us back to the feeling in Kerry that this is a 'free shot' for this
group.

The suggestion is that because it's largely a young squad trying to find their
feet at senior level after minor success, their day will come eventually  so
this one can be used as a learning experience. That all sounds a bit arrogant as
well.

Just because you win so many All-Irelands at minor level doesn't mean the
players will automatically convert that into senior All-Irelands over the next
decade. You take your chances when you can. The Dublin dressing room is not
exactly an old folks' home.

Brian Howard is 22, Con O'Callaghan 23, Jack McCaffrey 25 and Paul Mannion,
Brian Fenton and Ciarán Kilkenny are all just 26.

I remember talking to Henry Shefflin about Kilkenny's Drive for Five coming up
short.

He said the difference he sees is that many players in that dressing room knew
they were coming to the end of the road. They were trying to win one more before
finishing up.

But Dublin's age profile doesn't indicate this is a team reaching the end of the
line. Some might go but now a new core group of leaders have already taken over
the mantle of their key men.

They all have many years left ahead of them. And crucially, they know what it
takes to win All-Irelands and to beat Kerry.

headline: SNIFFER BEES IN DRUG TRAINING
content_plain:
BEES are being trained to sniff out drugs and explosives.

Experts reckon the insects may one day replace dogs in the hunt for illicit
items because they are cheaper and quicker to train.

And they could be ready to search for landmines in five years.

Dr Ross Gillanders, a researcher at the University of St Andrews, Scotland, has
been training them in a Nato-funded project.

Sugar water is used to teach the bees so they treat the odour of explosives as
if it is nectar.

They can detect it from a few hundred yards but that could eventually become a
mile. As soon as they are Police sting By ROBIN PERRIE sent out of the hive they
settle almost instantly on the spot where the bomb is hidden.

Physicist Dr Gillanders said: "Bees have an advantage in that they cannot
accidentally set off landmines and can cover ground not readily accessible for
dogs." But he admitted that a drawback of working with the bees is that they can
be unpredictable.

During one field trial he was left with 20 stings on an ankle that was not
covered by his beekeeping suit.

He said: "They seemed to know where to go for. It was the only exposed part."

... bee

headline: This gang are in the business of killing people
byline: EXCLUSIVE by STEPHEN BREEN Crime Editor EXCLUSIV
content_plain:
THE devastated dad of missing Willie Maughan last night hit out at the murder of
Drogheda feud victim Keith Branigan and said: "I told everyone this would happen
 they are in the business of killing people."

And grieving Joe Maughan  whose son, 34, and his Latvian girlfriend Ana, 21,
were killed by the gang behind Branigan's slaying  believes the ruthless mob
will identify other "soft targets" as the feud continues.

Willie and his pregnant fiancee were last sighted in Gormanston, Co Meath, on
April 14, 2015, on their way to meet Willie's mum Helen.

The chief suspects are associates of Owen Maguire, who survived a botched hit in
July 5, 2018, and gangster Cornelius Price.

Price  who was released from custody in June  had been living between the UK
and Ireland but the Gardai believe he was back in the country last weekend.

Although Maguire and Price aren't in the frame for the double murder, their
associates in Co Louth are now the chief suspects for masterminding Branigan's
killing.

He was riddled with bullets as he carried out work at a caravan park in
Clogherhead, Co Louth, after his killers repeatedly failed in their attempts to
murder his close associates.

Two woman, one of whom was pregnant, had a lucky escape after their cars were
struck by the hitman's stray bullets at the Ashling Holiday Park last Tuesday
afternoon.

As the huge investigation into the first killing in the Drogheda feud continues,
Joe pleaded with the Gardai to nail Maguire's associates. He said: "These evil
and I told everyone happen  they are in of killing people.

people are pure ryone this would n the business one of lfriend, son's mbed e 
ng r--ertss ht ud said "They have killed my sons and his girlfriend, dug up my
other grave and pipe-bombed my daughter's home  so this latest killing
shouldn't be a surprise to anyone. "Maguire's associates will also be looking
over their shoulders and I don't see an end to this feud until Maguire's gang
are brought to justice.

"Once the feud started last year I matsomethere's the last.

it would only be a matter of time before someone was killed and there's no doubt
it won't be "My hope is that get on top of them their every move to killing more
people."

the Gardai m and watch stop them from Ana's suspected One of Willie and killers
 who has also been linked to digging up the grave of Joe's other son Michael in
August 2016  has dyed his hair and is now in hiding over fears Maguire's
enemies are plotting to whack him.

Joe also told how he would continue with his own fight for justice. He added:
"Even though they've tried to silence me they won't stop me. The only person who
will stop me fighting for justice is God. We won't stop fighting to find Joe and
Ana.

"We just want them back so we can give them the Christian burial they deserve.
Our lives have been torn apart for over four years now and we just want to know
where they are. I would hate for other innocent fili t th h h t h families to go
through what we have experienced these last number of years. They have destroyed
so many lives and they need to be stopped.

"They won't intimidate me even though they had guns and they won't keep me
silent. They are using young people for their dirty work and what good is this
money to them if they're in jail or dead?" Following Branigan's killing last
week, there are now fears his associates will hit back in a revenge attack.
Although Branigan, 29, had a lengthy criminal record including nine convictions
for violent disorder he wasn't seen as a major gangland figure or actively
involved in the Drogheda feud over the past year. At present, Gardai believe
between 12 and 15 members from each rival faction in the Drogheda feud are
living under an active death threat although Branigan wasn't under any type of
threat when he was killed.

And as officers brace themselves for more violence, the Armed Support Unit and
armed detectives have stepped up patrols to prevent further attacks under
'Operation Stratus'.

A source said: "The key players in this feud have been identified and if spotted
on the streets they will be stopped and searched. Gardai can't be everywhere but
are employing all the resources available to prevent ng their lives."

W tt h more people from losing " Superintendent Andrew Watters, who is running
the probe into the hit, called it a "particularly indiscriminate and callous
act" and said it was "very traumatic" for residents.

He added: "There was a lot of families, women with young children, close to the
area of the shooting.

"The investigation is at a very early stage. A number of lines of investigation
are ongoing. We have an operation in place in the Drogheda District to deal with
serious organised crime and in that regard, I would like to reassure the people
of Drogheda and the surrounding areas.

"We have made a number of significant detections, arrests, prosecutions. We have
people before the courts on very serious charges t it b il diti on very strict
bail conditions, and just like to reassure the public the operation is ongoing."

" The feud erupted in July 2018Maguire cheated death. Gardai it started when
young men for Maguire's associates drug money turned against him.

Since then, there have been over incidents including three attempted murders, a
crude car bomb left residential area, pipe bombings, arson attacks, kidnappings,
and assaults.

Sinn Fein TD Imelda Munster called for 'round the clock' of the mobsters
involved in feud. She said: "It is clear thugs don't care who they put risk.
What has happened has sent h k th h th l k it shock waves through the close-knit
community in the village. It is natural that people are anxious that those
responsible are arrested and brought before the courts.

"People in Drogheda are of the belief this feud is nowhere near over and won't
be until the instigators are arrested and charged. Frustration has set in with
the local community who feel these culprits appear to act without fear of being
caught.

"I have repeatedly called for round-the-clock surveillance and I reiterate this
call again. It appears that is the only way to monitor their every move, curtail
their drug dealing and to prevent further attacks and shootings." @SteBreen

content_plain:
BAKING BAD Cops made a "huge drugs bust" at an airport  but they later realised
it was actually vegan cake mix, in London Gatwick.

headline: Car park mayhem after fire at shops
content_plain:
A SHOPPING centre was evacuated last night after a car went on fire in its
multi-storey car park.

Units of Cork City Fire Brigade rushed to the scene at Douglas Village Shopping
centre in the heart of Douglas village.

It's understood a people carrier went on fire in the car park which has access
to the main shopping area.

According to locals, the car exploded shortly before 7pm causing major damage to
other vehicles parked nearby.

In a tweet, the fire service said: "Large fire in Douglas Shopping Centre.
Several units from around the city in attendance. Crews working very hard in
heavy smoke and fire conditions to contain the fire."

The entire village was also engulfed in thick black smoke as was the nearby
South Link Road.

One local said: "My car is in there. I don't know if it's damaged. It's on the
second floor and I'm told the fire is on the first floor so fingers crossed it
will be OK."

A Garda spokesperson said: "There are no reports of any casualties at this
time."

headline: PROROGUE MO THOIN
subheadline: BREXIT CRISIS UK marches against shutdown
content_plain:
TENS of thousands of people took to the streets across the UK to protest Boris
Johnson's decision to suspend Parliament in the run-up to Brexit.

The large-scale demonstrations against the Prime Minister's controversial
suspension plan took place yesterday in cities including Belfast, London,
Manchester, and Glasgow.

Chants of "shame on you" were directed at Boris Johnson by demonstrators outside
Downing Street, as parts of central London came to a total standstill.

Demo ...

UK Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn told thousands at a Glasgow rally he was "proud"
to tell BoJo "no way, it's our Parliament".

He added: "It's not on and we're not having it."

There were 32 protests planned across the UK on yesterday, organised by
anti-Brexit campaign group Another Europe Is Possible, which has called for
daily demonstrations to take place.

The demos were triggered as a result of the Prime Minister's announcement on
Wednesday that he planned to suspend Parliament for up to five weeks ahead of
the October 31 Brexit deadline. The plan prompted an angry backlash from MPs and
no-deal Brexit opponents.

es Protesters gathered yesterday outside Oxford University's Balliol College,
which was attended by Mr Johnson, to express their displeasure at his handling
of Brexit.

UCaJt hBSr ada Meanwhile, Shadow home secretary Diane Abbott addressed the
London protesters from a stage near Downing Street.

in She told the crowds: "We cannot allow Boris Johnson shutdown Parliament cato
Birmingham li and to shutdown the voice of ordinary British people."

In a stinging attack on the PM outside Downing Street, Labour shadow chancellor
John McDonnell labelled Boris a "dictator" for his "very British coup" plan.

Addressing the crowd, he said: "We have defeated dictators in the past in our
history and we will defeat this dictator under Johnson."

Westminster Bridge was blocked by protesters, who were shouting: "If you shut
down our Parliament, we shut down your bridge."

The Metropolitan Police said that three people have been arrested at the
demonstration in London. Among them was London Assembly member Caroline Russell,
according to a spokeswoman for the UK Green Party.

Footage posted on social media appeared to show the politician being led away
from the crowds in handcuffs after she had been sitting and blocking the road.

Speaking at a demo in her Brighton constituency, former Green Party leader
Caroline Lucas thanked those who turned out, adding: "This is what democracy
looks like."

Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, Chancellor Sajid Javid defended the
prime minister's decision to suspend Parliament.

He said: "It's quite usual this time of year for Parliament to go in to a
recess. It's perfectly correct and appropriate to prorogue Parliament. "I think
it's absolutely right that this prime minister and his government get the chance
to set up their agenda."

He added: "I am very comfortable with the approach that we've taken because I
think it is absolutely right that this prime minister and his government gets an
opportunity to set up their agenda. "And when we think about the role of
Parliament, it is right that our Parliament gets to hear that agenda and then
also gets to vote on it."

headline: BOJO'S ELECTION BACK-UP
content_plain:
BORIS Johnson is poised to trigger a general election within days if his Brexit
plan is scuppered this week.

He is gearing up for a six-day scrap with MPs and peers that will decide
Britain's future  and his own.

The British PM plans a snap poll if Remainers find away to block him from
leaving the EU by October 31. If they fail and he delivers a Halloween Brexit,
Boris will look for a pre-Christmas election  with December 5 earmarked as a
possible date.

One senior aide said: "It's clear an election is looming on the horizon. The
only question is when. We'll have a better idea after the events of the next few
days have played out."

headline: Is 12 years jail enough for taking someone's life away?
subheadline: AS FURY MOUNTS OVER EARLY PAROLE RELEASES, WE ASK... SUNDAY ISSUE the
content_plain:
LAST month, we featured the story of Ann Walsh, whose ex murdered her 14 years
ago.

Ann's brother Stephen spoke out after learning killer Raymond Donovan, left, was
up for parole for the third time since 2006.

ftt This is despite being sentenced to mandatory life. He called for those
convicted of murder to be denied the ability to apply for d parole until they
have served 20 years of their sentence.

Currently Irish law allows a killer to apply for parole after seven years of
their sentence.

The Justice Department said: "While prisoners serving life sentences are
currently eligible for hearing after an initial parole h seven years, life
sentence prisoners released on parole in recent years have, on average, served
more than 18 years in prison."

The new Parole Act 2019, passed by the Oireachtas in July, will stop lags given
life applying for parole until at least 12 years into their sentence. But is 12
enough? Here we speak to two people with differing views.

6It's an incentive to engage with services7 FIONA NI CHINNEIDE Irish Penal
Reform Trust LIFE should not mean life. In Of these, 13 had served 20-25 LIFE
should not mean life. In Ireland, a life sentence rarely means the person spends
the rest of their life in prison.

The majority will be released on license or 'parole' at some point. Being
granted parole does not mean a life sentence is over. The person can be returned
to prison for a breach of parole conditions at any time for the rest of their
life.

Parole conditions can restrict where the person goes or lives, who they can
contact or associate with and most often requires the person to be of good
behaviour, sober habits and keep the peace. Parole also allows for supervision
in the community by probation officers and the Gardai.

Parole's main purpose is public safety. It does this by providing structured,
supported and supervised transition of prisoners back into the community. It
usually involves periods of temporary release, an important measure that
supports reintegration.

Parole also provides an incentive for prisoners to engage with services while in
jail, including programmes and treatment that address the grave crimes they
committed. Incentives in prison are proven to make prisons safer for everyone,
including staff.

Laws passed in July mean people sentenced to life can't apply for parole until
they have served a minimum of 12 years.

However, eligibility for review by the Parole Board is only the first step in a
long process towards release. In 2017, the average prison time served by lifers
recommended for release was 18 years. The time served by some prisoners was
significantly longer.

In 2017, of the people serving life sentences, 34 had already served more than
20 years.

Of these, 13 had served 20-25 years, seven had served 25-30 years, 12 had served
30-40 years and two had served over 40 years.

Headlines that suggest life-sentenced prisoners are released after seven or even
12 years do not reflect reality, and may cause unnecessary distress.

However, we do not agree with calls to introduce mandatory minimum periods.
There is no evidence mandatory sentencing either prevents or reduces crime.

But mandatory sentencing always results in unequal justice. No two cases are the
same and therefore, it is of critical importance that judges have the discretion
to impose a sentence that is proportionate to the gravity of the crime.

In Ireland, convictions for murder attract a mandatory sentence of life. One
effect of the mandatory nature of the sentence means there is no incentive for a
guilty plea. This means victims' families and friends almost always have to
endure a lengthy trial process.

Another effect is that there is no clarity around the length of time that a
person will serve as part of that sentence. IPRT is completely opposed to calls
to introduce mandatory or presumptive minimum sentence lengths. However,
legislation that allows judges the discretion to set a minimum length of time
that must be served in prison, based on the particular circumstances of the
individual case, are worth considering.

6Some believe murder should mean life in jail7 MARTIN CONWAY Senator FOURTEEN
years have now passed since Ann Walsh was murdered in the grounds of St Senan's
Church in Kilrush, Co Clare by Raymond Donovan.

St Senan's Church is a most beautiful sacred ground which has hosted many
special events. It is also where Ann met her brutal death aged just 24.

I vividly recall the days following this crime and the stunned reaction, not
just in Kilrush and Clare, but right across Ireland.

At the time, I ran a store in the town and I experienced first-hand the effect
Ann's murder had on the people of Kilrush and the surrounding area. What's
surprised me is how quickly 14 years have passed. It seems that this dreadful
crime was not that long ago. I am surprised the issue of parole is on the agenda
already and would share the family's concern with such a development. In the
Seanad recently, we debated the issue of sentencing, particularly in relation to
murder and mandatory life sentences during the various stages of the Parole Bill
2019. While this bill is a welcome development, there are provisions which did
not get universal agreement.

Positive provisions include the establishment, for the first time in the State,
of an independent statutory parole board and it sets out a clear and transparent
process the board will have to follow. The Act specifically provides that parole
can only be granted if the prisoner does not pose an undue risk to the public.

When the Act is commenced, a prisoner serving life will only become eligible for
parole after a minimum of 12 years is served.

This caused the most debate in the Seanad at the time as many senators believed
this was too short. While I voted for the bill, I was one of those who did
express reservations.

My reservations, like other members, was surrounding the provision which
stipulated that a person serving a mandatory life sentence for murder would be
eligible for parole after serving 12 years. I simply felt that it was not
acceptable to be eligible for parole and potentially released after just 12
years in prison.

I absolutely accept it would be a very rare situation where a person would get
parole immediately after serving 12 years but the fact it will be legally
possible is a concern. On the other hand, we will have, for the first time, a
parole board established on a statutory basis with very well defined criteria.
This will ensure much greater consistency and will bring us in line with
international best practice.

For the loved ones of family members who have been murdered, it is a life
sentence where life really is life and there are people in society who believe
that if you murder another human being that should mean life in prison. It is a
position that is hard to argue with.

As a society we have a duty to protect our citizens and like any other piece of
law, the Parole Act can be amended if it is demonstrated its provisions are not
working in the best interest of all of the people of our country.

headline: Brexit's revving up
content_plain:
Brexit's revving up AT least someone can celebrate a no-deal Brexit if it comes
to pass.

A report found a hard border would be good for our ailing motor industry as it'd
stop the influx of cheap imports.

Punters will have to drive a hard bargain down their local car dealer.

headline: Freeing Leon is danger to us all
content_plain:
GOD help anyone who crosses paths with Leon Wright. He is a menace to society.

The notorious thug  regarded as Ireland's most dangerous inmate  is back on
the streets after walking free from prison early on Friday.

Wright was locked up in the Midlands prison's National Violence Reduction Unit.
The €2.7million specialist facility was designed to hold lags who have a high
propensity for extreme violence.

During his time inside, he has attacked dozens of prison officers and been
disciplined over 212 times. He is such a loose cannon, that prison officers had
to wear riot gear to interact with him.

The question people will ask is, how has he been allowed back into decent
society? There will be no riot cops on hand to protect the public from him.
Gardai in particular will need to be on high alert. The warning issued to
members of the force this week was stark.

The special directive urged them to "assess all risk before engaging with Leon
Wright" as he is "extremely violent" and "does not react well to authority in
any shape or form".

It states officers should "exercise extreme caution" dealing with him. Warnings
like this are rare and show how seriously cops are taking his release.

Wright has severe mental health issues and is a clear danger to society. He
should be locked up, not back in decent society.

headline: FURY AT PENCE'S 'VIEWS'
content_plain:
THE Taoiseach needs to show US Vice President Mike Pence what 'an inclusive
country look likes' during his upcoming visit to Ireland, an LGBT group has
said.

LGBT Ireland CEO Paula Fagan has urged the Government to make it clear that
Pence's "regressive" views are "unacceptable in a modern democracy".

Pence and his wife Karen will arrive at Shannon on Tuesday after US President
Donald Trump cancelled his trip to Europe and chose to send his VP instead.

Pence, 60, has been very public about his anti-LGBT views.

Visit ... Pence The Republican has backed conversion therapy and a law that
would have legalized discrimination against LGBT people, among others.

Fagan said: "The Taoiseach and other ministers need to show Pence what an
inclusive LGBT country looks like and to see for himself that marriage equality
is one of the best things that happened this country.

"We can't stop him coming but we would hope some of the views he has previously
expressed could evolve and maybe change as a result of meeting real people here
in Ireland."

Pence is expected to be greeted by President Michael D Higgins in Aras an
Uachtarain and the Taoiseach in Farmleigh House during his trip to Dublin.

headline: Support feud cops
content_plain:
Support feud cops FOR years Joe Maughan warned about the lethal potential of the
Drogheda feud.

His son Willie, 34, and his girlfriend Ana, 21, were murdered by the gang behind
Keith Branigan's slaying.

Belatedly, people took notice as Drogheda descended into a war zone over the
past 12 months. His murder was the first officially linked to the feud.

Unless cops are given the proper resources needed to destroy these warring
factions, it is unlikely to be the last.

headline: Wiggins: I'd rather talk bikes than ride
content_plain:
By RACHEL DALE CYCLING veteran Bradley Wiggins says he does not miss the sport
"at all".

Wiggins, 39, turned professional in 2001 and won a hatful of awards including
Olympic golds and the Tour de France.

He spent 15 gruelling years as a professional, starting on the track before
moving to road.

The star eventually quit in 2016 and gave a terse reply when asked if he would
enjoy a comeback.

He said: "No, I don't miss it at all.

"It doesn't leave room for many other aspects in your life.

"I am fortunate that I can make a career talking and commentating about it now,
which I love doing as well.

"I've got the best of both worlds. I will always love cycling and the fans but I
don't miss the elite side of it because it's a very tough sport."

headline: LYSTER: DO I MISS IT? QUITE FRANKLY I DON'T!
subheadline: EXCLUSIVE: EX-HOST ON FINAL 'Football standard, not Dub strength, is problem'
content_plain:
BROADCASTING legend Michael Lyster adamantly insists that he does not miss his
former role as presenter of The Sunday Game Live.

Lyster, 65, retired at the end of the 2018 season after hosting the iconic RTE
show for 35 years.

Dublin are vying to be the first team to lift the Sam Maguire for the fifth time
in a row as they face Kerry in the 2019 All-Ireland Football final in Croke Park
today.

And speaking to the Irish Sun on Sunday in the run-up to the heavyweight clash,
Lyster revealed how his absence from the studio put a new perspective on the
game.

He said: "Quite frankly, no, I don't miss it. I mean, I did it for 35 years.
It's a long time. And I always knew that it was coming to an end because I knew
I'd be retiring at that stage. So it has been fine.

"It wasn't like it took me by surprise so when I stepped out of the role, I was
ready to step out."

Commenting on his first campaign outside of the studio, he said: "When you've
done something for so long, and then you're out of the loop, it puts a different
perspective on it, you know, but yeah, it's all good.

"I've enjoyed the season. The football hasn't been particularly great, to be
honest with you. But the hurling was pretty good."

Asked if the GAA needs a Kerry win to bring a stop to the negativity around
Dublin's domination, the Co Waterford born presenter responded: "I suppose they
probably do.

"It's interesting that back in 1982, when Kerry were going for the five in a
row, there was a lot of rumbling then from the GAA writers about where football
was. So sometimes things don't change all that much.

"I think the problem with the championship at the moment is not Dublin's
dominance, although that is a factor in it. But I think a bigger problem is the
standard of football.

"Let's face it, the standard in Leinster is poor. There is nobody to trouble
Dublin in Leinster and there hasn't been for the last five or six years. And
until other counties step up to the mark the problem will persist."

Asked what his own preferred outcome would be, he said: "Whatever way the final
works out, whatever the result, it's going to be a major occasion one way or the
other. "It's either going to be Dublin achieving this milestone, or it's going
to be the shock of Kerry depriving them of it, as they were themselves in 1982.
So there's a story in this no matter what way it plays out."

The veteran broadcaster has had a string of health issues over the last number
of years, suffering heart failure in 2012, a mini stoke in 2013 and a
potentially fatal cardiac arrest in 2015.

But Lyster said he couldn't rule out the possibility of getting in front of the
camera again, adding: "We will play that one by ear and see how it works out."

headline: Macca's grandkid robbed at knifepoint
content_plain:
By FIONA ELLIS PAUL McCartney has revealed that one of his grandchildren was
mugged at knifepoint.

The former Beatle said robbers took his grandson's phone in the recent incident
in London.

He said: "One of my older grandkids was mugged and got his phone taken. He was
saying the worst thing was he should have just thumped the guy, he came back and
felt a coward.

"I said 'No, no, no! The guy had a knife and you don't know, he might be able to
use that knife.' So it is scary these days."

The 77-year-old said he was able to talk to his grandson because he was mugged
in Liverpool when he was growing up.

He recalled: "It was four guys and they nicked my watch. I was of a similar age.

"I just happened to be on my own, bigger kids came along and it was the same
feeling."

headline: Q& A
content_plain:
QMY boss says she has to let me go after three years because the business has
slowed down. I can understand that, but now she's saying that I was a contractor
but I always thought I was an employee. I never had any contract at all so how
could I be a contractor? ATHIS is a tricky situation because without any
paperwork at all you'd have to fight your case outside of work.

If it turns out you were a contractor there are things like taxes that you
should have paid. Equally if you had the hallmarks of an employee and fit the
'employee test', you could be due severance pay.

QMY insurance disc hasn't arrived, and I got pulled over by the Gardai and they
said that I had to come to the station and produce it.

Turns out it was lost in the post or something and I only got it a day after the
deadline. Now I'm worried I'll get in trouble for being late but I did
everything I could to get it and I can prove I paid for it before my insurance
was up, what do you reckon? ATHE Gardai are usually a reasonable bunch. Show
them proof of payment from your card or account and the disc, I don't think a
day late will matter that much.

QI HAVE a house which has no mortgage on it and I want to buy another one but
have no money.

The frustrating thing is that the home I want next would be much cheaper but I
can't get a mortgage due to my age, is there anything I can do? AHAVE you
thought about a 'sale and lease back'? This is where you sell a house then rent
it back from the buyer for a certain amount of time.

You might need to leave money with a solicitor to hold and indemnify the deal
(so that you stick to your side of it), along with a penalty clause, but it
might work in your situation.

headline: I'VE been a busy bee [...]
content_plain:
lI'VE been a busy bee as this week as we quietly launched a new website, yes.ie,
which is all about 'self-driving' mortgages.

The plan is to give customers the ability to get the best prices available by
acting like their own broker. You could watch Love Island while making a
mortgage application over your phone, and all the documents can be done at home
so you aren't sending in paperwork or scanning things up and emailing them.

The advantage to this is that it's quicker, easier and will give people who use
it the advantage of a total view of all prices so you can make a smart decision
about the best choice for you while ensuring there are no pesky salespeople
hassling you about anything. The system does both mortgages and insurances like
life insurance (we don't do things like car insurance or house insurance yet).
We believe this will revolutionise the mortgage market because in time it means
you'd be able to switch a loan far quicker, and in doing so, save money.

There might come a day where to do that all you have to do is scan your
fingerprint. Obviously that type of financial technology is a long way away. We
haven't even done digital mortgages yet, but we plan to lead the way. Check it
out on yes.ie.

headline: lT has been a while [...]
content_plain:
lIT has been a while since I wrote about 'dual ownership', but in light of
people saying that renters have no rights, it deserves a revisit.

You can have something where two people own it, most people grasp that.

What does it mean for renters though? It means that a renter on a fixed term
contract is effectively an owner. It became law via the Land Act of 1881.

It was also key to Gladstone's appeasement of the Irish Land League at the time
and ever since then it stood the test of time.

Land courts determined fair rents and as long as the rent was being paid, meant
that you couldn't be evicted.

The crisis of homelessness could have been averted in large part if we got back
to people renting homes on long-term leases  the issue isn't that the
protection isn't there, it's that we don't use it.

headline: A CITY IN FLAMES
content_plain:
PROTESTERS and riot cops fight across a wall of fire yesterday as battles rage
in strife-hit Hong Kong.

Demonstrators hurled petrol bombs at police in response to a tear gas and water
cannon blitz.

It was ordered to try to break up a pro-democracy demonstration in the
China-controlled territory. Protesters were clubbed with batons outside the
government HQ.

Many responded by hurling missiles over barriers at cops. Protesters also
sheltered behind umbrellas to avoid water cannons which were laced with blue dye
to mark out troublemakers as the violence flared after a largely peaceful rally.

Protests which began in March over the territory's bill to allow extraditions to
China have grown into a pro-democracy crusade.

headline: PEOPLE say 'it's a mans [...]
content_plain:
PEOPLE say 'it's a mans world'  but they don't say that in German politics,
where Angela Merkel has been an unflagging leader for the last 14 years.

Part of her secret? She always pays attention to the German economy, which has
grown in all but one of her years in power.

Why does she disagree with the US and EU on a pipeline from Russia to Germany?
The economy.

Why is she pro-immigration? The economy  Germans don't have enough kids and
they need young people to move there to make up for that.

But now it seems the German economy is suffering and there are recession fears.

The problem is that key German industries are down on their luck, and big
markets that buy German goods are experiencing their own problems. Donald Trump
has dragged the US into a trade war with China so the traditional 'ready buyers'
aren't lining like they used to for German goods.

Add in Brexit and a slowing world economy, and let's hope they don't return to
being the 'sick man of Europe'.

headline: Getting rich is actually EEEasy
content_plain:
IN certain parts of Dublin if you mention the "three Es" it might be taken as
something you got up to on a Saturday night.

Not so in this column, here it's about the not-somagic recipe for becoming
wealthy.

In my book  and in most people's  the benchmark for 'wealth' is to have at
least €1,000,000 in assets without any debts attached to them.

There are three things which, if you do them all, virtually guarantee that you
are likely to be in this class of individual one day  and if you don't your
odds of being in this group get lower.

That isn't to say these are steadfast rules that are immutable, as with many
things the prove the rule.

exceptions e.h t I'd with ou hy y But I thought share them you so that you can't
say: Why didn't anybody ever tell me this? The three E's of wealth are
education, enduring marriage and end mortgage.

dof get part, ducation of money directed towards Most of us the education nobody
says education is bad. Lots and policy is getting people more education  and
it's something I regularly talk about in this column as a form of
self-improvement and better business prospects.

The 'right' type of education also matters. For instance, some people might get
a degree in sociology or some niche area that has no real industrial value,
that's a quick way to spend a few years earning the right to be poor.

Sometimes it can strangely help. A retired teacher I know told me a builder he
knows is great because he studied hotel management and it gave him a great
attitude for the things that go wrong on sites and because of that his clients
love him.

Enduring marriage is the next one. It's also not one that you'll ever hear Irish
mammies and daddies promoting, even though it was a large contributor to many of
their own successes. Brookings did an interesting paper on it recently called
'The Marriage Divide'.

There are many reasons for why married couples do better financially even though
having children and the like is very expensive. In the US, among poor Americans
only 26 per cent are married but 39 per cent of working class people are.
Marriage in high income families is 56 per cent. About 60 per cent of poor
Americans are single.

It affects kids too. For every 100 born to unmarried parents, 64 of them are
poor, while 13 are middle and upper class.

It's not politically correct to say it, but the large divergence in wealth
inequality came about as people started getting divorced more often. In the US,
it happened since the 70s.

And no, that doesn't mean I'm saying people should stay in bad marriages. But
you equally can't tell me that a family spread across two cheap to run they are
all one roof. Speaking of roofs, the last E End of mortgage.

homes is as c as when t under o Spea roofs is moT ab pe be fr ow This comes
about when a person becomes debt free and owns a large asset.

assW buy and p over capital day becom theirs and that c h f When people a home
pay it down time, the value one becomes entirely constitutes a huge amount of
wealth that renters simply never have access to nor do they generally save their
way to an equivalent value either.

Often I call a mortgage forced savings because it makes people make a payment
towards their wealth come rain, wind or snow. In times this becomes the primary
wealth of people and in Ireland it's the same as in other countries. In fact, a
Harvard study found that the biggest differentiator of wealth between black and
white people wasn't education or opportunity, it was years of homeownership.

So when you want to do right by your kids, remember that education is only one
part of it. Finding a good husband or wife, marrying them, getting a home and
paying it off are the ingredients of financial success. I do have to mention
money isn't everything though!

headline: TUNING UP TO TOP THE CHARTS
content_plain:
ALMOST two weeks ago I released my fourth music album, Far Far Away. It took
longer than expected (as anything worth doing often does) but was well worth it.

Tony Clayton Lee is one of Ireland's few top-notch music critics and he gave it
four out of five stars.

He said: "Some songs are, quite simply, gorgeous and very smartly shaped.
Exposed, heartfelt lyrics only add to the album's insightful charm. My learned
advice? You're as safe as houses with this one."

If you'd like to hear it you can do that on all the major digital platforms like
Spotify and iTunes. The people who helped make it happen were my long-time
friends and in that sense it has been a good journey of ideas, chats and cups of
coffee.

It's also a reminder that regular people can also make cool things if you are
willing to spend the time and effort on them.

That's one of the reasons I always suggest that people go out and try the things
they dream of.

ALBUM . . Far Far Away

headline: FADI'S NEW PAD
content_plain:
t id €54 i ht T l d h GEORGE Michael's ex Fadi Fawaz is snapped outside a
€54-a-night Travelodge  where he has been living after being accused of
trashing the singer's €5.5million home.

Jobless Fadi is said to have been living at the low-budget Covent Garden hotel
in central London for weeks. He was previously arrested on suspicion of

property. But when the Irish Sun caught up with him at his hideaway he bizarrely

headline: QUICK ON HIT TWEET
byline: By CRAIG FARRELL and JONATHAN KELLY
content_plain:
CORK City have offered a Twitter user a trial with the team after his tweet
requesting one went viral.

Richard Chibueze Allison contacted the League of Ireland club on the social
media site on Friday begging for a chance to prove himself on Leeside.

The club responded to the Nigerian national's plea, saying they would agree to
his request if he was able to get 50,000 retweets.

And after his message caused a Twitter storm, racking up 52,000 retweets in less
than 24 hours, the young defensive starlet  who lives in Calabar  got offered
, Trial ... Richard the chance to prove himself at club's home of Turner's
Cross.

Speaking to the Irish Sun, Richard confirmed that eighthplaced Cork had been in
touch to pass on information needed to secure his visa to allow him to travel
here and undertake the trial.

He added: "If given the chance I believe I'll give my all to the team."

He said he was delighted with the opportunity but still had "no idea" when
exactly it was to take place.

Richard also thanked punters on Twitter who retweeted his post, saying: "I can't
thank you all enough. I wish I could hug everyone right now."

headline: CRAPPY SITUATION
content_plain:
A woman is facing a €12,000 fine for not letting airport security search her
adult nappy, in Los Angeles, US.

headline: Balfe flick tipped for Oscar win
content_plain:
By BARRY MORAN A NEW car-racing movie starring Caitriona Balfe, Matt Damon and
Christian Bale has been tipped for Oscar glory.

Ford v Ferrari centres on the true story of the battle between the two car
giants to win Le Mans, a race in France, in 1966.

Variety forecasted movies that will be in contention at the upcoming Academy
awards, after its world premiere at the Telluride Film Festival.

They said: "The movie may have just raced its way into the Oscar lane."

The film follows US automotive visionary Carroll Shelby played by Damon and his
British driver, Ken Miles, played by Bale, who are on team Ford. Irish actor
Balfe plays Mollie Miles, Ken's wife.

headline: CHICKEN RUN
content_plain:
A man is suing food chain Popeyes after he spent "countless time driving" in
search of their chicken sandwich without success, in Tennessee, US.

headline: SOMEONE LIKE FEUD
subheadline:
RUMOUR HAS IT SI'S UPSET lCowell fury at Adele's Grenfell record snub lNow he's
blocked her songs from his shows
byline: EXCLUSIVE by CLEMMIE MOODIE Associate Showbiz Editor
content_plain:
SIMON Cowell has vetoed all Adele tracks from his shows after the star snubbed
his Grenfell charity single, the Irish Sun on Sunday can reveal.

Cowell, 59, does not want the Grammy-winner or any of her songs on The X Factor
or Britain's Got Talent: The Champions, which started last night. Tellingly, the
last time one of her records featured on BGT was in May 2017  a month before
the Grenfell Tower fire.

On The X Factor, her songs  previously a staple of the show  have not featured
since the blaze.

The singer famously showed up to the tower block wreckage in West London 24
hours after the tragedy.

But she refused to appear on Cowell's star-studded charity single, a re-working
of Simon and Garfunkel's Bridge Over Troubled Water. Last night a source told
the Irish Sun on Sunday: "Simon put his heart and soul into that recording, and
used up a lot of favours getting so many big names to lend their voices and give
up their time for free.

"He saw Adele down at Grenfell and assumed she'd leap at the chance to help
raise more funds. Unfortunately negotiations came to a grinding halt, and she
declined to take part.

"Understandably Simon was frustrated, and as a result currently refuses to play
any of her songs on his shows.

"Say what you like about Simon, he's a genuine guy. If Adele wouldn't help him
out, then he's not going to boost her album sales by playing her tracks.

"The stats speak for themselves  whilst pre-2017 Adele was a staple on The X
Factor, her tunes haven't appeared post-Grenfell.

"Clearly Adele is no longer in vogue with Simon or his creative team."

Songs penned by Adele used to be a popular choice among contestants on Cowell's
shows.

In 2011 then-judge Louis Walsh tried to ban X Factor wannabes from singing Adele
tracks at auditions because so many were doing them.

Past winners James Arthur, 31, and Sam Bailey, 42, were among those to perform
her songs.

But the last person to sing one was Ryan Lawrie in October 2016.

Adele herself has not appeared on it since December 2015.

In May 2017, BGT hopeful Kyle Tomlinson belted out Rolling In The Deep  the
last time one of her songs has featured on the show.

Industry experts previously claimed Adele's chart success has been helped by The
X Factor.

Stars including Robbie Williams, Liam Payne, Rita Ora, James Blunt and Stormzy
all appeared on Cowell's single, released a week after the devastating fire
killed 72 people.

@IrishSunOnline

headline: Washers recalled
content_plain:
A BATCH of dishwashers are being recalled from B&Q stores over fire fears.

The Cooke & Lewis free-standing slimline dishwasher was sold in shops around the
country.

A notice said: "B&Q has identified a safety issue with the Cooke & Lewis
CLDW451W-C/ DI6014 Free-standing slimline dishwasher white, where components may
overheat and this could result in a fire.

"The affected products were manufactured between 2012 and 2014; 2144 units are
affected."

Customers who believe they purchased this product are advised to unplug it and
contact the B&Q helpline on 1800 946 327,

headline: The recession was so brutal...it imploded our life but set us free
subheadline: IRISH AUTHOR'S BATTLE BACK FROM RUIN Says DERVLA McTIERNAN
content_plain:
By FIONA ELLIS AUTHOR Dervla McTiernan says the recession imploded her life 
but at the same time set her free.

The best-selling author has had her debut novel The Ruin developed for the big
screen by Colin Farrell as his first Chapel Place production.

And she couldn't be more thrilled and excited.

But less than a decade ago the former lawyer was left reeling after the
recession devastated her financially.

Dervla and her family packed up and left for Australia to start a new life in
2011. But now the author of The Ruin, The Scholar and The Good Turn reckons that
awful period in time was a gift.

She said: "I was a solicitor in Galway and had a small practice there and my
husband Kenny was a civil engineer. The recession decimated my practice and it
hit Kenny's work very badly as well.

"We were faced with starting again, and building everything from the bottom up,
and we looked at each other and we just said: 'Ah, I don't want to do it again.'
"We had just spent the last six years working every hour and we just wanted a
fresh start so we came to Perth.

"We didn't know a sinner.

When I look back on it, it was madness, and I was expecting a baby at the time
as well."

It was out of character for the then 34-year-old to make such a move.

She explained: "I am a little impulsive, but we'd always been incredibly
responsible both Kenny and I. We area little conservative and certainly very
responsible people. "But it didn't work out for us. We bought our house at the
wrong time, we were really hammered. It was absolutely brutal and it took us
years to recover and pick ourselves back up off the floor. "We lost ten years of
savings. We started from scratch and we were over here trying to raise a baby
and a twoyear-old with no family and no support  it was tough.

"But if you were to ask us now we would both say it was a gift in the long run.
It set us free. It imploded the life we had, and set us free to go after what we
wanted."

Dervla, mum to Freya and Oisin, only started following her true passion 
writing  in 2014. She said: "Books were always my passion, but I wasn't brave
enough to try. I started writing seriously mid-2014. I made a decision that I
was really going to do it.

"I made this commitment to myself, I would give it five years and If I didn't
get anywhere then we would see.

"I signed a contract with Harper Collins in October 2016 and The Ruin came out
February 2018."

Sometimes Dervla wonders what she might have achieved had she started writing
earlier.

She said: "Part of me wishes I started sooner now I am bursting with things I
want to do. There so many different types of things I want to try my hand at
within this area and I have a finite amount of time because the kids are still
young so I am always juggling.

"So part of me thinks, 'God, if I had my twenties and I really focused, what
could I have done?' "But the other part of me thinks, 'I didn't have a voice in
my twenties', I didn't know who the hell I was or what I thought about.

"I think I needed to grow up and have a few hard things happen to me and come
out the other side to find my voice."

6We lost 10 years of our savings. We started from scratch and we were in Perth
trying to raise a baby and a two-year-old child with no family and no support 7

headline: XBOX GAME PASS FOR PC [...]
content_plain:
XBOX GAME PASS FOR PC €3.99 per month* One-Month trial available for €1 IT could
be argued that Microsoft's boldest and best move of this console generation was
the Game Pass subscription service.

Being priced at €10 a month with over 100 games, seven titles added per month
and some wicked surprises here and there made it great value.

The fact that all of Microsoft's first-party titles would be on the service is
also a huge draw. Games like the upcoming Gears of War 5, the
critically-acclaimed Forza Horizon 4 and less-acclaimed Sea of Thieves have all
been available through Game Pass on their release day.

It was only a matter of time before the service expanded beyond the confines of
the Xbox One console and the first destination is Windows 10 PCs.

Many Xbox games are currently available on PC through the Play Anywhere service
so it was an easy decision to make first-party Microsoft titles available too.
Soccer spreadsheet Football Manager 2019 and the complete versions of Halo Wars
1 and 2 are PC royalty for €4 a month. And with Gears 5 emerging on the service
on the September 10, that €1 trial price is practically unmissable.

A small number of users have had issues installing certain games like Age of
Empires HD and Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus. A little search on the internet
for the error will fix it but it's still worth noting.

The selection isn't as strong as the Xbox Game Pass console version  there is a
greater number of filler titles and short indie experiences that don't add much
value to the line-up. But it must be noted that it costs less than half of the
console version per month.

The marquee titles are exceptional though. The aforementioned FM 2019, Halo
Wars, Age of Empires HD as well as upcoming Gears of War 5 and Age of Empires II
HD offer enough immediate variety and quality to make it worth the price of a
few months on their own.

*Or as part of Game Pass Ultimate (€12.99 per month)  Game Pass Ultimate offers
both Xbox Live Gold and Xbox Game Pass for both console and PC in one
subscription.

headline: O'Dowd's VP hope
content_plain:
SINN Fein's vice president is set to face a battle to keep her position. John
O'Dowd has confirmed he is seeking nominations from party colleagues for a
potential bid for Michelle O'Neill's role at the party conference in November.
O'Dowd said: "I will be seeking nominations for Leas Uachtaran of Sinn Fein as
we approach the Ard Fheis and the annual election of party leadership. I look
forward to the debate across the party and island."

O'Neill became vice president in January 2018 after Mary Lou McDonald took the
party's top job after Gerry Adams stepped down.

headline: Lad shot in leg by masked thug trio
content_plain:
By JOHN HAND COPS in Northern Ireland have launched a probe into a
"paramilitary-style attack" in which a 25-year-old man was shot.

Three masked thugs targeted the lad at a house in Mimosa Court in Gobnascale, Co
Derry at around 10.50pm on Friday night.

One of the men was armed with a hammer while a second, armed with a handgun,
shot the victim in the leg.

The gunman attempted to fire a number of subsequent shots, but it's believed the
gun jammed and the suspects fled.

The victim was brought to hospital with non lifethreatening injuries. PSNI
Detective Inspector Peter McKenna said: "This was a savage and brutal attack on
a young man in his home, carried out by faceless cowards.

"Nothing gives them the right to violate the human rights of others."

headline: TEEN AIN'T TINY
subheadline: STRONGMAN RAISING LIFTER Gavin, 13, 'unofficial coach' at champ dad's gym
content_plain:
GAVIN Maher is just 13  but he's already been pumping iron for four years. The
youngster will have to wait until he is 16 to enter junior strongman contests,
but he's been lifting weights and practising poses since the age of nine. Gavin
helps dad Keith Maher run Silverback's Gym in Graiguecullen, Co Carlow, as an
unofficial coach.

Keith was Ireland's Strongest Man in 2014 and is currently in training to enter
Britain's Strongest Man.

But while Gavin clearly inherited his strength from his dad, Keith said he
wasn't the inspiration for his son to hit the weights.

He said: "I never told him to pick up a weight. He didn't even go to the
contests when I was competing. This all started when he was nine, and he saw big
lads of 16 in the gym, and he just jumped in.

"I'd look at him to see if he's doing it right, but he doesn't need my help now
 he's giving tips to adults. If anyone is doing a benchsquat wrong, he'll tell
them!" Gavin started off powerlifting but is now focused on bodybuilding  the
old-fashioned Charles Atlas way.

He trains with European Champ Vinnie Craine and is focused on getting a
traditional muscled physique. Keith said: "He told me he doesn't want to be
bulky with a big gut, he wants to go for the classic build. So he's not
following in my footsteps  he wants to do what Vinnie is doing."

But, unlike some of the older bodybuilders and powerlifters, Gavin is not on a
strict diet. Keith said: "He would eat ice cream till it came out of his ears!
He's always asking me for money to go to Dunnes Stores to buy sweets ... On a
Friday morning, we go for a treat, a rasher sandwich, and he loves it. He burns
off all the calories in the gym.

"At a time when kids are told to do more physical activity, and there's so much
obesity, it's good to see a young lad has a healthy lifestyle.

"I try to encourage other young people to get into the gym. We tell kids in the
Carlow Youth Centre to come to our gym. Even if they don't have the money, they
are welcome."

Gavin's sister, Kia, 17, is not interested in bodybuilding at all, their dad
adds. "She's more into fashion."

But being fit is not just about building muscle, their dad says  "I'm just
happy they're active."

When Gavin is not in the gym, he finds other ways to keep on the move. His dad
said: "He's not the kind to sit around. He has an X-box but he's never opened
it! When he's not in the gym, he's out walking the dogs or looking after the
chickens.

"He's also into rally cars. He wants to be a mechanic when he leaves school, but
he has the option to work with me in the gym. He could work as a fitness trainer
because he knows how to talk to people."

Family friend, personal trainer and bodybuilder Nicoleta Chiorean, said: "I
think Gavin is going to be a champion. He will be big!"

headline: SUNDIAL
content_plain:
SUNDIAL R E TAMIDKSEE how many words of four or more letters you can "dial"
using the one at the centre in each word.

You can make at least one word using all of them. Don't use the letters more
than once in any word.

No proper names or plurals. Words from Collins Concise Dictionary.

BRILLIANT: 58. EXCELLENT: 49. GOOD: 41. GREAT SCORE FOR KIDS: 32. YESTERDAY:
Crunk, eking, gink, gunk, kepi, kern, king, knur, kuri, neck, nick, nicker,
nuke, peck, pecking, perk, perking, pick, picker, pike, piker, pink, pinker,
prick, prink, puck, pucker, pucking, puke, puking, punk, reck, recking, rick,
rink, ruck, rucking, unpick.

Nine-letter word: Puckering.

headline: Funeral Mass for bar bash victim, 34
content_plain:
By JOHN HAND A DAD-of-two who died after a brutal assault will be laid to rest
next week.

Vincent Parsons, from Clondalkin, west Dublin, lost his brave fight for life two
days after he was found with head injuries last Saturday night.

It's understood he was at a social event at the Killinarden Inn in Tallaght but
was later attacked in a grass area after leaving the pub.

Officers launched a murder probe after a post mortem revealed he was brutally
attacked.

The 34-year-old's funeral Mass will take place at The Church of the
Transfiguration in Bawnogue on Tuesday.

His death notice on RIP.ie read: "Tragically; sadly missed by his heartbroken
wife Claire, darling daughter Jade, little buddy son Gerard, mother Josie, aunt
Mary, brother Danny, sisters Marian, Celine, Mary, Elaine and Leighanne."

headline: Man dies after van crash on the M9
content_plain:
By CRAIG FARRELL A MAN died after crashing his van into a speed barrier
yesterday.

Emergency services attended the scene on the M9 motorway at Junction 5 in Co
Carlow at around 3.30pm. The man, in his 50s, was treated at the scene before
being rushed to St Luke's General Hospital in Co Kilkenny. But he was pronounced
dead a short time later.

Gardai are appealing for witnesses after launching an investigation into the
circumstances surrounding the smash.

Forensic collision investigators were to examine the crash site yesterday and
the local coroner was notified.

A Garda spokesman said: "It's understood the van left the motorway and struck a
speed barrier. Anyone with information is asked to contact Carlow Garda Station
059-9136620 or the Garda Confidential Line 1800 666 111."

headline: SKIB ROW HEROES
content_plain:
CORK pair Paul O'Donovan and Fintan McCarthy powered to glory at the World
Rowing Championships in Austria yesterday.

The Skibbereen stars crossed the line in Linz a full 2.5sec ahead of Italy in
the lightweight double sculls final.

Amazingly, they only paired up last month for the World Cup in Rotterdam where
they finished second.

The new partnership sealed their place in the Olympic Games on Thursday and
continued their remarkable progress with a time of 6:37.28 in yesterday's final.

There was no stopping them once they hit the front after the halfway mark.

headline: O'Rourke is gold-actico in Madrid
content_plain:
MAGNIFICENT middleweight Aoife O'Rourke was congratulated by the President after
becoming European champion  and also by the queen.

Undisputed lightweight champ Katie Taylor led the tributes to the 75kg
sensation, who beat Poland's Elziebta Wojcik yesterday in Madrid by unanimous
decision.

Victory meant O'Rourke became only the second Irishwoman to claim the senior
European title  after Taylor herself, who won it six times.

Taylor, now an unbeaten pro, tweeted: "Incredible stuff Aoife, huge
congratulations!!" President Michael D Higgins posted: "My heartfelt
congratulations to Aoife O'Rourke on winning gold, and to Amy Broadhurst on
winning the bronze medal, at the European Elite Women's Boxing Championships in
Madrid." It was a final display of pure guts and determination by the Castlerea
BC fighter.

One judge scored it a 30-27 shutout to O'Rourke, with the other four posting
29-28 verdicts in favour of the new champion.

The IABA's team manager JP Kinsella said: "A brilliant performance from Aoife
and a brilliant result. To say we are thrilled would be an understatement."

It was O'Rourke's third victory of the week in the Spanish capital.

She took out Ukraine's Tetiana Petrovich in the quarter-final and Anastasia
Shamonova of Russia in the semis.

And she simply refused to lose against Wojcik, who resorted to holding tactics
from the opening bell against her opponent's swarming attacks. Ireland's head
coach Zaur Antia said: "Aoife was phenomenal. Brilliant performance and she's
made history for such a young woman. She has a great future ahead of her  the
future is green."

Irish featherweight champ Eric Donovan, who took gold at the 2010 Europeans in
Moscow, reckons O'Rourke is looking good for next summer's Olympic Games.
'Lilywhite Lightning' said: "Congratulations to Aoife O'Rourke on becoming
Ireland's newest European boxing champion.

"What an incredible achievement. With the Tokyo Olympics just around the corner
this is very promising."

Team-mate Amy Broadhurst will take home a bronze medal from the tournament.

Having scooped six European medals in underage boxing, it was the Dundalk
lightweight's first major medal as a senior boxer.

The team returns home this morning and test matches are expected in the next
fortnight to help with the selection of the final team for October's Women's
World Championships, which take place in Ulan-Ude, Russia from October 3 to 13.

It was announced this week that qualifiers for the Tokyo games next year will
take place in London in March 2020 and Paris in May 2020.

And O'Rourke, after this spectacular success, will now become a firm medal hope.

headline: TEMPLEGATE
content_plain:
TEMPLEGATE ? LET's Dream big at Brighton. JOYFUL DREAM (4.00, nap) was
impressive when winning here last time. She was in front a long way from home
and kept producing more so this slightly longer trip won't be an issue.

HTHEGREYVTRAIN (2.00 Brighton, treble) has title-chasing Oisin Murphy (below)

headline: Water carry on by weary Rory
content_plain:
RORY McILROY remains in the mix for European Masters glory  despite ending up
in the drink TWICE.

He is looking to cash in on his red-hot form again after scooping $15MILLION by
winning the Tour Championship.

But he found water twice in the final five holes at Crans-sur-Sierre in
Switzerland for a one-under-par 69 that leaves him 11 under.

Though the weary Holywood hotshot (left) will still fancy his chances in today's
final round.

McIlroy is three shots off leader Andres Romero, who finished 14 under after a
third-round 66. And world No 2 McIlroy, who arrived in Switzerland just hours
after his big pay day in Atlanta, admitted: "I felt a little flat out there  a
little tired.

"Maybe it just all caught up with me.

I'm looking forward to getting to bed early and getting a good night's sleep.

"I played pretty solid but then made those mistakes coming in. If I play a good
front nine tomorrow, I'll be right in it."

Ryder Cup pal Tommy Fleetwood is also in the shake-up. The Englishman bogeyed
the second, third and sixth playing alongside Romero. But he birdied the ninth,
12th, 14th, 15th and 17th to reach 12 under alongside Malaysia's Gavin Green.

Fleetwood said: "It's easy to get down on yourself. It was a really terrible
start  but I actually didn't do that much wrong out there.

"Luckily, I had a good finish. It's that kind of golf course where you can get
hot.

"I definitely need a better start in the final round but as for the back nine, I
need more of that!" Argentine Romero's hopes looked to be fading when he dropped
three shots in his opening five holes as McIlroy and Australian Wade Ormsby
established a two-shot lead.

But as McIlroy and Ormsby suffered late stumbles, Romero came home in 31.

The 38-year-old produced a brilliant run of scoring on the back nine, going
birdieeagle-birdie-birdie from the 13th to edge a shot ahead of Ormsby, who
bogeyed the last in his round of 67.

Christiaan Bezuidenhout, Lorenzo Gagli and Kalle Samooja are also at 11 under.

They are a shot clear of 2017 Masters champion Sergio Garcia, Renato Paratore,
Matthias Schwab and Sebastian Soderberg.

headline: Count to Ten
byline: By KEVIN BYRNE PROMOTER Eddie Hearn
content_plain:
PROMOTER Eddie Hearn wants James Tennyson to skip British level to chase the
American dream instead.

The Belfast banger last night smashed England's Atif Shafiq in a lightweight
contest in London.

Last year, Tennyson challenged Tevin Farmer for the IBF world
super-featherweight title in Boston but was stopped in the fifth.

But ten months on he has regrouped in style.

Up a weight, he is looking strong and last night racked up his third win in a
row when he clubbed the unfortunate Shafiq into submission in the second round
at the O2.

Manager Mark Dunlop plans to guide him to the British title, with an eliminator
lined up against Wales' Craig Evans in October.

But Hearn  who is desperate to find new superstars to back up his big-money
deal with DAZN in the USA  believes 'The Assassin' is TV gold and might be
better off looking beyond that.

Hearn said: "James is a huge puncher. He struggled at superfeather and didn't
have enough in the tank against Farmer.

"But he will be a major problem at lightweight.

"He might move on for a big fight in the States. It's always a lot of fun to
watch James Tennyson.

"He has zero fear fighting anyone. He's not got a big name but he can punch. He
might have frailties but he can knock anyone out.

"He's a very exciting TV fighter. I want to say to his manager to skip British
level!" Hard-hitting Tennyson was hailed by Belfast trainer Ray Ginley as
'Ireland's biggest puncher, pound for pound', after the win.

Of his 25 pro victories, this was his 21st stoppage.

'Tenny' said: "I just had to be patient. He was tricky.

"That proves I'm a full lightweight. The performance showed that my power came
up a weight with me and it seems to be good.

"I like to be busy. I'd be more than happy to get two more fights before the end
of the year."

Also on the card, Russia's Alexander Povetkin beat Hughie Fury by unanimous
decision to claim the WBA International heavyweight title.

headline: EXPECTING AND FEEL SO ANGRY
content_plain:
Dear Deidre I LASH out at strangers in the shopping centre and worry I'll get
arrested.

I'm 25 and pregnant with my third child. I've always had anxiety and depression
but the pregnancy seems to make it worse. Most days I take my boys to school
then go home and sleep all day. I never answer the door.

When I must go out, I go mental if someone looks at me oddly. A security guard
was called in a shop yesterday and I had to leave. My husband just says it's
because I'm pregnant. He's 26 and I wish he was more understanding. I've never
felt so alone.

0 Deidre SAYS: You are not well and need urgent help. Hormonal changes may be
the problem or perhaps anxieties about how this child will affect your life and
family.

See your GP, preferably with your husband. To help the doctor understand, write
down your symptoms and explain clearly how you're feeling. Tell your midwife,
too.

Postnatal depression Ireland offers understanding support to help with
pre/antenatal and postnatal depression (pnd.ie)

headline: I'M BIG BELOW SO PASSION IS A PAIN
content_plain:
Dear Deidre I AM big down below and my girlfriend can't cope.

She's 19 and I'm 21. She's my first proper girlfriend and I like her loads.

I have done sexual stuff with girls before, but not had full sex and I didn't
realise I was so wellendowed. I thought I was run of the mill.

My girlfriend had never had sex before and she stopped me the first time we
tried, because she said it was too painful.

We have tried since then but she struggles when we want to have sex. This is
really affecting our sex life and I don't want our relationship to end. What can
I do to make this better for her? 0 Deidre SAYS: I wonder if you are really
extra-large down below - or whether lack of experience means you just don't give
sufficient time to foreplay.

If your girlfriend isn't properly aroused before intercourse, then it's going to
hurt.

Experiment together to find out what kind of touches work for her.

My e-leaflets How To Thrill A Woman In Bed and Too Large? can help.

headline: Amazing lover's gay secret has left me broken
content_plain:
Dear Deidre SEX with my lover is wildly adventurous and satisfying as I enjoy
being submissive, but I think he may be cheating on me - with guys.

I have been in a dead-end marriage for 12 years. My husband is a good person but
does not give me what I truly need and does not make me happy.

We have come to realise that we are not well matched and we lead pretty separate
lives but still live in the same house.

I am 34, he is 35 and we have a daughter of 11 and a son of nine. They are
unaware of our troubles because we don't argue and we do a lot as a family.

I realised that part of finding myself was to understand what I need in a
relationship. I started to explore the idea that I might be submissive, in all
aspects of a relationship including sexually.

I met a man online who swept me off my feet. He is 39 and in a hollow marriage
rather like mine. I felt I'd met my soulmate.

Never before had I enjoyed so much variety in the bedroom and had so much fun
socially. He may have taken me a bit out of my comfort zone but he is just
perfect for me. We manage to meet in a hotel most weeks.

But today while he was in the shower I saw that he was still logged in to his
email on my laptop. I didn't plan to snoop but saw he had signed up to a gay sex
site, looking to meet men.

I have asked him before whether he is bisexual and he said no, but I am broken.
I thought he was perfect but he is not the man I thought I knew.

I haven't said anything to him yet. If I speak to him about it I know he will
say that it does not affect his feelings for me, and I do not need to know about
it.

This man has given me the most amazing, exciting months of my life but can I
accept that? He is very open-minded sexually and thinks it is normal to involve
other people in your sex life so he probably doesn't think that would be
cheating. I'm still married anyway, so how can I complain about cheating? ?
DEIDRE SAYS: This has been an exciting adventure for you, but this man doesn't
care for you in any meaningful, lasting way.

He is using you to pursue his own agenda of pushing the sexual boundaries and
will always put his wants before your needs.

Truth is, your self-esteem will be pushed lower and lower the longer you keep
seeing him, quite apart from the risk to your sexual health.

I know you say your marriage is hollow but better settle it one way or the other
than let your children think your lack of deep love for each other is normal.
You may not argue but they will pick up on the lack of passion.

Stop seeing your lover, organise a sexual health check and tell your husband
it's crunch time - either you rebuild your love for one another or separate so
you're both free to find genuinely caring partners.

My e-leaflet Your Relationship MOT can help you give your marriage the best
chance.

content_plain:
LUCK OF THE LEGION (3.40 Worcester) might have won on handicap debut but for a

headline: Deidre's photo casebook
subheadline: SEAN'S SCRATCHCARD Adapted by LAURA COLLINS HABIT
content_plain:
Dear Sean WHAT lies behind your scratchcard habit? When you're thinking clearly
you know your chances of winning in any significant way are infinitesimal. So
what's driving you? If you feel trapped by routine and long for an adrenalin
rush in your life, get into a competitive sport that will give you a buzz in a
healthy way.

If you have mounting money worries and you are hoping for a magic wand, be
honest with your missus and read my e-leaflet Dealing With Debt.

Deidre

headline: Dear Deidre I HAVE made [...]
content_plain:
Dear Deidre I HAVE made a fool of myself over a younger woman.

My mum was admitted to hospital last month and will be there for a while. I
noticed a very attractive nurse. I was wary of asking her out because I am 42
and she looks half my age.

I gave her a long letter telling her how much I admired her. I said I realised I
was too old for her but hoped we could be friends. She thanked me afterwards and
said it was lovely.

I suspect that she then showed some of her colleagues, because the atmosphere
has deteriorated. I overheard her telling another nurse I'm a creep. It has got
to the point where I am relieved now if she is off duty when I visit my mum. I
have always treated women with respect but I never seem to have any luck.

0 Deidre SAYS: Nurses often have to be wary of men falling for their caring role
and not understanding the professional boundaries, but this nurse has been
insensitive.

Let it go, as the atmosphere will ease, but focus on building up a social life
that includes women so you can get to know them as friends to start with. A
relationship can then develop naturally.

My e-leaflet Finding The Love Of Your Life will help you get started.

headline: PUB QUIZ
content_plain:
PUB QUIZ 1 MOVIES Which day of the week was 'Freaky' in the title of a 2003
movie starring Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan? 2 MUSIC With which type of
music are B.B. King and Muddy Waters primarily associated? 3 TV & RADIO Which

the host of BBC Radio 1's early breakfast weekend show? 9 WORDS What is a
