denoting infinity c) a thigh-length ancient Roman toga 10 BRITAIN The area of
Mayfair is in which London borough? 11 THIS YEAR A jury has recently ruled which
singer copied her single 'Dark Horse' from a Christian rapper? 12 POT LUCK What
was the first animal sent to orbit the Earth?

headline: Dear Deidre OUR housemate's boyfriend [...]
content_plain:
Dear Deidre OUR housemate's boyfriend is treating our home like his own and
sponging off us but she can't see it.

We are four girls in our early 20s. One girl got a new boyfriend two months ago.
Their relationship is intense. She spent the whole of one day crying because she
could not see him till the next morning. Her changing moods affect us all.

He doesn't work and he sleeps and farts on the sofa all day. He constantly
cadges our cigarettes. He eats our food and takes our housemate's credit card to
buy stuff but only ever for himself. He uses our washing machine and watches TV
without contributing to any bills. Our flatmate used to be highly motivated and
energetic but now she is a lazy couch potato like him.

Their relationship is very unhealthy but she does not seem to care.

0 Deidre SAYS: It is her choice to see him but you do not have to accept a
housemate being forced on you all.

Tell them together that he must start to pay his way. Refuse to give him
cigarettes and demand bills are split five ways.

If they argue, say they will have to find somewhere else to live. My e-leaflet
on Standing Up For Yourself will help you stick to your guns.

headline: FAMILY FORUM
content_plain:
Dear Deidre MY fiancée's father wants to come and stay - but he hates pets of
all kinds and kicks our two dogs whenever he gets the chance.

He is a difficult man and drinks too much. When my fiancée was little, they
found a litter of kittens in the garden and he drowned them all.

I am 24. My girlfriend is 23 and is expecting our first child soon. I think this
is why her dad wants to stay, because we haven't seen him for two years.

I want to get on well with my fiancée's family. Her parents are divorced, so her
mum won't be visiting with him. Otherwise, I could ask her to keep watch on him.

I don't lose my temper easily but I love our two dogs. They are well behaved and
I don't know if I could hold myself back from belting this man if he tried to
hurt them.

0 Deidre SAYS: Does your girlfriend actually want her dad to come to stay? She
has a choice, especially if he is a difficult drunk. You can say no together.

If she truly does want to see him, tell him beforehand that he must not upset
your dogs - or you. Watch carefully and, whenever possible, keep a closed door
between her dad and your dogs.

If he really has a drink problem, though, alcohol may undo everyone's best
intentions - and then you'd best insist he leave.

Dear Deidre I AM at the end of my tether.

I have two sons and a daughter. The boys hate one another.

There is never a moment's peace in our home. They have to share a room but
otherwise I have to separate them all the time. They are 12 and 13. My daughter
is just nine.

Both the boys have had problems at school. I'm 37 and have to deal with this
myself, as my husband and I live apart. He sees the children when he can.

The eldest one seems angry with the world just about all the time. He can be
aggressive and rude to adults and to his teachers. When he is annoyed about
something, he cannot let it go. I also worry that my daughter is being affected
by the turmoil - but I don't know how to keep them happy.

0 Deidre SAYS: Children tend to learn about adult relationships from their own
parents' behaviour - especially the same-sex parent. How was your break-up? Why
isn't their dad making the effort to see the children regularly? Unless there is
some reason why he shouldn't see more of the children, especially his sons, talk
to your husband.

Say he needs to see more of the boys so they feel valued and important to him.
It could make so much difference to how they value themselves.

My e-leaflet Stressed With The Kids? should help.

headline: PACKY Blinder
subheadline:
IRISH ACTOR LEE'S 'S AGAINST-ALL-ODDS BATTLE TO SUCCEED Teachers said acting
wasn't a job for a boy from West Belfast, and the bullies didn't like that I was
into drama, but I tried ten times harder than everyone else, and now I'm...
content_plain:
HE was once told he would never be an actor by his school teachers  but now
Packy Lee is the "only one" Tommy Shelby trusts in Peaky Blinders.

The Belfast man has played Johnny Dogs in all five seasons so far  the gypsy
right-hand man of boss Tommy Shelby.

In last Sunday's episode, the gangster told Packy's character he was the "only
one in the world he trusts".

But if Packy had listened to his secondary school teachers, he would have never
made it to where he is now  a star in one of the BBC's biggest shows.

He told us: "If you said it now, people would say, 'OK, fair play to you.' But
25 years ago, if I said I wanted to be an actor, people laughed at me. That's
being honest.

"I asked if I could move school because my school didn't do GSCE drama. And they
called my parents in, got them into a room and they said, 'Now you listen to me
Mr Lee and Mrs Lee, your son is from West Belfast and there are no opportunities
or jobs in any industry of acting that he would classify for. It's just not
possible. So why would he move school to be an actor when the job criteria is
certainly not available?' "But with the help of the other school, Corpus
Christie College, I moved school, I did my GSCE drama, and I didn't look back.

"But I've bumped into a few of those teachers who were in that committee board
who were the ones who giggled and laughed at me wanting to leave.

"It's great to see them now. I'm just being honest. I'm not rude at all, I'm
very polite but there was no belief. If you don't believe, you're the one
letting other people down and stopping them fulfilling their dreams."

And it wasn't only the teachers who gave him a hard time.

Packy recalled: "Bullies in school because you're into drama ... people don't
like that  they want you to play football. 'Look at him he's a sissy.' When
you're going to the Arts theatre on Saturday instead of going to play football,
some people just don't like playing with you or hanging around with you as young
kids.

"But that's all changed because I believed in what I wanted to do and in my
dreams that they're bigger than Saturday afternoon football.

"If I wanted to be a footballer then I would be there on the Saturday afternoon
but I didn't. I wanted to be the actor, I wanted to learn the lines, I wanted to
be different people, different individuals."

And he said he had to work "ten times harder" than those who went to acting
school.

He said: "I couldn't afford drama school so I am what I am. As much as I would
have loved to have gone to drama school, I was able to do it a different way.

"I made sure I have a career, made sure I have a bit of work as an actor that I
can walk into a job but also bring money home to provide for a family.

"I had a different mindset to other people who were able to get a scholarship
and who were able to go to drama school and do the three years.

"Every time I got an audition, I give it that wee bit extra attention because
the opportunities didn't come that often.

"But now, all of a sudden because of Peaky Blinders, I'm in a different
category.

"I'm up for different work, I'm doing different work and I'm very proud of it.

"But I'm also very real, I know I am just an actor and a normal person like
everybody else, I do the normal things that we all do.

"I walk to the shopping centre and I'm doing messages and people will stop me
and go, 'You do your own shopping?' Are you for real? 'Do you not have someone
who does it for you?' What do people think I am? "I'm just an average guy from
West Belfast in an extraordinary job. And because the show is so massive at the
minute, it's made the job that bit more extraordinary." Fans of the show love
the gypsy Johnny, but they may be surprised to know he was only meant to appear
for one episode. Packy recalled: "I was only cast for one day, I was only meant
to do one day.

"They obviously enjoyed what I'd done, Steven enjoyed what I did and we chatted
about that and they kept me alive in it."

Speaking about his co-star, Cork man Ci said: "I have but also grea "I had kno

headline: 'Meaney was my film idol'
content_plain:
IT was an Irish film that got the Belfast man interested in acting for a career.

He made sure he had a back-up job in case it fell apart, but now he will be
working with the man who inspired him.

Packy said: "The Commitments was the one that got me going. I started learning
accents and watching things  trying to get the Dublin accent right, the Cork
accent, knowing the difference between different accents, trying to tackle
English.

"My parents helped me move school to do my drama but they also wanted me to have
a career  so I trained to be a chef.

"Then I auditioned for a job in the West End and got it. I auditioned for a job
in the National Theatre and got it.

"Then I was working with the likes of Jimmy Nesbitt, Conleth Hill, Jim Norton 
Irish royalty in my eyes. And to be the young lad sharing the stage with those
three in a show called Shoot the Crow on the West End was a great big change in
my career."

He added: "I'm about to shoot another movie shortly, that is why I am home, with
Colm Meaney, Alec Baldwin and Ned Dennehy.

"I'm a big fan of Mr Meaney, below, from the original days of The Snapper, The
Van and The Commitments. I know he does all this other stuff  but I have been a
fan of his from that original stuff. It's a great moment to finally get a chance
to work with him.

"It's a great movie, it's called Pixie. There's an amazing cast linked to it and
again we are flying the Irish flag very proudly."

headline: Hozier to go home
content_plain:
HOZIER has announced a one-off Dublin gig in the run-up to Christmas.

The singer, from Bray, Co Wicklow, will bring his Wasteland Baby! World Tour to
Dublin's 3Arena on December, 10.

The announcement comes after his headline performance on Friday night at
Electric Picnic.

Tickets are priced from €39.90 and will go on sale next Friday, September 6, at
9am.

headline: MARTIN: MY GRIEF TORMENT
subheadline:
EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW lTV host lost both of his parents in a month lMum had
dementia & wasn't told hubby died
content_plain:
VIRGIN TV star Martin King today tells of the agony of losing both his parents
in the space of a month.

Dad Martin Boyle died first on Easter Monday before his mum, who suffered from
dementia, passed away just over four weeks later.

The Six O'Clock Show host, 56, was told by docs not to tell his mum the tragic
news.

But Martin, right, told us: "She worked out that he had died. Then it was just
two days later that she died herself." Full Story  4&5 herself.

headline: DUBLIN v KERRY, CROKE PARK, [...]
content_plain: DUBLIN v KERRY, CROKE PARK, 3.30PM FIVE ALIVE-OH? SEE SUNSPORT AND GAME PULLOUT

headline: Exercise extreme caution! FULL STORY [...]
content_plain:
Exercise extreme caution!

FULL STORY  PAGE SEVEN

headline: POSITIVE VIBES
content_plain:
ALL the talk was Positive ahead of the Solario Stakes but the result was
agonisingly close for favourite backers.

Two-year-old Positive, owned by Chelsea vice-president Alan Spence, was sent off
a 4-5 shot for the Sandown Group 3 and just held off the challenge of outsider
Kameko by a nose under Adam Kirby.

The colt had finished clear second to star juvenile Pinatubo on his last start
in the Vintage Stakes at Glorious Goodwood and trainer Clive Cox said: "We're
very pleased.

"He has progressed every step of the way but he is still quite raw. More time is
going to see further progress  with the right sort of behaviour.

"It was close at the line but they went a good gallop and it was a good time so
we can be no more than pleased with him. He is well entered, he is in over seven
furlongs in the Dewhurst, he's in the Royal Lodge and the Champagne Stakes and
also the Lagardere in France so we are covering all bases.

"We will let the horse tell us."

Lavender's Blue blossomed with a 12-1 win in the Atalanta Stakes.

The Sir Michael Stoute-trained Jubiloso was sent off 4-5 favourite but faded and
Amanda Perrett's filly, owned by Benny Andersson of ABBA fame, cruised through
for a lengthand-a-half win.

Perrett said: "She deserves her chance in the Sun Chariot if the ground is OK.

"She wouldn't want it too soft." Hyanna gave Georgia Dobie a big Saturday winner
in the mile-and-aquarter handicap.

The filly, trained by Eve Johnson-Houghton swooped late to hold off the
wellbacked Migr-ation.

headline: LIFT GIRL: Rooney dropped trousers [...]
content_plain: LIFT GIRL: Rooney dropped trousers at pool S ¦ EE PAGES 8&9

headline: Peaking on BBC1
content_plain:
PEAKY Blinders has been such a success that it's been moved from BBC2 to BBC1 
and now even Netflix has taken it on board.

This is a strange feeling for Packy, who said: "I think it was 2012 when we
started this. So it's nearly turned out to be a ten-year contract  which is
incredible."

He added: "There's a photograph they released of me and Cillian on day one of
filming in 2012, and it's crazy to belong to that character and that world for
so long.

"I doubt I'll play another character like this in my life. I am very grateful
for it and taken aback by all the support. That's down to one thing only 
loyalty. Loyalty is a massive thing, in Ireland it is a massive thing. I tried
to bring that to Johnny Dogs."

headline: GIMME FIVE!
subheadline: ALL-IRELAND FINAL Paddy: Clux is the reason for Dubs success
content_plain:
ALL-IRELAND FINAL ALL-IRELAND FINAL GIMME FIVE! By JASON BYRNE STEPHEN CLUXTON
kick-started Dublin's Drive For Five. And the legendary stopper will complete
the job today when he again climbs the steps of the Hogan Stand to lift the Sam
Maguire Cup. That is the verdict of former Sky Blues captain Paddy Christie
(right) who credits Cluxton with providing the launch-pad for Dublin's decade of
dominance. Christie reckons it would never have happened only for the keeper's
nerveless lastgasp free to beat Kerry in the 2011 All-Ireland final. He said:
"They are going Turn to Page 51 Paddy: Clux is the reason for Dubs success FIVE
WILL MAKE YOU GET DOWN NOW ... Stephen Cluxton and Dublin can make history at
Croke Park today Dublin v Kerry 3.30 pm Croke Park 3.30 pm Croke Park FENTON ...
the greatest midfielder Dubs have had, says Redmond FIVE From Back Page For
Five. in a row now but that 2011 final was a big turning point because it looked
like they were going to lose. "If Cluxton hadn't kicked that free over, Kerry
probably would have won that day, or won a replay. "But that win changed
everything, and without him it wouldn't have happened. "I always take pleasure
in watching what he has achieved over the years. "He's a phenomenon, and he
deserves everything he gets."

headline: Cutting squad is tough Schmidt
content_plain:
JOE SCHMIDT is bracing himself for a 'horrible' couple of days as he finalises
his World Cup squad.

Ireland survived a late fightback from Wales to record a 22-17 win at the
Principality Stadium.

This was a big improvement on what he saw against England a week earlier.

It will be on his mind as he ponders his selections with coaching staff today
and tomorrow before submitting his 31-man panel to World Rugby, although it does
not have to be publicly revealed until September 8. Schmidt (left) knows from
2015 just how difficult the process will be. He said: "I think it's a horrible
couple of days.

"This time four years ago was probably the worst couple of days I've had in
coaching.

"I know how hard these players are working, this is the pinnacle and I know how
good they are.

"For those players who miss out, it's going to be a real body blow.

"I'm incredibly conscious of that and I sympathise with that but I can only take
31. That's the brutality of it."

Match Report  Pages 38, 39

headline: Lennon: Say sorry to me
content_plain:
Lennon: Say sorry to me By DAVID FRIEL NEIL LENNON has questioned why Rangers
apologised to Steve Clarke for sectarian abuse  but not him. The Celtic boss
(right) says Ibrox chiefs should have said sorry to him long before they slammed
fans for calling ex-Kilmarnock gaffer Clarke a 'fenian b******' in February. He
said: "It's embarrassing Turn to Page 45 Rangers v Celtic SORRY From Back Page
but then sometimes people turn a blind eye to it or go, 'Och it is only him, he
can deal with it'. "But at the end of the day we are human beings. "I think
Rangers put a statement out after Steve Clarke got the abuse, but there was none
forthcoming for me over the years. "I find that interesting as well." Uefa hit
Gers with two charges for sectarian singing during Euro qualifiers. Lenny does
not think it will change the abuse he expects to get from the Ibrox stands. He
said: "It's always been that way. It was ever thus." Old Firm special  See
Goals P12
