Ballybofey. It remains to be seen if the pair are part of his plans and
O'Donnell may seek to bring Dundalk assistant head coach Ruaidhrí Higgins in
with him. But, whoever he chooses to work with, O'Donnell is determined to bring
the good days back to Richmond Park with the side currently lying fifth in the
table, facing an uphill task to qualify for Europe.

He said: "I'm delighted to be at St Pat's, a massive club, a club I've always
admired from afar.

"I never got a chance to play for them but I always looked forward to playing at
Richmond Park with a great atmosphere and a good, tight ground. I know what it's
like when the place is bouncing and St Pat's are doing well."

headline: Rennie shows some tough love
content_plain:
WATERFORD needed to toughen up to stop the rot.

That is the view of Blues boss Alan Reynolds after his side recovered from four
straight defeats to draw 1-1 with fourth-placed Derry City on Friday night.

Waterford are just five points ahead of Finn Harps, who occupy occupying the
relegation play-off berth, after getting a result at the RSC.

They still have seven games left, including tomorrow's trip to Cork City and an
even longer trek to Harps on the penultimate night of the season.

Rennie (left) admits his side were becoming pushovers, prompting a midfield
overhaul on Friday.

The inclusion of Sam Bone and Georgie Poynton in the engine room put it up to a
physical Derry side.

He said: "I felt that we were too nice to play against.

"That's not something that I like about a team I manage.

We spoke about this again during the week and we changed things up.

"We decided to go a different route.

"Georgie and Sam give us that edge where they compete for everything.

"The likes of JJ Lunney and Tom Holland are technically gifted but are young and
need time."

headline: Ryan exit from Inter
content_plain:
Ryan exit from Inter RYAN NOLAN has left Inter Milan to join Arezzo.

Nolan, 20, has agreed a three-year deal with the Serie C club with Inter
retaining a 50 per cent sell-on clause for the defender.

Born in Shannon, Nolan moved to Spain at the age of eight before being snapped
up by the Italian giants in 2015.

Despite making the bench in the Europa League last season, Nolan  capped by
Ireland at youth level  had resigned himself to not making the breakthrough at
the club.

He will stay in Italy and bid to kickstart his career.

headline: Loss not worrying Fenn yet
content_plain:
NEALE FENN rued his side's missed chances as his life as Cork City boss got off
to a losing start at Turner's Cross.

Romeo Parkes and Ronan Coughlan both bagged braces for Sligo Rovers to hand the
visitors a 4-2 win.

Dan Casey had made it 1-1 and when Shane Griffin netted to put the score at 3-2,
the Leesiders were pushing hard for an equaliser only to be caught out. It is
not the result Fenn wanted after leaving his post at Longford Town to take over
at the club he played for  but he took plenty of positives from the
performance.

He said: "It was a weird game and Sligo were always dangerous when they
counter-attacked us but we had chances too and large possessions of the ball.

"We just didn't defend properly and that was our downfall.

"The lads reacted brilliantly to going 3-1 down after an hour and, at 3-2
behind, I thought we were going to be the team to get the next goal.

"Sligo caught us with a sucker punch for the fourth goal and we end up losing
the game.

"We had a lot of attempts on goal and that was a big positive from the previous
week up in Galway in the Cup.

"Sligo got in some big blocks and if they hadn't it might have been a different
story."

Rovers' last away win was back in May so boss Liam Buckley was a happy man at
full-time.

They opened up a fivepoint gap on Cork and Bucko said: "I am delighted with the
win on the road and it's opened up a gap on Cork now and that's what we wanted.

"We do have a game more played but hopefully we can maintain this distance
between us to the end of the season.

"It was a cracking game of football and both teams went for it from the
kick-off.

"But I felt we deserved the three points and some poor defending cost Cork at
crucial times in the game.

"It gives us a bit of breathing space now and that's important for us."

headline: Maciej's Students learning
content_plain:
MACIEJ TARNOGRODZKI believes his UCD players can only learn from the humbling
experience of being schooled by Dundalk twice in five days.

in The league leaders thumped the Students 5-0 at the UCD Bowl on Friday to add
to the 3-0 win over them at Oriel Park last Monday.

A sixth defeat on the spin in the league, in which they have conceded 30 goals,
leaves the Students six points adrift at the foot of the table.

And they have now also played a game more than second-bottom Finn Harps. With
six matches to go, they are staring automatic relegation in the face.

But Tarnogrodzki (left) wants his players to have the confidence to pass their
way to an escape route.

He said: "It's been a tough week and we're disappointed with the scoreline on
Friday.

In the second half we tried to play and kept the ball a little better. But when
you give the ball away a team like Dundalk will punish you.

"We need now to think about the games ahead.

"We'll learn from this week and we will get results in the games coming up. We
need to have belief."

headline: IN THE SLOW LANE
subheadline: Poch: It will take time to match Prem big spenders
content_plain:
MAURICIO POCHETTINO says Spurs' £600million stadium debt leaves them behind even
Arsenal on the Premier League grid.

Building the new ground has put the brakes on Tottenham's spending  just like
their North London rivals were shackled by the cost of the Emirates.

And boss Pochettino compared his club to a mid-ranking team in Formula One,
trying to keep up with mega-bucks rivals in England and in Europe.

Pochettino said: "Different clubs ask the bank for £600m to invest in the team.
Like Barcelona.

"They create a debt signing players and putting the debt on the pitch, trying to
win. We are different.

"We need to create the legacy for the future.

"In this period, we are suffering the restrictions but it's normal.

"The restrictions, OK, we need to work hard to find a way to compete in this
very tough league, in a different way to our rivals.

"Mercedes compete with Ferrari, McLaren, Red Bull ... we compete in the same
race and if you judge, it needs not only to be about the race but the whole
process."

Pochettino claims the comparison between his options at centre-forward and what
Arsenal can call on illustrates his point.

The departure of free agent Fernando Llorente has left Spurs looking a little
light up top.

Ireland hopeful Troy Parrott looks a sensational prospect but he is still just
17.

Pochettino added: "Arsenal in the last two years signed Pierre-Emerick
Aubameyang, the best striker in Germany, Alexandre Lacazette, the best striker
in France and one year after, Pepe. If you see look at fi us over five years, we
haven't signed one striker. Now our main striker is Harry Kane but our second
specific striker is 17 years old, Troy Parrott.

"That is the difference in the projects. I don't want to say one is wrong and
another is good.

"It's only that the way we operate is completely different."

Tottenham did break their transfer record to sign Lyon midfielder Tanguy
Ndombele in a £65m deal this summer, as well splashing out £25m on Fulham's
19-year-old winger Ryan Sessegnon.

But Poch insists the club do not have the money to transform themselves as
quickly as clubs like Liverpool, who beat them in the Champions League final in
June. The Spurs boss the said: "When Jurgen Klopp arrived in October 2015, more
than one year after me, when we drew 0-0 here, not one of their starting XI of
players is there in the starting XI today.

"And the substitutes are not there. If you compare with us, we have eight or
nine players still in the starting XI. Look at the difference."

Pochettino feels Spurs are victims of their own over-achievement, with the 1-0
home defeat to Newcastle last Sunday sparking talk of crisis  and even wild
rumours that he intended to quit after today's game.

Yet the Argentine HARRY PAIN ... Spurs star Kane was frustrated after the shock
defeat to Newcastle accepts his team's Premier League form  just four wins and
15 points from their last 15 games  must change.

He added: "The problem we had is we were so good in our results and
performances, that we didn't start in the way we'd expect or people would
expect.

"That led to, 'Big problem' and 'Pochettino is going to walk away' and this type
of situation that someone with no common sense created."

"In the Premier League over the last six months, I think it was not great. We
need to try to find the way to improve our results.

"Yes, of course it wasn't the best performance against Newcastle but there was
enough there to draw or win the game.

"But when the result is negative you lose all the reason and you cannot reverse
the opinion or perception.

"For me, I am not worried about our performance because we have a very good team
and I am optimistic and positive."

headline: UNAI: IT'S NOT ABOUT MEDIA
content_plain:
By JON WEST UNAI EMERY will be Arsenal's reluctant social-media star today
against Spurs.

The Gunners manager knows the cameras are sure to focus on him at the Emirates
during the first north London derby of the season.

And not only the ones broadcasting the clash live on Sky Sports  as for the
second time already this term Arsenal's own media team will be aiming their
lenses at their gaffer.

A clip of Emery getting rather excited about a tackle 20-year-old Joe Willock
made against Newcastle on opening day is fast approaching THREE MILLION views on
the club's Instagram.

The Spaniard (right) is unlikely to be any calmer on the touchline this
afternoon in the heat of a fierce derby but insists the only footage that
matters will be of his players.

Emery, 47, said: "The most important thing for the camera is the team.

"Maybe after the match the supporters can look at me and other things. I really,
really, really want the focus to be on the players until after the game."

Emery's animated antics are a far cry from the days of Arsene Wenger, who spent
his time fighting with the zip on his coat.

In contrast, Emery waves his arms about and often kicks imaginary balls. Emery,
who is in his second season as Arsenal's manager, added: "I have been like this
all my career. In Spain, in France and now here.

"It has been the same because I want to help and support the players. That's
all!

"Each moment is how I am feeling at that time. Sometimes I am sitting and
holding back before, then taking the best decision for the game."

The Newcastle game, which ended 1-0 to the Gunners, saw Emery field a youthful
starting line-up.

As well as midfielder Willock, the Spaniard gave the nod to Reiss Nelson, 19,
Ainsley Maitland-Niles, 22, and Matteo Guendouzi, 20.

Emery said: "We need young players. Our responsibility is to give them chances
to train, then play friendlies, then important matches."

headline: Referee is no Friend of mine
content_plain:
ASTON VILLA fans clashed with police after Henri Lansbury's late equaliser was
ruled out.

The sub looked to have snatched a point at Selhurst Park when he drove home in
stoppage time.

But referee Kevin Friend disallowed the goal and booked Jack Grealish for diving
in the build-up.

Stunned Grealish was stopped by his team-mates from confronting Friend while
police drew batons on some travelling fans as tempers flared. Cops confirmed one
fan was arrested for affray and an investigation has been launched into the
chaotic scenes.

Lansbury's goal was ruled out because Friend had already blown for diving
against Grealish inside the penalty box.

A possible penalty for Villa was checked by VAR official Andrew Madley but
Friend's original decision of a free-kick to Palace stood because there was no
obvious error.

All that led to Villa boss Dean Smith blasting Friend and VAR, while midfielder
John McGinn claimed his team had been "robbed".

Smith said: "It was a good goal. No one could understand why it wasn't given.
Mayhem ensued.

"I spoke in the week about VAR and subjective decisions but the system is meant
to right wrongs.

"I wondered what I'd be like when that system went against me."

Smith said he was hoping to speak to Friend  who also sent off Trezeguet 
before leaving London.

He added: "I didn't understand the officials' decision-making today. If you're
Jack Grealish, you'd be raging. He's had his integrity questioned."

Match report  Goals Page 7

headline: Parrott is next in line
content_plain:
M i i SPURS manager Mauricio Pochettino told Troy Parrott that he is the next
man up.

The highly-rated 17-year-old is with the Ireland Under-21s this week for their
Euro qualifiers with Armenia and Sweden.

Dubliner Parrott has yet to make his senior bow for Ireland and has not played a
competitive game for Spurs.

He featured heavily in Spurs' pre-season matches but he is still waiting for his
chance from boss Poch. However, the Argentine has warned him to be ready because
if anything happens to skipper Harry Kane, Parrott will be next in line.

Poch said: "If look at us over five years, we haven't signed one striker. Now
our main striker is Harry Kane but our second specific striker is 17-years-old,
Troy Parrott."

headline: MAGUIRE ON MISSING LIST
content_plain:
M Ire SEÁN MAGUIRE is set to miss Ireland's Euro 2020 qualifier with
Switzerland. The striker did not feature Preston North End's 1-1 with Nottingham
Forest.

str in Prest draw wit Boss that wa been stru ball at t has left blood He spec
day rec cou Th Thursday friendly Tuesday Alex Neil revealed was because he had
struck in the eye by a training. The impact him with rais' pressure there. is
due to see a specialist in the coming days but he has been recommended to take a
couple of weeks' rest. That will see him miss Thursday's big game and the
against Bulgaria on week. Mick McCarthy could replace Maguire (left) with Shane
Long, who made his first appearance of the season for Southampton off the bench
against Manchester United.

Meanwhile, young guns Michael Obafemi and Nathan Collins have been ruled out of
the Ireland Under-21 squad due to injury.

Ross County winger Simon Power and Southampton defender Kameron Ledwidge have
been called up to replace them by Stephen Kenny for the Euro qualifiers with
Armenia on Friday and Sweden four days later.

headline: Knee hell for Laporte
content_plain:
Manchester City ............... 4 Brighton...............................0
AYMERIC LAPORTE faces months out after being carried off with suspected knee
ligament damage.

The Manchester City defender, 25, was crocked after lunging into a rash
first-half challenge on Adam Webster.

Laporte  booked for the challenge  immediately signalled he needed help and
was treated for several minutes before going off.

Pep Guardiola hopes to discover the extent of the injury today but the look on
the City gaffer's face said it all.

He admitted: "He's gone to hospital and it doesn't look good. I don't know
exactly what he has  I think he will be out for a while but we will see."

Laporte's injury leaves City light at centre-back with John Stones also getting
over a thigh problem.

Midfielder Fernandinho will now be asked to drop back. Guardiola added: "He's
fast, he's intelligent, he's strong  he can play in both positions."

Match report  Goals P 1, 2, 3

headline: KLOPP OF THE PILE!
subheadline:
BURNLEY 0 LIVERPOOL 3 WOOD (OG) 33; MANE 37; FIRMINO 80 Jurgen's machine on
march
content_plain:
THE Liverpool winning machine just keeps roaring on.

Win after win after win ... This victory at Turf Moor was a club-record 13th
league win in a row, topping the mark set by Kenny Dalglish's side in 1990  the
year they last won the title.

You have to wonder what sort of new mark this team might set.

Good luck Newcastle, who are next up at Anfield after the international break.

Nowadays Liverpool just beat Burnley and Manchester City just beat Brighton.
Liverpool will no doubt beat Newcastle  that's just how it is.

And that is how it will continue to be for the foreseeable future at this rate.

They are that much better than the rest  and the Premier League table is
already showing it.

Liverpool must still wonder how on earth 97 points was not enough to end that
long title quest last season.

The small matter of City were in their way, the small margin of a point
separated them.

There were obvious questions at the beginning of the season whether or not
Liverpool could go again after that mammoth effort in the league and in Europe.

But those doubts have very quickly been answered  the appetite remains the
same.

It is four wins from four and a two-point lead over City.

As you would expect, Burnley had a good go.

Indeed, they had the first chance when after two minutes Chris Wood turned
inside Uefa Player of the Year Virgil van Dijk  not words you hear very often.

With space gained, his shot was then well placed towards the far bottom corner
but Adrian, looking for his first clean sheet in the Liverpool goal, dived full
length to palm it away.

Quickly, though, Liverpool set up camp in Burnley's half, with Mo Salah twice
going desperately close to scoring.

He rattled the post with a shot after five minutes then, after linking up with
Jordan Henderson, saw his shot hit keeper Nick Pope and rebound back off his own
knee before going wide.

The breakthrough came on 33 minutes when Trent Alexander- Arnold tried to curl
in a cross from outside the area.

The ball did not go to its intended far-post target.

Instead, it clipped the back of Clarets striker Wood in front of him and spun up
and over the stranded and unfortunate Pope.

Think Ronaldinho against England at the 2002 World Cup ... with a bit of help.

If that was unlucky the next goal four minutes later was downright careless on
the part of Burnley captain Ben Mee.

His terrible loose pass straight to Roberto Firmino gave away possession 15
yards inside the home half.

It was not even near to one of his team-mates and within seconds he paid the
price as Firmino sprinted away and fed Sadio Mane to his left, who then stroked
a shot into the far corner.

The third in the 80th minute saw Firmino became the first Brazilian in Premier
League history to reach 50 goals.

It came thanks to the industry of Salah, who made up for not setting his pal up
earlier when he was free.

Full of running, the Egyptian chased a ball down to the side of the Burnley box
and forced it across to Firmino just outside the area. His finish into the
bottom left-hand corner was clinical.

Job well and truly done for Jurgen Klopp's men.

Burnley ended up huffing and puffing but Liverpool looked like they could have
played again. They pass the ball through and around you. They hound you down,
nick the ball and race away.

If you make a mistake you pay the price. Give them an opening and they will find
it. They can mix it up, too. They can stand up to anything thrown at them.

So into the international break with the top of the Premier League table taking
on a very familiar look.

It is early days, and there is a long way to go, but already another
blow-for-blow epic between Liverpool and City is on the cards.

Already we wonder who might get the other two places in the top four.

Because if anything the gap between these two and the rest looks even wider than
last season.

headline: Charlie: Fenton is best ever
content_plain:
By GORDON MANNING DUBLIN legend Charlie Redmond believes Brian Fenton is the man
to steer Dublin's Drive For Five to victory lane.

Dead-ball king Redmond, an All-Ireland winner in 1995, reckons Fenton (below) is
the greatest midfielder to ever pull on the blue jersey.

And the former Dublin forward believes the Raheny man  whose dad is from Kerry
 will be key for the Dubs when they tackle the Kingdom to try to win an
unprecedented fifth successive All-Ireland SFC title.

Redmond said: "Brian Mullins was brilliant at midfield.

"And the team I had, we had a great pairing in Paul Bealin and Brian Stynes, but
this guy is better, I think, than all of them.

"I never thought I'd see a better player than Mullins and I never thought I'd
see a better pairing than Bealin and Stynes at midfield, but this guy, you could
put him into any team anywhere in the history of Dublin football."

headline: TOP REELING
subheadline: Cluxton's still changing the way football is played
content_plain:
ONE night at Dublin training in 2002, the late, great Dave Billings said
something daft.

Blues goalkeeper Davy Byrne had just retired from intercounty football and a
20-yearold Stephen Cluxton was parachuted in as their new No 1. Billings  who
passed away four years ago  was a selector under Tommy Lyons at the time.

And he looked on as their freshfaced stopper was practising his kickouts in a
most peculiar way.

Cluxton wanted a target, so he decided to place the ball on the 45-metre line
and aim for goal.

Keen to work on his catching, defender Paddy Christie stood behind the posts and
leapt at the balls the Parnells youngster was pinging over the crossbar.

In passing, Billings suggested 'Clucko' should hit the Dublin 45s.

Christie said he was mad and thought no more of it.

Little did they know, they were watching the man who would transform the game
forever.

The schoolteacher has since taught us how the role of the goalkeeper can have
such a bigger impact than was ever envisaged.

Nine years on from that training session, Dublin faced Kerry in the All-Ireland
final. In the dying moments they won a free just inside the 45m line facing Hill
16.

Bernard Brogan did not fancy it and up came the keeper.

He planted it over the bar to seal a 1-12 to 1-11 win as the Dubs ended a
16-year famine.

Now they are chasing their fifth All-Ireland title in a row today against the
Kingdom  and captain Clucko's kickouts have been the launch-pad for all of that
success.

Daft? Not a bit of it. Christie told SunSport: "Dave Billings, God rest him, was
a selector with Tommy Lyons.

"Clucko was practicing kickouts and he used to kick 45s because it gave him a
target to hit rather than hitting into an empty space.

VISIONARY great "I always wanted to work on catching high ball at the edge of
the square so I used to stand behind the goal a lot of the time to catch the
balls that Cluxton was kicking in.

"One day when Cluxton was kicking the 45s over the bar, Billings said 'It might
not be a bad idea to bring him up for 45s'.

"That was in 2002 and before he started doing these short kickouts. I didn't pay
any heed to Billo at the time because it was a crazy idea and it just wasn't
done.

"I took one against Donegal and one against Armagh in the semi-final that year,
and even that was considered a bit iffy because I wasn't a forward. The refs
weren't happy about it either because it was considered time-wasting.

"Then in 2011, he goes and does it with that final kick and the rest is history.
I often wondered had I listened to Dave and tried to push it a bit, would it
have made a difference.

"But it was just considered ... the late, Dave Billings crazy because nobody did
that. It was a visionary from Dave and eventually Pat Gilroy went for it."

Christie made his SFC debut for the Dubs in 1997 and was a fans' favourite by
the time Cluxton arrived into the squad in 2001.

The Ballymun defender was always first at training and football was the dominant
force in his life.

But his own dedication was soon eclipsed by the young stopper who is still
raising standards 18 years later.

All those hours on the training field are why Cluxton has six All-Ireland medals
and will go down as the greatest keeper of them all.

Christie said: "He was phenomenal. For a fella of his age at the time, his
professionalism and the way he went about things and his attitude to training
was hard to beat.

"I would have always prided myself personally on giving a lot to training and
matches and being well-prepared, because football was No 1 in my life.

"I was always down as one of the first to turn up for training.

"But often I wasn't the first because it was Stephen.

"He was so young, and for this guy to be at the forefront at training and show
that sort of dedication was very impressive.

"He's got such nerve, and for a fella who isn't that big he's got a serious
strike. That's all to do with his technique and the amount of practice he puts
in from turning up so early for training every night."

Christie retired from inter-county football in 2007 and is one of those Hill 16
heroes who never got his hands on Sam.

Dublin were a hard-luck story in those years and were always the bridesmaid as
Kerry, Galway, Meath Armagh and Tyrone bagged titles.

Now game-changer Cluxton is the only member of Gavin's squad left from when
Christie was in the dressing room.

They are chasing history today against the Kingdom and could go where no team
has gone before.

And the 2002 All-Star winner stressed that Cluxton's beauty back in 2011 was the
spark that lit the flame.

He said: "They are going for five in a row now but that 2011 final was a big
turning point because it looked like they were going to lose.

"If Cluxton hadn't kicked that over, Kerry always had the Indian sign over us
and they probably would have maybe won that day, or even won a replay.

"But that win changed everything, and without him it wouldn't have happened.

"I always take pleasure in watching what he has achieved over the years.

"He's a phenomenon, and he deserves everything he gets."

GORDON MANNING KERRY'S hope is that Dublin's full-back line can be got at. But
that's all it is, hope.

We have already seen this year that the Kingdom's defence can be got at.

Kerry need a huge display from David Moran and David Clifford.

They need Dublin to have an off day for 70-odd minutes. But that hasn't happened
in five years now.

All Kerry really have is a hope that it might today.

VERDICT: Dublin JASON BYRNE JIM GAVIN'S Dublin have huge pressure on them to
deliver but there is nothing to suggest they will bottle this now.

Kerry's David Clifford was born to play on days like these but he'll have to
wait for his first senior medal.

Dublin have drowned out all of the noise that goes with chasing history  now it
is time to seal the five in a row.

VERDICT: Dublin PAUL KEANE YOU mightn't have noticed but none of the Dublin subs
that came on against Mayo in the semi-final managed to score.

It was only the second time that happened in Jim Gavin's 46 Championship games
in charge  and a repeat is unlikely.

The Dubs have always used supersubs as their battering ram to famous wins.
History will finally be made today and Dublin's awesome bench will finish the
job for them.

VERDICT: Dublin COLLIE MORAN PETER KEANE'S Kerry will need at least two goals,
and probably three, to beat Dublin.

But they have only averaged one goal per game in this year's Championship.

There is a risk for the Kingdom that the Dubs could put up a high score at the
other end.

If Jim Gavin's side get a run on Kerry's young players then Croke Park could be
a very lonely place to be. Dublin by eight points or more.

VERDICT: Dublin GRAHAM GERAGHTY DUBLIN are so close to the five in a row they
can touch it.

Now it's just a case of how much are they going to win by because I don't give
Kerry a chance at all.

It will be five in a row and possibly a lot more. I can't see who can stop them
in 2020 either.

Kerry will try and play football but that will open things up and fall into
Dublin's favour.

VERDICT: Dublin DAMIAN LAWLOR THE GAA romantic in me is screaming that there is
an upset on the cards here, that Kerry could force a last-minute draw, maybe
even an unlikely win.

But the road-weary scribe in me simply cannot dismiss the quality, tempo,
patience, versatility, reserves and downright brilliance that Dublin can summon.

They won't have it all their own way but they will find a way.

VERDICT: Dublin The drive for five "I JUST can't see Dublin being beaten. I
don't see it as being a cakewalk or a walk in the park, I just think they have
too much in their armoury.

"The main reasons being I think the Dublin forward line ... people are saying
Kerry's attack are just as strong, but I'm not sure just yet.

"There are fellas on the Dublin bench who would be central players on most other
inter-county teams and they'll just have too much."

Playing with Jim Gavin "BACK in the late 90s we were after playing a match and
he took a banana out of his gear bag. He was ridiculed. The lads were laughing
at him because they were going for a piss-up.

"He was always very organised and dedicated as a player.

Being honest about it, he wasn't one of the better footballers in the group but
he took what he had and used it.

"He was small, wasn't the best in the air and he had a lot of different things
going against him but made a niche for himself as a defensive wing-forward and
worked extremely hard."

Diarmuid Connolly "DIARMUID will only feature today if there's an emergency. It
would be hard on the other forwards on the bench and Jim thinks of the future
all the time.

"That's why they are what they are. If Jim was a short-term guy, they wouldn't
be going for five All-Irelands in a row.

"It's attractive to bring someone of that quality on but in the long-term it
could do damage and make lads unhappy, so it could be a last resort. But if they
were two points behind with 10 minutes to go, it would be crazy not to bring
him."

This Kerry team "DEFENSIVELY Kerry will need to tighten up a lot, because Cathal
McShane did a lot of damage against them in the semi-final against Tyrone.

"If Con O'Callaghan gets that same sort of room and freedom in the final, I
can't see them getting near Dublin.

"They need to over-perform and Dublin to under-perform for them to win."

TURNING POINT ... Cluxton's famous point in the 2011 final was launchpad for
Dublin

headline: EASTERN PROMISE
content_plain:
WILL ADDISON WITH versatility a morethan-useful asset to have when a coach is
selecting a squad, the Ulster man showed that he is an option at full-back as
well as centre and wing.

It was his good aerial take which led to the opening try. Returned to the fray
after a HIA.

JACK CARTY THE official man-of-thematch award might have been overly-generous
given to him.

But the Connacht man surely did enough to get the nod ahead of Ross Byrne to
travel to Japan as third-choice outhalf behind Johnny Sexton and Joey Carbery.

DAVE KILCOYNE AFTER last week, there was an understandable emphasis on getting
the set-piece right  but the Munster man did not just show up in the scrum.

He put in a massive effort on both sides of the ball to remove any doubt there
was about his place in the squad.

ANDREW PORTER HE might have been dismayed to see John Ryan get the start here.

But showing that he can do a good job on either side of the scrum should tilt
things in his favour when it comes to Joe Schmidt choosing who is the fifth prop
to travel.

headline: NIPPON THE BUD
content_plain:
TADHG BEIRNE THE versatile forward carved out quite the reputation for himself
in Wales before returning to join Munster in a bid to force his way into the
international reckoning.

His ability to play in the second and back row is a trump card but quiet here.

JACK McGRATH HE was watching on in the stands as cover in case there was a late
injury.

And he must have felt his chances of making the plane slip further away as Dave
Kilcoyne turned in a fine display in front of him. May need an injury for him to
earn a reprieve.

headline: WILL POWER
byline: By NEIL O'RIORDAN at PRINCIPALITY STADIUM By NEIL
content_plain:
W l d it IN the final 16 minutes here, Wales scored 14 points without reply.

They may not be as numerous but there are still plenty of unanswered questions
for Joe Schmidt.

This was better from Ireland compared to the display against England but, then,
it came against a muchinferior side, with Warren Gatland having made 14 changes
for his last home game as Wales coach.

So figuring out what weighting to attach to each display, previous performances,
form in training, physical condition, versatility and overall balance of the
squad are all things which Schmidt must factor in when trying to decide which 31
players to bring to Japan.

He has done this once before but he is not sure he got it right and so is wary
of jumping to conclusions on the basis of what he saw here.

Schmidt said: "Will Addison did some things really well.

"He got a cut which was superficial and then got a little bit of cramp.

"Because he hadn't played in so long, we decided to take him off so he didn't
develop any injury as a result of his calf cramping up. He's got such a balanced
running style, he gets a good look at the pitch when he's running back to
full-back.

"He's accomplished at kicking and he's accomplished at kicking at goal.

"He's a bit underdone, he hasn't got as much rugby as we would like because he
hasn't played much this year, he missed the Six Nations.

"But his versatility is a huge asset in general.

"He can play on the wing because he's got high speed, he obviously stepped in
very late to play 13 against Argentina last year.

"So he can cover the full spectrum of the back three and 13.

"That's an asset when you're trying to narrow the squad down.

"So we're looking at him and trying to compare him to the other guys to see how
they best fit the mould and I'll tell you now, I'm not sure.

"Whatever you do, there's always a risk you don't get it quite right.

"I don't think we quite got it right last time. Some times in retrospect is the
only time you know, 'Did I get that right or not?' "Going forward, you're
predicting as best you can, trying to ensure they're in the best physical
condition and ready to go.

"But you don't really know until you get out there and are in the thick of it
really."

Still, at the very least it can be said that Ulster man Addison did his chances
no harm.

Likewise for Jack Carty at out-half, even if his task was considerably easier
than that which rival Ross Byrne had against England.

The smart money would be on Connacht man Carty getting the nod behind Johnny
Sexton  who should start against Wales next Saturday  and Joey Carbery, who
may be on the bench and should be fully ready for the opener against Scotland.

Schmidt said: "He's done well but it's apples, oranges and lemons.

"We've got different options at 10, one who hasn't played yet at all but we know
he'll play next week and another who I thought had 50 superb minutes against
Italy.

"He's currently injured but he might be back on the bench next week, or he'll
certainly be back against Scotland. Jack has done well. I think Ross was unlucky
because he had tired legs and front-foot ball and the space that Jack got but
Jack made the most of it."

Carty, starting a Test match for the first time, settled his nerves with a
ninth-minute penalty.

Jarrod Evans levelled matters after an infringement by Ireland captain Peter
O'Mahony but, thereafter, the visitors took control.

After a good take in the air by Addison, and a strong carry by David Kilcoyne,
Carty offloaded to Andrew Conway, who made use of Chris Farrell's support as a
decoy before picking out Jacob Stockdale to touch down in the corner.

Stockdale grabbed a second when he pounced on Aaron Shingler's loose pass,
kicking the ball ahead of Owen Lane before collecting it ahead of Hallam Amos.

Carty converted the first but not the second with Stockdale withdrawn at the
interval after a confidencebuilding 40 minutes.

Next, it was the turn of Ireland's pack to get a lift.

Five scrum penalties in a row saw Leon Brown yellow-carded and, later, a penalty
try awarded to stretch their advantage to 19 points.

In particular, Dave Kilcoyne and replacement Andrew Porter will feel that their
performances should help ensure they will not be the recipients of bad news.

There were further chances but two other scores were disallowed as Carty's pass
to Conway was forward and Bundee Aki was penalised for tackling in the air in
the build-up to Garry Ringrose touching down.

And Wales' late pressure was rewarded with two converted tries from Owen Lane
and Rhys Patchell to ensure there were only five points between the sides at the
end.

Schmidt said: "We know that we created lot of angst outside our environment with
how we played against England.

"We knew how hard we would be worked, we knew we were vulnerable, but it was
still unacceptable to fall off the number of tackles and be as far behind in the
game as we were.

"We've restored a bit of self-confidence as much as anything." And pride,
according to O'Mahony, one of just four survivors in the starting XV.

The Munster flanker said: "From the players' point of view, it's been a long
week.

"Guys were itching to get out there and we left the jersey in a better place
than certainly last week."

WALES: Amos, Lane, Williams, Watkin, S Evans (Homes 48), J Evans (Patchell 41),
A Davies (T Williams 48); Carre (R Evans 41), Elias (Dee 63), Lee (Brown 41),
Beard, B Davies (Ball 48), Shingler (Wainwright 63), J Davies (Lee 52-62),
Navidi. IRELAND: Addison (Ringrose 43-52), Conway, Farrell, Aki, Stockdale (D
Kearne 41), Carty, Marmion (L McGrath 60); Kilcoyne (Porter 45), Scannell (Best
52), John Ryan (Furlong 52), Henderson, James Ryan (Toner 52), Beirne, O'Mahony
(Murphy 60), Conan.

SCORERS  Wales: try, Lane, Patchell; con, Patchell 2; pen, J Evans. Ireland:
tries, Stockdale 2, penalty try; con, Carty; pen, Carty.

headline: Hutchin' at straws
content_plain:
Georgia.............10 Scotland..........44 RORY HUTCHINSON scored two tries to
force himself into World Cup contention as Scotland ran riot.

With coach Gregor Townsend set to reveal his squad on Tuesday, the centre made
the most of his first Test start.

Hutchinson went over on 19 minutes after Finn Russell opened up the Georgia

Then he underlined his pace and power by scything through for his second after

headline: Cole hot to make it happen
content_plain:
By ADAM HATHAWAY DAN COLE knows he has one final shot at World Cup glory in
Japan after England fired blanks in the last two tournaments.

Prop Cole was part of the 2011 fiasco in New Zealand that ended in a
quarter-final exit to France after a campaign dogged by dwarf throwing and
nights on the sauce.

And in 2015 he was in the side that became the only host team ever to fail to
make the knockout stages after defeats by Wales and Australia.

Cole, who turned 32 in May, will not make the finals in France in 2023 but
reckons this England side are a step up from the last two.

The Leicester forward said: "I am 32 now. I doubt I will get there at 36. It
would be nice but I do not think it will happen. When you are young you do not
worry too much because you will get another one.

"But as one of the senior guys I have to make sure that everyone pushes because
there is no tomorrow in some regard.

"This is the best squad I have been with in terms of tightness.

"In the last World Cup it was too individual, but now everyone is pushing each
other and working hard. There is a togetherness.

"The squad was announced early, which gives you some confidence, but there is
still a lot of work to do ahead of Japan."

Head coach Eddie Jones has gambled by picking only two tighthead props  Cole
and Kyle Sinckler  in his 31-man squad.

Cole added: "We have a four-day turnaround and then a longer one. You want to
play, not make up the numbers."

headline: WHY YOU REALLY NEED TO GIVE THIS A WORKOUT
subheadline:
A strong pelvic floor boosts your sex life, stops you farting in public and
helps with giving birth, so why are we neglecting some of the most important
muscles in our body?
content_plain:
Have you ever sneezed and felt some pee come out? How about when doing a star
jump? Let's not mention the time you took the kids to the trampoline park. The
unspoken truth is that many women of all ages are secretly dealing with leaks
caused by a weak pelvic floor.

"Stats show urinary incontinence affects one in three women, but I suspect the
numbers are much higher," says Jane Simpson, a continence specialist and author
of The Pelvic Floor Bible. "People have busy lives so they just find ways around
it, like wearing a pad when working out, but we shouldn't accept that."

The pelvic floor is a group of muscles that work like a sling, keeping your
lower organs in place. It's crucial for helping you control bodily functions
such as going to the loo, and even helps with orgasms, which involve a rapid
contraction of the superficial pelvic floor muscles.

"Plenty of factors can weaken the pelvic floor muscles, including pregnancy,
childbirth, menopause and high-impact sport," explains Jane. The good news is
that these muscles can be strengthened with exercises at home in just five
minutes or less a day. Sounds like our kind of workout!

TEST YOUR STRENGTH 

A simple way to see if you've got control of your pelvic floor muscles is to try
to stop the flow of urine midstream. "This is recommended as a test, not an
exercise, as it's bad for your bladder to keep stopping and starting," warns
Jane. "If you succeed, your muscles are engaging, although they may still need
strengthening. Alternatively, insert a finger and see if you can squeeze it, or
try tensing around your partner's penis during sex.

If you feel a dragging sensation or heaviness, you may have a prolapse, where
the pelvic floor isn't supporting your organs well enough."

START EARLY 

Leaks are no fun and having a prolapse can be tough, so prevention is key.
"Younger women are increasingly doing high-intensity exercises such as HIIT,
which put huge stress on the pelvic floor," says Jane. "More women are also
having their first baby when they're older, which studies show increases their
likelihood of major pelvic floor injuries during birth." Research has found that
pelvic floor exercises before conceiving or in the early stages of pregnancy
helps prevent bladder weakness in the future.* You'll definitely thank yourself
later.

FIVE-MINUTE WORKOUT 

Most of us exercise the rest of our body regularly (well, ish) and clean our
teeth every day, but because our pelvic floor is out of sight, we tend to ignore
it - even when it's behaving badly. "Like any muscle, the key to keeping it
working well is to repeatedly contract and release it through exercise," says
Rosie Stockley, personal trainer and founder of Mamawell, which specialises in
pre- and post-natal fitness. She suggests trying this daily five-minute quick
fix: 1 Sit on a chair with your feet on the floor or lie on your back with your
knees bent.

2 Take three deep breaths to relax - you don't want to be holding in your tummy.

3 Pretend you're trying to stop a wee, while at the same time trying not to
fart. Make sure you're not squeezing your buttocks.

4 Hold for 10 seconds while breathing normally. 5 Let everything go and take a
deep breath before tensing again.

6 Repeat 10 times. If you've recently had a baby, try this at least twice a day.

'APPY SQUEEZING 

Finding it hard to remember to do those exercises? There's an app for that.
"Giving my younger clients a piece of paper with exercises on rarely works, but
tech has been shown to be helpful in forming regular habits," says Jane. Squeezy
(£2.99) is recommended by the NHS and is designed by women's health specialists.
It has guided pelvic floor exercises with regular reminders to do them, and it
even bleeps during the routines so you know you're doing them for long enough.
You can also customise your workout and track your progress.

PT FOR YOUR PF 

At £169 it may be spenny, but if you want a high-tech personal coach for your
lady regions try the Elvie Trainer. This kit has a silicone wand that you insert
with the tail remaining outside (like a tampon), before it connects via
Bluetooth to an app on your phone that will guide you through a series of
five-minute exercises. It can also track your symptoms and progress. There are
four levels to try and you can set goals and schedule reminders. "Always read
the manufacturer's instructions or ask your GP first," advises Rosie. "You can't
use it if pregnant or if you've had cancerous cells in the cervix."

GAME OF CONES 

Vaginal cones are small weights made from silicone or plastic-coated metal that
can be used to help train your pelvic floor muscles. "They're not good if you've
got a prolapse, so speak to your GP or a women's health specialist," warns Jane.
Kegal8 vaginal cones, £34.99, are a similar shape to a tampon, and once you've
inserted one, you contract your pelvic floor muscles to stop it from slipping
out. They come in different weights (usually 5-20g) and you can increase the
weight as your muscles strengthen over time. Always follow instructions
carefully.

BUILD IT UP 

Getting back into exercise is daunting, but if you've just had a baby there's an
extra obstacle to worry about. "No matter how sporty you were before, always
focus on your pelvic floor first," says Rosie, who recommends building exercise
up slowly. Start with running for one minute then briskly walking for one
minute. In that time, consider whether your pelvic floor feels heavy. If not,
run for one more minute. If you experience leaking or heaviness, stop and use
the time to exercise your pelvic floor again. Try to do one minute of pelvic
floor exercises before you start in order to get those muscles working. When
doing high-intensity exercise, don't contract your pelvic floor constantly as
it'll put the muscles under too much strain.

SEE A PHYSIO 

"If after three to six months of daily exercise you can't feel any difference,
see a women's health physiotherapist," says Jane. "They can offer treatments
such as biostimulation using electrodes in the vagina, and advise on advanced
exercises." Ask your GP about referring you to an NHS physio. F TA M P O N TRICK
An exercise hack if you're a tampon user is to insert one and pull gently on the
string whilst at the same time trying to contract your muscles to stop it coming
out - a bit like a tug of war.

KEEP REGULAR Around 50% of people with chronic constipation suffer pelvic floor
problems. You can keep things moving by upping your fibre (by eating foods such
as wholegrains), drinking plenty of fluids and doing regular exercise.

'Prevent prolapse with pelvic exercises'

headline: CELEBRITY BEAUTY
subheadline:
Want to be as cameraready as these stars? Their beauty champions will have you
ready for your close-up in no time
content_plain:
TAKE A WILLOUGHBROW Follow Holly Willoughby's lead and snap up the Lily Lolo
Brow Duo Pencil, £8, to fill in sparse spots on your brows. The TV presenter and
style icon is particularly fond of the double-ended pencil, which comes with a
highlighting shade to brighten the brow bone. If you want to keep your arches
looking natural like Holly's, she suggests picking a shade that's slightly
lighter than your brow hairs.

THE HEIDI GRAIL Still not found a gold-standard moisturiser? Take a leaf out of
Heidi Klum's book and try Mario Badescu Buttermilk Moisturizer, £15.50. The
supermodel has been using it for years and says that unlike some rich creams it
doesn't clog pores. That'll be thanks to the lactic acid, which gently
exfoliates skin, as well as anti-inflammatory allantoin, which helps soothe
sensitivity.

CHRISSY NOSE BEST In true Chrissy Teigen form, the model, TV presenter, celeb
chef and all-round social media star took to Instagram to share her love for
Bioré Ultra Deep Cleansing Pore Strips, £8.99 for six. Tea tree oil, menthol and
witch hazel get to work to clear congested pores and banish blackheads. The
queen of real talk even admits to examining the strips after, too. Gross, but so
relatable.

CARA'S SMOOTH OPERATOR Minimise the appearance of scars, fine lines and wrinkles
with Cara Delevingne's go-to skin smoothing hero, Trilogy Certified Organic
Rosehip Oil, £19.50. The actress and supermodel uses it twice a day on her face,
but the wonder oil, which is packed with essential fatty acids including omegas
3, 6 and 9, can be used all over the body and even helps repair damaged hair.
And because of its super-fine, non-comedogenic formula, it's great for all skin
types, whether you're trying to combat dryness, stretch marks or acne.

BRONZE 'CHELLE Not ready to ditch the contour just yet? When actress Michelle
Keegan says she can't see herself moving on from the trend any time soon, you
know you can relax. Sweep Benefit Hoola Bronzer, £26, under your cheekbones, jaw
and in the socket of your eyes to add dimension to your features. The Our Girl
star has been using the cult classic since she worked on a Benefit counter way
before she made it on to our screens.

DREW'S GO-TO 'POO It's not all salon visits and blow-dries for this Charlie's
Angel. Self-confessed dry shampoo enthusiast Drew Barrymore loves Batiste Dry
Shampoo, £2.99, claiming it's "better than any I have ever tried", and that it
"actually does what it promises to do", from adding texture to absorbing excess
oil. She even keeps a mini can in her bag for on-the-go top-ups - our kinda
girl!

BALM IT LIKE BECKHAM Suffer from dry, patchy skin? Do as Victoria Beckham does
and keep a tube of Weleda Skin Food, £7.95, in your handbag. The designer is
obsessed with the thick, buttery formula and claims to use it over her entire
body. Other fans of the 100% natural balm include Adele, Rosie
Huntington-Whiteley and Alexa Chung - as if you needed any more convincing.

EM'S MAGIC MARKER We love a good multitasker, and it seems Harry Potter star
Emma Watson does, too. She revealed she reaches for The Body Shop Lip & Cheek
Stain in Red Pomegranate, £8, every day to add a bit of colour to her face and
stop her looking washed out without masking her freckles. It's enriched with
soothing aloe vera and glycerine to help prevent chapped lips and give cheeks a
subtle rosy glow. According to the actress: "You can kiss someone while you're
wearing it and it's not going to come off." Who are we to argue? F

headline: EUROPE'S MOST WANTED
subheadline:
Avoid tourist traps and crammed beaches in these idyllic under-theradar
locations
content_plain:
KEFALONIA, GREECE Deputy Editor Ellie O'Mahoney and husband Mark kicked back on
the Greek island of Kefalonia.

THE PAD 

Some villas look amazing on the website and then are a let-down in real life -
but not Villa Kamini. The hillside vantage point means that from the pool you
have an incredible view of the pristine blue waters of the Ionian sea, as well
as the picture-perfect town of Assos with its fortress just 10 minutes' drive
away. Although only built in the last 10 years, the three-bedroom villa has
classic exposed beams and stone walls, plus the prettiest alfresco dining area.
The drive there winds along the coastal road and the views are as awe-inspiring
as they are distracting! 

EXPLORE 

Visit the jaw-dropping Melissani Lake, hidden inside a beautiful cave. Board the
manned rowing boat to marvel at stalactites and stalagmites and the water's
brilliant turquoise colour. The best time to go is in the middle of the day,
with the sun overhead creating a magical blue light effect. Entry costs £6.50
for adults. Don't forget to check out Antisamos Bay, where Captain Corelli's
Mandolin was filmed. The cove is stunning, but what will keep you there all day
is Acron beach bar, which offers free sunloungers and parasols. Lie back and sip
on an espresso martini or three (Acronantisamos.com). 

REFUEL 

The wonderful Odysseas Taverna on Agia Jerusalem beach couldn't be closer to the
sea. Have lunch under the vines before spending the afternoon searching for
shells. The freshly fried fish, £21.30, serves two and tastes as if it's swum
straight on to your plate, while the olive bread is totally moreish. Don't leave
before buying some of the plum jam, £7.40, to take home. Drive down the coast to
Alaties beach for a swim in the tiny pebbly cove, before ordering sundowners
from the hammocks at Acqua. DON'T MISS Enjoy a massage in the villa's garden to
the sound of crickets, £28 for 45 minutes (4spaservices@gmail.com). Bliss.

BOOK IT 

From May 2020, seven nights self-catering at Villa Kamini costs from £752 per
person including return flights and car hire. Book before January 31, 2020, to
receive 5% off. Call GIC The Villa Collection on 020 8232 9780
(Gicthevillacollection.com).

FORMENTERA, SPAIN Art Editor Nikki Ackerman and boyfriend Tom got their dose of
vitamin sea on the Spanish isle.

THE PAD Formentera's first-ever five-star digs, Five Flowers Hotel & Spa, is
located in buzzing Es Pujols on the north of the island. Expect an explosion of
colour with its flower-power themed decor and sleek, modern rooms. The serene
pool area has a luxury feel, with comfy day beds ideal for couples. For a change
of scene there's also a rooftop pool and sky bar made for watching the sunset,
plus a peaceful underground spa complete with sauna, steam room and huge
Jacuzzi. Family-friendly Hotel Blanco is also just next door, with boho-style
interiors and rooms with private outdoor tubs.

EXPLORE 

Known as the Caribbean of the Med, Formentera has some of the best beaches in
the Balearics, with the clearest turquoise seas and powdery white sand. Ses
Illetes is the most popular on the island and only 15 minutes cycle away from
Five Flowers - get there early for that perfect Insta shot! Alternatively, hop
on a scooter and head 15 minutes south to Migjorn, a long stretch of beautiful
wide beaches, dotted with laid-back bars and snack shacks such as Kiosko 62,
where you can grab an ice-cold sangria for £5. Bikes cost from £9 per day and
scooters from £28 (Motorentpujols.com).

REFUEL 

Start the day with tropical fruit spreads, mouth-wateringly good local meat and
cheese platters and fresh pastries at the hotel buffet. For lunch, you won't
need to leave your sunbed - order the croquettes with calamari and shrimps, £11,
alongside patatas bravas, £8. Dinner at Kokoy on the roof terrace is a treat,
with a Michelin-starred chef producing the finest Japanese-Mediterranean fusion
delights. The 11-plate tasting menu includes delicious lobster, scallops and
Wagyu beef. It's pricey at £82 a head, but worth every penny. Carmen restaurant
at Hotel Blanco is equally as impressive, serving up the tastiest octopus, £17,
and sirloin steak, £27. 

DON'T MISS Es Pujols night market lights up the beach promenade, with dozens of
stalls selling handmade jewellery, clothing and ceramics from local artists for
the perfect holiday memento.

BOOK IT 

Double rooms at Five Flowers Hotel & Spa cost from £113 (Fiveflowershotel.com)
and £90 at Hotel Blanco (Blancohotelformentera.com). Flights from London to
Ibiza cost from £13 each way (Ryanair.com), and ferries from Ibiza to Formentera
cost from £40 return (Trasmapi.com).

UMBRIA, ITALY Writer Emma Ledger and boyfriend Alex soaked up the Italian good
life.

THE PAD 

The region of Umbria gets stick for being the poor man's Tuscany, but anyone who
says that hasn't visited Tenuta di Murlo - a sprawling private estate of rolling
green hills dotted with villas, cottages and deluxe rooms that sleep from two to
18 people. Just 20 minutes from Perugia airport, you'll feel your shoulders
physically drop on arrival, with nothing but the sun-soaked silence of thousands
of hectares of vineyards, olive groves and woodland. You can do yoga, horse
riding and fishing or just chill by your private pool, but what really sets this
place apart is its dedicated staff. 

EXPLORE 

You could quite happily spend a week exploring Tenuta di Murlo's estate, but if
you fancy a day trip, the hilltop town Assisi is only 15 minutes' drive away.
Best known as the birthplace of St Francis, one of Italy's patron saints, it's
full of history and offers incredible panoramic views. The Basilica of St
Francis is a beautiful, two-level church. Entry is free, but remember to cover
your shoulders and knees.

REFUEL 

People travel for miles to visit the estate's restaurant Il Caldaro
(Ilcaldaro.it). The kitchen prepares phenomenal breakfast, lunch and evening
meals, all served in the expansive gardens brimming with lavender. Brekkie
showcases the estate's fruit and honey and home-made cakes. For dinner try the
grilled lamb, £12, and the goose ragu, £11, is unbelievable. 

DON'T MISS 

In Assisi, don't leave without visiting Buca di San Francesco, a stone-walled
restaurant with a pretty garden serving local specialities, such as the freshest
tomato bruschetta, £6, and truffle pasta, £10 (Bucadisanfrancesco.it).

BOOK IT 

Flights from London to Perugia San Francesco d'Assisi cost from £40 return
(Ryanair.com). A deluxe room at Tenuta di Murlo costs from £105 per night B&B
(Murlo.com). Hire a car from Perugia airport from £63 per week (Rentalcars.com).
F

headline: SEARCH FOR THE HERO
subheadline:
ADVERTISEMENT FEATURE Pick up some movie magic along with your shopping at
Sainsbury's and inspire the kids with these exclusive free Heroes collectable
cards
content_plain:
The holidays are almost over, but along with stocking up on school uniform,
packed lunches and new pencil cases, when you do your weekly shop at Sainsbury's
you can now add a touch of fun and inspo for the kids. Sainsbury's has teamed up
with Disney to create a unique Heroes collectable cards series. For the first
time, Disney, Pixar, Star Wars and Marvel feature together in a card collection
kids will love, as it celebrates the greatest characters from all their fave
films.

Until October 2, you'll receive free card packs for every £10 you spend in store
or online at Sainsbury's. Each card is dedicated to a different hero, from
Frozen's protective princess Elsa to super-speedy kid Dash from The Incredibles.
Not only can kids use the cards to play fun and creative games or trade with
their friends, but each card also highlights the best things about the
character, such as their determination, energy or kindness, with ratings for
bravery, loyalty and strength. We all know how important great role models are
for children, and Heroes encourages them to discover, challenge and unleash
their own special powers. Having fun, with a little life lesson on the side? Oh,
yes!

Here's how it works. There are 144 cards in total, divided into six themes: Eat
Well, Get Active, Express Yourself, Be Smart, Do Good and Team Up, and each
theme includes characters from Disney, Pixar, Star Wars and Marvel movies.
Snappy and colourful, the cards sneak a little positive inspiration into your
child's day, encouraging them to unlock their own inner hero. So if at teatime
veggies are a struggle, whip out an Eat Well card to get them tucking into their
greens. As Marvel's The Hulk reminds us, you need the right food if you want to
keep those muscles working!

The Get Active cards include Rey from Star Wars, with her lightning-quick moves,
or when a little encouragement is needed turn to the Express Yourself cards,
which feature Woody, the cowboy who's always ready with a plan in Disney and
Pixar's Toy Story 4. In the Be Smart cards, you'll find brave Belle from
Disney's Beauty And The Beast, who loves reading, and Disney's Snow White is
among the Do Good cards. Her positivity might be handy at bedtime, when everyone
is Sleepy but they're behaving like Grumpy. And if your little ones are shy
about making friends, The Avengers from Marvel are a reminder of how good it is
to Team Up.

The Heroes album to accompany the cards costs £2.50, available exclusively at
Sainsbury's. It's filled with interesting facts, games and challenges, tips
about eating well and getting active, and showing kids what special cards to
look out for.

Some of the cards sparkle, glow in the dark or have a secret picture beneath a
rub-away surface.

You never know, parents might be inspired by Heroes, too. After all, there are
times when you have to work together to get the family out of the house in the
morning. Yes, you're just like Chewbacca and Han Solo teaming up to take on the
Death Star. One tip, though: don't dwell too long on which of you is the big
hairy one START COLLECTING NOW Until October 2, 2019, you'll receive a free
pack of four cards for every £10 you spend in store or online at Sainsbury's.
The Heroes album is available at Sainsbury's for £2.50, which includes two free
packs of cards, and booster packs cost 50p.

'The cards help kids to unlock their inner hero'

ARIES 

MAR 21 - APR 20 

As your workplace bonds strengthen, you take a place in a team - even if it
doesn't seem like the place you want to be. New sides of you begin to emerge and
secret skills are uncovered. In love? A partnership moon opens two hearts at the
same time to big changes. Single? You'll find a new love interest is an expert
in healthy eating.

GEMINI 

MAY 22 - JUNE 21 

Walking on the lighter side of life can restore emotional balance, which means
you'll be able to see who could be good for you. This week, big power-planet
bonds in your personal headspace zone help you reboot tricky connections.
Meanwhile, your moon-path is part "just do it", part dreamy, so people may not
realise how strong you are until you end up in charge.

LEO 

JULY 23 - AUG 23 

Hiding your real feelings even for the best reasons is not a good solution to a
problem. Instead, follow your heart and find a way to speak about your emotions
to reset a key relationship. This week, so much of your chart is about value:
finding it and rewarding it. This helps you overhaul everything, from love bonds
to long-term career ambitions.

CAPRICORN 

DEC 22 - JAN 20 

Your ability to learn in life and love tops all of the zodiac signs this week.
This intuition gives you a heads-up when making snap decisions or finalising key
documents, but best of all you'll find you won't be held back by other people's
dreams or opinions. Meanwhile, a name you've heard several times lately is your
best-ever love clue.

LIBRA 

SEPT 23 - OCT 23 

Start this month off with clear decisions about cash, love or time. Now you have
a new sense of belief in yourself, a fresh vision for your future can appear.
Luck sparkles around words you write and read, but you'll also find it in how
open you are to sharing your dreams with others. In love, pure happiness links
to an unexpected "L" name.

AQUARIUS 

JAN 21 - FEB 18 

When you allow yourself to cut loose from tight schedules or expectations,
you'll make time for something special - and yes, you'll be ready. This week,
your chart of growth and personal change is powered by the planets, which makes
you become the best version of yourself. Elsewhere, Saturn's steady support
helps you stick to a secret promise.

SCORPIO 

OCT 24 - NOV 22 

The people you surround yourself with matter so much right now, and instead of
waiting for a member of your family to call, you should make the first move. At
work, one group can become two and achieve more as a result. A casual bond has
the chance to grow into something serious - but only if you switch off the
doubting voice in your heart and mind.

PISCES 

FEB 19 - MAR 20 

You're ready to transform a part-time connection or contract into something that
sits firmly in your favour. This week, what may feel like a problem at first
then develops into an such an exciting challenge. Numbers that start with seven
and names that remind you of holidays are very lucky.

Elsewhere, a caring moon leads you to a local charity group.

TAURUS 

APR 21 - MAY 21 

Make sure you find time for fun this week. As your creativity revs up, you'll
find that your unusual take on the world will reach the right audience.
Elsewhere, your work ideas are pure genius.

Screens and dreams make a perfect match in more ways than one. As the planets of
passion and protection join forces, love settles into a future-proof pattern.

CANCER 

JUNE 22 - JULY 22 

You'll build brilliant bonds in the next few days if you focus on communication.
But be sure to always stay true to yourself, so connections begin - and stay -
genuine. Names that share a special date are ready to start an important
planning process. Your memory zone is moonintense and a significant journey is
back on.

SAGITTARIUS 

NOV 23 - DEC 21 

This week, your success sector shines bright with planet potential and you
pursue your goals with a deep sense of purpose. Meanwhile, if you've been
seeking approval in a relationship, it's time to stop and set your own rules and

headline: VACAY VIBES
subheadline: Holiday a distant memory now? ALEX JAMES to the rescue!
content_plain:
CHEAT'S PAELLA 

SERVES 4 

 Prep time 5 minutes 

Cooking time 30 minutes 

Cals 602 

Sat fat 7g

*1tbsp olive oil

*200g cured chorizo, diced

*1 onion, finely sliced

*2 cloves garlic, crushed

*2tsp sweet smoked paprika

*1/2tsp turmeric

*300g paella rice

*900ml chicken stock

*Pinch saffron

*150g frozen peas

*165g raw king prawns

*15g parsley, roughly chopped

*1 lemon, cut into wedges 

1 Heat the oil on a medium-high heat in a large non-stick frying pan. Add the
chorizo and cook for 3 minutes until crispy. Turn the heat down to medium, add
the onion and cook for a further 3 minutes. 

2 Add the garlic, paprika and turmeric and cook for another minute, stirring
continuously. Add the rice to the pan, coat in the spices and chorizo oil and
fry for 2 minutes.

3 Add the stock, saffron and some salt and pepper and bring to the boil on a
medium-high heat. Simmer for 20 minutes, stirring occasionally. 

4 Once the rice is almost cooked, add the peas and stir to combine, then add the
prawns to the top of the rice. Cover with a lid for 3 minutes until the prawns
are cooked and pink. Serve the paella with the parsley scattered on top and the
lemon wedges on the side to squeeze over.

TUNA NIÇOISE TART 

SERVES 4 

Prep time 

5 minutes 

Cooking time 35 minutes 

Cals 664 

Sat fat 26g

*1 x 320g pack pre-rolled puff pastry

*1 x 160g tin tuna in olive oil

*50g black olives

*150g cherry vine tomatoes

*150g fine green beans

*1/2 red onion, finely sliced

*5 large eggs, whisked

*150g crème fraiche

*30g capers

*4 quail's eggs 

1 Preheat your oven to 200°C/ 180°C fan/gas mark 6. Grease a 20cm x 30cm tart
case with a removable base with butter or oil. Place the pastry sheet over the
tart case and carefully push against the edges without making any holes. 2 Add a
sheet of baking parchment over the pastry, pour over some baking beans and blind
bake in the oven for 15 minutes until the pastry is starting to turn golden.
Take out of the oven and remove the baking beans and parchment.

3 Scatter the tuna, olives, tomatoes, green beans and red onion over the inside
of the pastry.

4 Whisk the eggs with the crème fraiche and season. Pour the egg mixture over
the top tart, then add the capers and some black pepper. 5 Bake in the oven for
15 minutes until half-cooked. Crack the quail's eggs on top of the tart and
return to the oven for 5-8 minutes until the eggs are just cooked. Serve warm
with a green salad on the side. F #FABBITES ROTHAY MANOR, AMBLESIDE In 140
characters A gastro getaway in the middle of the Lakes, this has special
occasion written all over it.

Fab for Adventurous foodies who aren't afraid to Google a few ingredients while
working their way through the menu. The vibe Top-notch nosh with sparkling
service, gorge garden views and rooms above if you fancy making a weekend of it.
Eat The seasonal, sustainably sourced menu changes regularly, but we loved the
squab pigeon with blood orange, chicory and coriander, and the monkfish with
squid, kohlrabi, cucumber and dill. You can splash out on the five-course
tasting menu, £65, or try two courses for £49. Our fave dessert was the 80% dark
choc pud with passionfruit and violet - yum!

Drink Relax with a Cumbrian gin in the lounge pre-dinner - the Cuckold's Revenge
is served with orange and cinnamon and Lamb & Watt Tonic, £6.50. And for wine
choices, a well-crafted list + knowledgeable sommelier = happy days!

Hot gossip Love gin? Make a pilgrimage to the Kindred Spirits shop in Ambleside
- it's filled to the brim with gorge glassware and delish flavours like rhubarb
crumble.

ROTHAYMANOR.CO.UK TWITTER @ROTHAYMANOR FACEBOOK @ROTHAYMANORHOTEL INSTAGRAM
@ROTHAYMANOR
