headline: 'WHY I'M EMBRACING BODY NEUTRALITY'
subheadline:
After struggling with self-acceptance, writer DAISY JORDAN, 28, explains how she
finally made peace with her shape
content_plain:
During a girls' holiday in Italy last year my friend Delia, 30, announced: "I
love my body. It's not perfect, but I finally like what I see in the mirror."

" I smiled meekly in response. Of course I was happy for her, but I felt a
little jealous. For as long as I could remember I'd been reading life-coaching
books, following countless empowering Instagram accounts and dieting in the hope
of falling in love with my figure, but it never happened. No matter how hard I
tried, I couldn't relate. When I looked in the mirror, instead of loving what
was in front of me, all I saw was thick thighs and wide hips.

However, this June I came across an article about body neutrality, which changed
my perspective. The trend refers to simply accepting your shape as it is without
love or hate, and acknowledging what your body does for you. Reading it, I
finally found a realistic approach to changing the way I saw myself.

My journey to self-acceptance has been rocky. Going to an all-girls' school in
South Wales, I became very aware of my appearance in my early teens. Comparison
was my worst enemy, and when my hips and breasts started to develop I felt dumpy
next to my slim friends. Naively, I believed that I wouldn't be happy until I
lost weight, so in January 2005, aged 15, I drastically cut down on calories and
with my parents' blessing joined a gym, working out three times a week. Soon my
jeans felt baggier and my legs were slimmer, and I was thrilled. But my
low-calorie diet wasn't healthy or sustainable, so when I switched back to
eating normally the pounds crept back on and I hated my body once more.

I spent the next 10 years yo-yo dieting and at 25 weighed 9st 7lb, which was
healthy for my 5ft 7in height. My friends commented on how great I looked and
while I knew I wasn't overweight, I never felt content - there was always an
area to tone or an imperfection to fix. When I saw other women celebrating their
bodies, I felt like a failure. Why couldn't I be that happy? I'm not the only
one who feels this way. A recent survey found that one in five UK adults feel
shame about their bodies, while 19% say they're disgusted by what they see in
the mirror.* With so many of us struggling to find peace, loving your body can
feel like a mountain to climb, so it's no surprise that the neutrality movement,
which started in America and began popping up on social media in 2015, has
become so popular. Helena Lewis, psychotherapist and founder of On Route Health,
also prefers this new trend. "Culturally, we have moved away from valuing the
functionality of our body and the focus has been on image," she says. "For
people who are caught up in what feels like a constant battle against
self-hatred, changing their mindset to celebrate every part of their body may
seem impossible. Body neutrality teaches us that you might not love every single
patch of cellulite and belly roll, but you should accept them and not punish
yourself for it."

Embracing body neutrality hasn't been easy. I knew I couldn't spend my life
trying to "improve", so after reading that article I decided to focus on what my
body has done for me and not on how it looks. For example, rather than feeling
bad about my thighs, I thought about how amazing they were to have carried me
through a half-marathon three years ago. It was a struggle at first, and I've
often had to force myself to ignore negative thoughts. Just last month when I
was getting ready for a night out I felt insecure about how I looked, but
focused instead on the fact my body allows me to go for it on the dance floor.
So I put on a killer outfit, enjoyed a glass of wine and had a laugh with my
mates.

The pessimistic thoughts have gradually quietened down, and now when I catch my
reflection in a mirror I feel OK instead of rubbish. By focusing less on my
image, I was able to relax my exercise regime and enjoy food without the guilt,
and it was liberating when I recently noticed I'd put on a few pounds and
realised I didn't care.

I might not be ready to flaunt every curve, dimple and love handle on Instagram,
but I'm not horrible to myself any more either. At last, I accept my body - and
for me, that's a huge triumph. F

headline: FABULIST
subheadline:
Fake news, pharoahs and hide-behind-your-hands horror - this week is
terrifyingly good
content_plain:
THE CAPTURE 

The Beeb's new six-part thriller follows soldier Shaun Emery (Callum Turner) as
he fights to prove his innocence against charges of murder in Afghanistan.
Following damning CCTV footage on a night out, the quickly unravelling story -
starring the always brilliant Holliday Grainger as DI Rachel Carey - will
immerse you in the murky waters of fake news, intelligence and the powers that
be. Tuesday, 9pm, BBC1 

JAX JONES 

The king of collabs releases his debut album Snacks this Friday. Since bursting
into our lives with 2016 anthem House Work, the DJ and producer has released a
series of bangers with all the hottest pop stars, including Ring Ring with
Mabel, One Touch with Jess Glynne and You Don't Know Me with RAYE. Out Friday 

IT: CHAPTER TWO (15) 

We're still not over It (geddit?) and now Stephen King's haunting tale is back
for a second instalment. Almost 30 years on from the Losers' Club's first
terrifying encounter with child-killing clown Pennywise, the group are now
adults who think they're free of their tormentor. Unfortunately for them,
they're destined to meet the shapeshifting villain once again. Be warned - it
looks terrifying AF. In cinemas Friday 

NOVA BATIDA 

World-class surfing, yoga and museum tours in Lisbon, as well as an eclectic
range of music? Sign us up! Featuring music from the likes of Friendly Fires and
Octavian, this fest in the Portuguese capital is all about balance. Tickets
start from £109 - treat yo'self. September 13-15, Novabatida.com TUTANKHAMUN: 

TREASURES OF THE GOLDEN PHARAOH 

Fancy taking a look at the treasure buried with an ancient king? Tutankhamun's
gold is making its way from Egypt to Chelsea, and it's the last chance to see
more than 150 original artefacts before they're permanently rehomed in Cairo.
November 2-May 3, 2020, Tutankhamun-london.com 

GROAN UPS 

The latest offering from Mischief Theatre starts a new term in London's Covent
Garden. The cast play an unruly classroom of six year olds through to the
tumultuous teen years and on to the challenges of adulthood, and it's full of
immature humour at its finest. September 20-December 1, Mischieftheatre.co.uk 

LIVING MY BEST LIFE BY CLAIRE FROST 

After being dumped by her boyfriend of 10 years, Bell is struggling to move on.
Single mum Millie is a social media influencer, but is lying to her followers
and herself. As the pair become unlikely mates, they start to realise what truly
matters. Penned by Fabulous' Assistant Editor, you won't be able to put down
this funny, feel-good tale of fearlessness and friendship. To win a copy, visit
Fabulousmag.co.uk.* Out Thursday (£7.99, Simon & Schuster)

headline: 'I WENT TO MY DAUGHTER'S PROM AFTER SHE DIED'
content_plain:
SARAH GRIFFITHS, 43, RUNS A CANDLE BUSINESS AND LIVES IN BLACKWOOD, SOUTH WALES,
WITH HUSBAND LEIGHTON. SHE HAS TWO SONS, EVAN, 14, AND ZAK, NINE. 

"Standing in front of the mirror I stepped into my gold off-the-shoulder dress.
As I looked at my reflection, I tried hard not to cry. It should have been my
daughter Daisy standing in my bedroom admiring herself, not me.

When Daisy was born on Christmas Eve 2002, she was the best present ever. I had
Evan three years later, followed by Zak in 2010, but my bond with Daisy always
remained strong. From days out in the park to pamper parties, we enjoyed every
second together.

It used to make me smile when Daisy was 11 and would chat excitedly with her
friend Molly about their prom night at Islwyn High School, even though it was
years away. I could just imagine her painting everyone's nails and getting her
make-up just right.

Daisy was always sporty, and by the age of 12 was into netball, athletics and
cross-country running. But in June 2015 she began to have pains and spasms in
her leg, so the GP sent her for a scan at Nevill Hall Hospital to investigate.
Following that she was urgently referred for an MRI, which showed a mass on her
pelvic area. She had a biopsy, and when we got the results back on July 16,
2015, we were given the horrific news that Daisy had Ewing sarcoma, a rare form
of bone cancer.

The doctor explained it was curable, but she would need chemotherapy and would
probably lose her hair. I managed to hold it together for Daisy, but in private
I cried myself to sleep each night. When she started her treatment that August,
we had to shave her hair as it began falling out. Knowing that the cancer was
curable gave my husband Leighton and me the strength to stay positive for Daisy
and the boys.

Finally, in August 2016, after 18 months of gruelling chemo, Daisy finished her
treatment, ringing the bell at the children's hospital in Cardiff with joy.
However, three weeks later, a follow-up CT scan showed the cancer was in her
lungs. Heartbreakingly, this time it wasn't curable.

I was floored. Daisy tried to stay upbeat, but as the months went by I could see
my beautiful girl growing weaker. There was no more treatment available, only
pain management, and she wore a morphine patch most days.

We decided to focus on making memories. Local charity Dreams & Wishes sent Daisy
to Welsh national rugby matches as a VIP, and gave her an iPad so she could
video call her pals during long hospital stays. In March 2017, friends and
family organised a fund-raising ball called Daisy's Dance. That night, I wrapped
my arms around my little girl's tiny frame and we danced together. I had a big
smile on my face, but inside I was broken.

After the ball, Daisy's health deteriorated. A few days later a nurse visited
the house and Daisy asked her if it was time for her to go. The nurse said yes,
and Daisy collapsed into my arms, saying that she didn't feel ready and wanted
to go to prom. It was devastating to hear. On May 1, 2017, aged just 14, she
passed away at home with us by her side. I knew I'd never be the same again.

Although we were upset, we wanted to make sure Daisy's funeral was a celebration
of her life. We packed it full of happy memories and played her favourite Ed
Sheeran song Castle On The Hill. Since then we've had good and bad days. I'll
often cry openly in front of the kids if I feel sad, as I feel we should let our
emotions out.

It's been so important to me to keep Daisy's memory alive, so last year I became
an ambassador for Dreams & Wishes, organising events and sharing my story to
celebrate her legacy. In May this year, Libby, one of Daisy's best friends,
asked if I'd like to come to their prom in Daisy's place to honour her. I asked
her if she was sure as it might be upsetting, but Libby insisted that they
wouldn't do it without me.

The night before I couldn't stop crying, but on the day my pride for Daisy and
her friends took over. Zak walked me down the red carpet in a suit, and in the
school hall I stayed close to the teachers for support because watching all the
kids having an amazing night left me overwhelmed with emotion. It was great
being there on behalf of Daisy, but it was also bittersweet. While the other
parents were still looking forward to their children's futures, Daisy will
always be 14 to me.

Two years on, it still hits me hard some days. But Daisy never gave up and I
can't either. She was a gift to me for 14 years and I'll treasure her forever."
F BTW Ewing sarcoma is a rare cancer that affects the long bones, ribs, pelvis
and spine. It usually occurs in teenagers, and is more common in boys.

For help and support, visit Macmillan.org.uk.

Clockwise from top left: Sarah at the prom with Zak in May; dancing with Daisy
at a fund-raising ball in March 2017; Daisy during treatment, aged 13

headline: Graph of greatness
subheadline: CELEBRITY The good and bad of what we're talking about this week
content_plain:
EMILIA CLARKE 

We were devo'd when we said bye to the 32-year-old actress at the end of Game Of
Thrones, so the news that she's the leading lady in festive flick Last Christmas
is very welcome. The Chrimbo countdown starts now!

GALAXY TRUFFLES 

The best choc in the Celebrations tin is not only getting a delicious revival,
but now it also has a whole box of its own, and you can nab one from Tesco for
just £4.99. Our prayers have been answered.

MAYA JAMA 

The DJ, model and all-round babe may have split from Stormzy, but she said she
feels like she's made it in life cos McDonald's set up a pop-up stall at her
25th birthday bash. Ours is a Big Mac, MJ.

CYCLE 300 

Cancer Research UK is asking us all to cycle 300 miles throughout September to
raise money for the charity - and you can even do it inside if the weather
doesn't play ball. What a wheely inspiring idea.

ROSALÍA 

Spanish pop is taking over the charts, and this superstar is making waves.
Following fab track Con Altura with Sean Paul, the 25 year old has released
single Yo X Ti, Tu X Mi. Let's just not attempt to sing along, eh 

FIZZ FANGS 

 Us Brits drink a NOT whopping 8.2 million litres of prosecco each week.* Ever
heard of prosecco teeth, you lot? SO GREAT 

OUR THIRTIES 

Apparently, 32 is the age when people suffer low "health-esteem", with 77%
feeling like they need to get down the gym more.**

headline: The final say
content_plain:
ROBERT RINDER, 41, IS DAYTIME TV'S MOST FAMOUS JUDGE AND ALSO STARRED ON
STRICTLY COME DANCING IN 2016. 

What is your greatest fear?

Coming to the end of my life unfulfilled.

Or dying in a banal way. For years I lived and worked in the Caribbean, but I
never learned to scuba dive because I thought: "Can you imagine the snickering
in the crematorium if I died of the bends?" 

Which word do you overuse?

I'm saying ostensibly a lot recently. And curate.

What is your worst habit?

I don't have any ugly bad habits. I could never commit to drink or drugs and I
don't really pick my nose.

What does being in love feel like?

Madness. Love interferes with every facet of your emotional chemistry. It has
the capacity to improve everything. It makes you feel like everything will be
fine.

Who would you invite to a dinner party?

I met Emma Thompson not long ago and I had to prepare the discussion beforehand
because my friend said it was likely it'd look like I should be sectioned. So
I'd love her, [Russian novelist] Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, [late writer]
Christopher Hitchens and Joan Rivers. That would be quite a party! Leave or
Remain?

I don't do politics, but neither do I delight in sitting on the fence. If you
take the court seriously, don't talk about politics.

What is your earliest memory?

I am genuinely confident I have memories of being born. I can certainly remember
being in my cot and thinking: "What can I do to get my mum to come in here?" and
"Why has she decorated this room so appallingly?" 

What possession would you rescue from a burning building?

I have some lovely art and lots of books, but it would have to be my lucky
hairbrush. I'm not superstitious, but I've had it for about 20 years. I've
travelled around the world with it.

Who was your first kiss?

I think it was Nikki Glazer when I was In 11 - she had braces. And the good news
is we've been great friends since we were seven. We meet twice a year. Which
celeb would you love to snog?

Taron Egerton. I was on a plane with him but had no idea who he was and he fell
asleep in a slightly compromising way. He is the most beautiful human I have
ever seen close up.

If you could travel back in time, where would you go?

I wouldn't mind being in the court of Louis XIV as long as I had a grand
position. And it would be fun to hang around with the Bloomsbury Set in the
'20s.

Clean or messy?

Not just clean - fiercely clean. The most important person in my life is Petia,
my cleaner. I auditioned 12 and I settled on her. To me the smell of bleach is
Chanel No.5. 

What's top of your bucket list?

I think it's dangerous to have a bucket list because you over-romanticise grand
things, which is a sure-fire way to disappoint. But I'd like to meet Howard
Stern and read War And Peace in Russian. What is your biggest regret?

There are far too many to articulate! F ?

Watch The Rob Rinder Verdict, Friday, 10pm, Channel 4.

'I have far too many regrets to articulate'

headline: 24 HOURS WITH
content_plain:
I'm a serial snoozer. We shoot Emmerdale at the studio Monday to Friday every
week and it's always an early start. I set my alarm for 5.50am so that I can
have two snoozes until 6.10am, when I'll roll out of bed and into the shower. I
wash my hair every morning, otherwise I feel gross and my roots look greasy.
I've now mastered the art of getting ready, including drying my hair and letting
our cavapoo Fred out for a quick wee by 6.30am. Then I'll grab a banana and
drive to work. I love a strong Yorkshire tea. I drink two cups while I get my
make-up done before filming begins. I share a dressing room with Amy Walsh
[Tracy Metcalfe] and Emma Atkins [Charity Dingle] and we love a gossip -
anything to fill the 40 minutes. We'll go over any lines together while getting
into our outfits before heading to set for the first scene at 8am.

My job is an emotional rollercoaster. Vanessa Woodfield - my character in the
soap - is going through a lot of break-up-induced heartache. It can be touching
but draining to constantly act out those emotions, so as a team we try to keep
it light-hearted between scenes. But I wouldn't have it any other way. I love my
job and I thrive off being busy. We'll get four scenes done in the morning
before we have lunch. I'm a sucker for crisps. Alongside my tuna and cheese melt
from the ITV Studios canteen, I'll have salt and vinegar crisps. I also love
fish and chips on a Friday. Some of my colleagues will do yoga or go on a run
during the break - I don't! I might try and do a plank now and again. I work
with my wife. Kate [Brooks, 42] is a producer on Emmerdale, so we're both tied
to the studios. Once we're finished for the day at about 6pm, we'll have a cosy
evening indoors. Whoever gets home first will prepare tea. Kate doesn't eat red
meat any more so we'll have a chicken stir-fry and pop on whatever series we're
hooked on at the time. At the moment we're obsessed with Stranger Things and Big
Little Lies. About 40 minutes later I'll have my head in the treat cupboard.
Weekends are hectic. Our jobs are really demanding, so weekends are spent trying
to squeeze in friends and family. Kate's family live in Liverpool and we
regularly travel to see them from our house in Leeds. We also have to do boring
tasks such as getting tax, VAT and bills in order. For a special treat we'll go
to the theatre or to a gig. This year we've already seen Kylie twice, Pink,
Billy Joel and Rod Stewart. Our guilty pleasure is having a TV in the bedroom. I
know some people don't agree with having one where you sleep, but we love it. We
try to sleep at 10pm, but we'll always watch one more episode. I never make it
past the first half, though, and my eyes shut around 10.30pm. ? Watch Emmerdale,
weeknights, 7pm, ITV.

headline: POWDER UP
subheadline: Matte lips don't have to be dry and flaky with these new-gen powder pouts
content_plain:
STATEMENT SMACKERS Powder formulas are chock-full of rich pigment, so if you're
after a bold lip, look no further. Plus, the colour will stay put throughout the
day, so you won't even have to top up.

ALL-ROUNDER Not all powders are matte. These days everything from
multi-dimensional shimmers to flat mattes create a soft-focus, powdery finish
that is anything but chalky.

3 KEEP BALM Worried powder-based lipstick will dry out your pout? For a smooth
finish that looks flawless, prep your smackers with an exfoliating scrub before
layering on a dab of clear lip balm to create a protective barrier and prevent
any chapping. Swipe your lipstick on top, et voilà!

4 LOW-KEY LIP For a subtle take on the trend, blur the powder over your lipline
to create an undone look. Apply the powder in the centre, then use a sponge to
diffuse it out towards the corners of your mouth.

5 TAILOR-MADE Thankfully, these lippies don't look caked on or flaky, plus,
they're super-easy to work with. Unlike old liquid lipsticks, new powder
formulas can be layered without clumping, making them perfect to take you from
day to night with a few extra swipes.

1 Shiseido ModernMatte Powder Lipstick in 511, £25 2 Mac Powder Kiss Lipstick in
Sexy But Sweet, £17.50 3 Avon Mark. Epic Lip Powder Pen Lipstick in Flutter Fly,
£8 4 Nars Powermatte Lip Pigment in Walk This Way, £23 5 Dior Ultra Care Liquid
in 999, £30 6 Buxom PillowPout Creamy Plumping Lip Powder in Soft Whisper, £15 7
Nyx Professional Makeup Powder Puff Lippie Lip Cream in Senior Class, £6.40 8
Laura Mercier Lip Powder Collection in New York, £25 

ASK THE BEAUTY TEAM 

My make-up never looks good after the gym as my skin is hot and red, but I don't
want to go to work bare-faced. Help! Linda, Hull 

I feel your pain. My face goes full-on tomato after exercising, but I've learned
a few tricks to keep it under control. Rinse your face with cold water
immediately after your workout to bring your temperature down, then spray
hydrating Avène Eau Thermal Water Spray, £4.50, to reduce skin sensitivity
(store it in the fridge to make it extra cool). The secret to good-looking
make-up after a workout is primer. Origins Original Skin Pore Perfecting Cooling
Primer, £27, is enriched with anti-inflammatory willowherb, plus it mattifies
skin so it will wick away moisture. Still looking flushed? Try a green-tinted
base product to counteract redness. Erborian CC Red Correct, £38, matches your
skin tone on application, provides good coverage and is SPF25 to boot. Tara
Ledden, Beauty Assistant 

DO YOU HAVE A BEAUTY PROBLEM? EMAIL US AT BEAUTY@FABULOUSMAFG.aCbOu.UloKusmag.

headline: LIFE CLINIC
content_plain:
Medical query? DOCTOR HILARY is here to help I had a traumatic childhood and
lost my parents in my 20s. My friend thinks I have complex post-traumatic stress
disorder, but I don't know where to turn for help - I'm struggling to get a GP
appointment and charities aren't replying. Elle, via email CPTSD is a
distressing condition where it is difficult to control your emotions. You may
feel hostile to or distrustful of others and that no one understands you, as
well as feeling isolated and depressed. Talking therapies and EMDR (using rapid
eye movements when describing trauma) plus antidepressants can help. Visit
Nhs.uk for psychological therapies (IAPT) and Mind.org.uk for local resources.
Also try audiobooks like The Body Keeps The Score by Bessel van der Kolk.

I was told to stop taking alendronic acid for osteoporosis and now I have a
different infusion once a year instead. However, my hair and eyebrows are
falling out. Blood and hormone tests are clear. How can I stop it happening?
Jennie, via email Alendronic acid can be an effective treatment for
osteoporosis, but not everyone can tolerate it. Zoledronic acid as a yearly
infusion is an excellent alternative, reducing the risk of vertebral fracture by
70% and hip fracture by 41%. However, hair loss is a recognised side effect. I
recommend the Get Ahead Of Hair Loss event held in London this month, where you
can meet experts in hair science and trichology - visit Getaheadofhairloss.com.

Sexpert SUSAN QUILLIAM sorts out your relationships A male colleague constantly
approaches me for chats, hugs me and leaves notes on my desk. I'm not
interested, but as he's not asked me out yet, I don't know how to let him know.
Help! Kris, via email Give this guy the message by cutting short your chats,
refusing hugs and keeping interactions professional. Alternatively, gently tell
him that you appreciate his attention but find it embarrassing, and ask him to
back off. If he persists, there are formal disciplinary steps you can take. And
remember, you don't need to return this guy's approaches if you don't want to.

My boyfriend went on a lads' holiday and I'm convinced he cheated on me, as he
acts strangely whenever I bring it up. It's making it hard to trust him. What's
your advice? Michelle, via email Why do you think your boyfriend cheated? Is it
because he's been unfaithful before? If so, bring this to a head, challenge him
directly, be prepared to hear bad news and handle that, for surely it's better
to know the truth than to keep wondering? Or has your boyfriend never been
unfaithful but he's picked up on your jealousy and it's making him feel nervous,
which is why he's acting strangely even though nothing happened? If so, back
off, stay calm and think about why you find it hard to trust. Either way, the
two of you need to work on your relationship to make it happy and healthy.

FIVE-MINUTE HACK 

Medina Grillo, author of Home Sweet Rented Home (£15, Mitchell Beazley), on how
to make a rental feel more like your own space.

There are so many things you can do to a rented house to make it feel more
homely rather than four walls you happen to be leasing for a while. Here are a
few budget hacks you can do easily and cheaply that won't result in you losing
your deposit!

Create a blackboard memo wall on the back of a door using a roll of sticky vinyl
paper. It's easy to peel and remove once you leave. And use contact adhesive
strips to hang pictures (or other decorative items like hats or baskets) on the
wall without causing damage.

Are your windows looking a little bare? Replace existing curtains with new ones
that match your style. Remember, you can also change drapes depending on
seasons. Choose lighter, thin cotton or linen fabrics for warm weather and
thicker lined curtains for when it gets colder.

Add a colourful throw to a worn or tattered sofa, and you can't go wrong with a
rug. Use them to cover old or worn carpets, or just to add a little extra
personality to your space.

headline: THE RAPE SCANDAL ENGULFING BRITISH UNIVERSITIES
subheadline:
Allegations of rape and sexual assault have risen tenfold at UK universities,
sparking student protests across the country. Fa bulous investigates why rape
culture has become so prolific on campus BY LAURA SILVERMAN & EMILY COPE
content_plain:
alking into a student club with friends, Josie* locked eyes with a man across
the room and felt her chest tighten.

W"I tried to fight back a panic attack as the memories flooded my mind. Just a
few months before, he'd choked me unconscious and then raped me," says Josie,
21.

"Despite my constant pleas to the university, he hadn't been suspended and I was
forced to live in constant fear of bumping into him."

Josie had been studying geography at a British university when the alleged
attack happened last December. Despite police currently investigating, her
fellow student is still studying at the same university. Terrified of seeing
him, Josie has postponed her degree. She is also suffering from post-traumatic
stress disorder.

"My life has changed forever, but he still walks around campus as if nothing has
happened," says Josie. "The university has completely failed to protect me. I
feel humiliated and let down."

Josie's ordeal comes as rape culture at UK universities reaches an all-time
high. Recent research by sexual health and wellbeing charity Brook revealed that
more than half of students have experienced unwanted advances or assault. And
the situation has worsened, with the number of allegations reported to police
rising tenfold in four years, from 65 in 2014 to 626 in 2018.* But given that
such a tiny proportion of people report attacks, the real figures are likely to
be much higher.

In recent years, students at Goldsmiths, University of London, have protested
against the institution's response to sexual harassment claims, while similar
demonstrations have been staged by those studying at Roehampton and Bristol. On
top of this, the University of Cambridge is being sued by former student
Danielle Bradford over its handling of her sexual harassment complaint. She
claims that she was discouraged from launching a formal complaint despite being
bombarded with sexual texts by a course supervisor.

Nina Burrowes, a psychologist and founder of The Consent Collective, which runs
workshops and lectures on campuses, says universities are failing to both
protect and support students. "Sexual violence cannot be tolerated anywhere, but
university students are particularly at risk because they are away from home for
the first time," she says.

Universities UK, a representative organisation for all universities across the
UK, established a task force in 2016 to address sexual violence, but admits
there is still work to be done.

"Every case is one too many," spokesperson Clara Plackett says. "It is important
to create an environment where students feel able to come forward confident that
an incident will be addressed. We will be publishing guidance in the coming
academic year and recommendations on what further action is necessary to drive
improvement, as well as a sector-wide survey to assess progress."

But for Josie, this is too little too late.

"My attacker asked to walk me home from a club and I accepted because I thought
I'd be safer with him," she says. "When we got back to mine he asked to come
inside to warm up. Once he was in my house, he kissed me against my will before
choking me. I passed out and when I woke up he was raping me. I was terrified."

The next day Josie went to hospital to get checked over. The police were called
and took her to a sexual assault referral centre (SARC), where she was examined
and prescribed HIV prevention medication, but she was afraid to take the case
further. "I'd heard horror stories about women torn to pieces in court and I
couldn't cope with that," she says.

But two months after the attack, backed by witnesses, she submitted a report to
her university. Josie hoped the institution would suspend her rapist because his
behaviour violated the student code of conduct.

"I didn't feel safe on campus and I wanted the guy out of uni," says Josie.

"I emailed the university countless times, but I was told that I'd have to wait.

Weeks went by and I heard nothing."

Terrified of bumping into her attacker, the former A* student began to fall
behind with her work and applied for student counselling, but was put on a
three-month waiting list. "I couldn't concentrate for longer than half an hour,"
she says. "I wasn't coping well and really needed help.

"Whenever I walked round the corner or went to the gym, I'd feel sick in case I
saw him. The first time I came face to face with him was at a night out that I'd
been looking forward to for months. I was standing in a queue for some food when
he came towards me, and I froze.

"A friend spotted what was happening and came between us, pushing me behind her.
Shaking, I spent the rest of the night surrounded by friends and scared to be
alone, then I left early.

"When a space for counselling finally became free, I turned up only to discover
that the counsellor was a financial advisor. I'd been booked in with the wrong
person and he simply sent me away."

The following month, Josie decided to take matters into her own hands and met
with the student president. Together they sent out a rallying cry to other
students who had experienced sexual violence on campus and who felt let down by
the university's handling of the situation.

Dozens answered their call and the group began meeting frequently to devise an
outline of what they thought needed to change. In June they approached the
university with their demands, which included specialised counselling services
for assault survivors and a more streamlined approach to banning alleged
attackers from student events. Within days the university finally took action,
hiring an independent investigator.

On the investigator's advice - and at the urging of her parents, who were
horrified when she told them what had happened - Josie got in touch with the
police again, and the case is now formally being examined. The investigator also
told her that he would recommend the university suspend the student, but this is
yet to happen.

It was only after a meeting with the vice .

chancellor that Josie found out the university had enforced a no-contact rule on
her attacker in March, meaning he wasn't allowed to approach her in person or
online.

Despite her fears, Josie has no regrets about finally reporting the crime.
"Going back to the police was a big decision, but I finally felt like I was
being listened to. It angers me that action was only taken by the university
when I made some noise. They haven't done enough to protect or support me, but
the no-contact rule they issued is a step in the right direction.

"I don't think I'll ever be the same person. I find it really hard to trust
people. I've lost a lot of friends, but I've found out who my real ones are, and
now I get scared on my own."

Josie's university insists that it takes all allegations of sexual violence
"extremely seriously".

"The university is investing significantly in resources for student wellbeing,"
says a spokesperson. "We are working closely with the students' union to create
an inclusive, respectful and safe campus."

It's also hiring more specialist counsellors and training staff in nightclubs to
spot sexual harassment, as well as advising lecturers what to do if someone
confides in them, and introducing lectures to educate students about consent.
Nevertheless, Josie's alleged attacker still remains a student. After taking
eight months off university to deal with her PTSD and panic attacks, Josie plans
to restart her degree later this month. "I don't know how long it will take me
to recover completely, but I am determined to return to my studies," she says.

Evidence that the rape culture at UK universities has reached crisis point was
never more apparent than this February, when hundreds of students protested at
the University of Warwick after male students made a series of rape threats on a
private message group.

Their remarks - which included "sometimes it's fun to just go wild and rape 100
girls" - were reported to the university last year by a female student who had
been mentioned in the chat, and the 11 males in the Facebook group were
temporarily suspended from their studies.

Student Megan Wain, 21, was one of the women targeted.

"When the girl who'd reported the messages told me about them, I felt sick," she
says. "I'd been on nights out with them or sat next to them in lectures. Our
names had been retracted from the transcript I saw, and I didn't want to know
what was said about me specifically.

"It was horrifying. I trusted these men deeply, and some I would even class as
my best friends. To see what they were capable of was extremely distressing. I
was shocked I hadn't noticed their behaviour as I was so close to them. This
made me feel anxious, as I doubted everyone's intentions."

Despite the university banning five of the 11 from the campus following an
investigation, they were still allowed to live in their uni accommodation.

"They were literally living a road away from me," says Megan. "Whenever I saw
one of them walking around, I'd feel sick with anxiety. My friend was approached
by one of them on the street after she had reported it. He angrily told her to
stop going any further with her statement and threatened her with his legal
team, saying he'd sue her for it."

Megan became so distressed that she skipped lectures and social events and began
suffering panic attacks. The university encouraged the victims to have
counselling, but there was a three-month waiting list. Unable to cope, she moved
home to Birmingham in June 2018 after her second year, and for the rest of her
degree made the three-hour round trip to campus each day.

But Megan was dealt another blow this January when she discovered that a 10-year
expulsion on two of the men had been lifted following an appeal.

"I knew nothing about it until a friend told me that she'd read it in the
student paper," says Megan. "The girls mentioned in the chat had been pushing
for an update, but the university refused to tell us what was happening because
of data protection. We felt like we had the right to know, but we were treated
as though we'd done something wrong."

The decision caused outrage, sparking protests the following month. The hashtag
#ShameOnYouWarwick went viral on social media. Since then, nearly 85,000 people
have signed a petition calling for the culprits to be permanently banned from
studying at Warwick.

Megan graduated with a 2.1 and is about to start a master's degree in social and
political theory at the University of Birmingham. But the incident makes it hard
for her to trust anyone.

"It's changed the way I look at every friendship," she admits. "Those men were
my mates. I was always round at their house for dinner. I'd gone on nights out
with them and I'd trusted them to get me home safely. Then they said such
explicit and violent things about me and others. I've been on a few dates
recently, but I don't know if I'll be able to trust men again.

"I also feel let down by the university. The men who said they wanted to rape
and attack me have got away with it. Without consequences there will never be an
end to rape culture."

A spokesperson for the University of Warwick said: "We are improving how we
handle student disciplinary and appeals processes following recommendations from
an independent external review."

Two other women mentioned in the chat are suing Warwick over how the university
handled the case. They expressed concern about the fact that the investigating
officer, Peter Dunn, was also the university's head of press and therefore
responsible for protecting the institution's reputation. Warwick admitted "the
potential for conflict" between these two roles, but insists that other members
of the team looked after media duties during the investigation. The spokesperson
for the university adds that it is now providing "additional specific wellbeing
resources" to those affected.

According to Nina, the Warwick case is symptomatic of what's happening on many
campuses.

"Part of the reason rape is being [joked] about is that it's taboo, especially
after #MeToo. The men are saying: 'Look at how non-PC I am.' But I also think it
reflects a sense of male entitlement. Bragging seems to have become a thing
among men to make their friends like them more. What would have been whispered
in a corridor years ago is now texted or tweeted. Men aren't worried about
sharing this sort of thing - this generation has grown up with smartphones."

But she adds that times are changing. "Expectations have adjusted and
universities need to take a zerotolerance approach. The #MeToo generation will
not tolerate being ignored any more." F

'The university has failed to protect me and I feel let down''The #MeToo
generation will not be ignored any more'

headline: 'I QUIT CORRIE FOR MY FAMILY AND IT'S THE BEST THING I EVER DID'
subheadline:
She left TV's biggest soap to strike out on her own. And the gamble has
certainly paid off for CATHERINE TYLDESLEY
content_plain:
COVER STAR hen the news broke that Catherine Tyldesley had signed up for
Strictly, one of the first people to get in touch was her former dance teacher.
"Well, this is a turn up for the books!" she joked.

Because when Cath was at theatre school, she weighed 15st and was so chronically
lacking in confidence that she did everything she possibly could to dodge dance
lessons.

"I never felt body confident enough to do it," she says today. "I felt so much
bigger than everyone else and I used to think: 'Who would be able to lift me?'
About 90% of the classes I just didn't turn up to. Dance wasn't my thing at
all."

Since then, Cath has dropped from a size 22 to a 10, gained much-needed
self-esteem and looks completely fabulous, but she says there's still a
psychological hangover from the days she wrestled with her body image.

"In my head I'm still too big, so I'm hoping [Strictly] will be a bit
therapeutic for me. And it might help me break through everything I'm terrified
of. At the minute it feels like it's happening to someone else, I'm so far out
of my comfort zone. I'm scared of doing a forward roll, so god knows how I'll
cope with the lifts."

The dance training will also give Cath, 35, a new element in her dedicated
health and fitness regime, and it's one she's relishing. She's been upping the
cardio in preparation for some of the faster-paced Latin dances and is
interested to see how her body is going to respond.

"I'm not skinny - I'd say I'm an average size. I work out and eat well, and
this," she gestures up and down, "is as good as it's going to get. I'm not going
to do anything stupid to get any smaller.

"I will never have a six-pack and I'm fine with that. It's never going to
happen. People are usually lovely to me, but I have the odd person calling me
fat or too thin. So you can never win. I never read comments in the newspapers
or on social media - it's bad for your mental health. My husband loves me the
way I am and that's what's most important."

It's been 13 months since Cath quit Coronation Street leaving Eva "The Diva"
Price and seven years of tears, laughs and drama behind. It was a brave move,
taking her away from the financial security of a regular job, and although she's
got work coming out of her ears (apart from Strictly she's also starred in the
acclaimed 15 Days for Channel 5 and the highly anticipated BBC1 comedy series
Scarborough - more on this later), she admits she was nervous about what the
future held.

"But I'm also really into positive thinking and just always thought that good
things would happen," she says. "Luckily I can sing, so if I had to sing for my
supper again, it's OK, I could do that!

"What is nerve-wracking, though, is turning things down. In the past I've done
things I probably shouldn't have. Now I'm older, if it doesn't feel right I
don't do it."

She's loved the flexibility that leaving the Street and its 12-hour days has
given her, as well as the extra time at home with "my boys" - son Alfie turned
four in March and is about to start reception.

And the family has also acquired another member in the form of miniature
dachshund Geoff. Cath jokes that his arrival earlier this year has given PT
husband Tom, 32, the impression their family is now complete.

"Tom thinks that this is his get-out clause. He's like: 'We don't need another
baby now!' So, yeah, he needs convincing about having a second baby, but you
know, I'm the boss. We will have another one eventually, when the time is
right."

Cath and Tom met at a time in her life when she was thoroughly disillusioned
with men and intending on staying single after a series of heartbreaks. But
life's a funny old game, and Alfie was conceived within months of them getting
together back in 2014. She has spoken before about the happy surprise that
turned her world upside down in the best possible way.

"If it had been any of my friends I would have been like: 'Whoa.' But Tom was
amazing from start to finish and Alfie was the best surprise.

"Looking back, we were both so broody. If we were at a social event we'd end up
with other people's babies, so it wouldn't have been long before we started
trying anyway. He is just the best dad and they are like two peas in a pod."

Like many mums, Cath worries about getting the work/life balance right and
regularly has attacks of guilt if she thinks she's falling short. But she's a
recent meditation convert, and the practice is helping keep a sense of
perspective.

"I sometimes feel like I'm the only mum who forgets about teddy bear breakfast
or cake bake day. You are constantly surrounded by guilt. But since I've started
meditating it's been amazing. It just resets you, especially when you're a mum
and you're go, go, go all day. Kids have no mercy.

"I think it's important for your mental health to just breathe and be mindful. I
live my life at 110mph and love being busy, but I do need to remind myself to
take it easier. Like, no need to be so aggressive with the washer! Just put it
in slowly. .

"And Alfie is just great. He's just started theatre school and I've turned into
a proper theatre school mum. They're doing Joseph, and because he's a tiddler,
he's something like 'Narrator 13' but I've got him doing an American accent so
he stands out and people will remember him!" If rumours are to be believed, Cath
left Corrie last August amid unrest among the cast, unhappy with the exhausting
filming schedule under new producer Iain MacLeod. She is one of many big names
to have handed in their notice (Kym Marsh, Lucy Fallon and Faye Brookes, among
others, are also saying ta-ra, chuck) and the mass exodus is said to be a sign
of the troubles. Cath claims this isn't true, and says the constant speculation
is causing some irritation.

"Honestly, I feel frustrated for them because I'm in touch with everyone and I
think they're all a bit upset about it. It's a brilliant place to work - Iain is
doing a great job, but these rumours keep popping up. I had lunch with Jane
Danson [Leanne Battersby] the other day and I asked her if everything was cool,
and she was like: 'Yes, it's as great as it has always been!' It's just a pure
coincidence that everyone is leaving at the same time.

"It was my second home for seven years and I have nothing but good things to say
about it."

Would she ever go back? "I'd love to at some point. I do get a little pang now
and again. But it was the right thing to do for my family. I'm often able to do
the school run now, which is lovely because of the age Alfie is. That's one of
the reasons I turned a lot of things down last year. He was starting pre-school
and I thought I don't want to look back and feel I missed that section of his
life.

"It's been nice not having to clear holidays with anybody. We've done a lot of
weekends away in the UK, Dubai, Portugal, France, Spain. It's been lovely."

She says it was former Corrie producer Kate Oates, now at EastEnders, who gave
her the confidence to spread her wings away from Weatherfield.

"Kate really fuelled my desire to try other things, and I wanted to do a gritty
drama. Amazingly, 15 Days came up and it was brilliantly written and so
wellreceived. But after that I called my agent and was like: 'I need to do a
comedy,' and then Scarborough came in literally a week later.

"I really feel like comedy is where my roots are. It feels nice to be laughing
instead of crying. And when I read the script for Scarborough, I fell in love
with all of the characters because it's so warm and genuine.

"It's been an absolute joy, one of my favourite jobs ever, hands down. No one
wanted it to finish."

Scarborough is the latest series from Benidorm writer Derren Litten, and also
stars Jason Manford and Stephanie Cole. Set in the North Yorkshire seaside town,
the show sees Cath and Jason play Karen and Mike, a couple who are trying to
give their relationship another go five years after they split.

"Jason became like my brother," says Cath of the friendship the two of them
developed during filming.

"Straight away I felt so comfortable with him. I often think that comedians make
brilliant actors because they're very observant of people, and he just blew me
away. We have some tender, almost heartbreaking, scenes - even though it's a
comedy there are still beautiful scenes - and he totally had me.

"I remember we did a fairground scene on this ride for about three hours and
Jason was making me laugh so much I dribbled. The ride was going so fast the
dribble just went all over him and then my boob fell out. The whole thing was
hysterical."

The people of Scarborough "couldn't have been more welcoming" and Cath reckons
the show might work wonders for the seaside town's tourist industry.

"It's such a charming town and an absolute dream to film in. Derren won some
tourism awards for Benidorm because the show increased the numbers of visitors,
and I think that will happen with Scarborough. It's so gorgeous and it's been
shot beautifully."

Cath says she tried to eat healthily during filming and trained with kettlebells
between scenes ("the location guys hated me because they had to lug them around
everywhere"), but the local fish and chips often proved too much of a
temptation.

"This past six months has been the most difficult in terms of training because I
just haven't had the time. There were points where I hadn't exercised in weeks
and I really missed it. It's a mental thing for me - it's not really about
weight loss any more. It's more that if I eat badly I don't feel great. And
after a few days of not doing something I start to feel a bit narky."

Enter Strictly Come Dancing. It seems to have come round at the perfect time in
more ways than one.

"Yeah, it feels right," she agrees. "Last year it wasn't the right time but now
is good."

She laughs off any mention of the infamous Strictly Curse, though.

"Obviously there's a history of things happening, but Tom is really chilled out
about it to the point where I'm like: 'Are you even bothered?' "But he gets on
with everybody and that's why we work, and he wants to be part of the experience
as much as I do. There's just something so special about Strictly. I've always
been a huge fan of the show, my whole family love it, it's so well-loved and
classy and brilliant. To actually be on it is a dream come true." F. Scarborough
starts Friday, 9.30pm, BBC1.

THE LASTBook you read? Gracie Fields' biography for a play I did earlier this
year.

She was so fascinating.

Movie you watched? Green Book. Amazing - so good.

Box set you watched? This Is Us. It makes you want to wake your child up and be
a better mum.

DM you received? From Derren Litten about my dog Geoff.

Time you were drunk? The wrap party for Scarborough.

Time you cried? Watching This Is Us.

Time you lost your temper? I got a new car and a guy reversed into me because he
was smoking!

'Tom is really chilled out about the Strictly Curse'

headline: 'SIMON DIDN'T KNOW HOW TO PICK A HIT FOR US'
subheadline:
They crashed, bur ned and split back in 2012. But now WeStLiFeare back and this
time they're doing things differently
content_plain:
For millions of devoted Westlife fans the wait is almost over.

Following a reunion tour earlier this year that sold out in just six minutes,
the boys' hugely anticipated new album Spectrum has a release date of November
15. And with single Hello My Love soaring to the top of the charts in January,
plus more soon-to-be released tracks written by James Bay and self-confessed
Westlife fan Ed Sheeran, expectations are high.

Whether you love 'em or think they're a tad cheesy, more than two decades on
from the release of their first single Swear It Again the band's popularity has
undoubtedly endured. With 55 million records sold worldwide, they remain the
only band to have their first seven singles enter the UK charts at No.1. Despite
their successes, they have also faced their fair share of challenges, including
Brian McFadden's departure in 2004 and a seven-year hiatus when it looked like
they'd never reunite.

We sat down with the boys to hear all about their split, the reunion, life on
the road again and juggling the band with fatherhood 

SHANE FILAN, 40 

When the band split in 2012, was a reunion always part of the plan?

No, definitely not. After our last gig at Croke Park [Dublin, in June 2012] that
was it, we were done. We genuinely weren't enjoying it any more. It's only in
the last couple of years that I started to really miss the other guys and
performing together enough to want to do it all over again. are you doing
anything differently this time around?

Before, we worked too much, didn't have enough time off, didn't see our families
enough, so we burnt out and were sick of Westlife. This time family comes first
- we have nine children between us, with one on the way. If we're on the road,
we're never away longer than 10 days before we have a break. In the future I
don't want my kids [Nicole, 14, Patrick, 10, and Shane, nine] to say: "You were
always working, Dad."

you've had a successful solo career, but why didn't you go down the reality tV
route like kian and Nicky?

I was offered every show two or three times, but it was never for me. All I've
ever wanted to do is sing and that didn't change after the band split. Now Mark
and I are writing together, which is brilliant. Kian and Nicky always loved
reality shows, but it never appealed to me. is there still an appetite for bands
like Westlife?

I think there will always be a demand for bands that make good music. So much
has changed since we've been away, though, and our new songs need to fit into
this new scene. If we released Flying Without Wings or Swear It Again now, they
wouldn't get played on the radio. These days it's songs with tempo that get
airtime, which is why Hello My Love was such a massive hit for us.

What do you say to criticism that this reunion is just about cashing in?

If that was the case we could have done it years ago. We've been asked so many
times. But it never felt right - we all only wanted to do it for the right
reasons. If it was just about the money, we could have done a nostalgia tour
then disappeared again. We wouldn't have signed a new deal and recorded an
album, with plans to tour again. you and wife Gillian were declared bankrupt in
2012 and 2018 respectively. after such a difficult time, does 2019 feel like a
new chapter for you both?

I feel like now it's time to enjoy life - both family and band life. Everything
feels more special this time around. Getting to share it all with Gillian and
the kids is incredible.

NICKY BYRNE, 40 

Why did you decide to go back?

My dad died 10 years ago and something I inherited from him was his work ethic.
I'm too young to sit about doing nothing. Also, my 12-year-old sons Rocco and
Jay have only vague memories of me performing last time around and my daughter
Gia, five, has never known me as a pop star, so I wanted them to see this side
of me. the band has always managed to maintain a squeaky-clean image. are you
just better than other acts at hiding bad behaviour?

We all loved a drink, but falling around a hotel bar after one too many was
about as scandalous as it got. I've never taken drugs or even smoked a
cigarette. Now with so many children between us there are fewer late nights and
the beers on the backstage rider have been replaced with Percy Pigs!

Why isn't brian part of the band's reunion?

We tried everything to keep Brian as part of the band in 2004, but he walked
away and we s**t ourselves. We realised if we wanted Westlife to survive, we
needed to pull together. Him leaving really galvanised us and we became
something different. Brian wouldn't know this band if he stepped back into it
because this isn't the band he left. I wish him all the best, but I don't know
him any more. .

As a band, you've never been seen as cool. Does it bother you?

When I was younger it definitely did. I was always a cool guy, then I found
myself dressed in a black suit singing Mandy and people were slagging me off!
Now I don't care so much. As the years went by we became boring. We weren't
picking the records ourselves - Simon Cowell was doing it, but he'd lost
confidence in us and didn't know how to pick a hit for us. We'd spend months
making original music then he'd insist we do a cover. It would be a big hit but
wasn't necessarily what we wanted to sing. What's next for Westlife?

I look at Take That as an example of how a band can come back from a split and
carry on for years with credibility. I think we can keep Westlife in our lives
forever this time.

KIAN EGAN, 39 

What do you make of Brian McFadden tweeting last year that ego is destroying the
potential for a five-man Westlife reunion?

That's completely untrue. We started as a five-piece and five years in he
decided he didn't want to do it any more. We went on for eight more years and
became a different band, and that's the one you see today.

Do you sing more lead vocals on the new album?

Definitely. I'm much more confident. In the past we were told Mark and Shane
sang the lead parts and that's just the way it was. Now I've had a successful
solo album and commanded an audience of 20,000 people on my own, you're
definitely going to hear more from me.

You've got three boys - Koa, seven, Zekey, four, and Cobi, 23 months. Any plans
for another, or are you and wife (former Hollyoaks actress Jodi Albert) done?

Not right now. It would be crazy to have a fourth when I'm back on the road and
working so much again, but it's definitely a possibility. I love the idea of
having a little girl after three sons - it's hard to think of never getting to
walk a daughter down the aisle on her wedding day. But I also believe you get
the babies you're meant to get, so if we did have another, as long as it was
healthy, I'd be happy. How did you feel when the band split in 2012?

I was the one fighting to keep it going, more than anyone else. One night, we
were drunk in a taxi after a night out and I blurted out: "This is stupid, lads,
I really think we're going to miss this." You could have heard a pin drop! But
they were right - we had to end on a high rather than see it all dwindle away.
Does it feel different now?

I feel like we're getting to live the dream a second time around, but this time
we're in control. In the early years there was a lot of fear instilled in us,
that if we didn't do what we were told and keep going it would all fall apart.
In the end, we broke. This time we're making the decisions and it feels great.

MARK FEEHILY, 39 

Your first baby is due later this year - congrats! How are you feeling about
becoming a dad with fiancé Cailean?

It's the best thing that's ever happened to me. It's something I've wanted for
years, I've always been a broody guy, but now everything is so great in my
personal life and my career, the time feels right. It hasn't been a knee-jerk
reaction, we've been researching the surrogacy process for the last three years.

How involved are you with the mother?

Fully involved. This is something she has wanted to do all her life. It's as far
from a cold, hard commercial transaction as you can get. Cailean and I have been
at scans and appointments with her, and when we haven't been able to be there in
person, we've Skyped in.

Do you know who the biological father is?

For now we're keeping that private. I want to wait until we feel comfortable
sharing some parts of this journey. The baby's not even here yet and I'm blown
away by how protective I feel of it. Just posting a scan on Instagram to
announce the pregnancy felt like a huge step.

You haven't always been in such a good place, have you?

I've had ups and downs in my life, but Cailean has been such a positive
influence. In the past I was always searching - for love, a new career after
Westlife ended I never felt fulfilled. Now I've found everything I was looking
for. I used to be out every night, now I'm happiest at home in Sligo with a
glass of red wine and a box set. I wish I could tell my 14-year-old self how
content I am now with who I am as a person, my sexuality and the life I've built
for myself.

What brought you back to the band?

The day after our final gig I got on a plane to America with no idea when I was
coming back. I desperately needed to get away and push a reset button in my
head. It took a long time, but eventually I missed it - the boys, the crowds,
singing my first line in Flying Without Wings and hearing thousands of people
lose their minds. I wanted all that again. F. Westlife's new album Spectrum is
out on November 15. Preorder at Westlife.com.

WATCH IT!Watch our exclusive video with Westlife at Fabulousmag.

co.uk now.

'I desperately needed to push a reset button in my head' MARK

headline: Cocu left 'ashamed' by Rams
content_plain:
PHILLIP COCU admitted he was ashamed after a battering by the Bees.

Bryan Mbeumo and an Ollie Watkins double in the first half bagged Brentford a
first home league win in their last season at Griffin Park.

But ex-Barcelona star Cocu was left stunned by the worst 45 minutes his
struggling side have played under him.

The 1,600 Rams fans chanted "what the f****** hell was that" after an abject
performance.

Cocu said: "The fans were disappointed and they've every right to be.

"We should be ashamed of that first half  and we can never play like that
again.

"It is the worst we've played since I've been here, I didn't expect it.

"We were at 75 per cent when we should be at our maximum."

The hosts started well and they made it count with two goals in as many minutes.

a Mbeumo netted on the rebound after Derby skipper Richard Keogh
Brentford............3 Derby .................. 0 cleared a Watkins drive off
the line after 17 minutes.

And winger Mbeumo returned the compliment when he broke swiftly down the right
and pulled the ball low across the area for unmarked Watkins to sidefoot home
from ten yards.

Watkins bagged his second on the stroke of half-time.

The frontman steered home a rebound from close range after his first effort was
blocked.

Brentford boss Thomas Frank said: "Derby couldn't cope with our intensity.

"That is one of the best games we've played since I took over.

"It's really about time we put in a performance like that.

"I am so pleased for Ollie  but if I was being harsh he should have had a
hat-trick.

"How far can we go? Firstly, we just need to maintain that level."

headline: JOR WELCOME
content_plain:
JORDAN HUGILL ruined caretaker boss Lee Bullen's perfect Hillsborough record.

The on-loan West Ham striker, 27, scored his fourth and fifth goal in six league
games for QPR.

But he was perhaps fortunate to be on the pitch to complete the comeback after
he was booked for a nasty clash with Barry Bannan, and then escaped a second
yellow for diving minutes later.

Sheffield Wednesday took the lead on 23 minutes, when Steven Fletcher scored
from the spot after Fernando Forestieri was fouled by Grant Hall.

Then Hugill, slipped through on goal by Nahki Wells, skipped past Owls keeper
Keiren Westwood before sliding his shot into the net on the hour mark.

Four minutes later Westwood was stranded again when Hugill cushioned Sheffield
Wed.......................1 QPR......................................... 2 home
Ryan Manning's neat delivery. QPR chief Mark Warburton said: "I knew getting
Jordan would work because we have the quality to create chances.

"There was a lot of interest in him, of course and, when you meet a player, you
have to tell him what he can expect.

"We talked about the chances he would get and I knew he'd feed off that."

The defeat was a blow to Owls' interim boss Bullen as he aims to get the job
full-time. Bullen, who won his first two home games, said: "I know the demands
of this club and that is not acceptable.

"The two goals we lost, you would not see in a primary school playground."

headline: BERTIE ASSET
content_plain:
ALBERT ADOMAH bagged a dramatic Forest equaliser just two minutes after he
climbed off the bench.

The Ghana winger latched on to a stunning defence-splitter from fellow sub Joao
Carvalho before slamming home on 79 minutes.

Adomah's swoop came after Billy Bodin blasted North End in front minutes before
the interval.

Forest boss Sabri Lamouchi said: "It was a great finish from Albert, he'd just
gone on and took it so well.

"It wasn't easy against Preston, they're a very good team. So it was a good draw
for us in the end."

Preston dominated the first half and Wales striker Bodin broke the deadlock as
he smashed his side ahead on 40 Nottm
Forest.........................Preston....................................

minutes with a moment of individual brilliance at the back stick.

He saw his first point-blank strike blocked by Joe Worrall after wriggling into
space  but he made no mistake with a second thunderous hit.

Forest finally stepped up the tempo after the break and Adomah eventually
grabbed a share of the spoils.

Preston chief Alex Neil said: "It feels as if two points slipped away from us.

"We totally dominated the first and had four very good chances.

"But to be fair about it, Forest did scrappy bits better than we did in second
half."

headline: KAM 'N GET IT
content_plain:
KAMIL GROSICKI thwarted Millwall with a freakish leveller to bamboozle fellow
Pole Bartosz Bialkowski.

The Hull winger's arcing 35-yard free-kick on 18 minutes looped and then dropped
behind the Lions keeper and into the net.

It wiped out Jed Wallace's 10thminute penalty which was awarded after Jordy de
Wijs fouled Matt Smith.

The Tigers then had striker Josh Magennis sent off in added-time after a second
caution for a foul on Ryan Leonard.

It meant they played the final two minutes with nine men, having been down to
ten since the 78th minute when third substitute Jon Toral limped off after just
four minutes on the pitch.

Hull boss Grant McCann said: "Kamil Millwall....................................
1 Hull............................................1 will say he meant it. He did
one like in training on Friday and it stopped the session.

"This was a big point for us. Millwall is a tough place to come and we answered
a lot of questions. The penalty award was harsh but we showed what we are
about."

" Millwall boss Neil Harris said: wouldn't surprise me if Grosicki meant to
score. I've watched him for a while and he's shown that ability.

"This was disappointing. We dominated a lot of territory but just didn't deliver
the quality when we needed it."

Kevin Stewart could have won it for Hull but somehow missed an open goal from
just three yards out.

headline: Wayne's a number Swan hit
content_plain:
By MICHAEL MORGAN SUB Wayne Routledge SUPER SUB Wayne Routledge plundered a
dramatic lastgasp winner to send Swansea top of the Championship.

The winger, on for Yan Dhanda, fired home from close-range after the Leeds
defence had failed to clear Matt Grimes' 90th-minute ball into the box.

It was a strike that kept City's impressive unbeaten start to the season going
and came after they had taken a real pounding from the home side.

Even Swans boss Steve Cooper was honest enough to admit: "I don't know about it
being the perfect performance, but it was certainly the perfect result for us
away from home.

"We had to work very hard for it, that's for sure.

"But we defended properly and showed no fear.

"Every one of my players performed well and we tried to come here and win the
game.

"Now we can look forward to going into the international break on top of the
table.

"We've worked hard to get where we are, we are progressing as a team and I'm
very happy with that.

"But it's far too early to start making any predictions.

"There are still 40 league games to go and all we've done is give ourselves a
good start."

Leeds, who welcomed back skipper Liam Cooper after two weeks out with an ankle
injury, had won their previous ten home meetings with Swansea.

And victory number 11 looked on the cards as the Swans did well to survive a
battering in the opening 20 minutes.

Desperate defending coupled with much-needed slices of luck came to their
rescue.

The first chance came after only four minutes when Ezgjan Alioski cleverly
created space for himself before firing a rising drive from the edge of the box
inches over.

And it was the Macedonian who went close again when, from a Stuart Dallas feed
four minutes later, he let fly with a blistering drive which drew
Leeds......................................0
Swansea................................ 1 a smart save from Freddie Woodman.
Then, on 11 minutes, Patrick Bamford scuffed a close range shot after a
beautiful Pablo Hernandez corner.

Bamford was also out of luck when he arrowed a header inches wide from a
16th-minute Dallas corner.

The visitors did not get a sight of Kiko Casilla's goal until the 34thminute
when skipper Grimes smacked an angled free-kick from just outside the box into
the side-netting.

United then found top gear again, Dallas seeing a full-blooded volley bravely
blocked by Joe Rodon.

And, on the stroke of half-time, Cooper was unfortunate to plant a header
against the bar from another well-flighted Hernandez corner.

There was no let-up from Leeds after the break either.

Bamford was out of luck again with an angled shot on the turn which flew just
over with Woodman beaten.

City's rearguard was carved open for the umpteenth time three minutes later, but
Woodman did well to hold on to a 20-yard Hernandez scorcher.

Boss Marcelo Bielsa threw on striker Eddie Nketiah to replace Bamford on 61
minutes, and the new darling of the Leeds fans had to wait only four minutes
before getting his first sniff.

The Arsenal loanee had scored three times in four outings for the Yorkshire side
and looked on course for a fourth as he outpaced his markers.

But, this time, his radar was off as he blazed a 20-yard drive over.

Then came Routledge's smash and grab winner to knock Leeds off top spot and have
Bielsa bemoaning missed chances.

The Argentine said: "We had 12 or more goalscoring opportunities, 70 per cent of
the ball and good refereeing, so I'm not going to blame bad luck.

"The performance was very positive from each player.

"There was a good balance in the team but we just couldn't break down Swansea's
resistance.

"I am disappointed we are not going into the international break with a win but
I am happy with our start to the season."

headline: . BEN'S X-RATED
content_plain:
By ALAN NIXON BEN WILLIAMS got a straight red for an X-rated lunge  but it was
the only black mark for Barnsley.

Left-back Williams, 20, lunged in on Wigan sub Lee Evans in injury time.

He had already been booked and it sparked an ugly melee among the players before
Latics boss Paul Cook helped break it up.

The flashpoint came at the end of a nervy match that felt like the first
relegation six-pointer of the season.

But Barnsley boss Daniel Stendel was proud of his side  apart from that feisty
finish.

He said: "I'm very satisfied with my team. We played a very good away game and
give credit to Wigan's keeper."

The Tykes were far more dangerous throughout, with Mamadou Thiam forcing a
terrific save out of David Marshall from a 30-yard rocket.

Conor Chaplin pounced on a mistake by Latics defender Chey Dunkley  but he then
bravely blocked his shot.

And hitman Kieffer Moore found it hard going against ex-club Barnsley  and was
subbed early.

Tykes skipper Mike Bahre and Luke Thomas also went close before sub Patrick
Schmidt missed a sitter.

Latics hitman Joe Garner saw a late header brilliantly saved by keeper Bradley
Collins.

Boss Cook, whose side ended a fivegame losing streak, admitted: "We were
excellent defensively but going forward we must be more of a threat."

headline: Lennon fury at fan abuse
content_plain:
Rangers v Celtic Noon, Sky Sports Main Event NEIL LENNON lit the blue touchpaper
by slamming Rangers ahead of today's Old Firm clash at Ibrox.

The Celtic boss insists Gers chiefs should have apologised to him long ago for
the sectarian abuse aimed at him by fans.

He said: "It is embarrassing, but then sometimes people turn a blind eye to it
or go, 'it is only him, he can deal with it.'" Rangers have been hit by two Uefa
charges for racist behaviour over sectarian singing during their Europa League
qualifiers.

ds Lennon added: "It has always been that way so I can't imagine that changing
overnight."

Meanwhile, Rangers boss Steven Gerrard has demanded his side do not get carried
away with qualifying for the Europa group stage.

He said: "We are not in a position where we should be patting ourselves on the
back.

"The next challenge is can we go and win something. That is the hardest part."

Norwegian winger Mohamed Elyounoussi could make his debut for Celtic after
joining on a season-long loan from Southampton.

LIVINGSTON boss Gary Holt missed his side's 2-1 home win over ST MIRREN after a
weights session led to him being hospitalised.

Alan Lithgow and Lyndon Dykes scored for the hosts with Kyle Magennis replying.

headline: RAN 'EM RAGGED
content_plain:
MAN CITY.........4 De Bruyne 2; Aguero 42, 55; B Silva 79 BRIGHTON..........0
HOME comforts, seventh heaven and a century of smiles ... Sergio Aguero is
leaving City fans spoilt for choice this season.

Another double from the champions' deadliest marksman brought up 101 goals in
134 games under Pep Guardiola.

Not bad for a guy whose workrate the gaffer doubted so much at first that he
went out and spent £28.6million on Gabriel Jesus.

A double which made it 99 goals at the Etihad  a record just Wayne Rooney and
Thierry Henry, at Old Trafford and Highbury respectively, can better for Prem
goals at one venue.

A double which made it six in just four matches before the end of August for the
Argentine. And just for good measure, a double which means Aguero's last seven
shots on target have all ended in the back of the net.

All of which ensured a fixture that on paper always looked like one of the
biggest mismatches you'll see all year, did indeed end up as just that.

To be fair to all those who questioned Brighton's 33-1 odds  although there
were not too many outside of East Sussex  it did take just 69 seconds to see
why.

That is how long it took before City were ahead. That is how long before an
uphill task became an Everest-sized one, as the first real attack brought the
ultimate reward.

Indeed, you could have added a nought to Brighton's price and there still would
not have been many takers.

The worrying thing for them in that blink-of-an-eye opening was how easily they
were sliced open.

There was not a hint of onetouch, pinball-passing incision about it, either.

Just a ball down the line from Oleksandr Zinchenko, a pull back from David Silva
and Kevin De Bruyne, nonchalantly strolling into the box to sidefoot home from
eight yards.

Riyad Mahrez fired straight at keeper Mat Ryan after jinking impishly inside, De
Bruyne drilled a low fizzer a couple of feet wide and Aguero pulled another just
too far left.

Oh and in between times, Kyle Walker took out the frustration of his England
axing in a thunder-ing 50-50 with Dale Stephens that had 50,000-plus wincing.

Not half as much as they were ten minutes from the break, when Aymeric Laporte
flew into a challenge  although it was more like an assault  to stop Adam
Webster.

It certainly did that, earning a justifiable yellow card.

More worrying was the sight of Laporte leaving on a stretcher in agony, his
right knee banged horribly in the collision.

With John Stones sidelined and no new centre-back in the summer  Harry Maguire
anyone?  Pep will be praying the Frenchman is not too seriously injured.

But the way Laporte immediately flung his arm into the air for treatment and the
anguish on his face, made it look like we are talking months rather than weeks.

That brief Brighton foray was also a timely slap in the face that, for all the
dominance, a one-goal cushion still meant where there is life and all that. But
not for long. Not after Aguero pounced for the first time in the afternoon.

And if the opener was a pretty basic affair, this one had the Guardiola stamp
running through it from start to finish.

It began with Zinchenko to Nicolas Otamendi on halfway and continued with Walker
rolling a ball forwards from midfield  and that is when the gentle strokes
became rapier thrusts.

Mahrez backheeled telepathically to the right, De Bruyne delivered radar-like at
full pace and Aguero stepped back across before smashing into the roof of the
net.

It was magical, magnificent ... and effectively match-ending. Certainly as a
contest.

From that moment it became damage limitation, even if Fernandinho did have to
head one 50th-minute goalbound shot from Leandro Trossard to safety after a
Zinchenko rush of blood. Another shake-from-the-slumbers warning for City? It
may well have been because a couple of minutes later it was 3-0. Zinchenko,
spending more time in the opposition half than his own, fed Silva and when he
teed up Aguero, the curled edge-ofthe-box strike could not have been more
clinical.

De Bruyne went close to a stunning fourth when he volleyed a ball wide.

But they did not have long to wait for it. And in Bernardo Silva's case, just 17
seconds after stepping from the bench to replace namesake David.

His first burst into the box was on to Aguero's set-up, which he despatched
across Ryan into the far corner.

Two-horse race? If City keep up this sort of form, even that will be a tad
optimistic.

headline: PAUL TISDALE admitted MK [...]
content_plain:
Accrington........2 MK Dons............1 PAUL TISDALE admitted MK Dons did not
deserve anything against Stanley.

Kieran Agard slotted the visitors ahead after 18th minutes but Colby Bishop and
Mark Hughes replied after the break.

Boss Tisdale said: "We didn't deserve to get anything from the game. We must
play a lot better."

Bishop had a penalty saved and Rhys Healey had a late goal ruled out for offside
for MK.

Stanley No 2 Jimmy Bell said: "It's a big relief to get the first win. It's
massive for our confidence."

headline: Get Mad, get even
content_plain:
By NOEL RICHARD DARREN FERGUSON has revealed Sunderland could buy star man
Marcus Maddison  after he ripped the nine-man Black Cats apart.

Peterborough midfielder Maddison struck twice in either half  including a
30-yard free-kick  against the club he supports, either side of Josh Knight's
first Posh goal.

Discipline then cost the Wearsiders, who had Luke O'Nien sent off for a clash
with Ivan Toney, before Charlie Wyke got a second yellow card for a late foul.

Posh boss Ferguson said: "There's only really one club who might buy him  and
we've just played them.

"If they meet the release clause he can go."

Sunderland boss Jack Ross said: "It's a sore one for us but there are days where
you have to take your medicine.

"I don't think Luke's is a red card."
