headline: EXCITING VENTURE
content_plain:
THEY sang and sang and sang. And who could blame the visiting fans? From being
close to extinction Bolton are very much alive and kicking.

For much of this summer, their supporters have been on what looked like a death
march to a funeral pyre, the near-certain end of one of the founders of the
Football League.

History  and do not forget the four FA Cup final triumphs  counts for nothing
with hard-headed moneymen in the unyielding world of football finance.

But that solemn beat was changed dramatically on Wednesday when Football
Ventures took over with Nick Mason, Pink Floyd's percussionist, one of the
club's saviours. So despite the result, it was a carnival-like atmosphere at
Priestfield in the August sun with fans  smiling and laughing in their Bolton
shirts  showing no signs of fatigue following a monster drive from the
north-west.

Even new CEO Emma Beaugeard turned up wearing a black trackie with a Bolton
badge, smiling: "Oh my God, we're going to win  there are so many Bolton fans
here!" Trotters supporters have had so many false dawns since the club went into
administration in May they may have been sceptical about its survival and needed
proof yesterday.

That arrived at precisely 1.44pm when the coach carrying a firstteam squad
packed with fresh-faced kids turned into Redfern Avenue.

No one was happier than lifelong Bolton fan Alan Cook, a 46-year-old van driver
from Runcorn.

He said: "I never thought I'd see this day. Truthfully, I thought we were buried
like Bury at the start of the week.

"I was sat in front of the television crying my eyes out. That's why this game
is so emotional."

The task now ahead of them is a monstrous one though, bottom of League One on
minus 11 points having now lost three successive games 5-0. London-based Bolton
fan Alex Adamson, 30, said: "If we stay up by the skin of our teeth, I'll be
over the moon. But it's going to be difficult."

Bolton were given a warm welcome by Gillingham with owner Paul Scally and
manager Steve Evans writing generous words in the matchday programme.

Even the PA announcer said how great it was to see their 740 supporters in the
Brian Moore Stand, leading to spontaneous applause from home fans.

Men against boys is an old football cliche but it really was yesterday, with
Bolton starting three 18-year-olds  Ronan Darcy, Jordan Boon and Eddie Brown.

They then brought on sub Callum King-Harmes, even younger at 17.

Exactly 27 minutes into the game, the ground erupted into applause for Bury,
expelled from the Football League on August 27, with fans chanting "F*** EFL,
f*** EFL".

Gills went in two up at the break with goals from Connor Ogilvie and Olly Lee,
the son of former England star Robert, who is on loan from Hearts.

Brandon Hanlan added a third in the 54th minute before Lee scored again and Boon
netted an own goal. Bolton had their chances, but Brown could not get his shot
away after rounding the keeper and then one of their veterans, NINETEEN-YEAR-OLD
Dennis Politic, forced a smart save from a free-kick.

Jack Hobbs even headed against the bar in the 86th minute.

Former Rochdale boss Keith Hill was appointed as the Trotters' new manager an
hour-and-a-half after this defeat.

Jimmy Phillips, Wanderers' caretaker chief, knew a permanent appointment was
needed.

The proud Boltonian put the loss into perspective, saying: "It's tragic what
happened to Bury so I'm delighted we still have a club.

"Yes, it's been difficult with the results but we have a club we can support and
work for. We need to get some senior players into the building who've got big
hearts and are up for a fight.

"We've got 39 matches to play and need to win four or five more games than the
others. It's most certainly achievable although a tough task."

Gillingham boss Evans added: "I started at Bolton as a 15-year-old. We needed to
go out and produce a performance.

"From ten minutes to 75, some of our football was outstanding."

So the good news from Priestfield? Bolton are off life-support.

And the bad news? There was no bad news despite the thrashing, only cheering,
clapping and laughing.

"We love you, Bolton, we do" they sang at the end. And they meant every word.

headline: TYLER WALKER has been involved [...]
content_plain:
TYLER WALKER has been involved in five goals in his last four league games for
Lincoln (4 goals, 1 assist)  his longest run of goal involvements in
consecutive games in his EFL career.

headline: IN netting yesterday against Southend, [...]
content_plain:
IN netting yesterday against Southend, Rochdale's Ian Henderson scored his 100th
league goal for the club in 268 games.

headline:
Southend.......................... 0 Rochdale...........................3
UNDER-FIRE Southend boss [...]
content_plain:
Southend.......................... 0 Rochdale...........................3
UNDER-FIRE Southend boss Kevin Bond has vowed to fight on.

The Shrimpers' defeat at Roots Hall means they have lost all six of their League
One games this season.

But Bond said: "I'm not thinking of my position. I'm thinking of Southend, the
result and what we might be able to do it about it."

Jimmy Keohane's low cross was fired home by Ian Henderson from six yards on 35
minutes. Two minutes later Callum Camps diverted Rhys Norrington-Davies' centre
to Aaron Morley, who finished confidently.

Camps added a third on 77 minutes and Dale boss Brian Barry-Murphy said: "The
intensity was spot on."

headline: Danny delight
content_plain:
Lincoln.................... 2 Fleetwood..............0 DANNY COWLEY was
delighted to see Lincoln end a run of three defeats.

Two first-half goals from Tyler Walker put the Imps back in the top two.

Gaffer Cowley saw his battlers give Premier League Everton a scare before going
down 4-2 late on in the Carabao Cup on Wednesday.

He said: "We expended so much energy and emotion against Everton, which makes
this win even better.

"It was such a focused and disciplined performance against a good side.

"We had to be compact and didn't have a lot of possession but we still managed
to limit them to very few chances."

Walker's diving header from Harry Toffolo's pinpoint cross set the hosts on
their way, before Callum Connolly played the striker in againt two minutes
later.

Frustrated Fleetwood boss Joey Barton said: "The lads shot themselves in the
foot and that's the reality.

"I thought we dominated but they took their chances."

headline: Nigel chuffed
content_plain:
Burton..................... 2 Bristol Rovers.......0 NIGEL CLOUGH praised
Burton's defensive strength as they beat Bristol Rovers with two late sucker
punches.

Lucas Akins and Ryan Edwards scored to give Albion a first home win of the
season.

And though Clough's men were under the cosh for long spells the Pirates could
not break them down.

The Albion boss said: "We soaked up pressure and defended brilliantly.

"Because of how we defended, we earned the chance to win."

Tyler Smith fired wide for Rovers before Burton's Liam Boyce's was denied by
Bristol keeper Anssi Jaakkola.

Luke Leahy, Alfie Kilgour, Ollie Clarke and Smith all went close as the visitors
dominated after the break.

But Akins slotted home with three minutes to go.

And Edwards sealed the win in stoppage time after a brilliant counter attack.

Disappointed Rovers chief Graham Coughlan said: "Burton took their chances, we
didn't. It's a sickener."

headline: Gnan's house
content_plain:
Blackpool............... 1 Portsmouth............1 ARMAND GNANDUILLET'S slick
finish earned Blackpool a share of the spoils and extended their unbeaten start
to the season.

Seasiders boss Simon Grayson could not fault the application of his players on a
day when both sides traded chances in a cracker.

He said: "My players gave it everything. They deserve lots of credit because
Portsmouth are a really good side. "On another day we might have gone on and
nicked it but a point each was probably about right."

Marcus Harness struck for Pompey in the 17th minute, curling into the corner
after pouncing on a loose ball.

And it was almost 2-0 when John Marquis missed by a whisker.

The hosts grabbed their point when Gnanduillet stooped to head home after 58
minutes.

Pompey boss Kenny Jackett said: "It's another point closer to where we want to
be. But we had enough chances to have taken the game away from Blackpool."

headline: Wimbledon........... 0 Wycombe.............. 0 GARETH AINSWORTH hopes [...]
content_plain:
Wimbledon........... 0 Wycombe.............. 0 GARETH AINSWORTH hopes he can
break Wycombe's Wimbledon hoodoo one day.

The Chairboys are winless at Kingsmeadow since 2008.

Wanderers are unbeaten in six league games but boss Ainsworth moaned: "I've
broken a lot of records here but unfortunately the away one at Wimbledon still
stands.

"Hopefully we can come back one day and put that one to bed."

Dons boss Wally Downes said: "We're always up for the battle and managed to keep
going until the end."

headline: Slips hits Fan
content_plain:
Oxford..................... 3 Coventry.................3 FANKATY DABO scored TWO
own goals as Oxford pulled off a second late comeback of the week.

The U's scored twice from the 87th minute on Tuesday as they dumped Millwall out
of the Carabao Cup.

Yesterday they left it until the 95th minute as Coventry defender Dabo turned in
Elliott Moore's strike.

Coventry boss Mark Robins said: "Dabo will deal with it and hopefully will get
himself in better positions to deal with crosses."

Oxford, trailing to Zain Westbrooke's free-kick and Matty Godden's header,
pulled one back through Jamie Mackie's volley.

They levelled on 85 minutes when a stretching Dabo steered Chris Cadden's
farpost cross into his own net. Callum O'Hare's addedtime shot off the bar gave
Coventry the lead back, only for Dabo's second own goal.

Oxford boss Karl Robinson said: "My players gave everything and it's gutting we
finished with a point."

headline: Rotherham.............1 Tranmere.................1 MICKY MELLON was [...]
content_plain:
Rotherham.............1 Tranmere.................1 MICKY MELLON was proud of
Rovers' fight after Stefan Payne's injury-time equaliser.

Rotherham's Ben Wiles thumped in what looked like the winner on 73 minutes.

But five minutes into injury time, Payne bundled in from close-range after a
goal-line scramble.

Boss Mellon said: "It was important we got our rewards.

"The boys left nothing on the pitch and kept fighting."

Millers chief Paul Warne added: "We are disappointed with the equaliser and will
have to learn from it."

headline: SERG101
content_plain:
SERG101 Aguero's tonderful for Pep Manchester City..............4
Brighton..............................0 By PHIL THOMAS SERGIO AGUERO made it a
century of goals for Pep Guardiola as Manchester City dished out a clinical
lesson in finishing. Aguero struck twice to rack up 101 goals under the Spaniard
and take his tally to half a dozen after just four games this season. And that
saw him equal a Premier League best haul for August  level with former City
striker Edin Dzeko, who did it in 2011, and Blackburn hotshot Chris Sutton from
1997. Manager Guardiola purred: "Sergio has scored goals with Argentina, in Turn
to Page 3 TON OF FUN ... Aguero hails his second goal while (below) he scores
his first to make it 100 goals under boss Pep Guardiola MAN CITY GOALS UNDER PEP
(all competitions) Sergio Aguero 101 Raheem Sterling 64 Gabriel Jesus 46 Leroy
Sane 39 David Silva 28 Kevin De Bruyne 26 Bernardo Silva 23 Ilkay Gundogan 17
Riyad Mahrez 12 Fernandinho 9 SERG From Page 1 England with all the managers
he's had, with the national team. "He's a special talent and I love that from
day one he has tried to do it. "We changed many things, how we wanted him to
play but from day one I have been delighted with his commitment. "There are no
complaints. Of course we need his goals, everyone knows it but even days he
doesn't, with commitment like this there can be nothing to say. I'm so happy for
him and the team." Pep  who along with his players wore black armbands in
tribute to former Barcelona team-mate Luis Enrique's nineyear- old daughter,
Xana, who died from bone cancer this week  was also keen to praise Brighton for
trying to play football against the champions. He added: "The result was 4-0 but
the performance wasn't because they did really well. "Few teams come here and
play with that courage. "The difference was, as I have said many times, the
players we have got up front. "Managers like Graham Potter are very good for
football. "The credit is to Brighton. When I said they were good some people
didn't believe me. "They created some problems that usually we don't have."
Seagulls chief Potter agreed with Guardiola's appraisal and said: "The result
isn't something we enjoy but the performance was one of real courage. "Whatever
you do here it's very difficult. We just wanted to try to be ourselves and test
ourselves against the very best. "It's only our fourth game together and we
thought it was a chance to learn and develop. We can take a lot from the
performance." POTTER ... proud of his team

headline: Player welfare ain't so Super p
subheadline:
Phil Thomas NO-NONSENSE ATTITUDE AND GRITTY OPINION NONSENSE ATTITUDE AND GRITTY
OPINION
content_plain:
THOSE in high places at the Super League are constantly telling us player
welfare is their No 1 priority.

how rity.

Ss ru It would have been nice if  when they had the chance to prove as much 
they had done so.

uch ny n-b There certainly weren't too many at Warrington who reckon their
well-being was high on the list this week.

n r the rsday, Last Saturday, the Wolves won Challenge Cup at Wembley. On
Thursday, boss Steve Price (right) and Co were back in Super League action,
battling to stay in second place with a game at Salford.

The match, originally for today, had been brought forward 72 hours so it could
be shown on Sky and Wire made six changes. Fair enough, Sky argue they pump a

cth can the un ue nd But just for once, could Super League bosses not have dug

headline: Klopp Kop-out no big shock
subheadline:
Phil Thomas NO-NONSENSE ATTITUDE AND GRITTY OPINION NONSENSE ATTITUDE AND GRITTY
OPINION
content_plain:
WHY all the hoo-ha over Jurgen Klopp suggesting he may take a sabbatical after
he's been at Liverpool for seven years? Firstly, that isn't until 2022. That's
longer than 14 of the current Premier League bosses have been in situ. Secondly,
Klopp (left) has always said seven years is his optimum time at a club.

It's how long he was at Mainz and how long he was at Borussia Dortmund, so what
makes the Scousers think it would be any different on Merseyside? And one more
thing. Another three years would surely put the finishing touches to Steven
Gerrard's managerial apprenticeship.

headline: Gaffe just what Lyon deserved
subheadline:
Phil Thomas NO-NONSENSE ATTITUDE AND GRITTY OPINION NONSENSE ATTITUDE AND GRITTY
OPINION
content_plain:
FOR every hero there is invariably a villain ... and sometimes watching them
squirm can be almost as enjoyable.

Yes, Ben Stokes' Superman impression at Headingley was magnificent.
Edge-ofthe-seat sport at its very best.

Watching those few hours in West Yorkshire was truly spellbinding.

The fact it came after Nathan Lyon missed a simple run-out chance which would
have seen Australia not only win the Test but The Ashes? You couldn't put a
price on that.

Lyon (right) is the Aussies' champion sledger. The man who said he wanted to
finish careers.

How fittingly ironic, then, that for all the wickets he has taken, blowing
victory for his nation will be the most memorable moment of his own.

One question over Stokes and his celebration meal, when he spent £57 in
McDonald's. Why did he have to pay in the first place? The least he and his
team-mates deserved was a free quarter-pounder.

headline: Stags find instant karma
subheadline:
Phil Thomas NO-NONSENSE ATTITUDE AND GRITTY OPINION NONSENSE ATTITUDE AND GRITTY
OPINION
content_plain:
Stags find instant karma footballing world feels for Bury  OF COURSE the whole
of the  that goes without saying.

But for all the sympathy in their direction, spare a second to imagine what
they're thinking at Mansfield.

When Bury won promotion last season under boss Ryan Lowe (right), thanks in no
small part to signing players they couldn't afford, the Stags missed out by one
place.

Doubtless no one associated with Mansfield is taking any joy in events at Gigg
Lane. But the word "karma" may well have flashed across a few minds.

headline: WEST HAM are unbeaten in [...]
content_plain:
WEST HAM are unbeaten in their last nine home games against Norwich in all
competitions (W5 D4).

headline: Special Glum
subheadline:
Phil Thomas NO-NONSENSE ATTITUDE AND GRITTY OPINION NONSENSE ATTITUDE AND GRITTY
OPINION GRUMPY SPURS BOSS IS TURNING INTO THE...
content_plain:
FOR more than two years he has been the poster boy of football managers.

To fellow bosses he was the role model who set the example they all wanted to
follow.

To every club owner, chairman and chief executive he was the perfect man to have
in charge.

No transfer kitty? No problem. Certainly no whinging and whining about trying to
do the job with one hand tied behind your back.

Just heads down, work with what you've got. Players who would run through walls
for the cause. And results that exceeded even the most hard-to-please fan's
demands.

In short, Mauricio Pochettino was the manager everyone  Manchester City and
Liverpool aside  wanted at their club.

For the rest, though, they could only dream of a gaffer like that. And all that
without even having a home ground to call his own for 12 months.

So when Pochettino led Tottenham to the Champions League final, everyone
believed it was just the beginning.

The platform which, with a decent summer budget and base that could become a
fortress, would see the promise of silverware turn into reality at last.

Only in the three months since that night in Madrid, something has happened to
Pochettino.

Something that is steadily seeing him morph into one of his own managerial
heroes. And not in a good way.

For Mauricio has gradually started to sound increasingly like Jose Mourinho.
Only not the witty, knock-em-dead Special One of the early years.

More the grumbling, groaning, never-satisfied curmudgeon of recent seasons.

Consider these utterings of the past couple of months or so ... starting with a
dig at the players for not showing enough desire.

Admitting he had no idea which players would still be there after the transfer
window. How that was making him feel vulnerable.

Insisting that it would be more accurate to call him the coach, not the manager,
because he wasn't the one where the buck stopped on transfers. All shocking
domestic form under the carpet.

Indeed, since February, Spurs have been the 12th best team in the Premier
League. They've won only six of 17 games.

Had Lucas Moura not hit that last-second winner at the Amsterdam Arena, perhaps
there would have been doubts over Pochettino's future from the other side.

On Friday there was another twist, when the odds on his leaving Tottenham were
slashed.

Some even suggested he would walk after today's North London derby.

That, however unhappy he may be, is highly unlikely. Not less than 16 months
into a new five-year contract.

But that's not to say it won't happen a little further down the line. Maybe even
before Christmas. Certainly if another door was to swing open.

Only last week Poch was stressing how exciting it is to work with young players.
Most assumed he meant helping bring through the next raft of rookies at
Tottenham.

Then again, wouldn't that be even more the case at Old Trafford? Just a thought
...

a classic Mourinho. Only this time none of them were. Every one was Pochettino.

If they weren't said by a man who had an agenda, they did nothing to quieten
those convinced otherwise.

to If they were said by a man who was trying to manipulate the media, trying to
get a message across in a "poor me" kind of way, then it was all pretty
cumbersome.

For while Mourinho at his peak could manipulate the media, and have them dancing
to his tune without some of them actually realising they'd been drawn in, Poch
isn't quite as cute.

of Just why he has gone from Mr Happy to Mr Grumpy quite so quickly is the
head-scratcher.

.Obviously last week's loss to Newcastle, who you wouldn't have fancied to beat
an egg to that point, didn't help.

Neither did the saga over Christian Eriksen's future.

But all of a sudden Pochettino has a longer face than Tiger Roll. Half empty has
definitely taken over from half full.

Maybe we should have seen it coming. After all, that European adventure brushed
some pretty

headline: SEBSATION
content_plain:
way to greatness WEST HAM....... .2 Haller 24; Yarmolenko 56
NORWICH............0 IT does not take a lot to gain legendary status at West Ham
these days and Sebastien Haller is already well on his way to becoming an East
End icon.

The £42million Frenchman is only the fourth player in the club's history to
score three goals in his first three Premier League games.

He follows Trevor Sinclair, Ian Wright and Demba Ba.

And if he can keep up this form for the rest of the season, they will probably
build a statue of him at the London Stadium.

Haller's 24th-minute strike came hot on the heels of last week's winning double
at Watford.

Andriy Yarmolenko's first goal since last September confirmed Norwich's 19th
consecutive trip to the capital without a Premier League victory.

Yet Haller might want to think twice about going to Norfolk again any time soon
after his reckless late challenge forced defender Christoph Zimmermann out of
the game.

West Ham's record signing revealed this week he rejected a move to Norwich after
visiting the city in 2016. And the Canaries' loss is proving to be West Ham's
gain after Haller's flying start to life in England.

Yet it was not all sweetness and light for the Hammers and manager Manuel
Pellegrini was far from impressed by his team's early efforts.

There was a real lack of intensity from his players as they allowed Norwich to
dominate possession and establish a toehold on the game.

Norwich winger Todd Cantwell was able to slalom through three half-hearted
challenges during one particularly slack passage of play.

gamesnot In fact West Ham were so poor they were forced to resort to
gamesmanship when Yarmolenko was guilty of a shameful dive under Cantwell's
challenge in the box.

Ref Paul Tierney failed to take any action, which allowed the winger to go down
easily again with barely any contact from Max Aarons.

But Norwich were unable to take advantage of their early control and gradually
conceded the initiative.

Felipe Anderson's charge on goal demanded a heroic last-ditch challenge from
Zimmermann.

But that was to be the towering German's last meaningful contribution to the
game before being taken out by Haller's lunge, which again went unpunished by
Tierney.

And Zimmermann was still feeling the effects of that challenge when Haller found
space in the penalty area to fire West Ham ahead from Arthur Masuaku's inviting
cross.

Even that breakthrough goal could not settle Hammers' nerves and they were lucky
not to concede a 31stminute equaliser following more unconvincing defending.

Unfortunately for Norwich, Cantwell was millimetres too short to make a clean
connection with Aaron's cross and headed a glorious opportunity over from a yard
out.

And any thoughts of a second-half comeback were dismissed when Yarmolenko put
the game beyond doubt in the 56th minute.

The lively Ukrainian certainly did not look like someone still finding his way
back after ten months on the sidelines with a torn Achilles.

He pounced on Cantwell's loose control to tee up Mark Noble and when the ball
came back to him off Ben Godfrey, he smashed home beyond keeper Tim Krul's dive.

That was too much for the visitors to bear and Daniel Farke will be concerned at
how quickly his players allowed their heads to drop, with only Krul saving them
from a real beating late on.

headline: Rookie errors
content_plain:
Chelsea..........2 Abraham 19, 42 Sheff Utd.......2 Robinson 46; Zouma (og) 89
FRANK LAMPARD watched the youngest Chelsea team in Premier League history blow a
two-goal lead at Stamford Bridge.

And even worse last night the baby-faced Blues would struggle to buy a beer in a
supermarket to drown their sorrows.

A starting XI with an average age of 24 years and 158 days fell foul of the
under-25 rule in many ways.

Not only would they need ID to get booze but they also look worryingly immature
at times.

The team which trudged off the pitch at the final whistle included pint-sized
midfielder Billy Gilmour, 18, who even if he did have proof of age would
struggle to see over the counter.

Two goals from in-form Tammy Abraham gave them a cushion from which to go on and
build a solid victory. Yet once Sheffield United pulled a goal back less than a
minute into the second half, Chelsea crumbled.

Perhaps it is because the team is so young the boys out there in blue have such
short attention spans.

Boss Lampard's bold policy of giving the kids a chance is to be applauded but it
came at a hefty price yesterday.

He was denied a first home win since taking over as boss in the summer.

And for the second game in a row at home he has looked on as his rookies wobbled
after getting themselves in the driving seat.

Bizarrely it was two of the wiser heads who contributed to their downfall.

Skipper Cesar Azpilicueta allowed himself to be mugged on the edge of his box
for the equaliser then Kurt Zouma's outstretched boot scored the calamitous own
goal which totally transformed the mood.

Even with Chelsea 2-1 up and clinging on, the punters were loving the
electricity in the air as a team of home-grown players were rocking and rolling
in a game full of ebbs and flows.

When Lampard brought on Gilmour  born in the same June week in 2001 his manager
signed for Chelsea  for his debut alongside Michy Batshuayi, it looked like
another brave masterstroke.

Today it looks like a huge blunder from a man who is himself a rookie in terms
of management  this being only his second season as a coach.

The decision to drop Denmark star Andreas Christensen and replace him with
Fikayo Tomori was a surprise one. Replacing a 23-year-old with somebody two
years younger was enough to nudge the average age of the starting XI down to a
record in the modern game.

Tomori's one and only previous appearance for the first team was as a sub in a
meaningless run out against Leicester three years ago.

Without a shot on target in the first half from the visitors, there was little
Tomori could do in order to impress and stake a claim to keep his place.

But disaster struck just 50 seconds into the second half when the Blades hit
back with a goal to remind everyone that Lampard's fledgling Chelsea are a long
way from a polished team.

Taking the return pass from his throw in on the left flank, Enda Stevens drifted
through the Chelsea defence, stopping en route to nutmeg Azpilicueta.

From the by-line he cut the ball back where striker Callum Robinson stood
unopposed and proceeded to hook the ball into the opposite corner of the net
from eight yards out.

For a long time now Chelsea have been wobbly. This is not all Lampard's fault.

But he must be concerned at the lack of mental strength to chuck away a game
against a spirited team but one which should have been rolled over.

Abraham grabbed the first goal on 19 minutes after it had been pawed clear by
Blades keeper Dean Henderson.

His second was another example of his striking instincts, capitalising on a
horrendous mix-up between Jack O'Connell and George Baldock at the back before
firing in.

Henderson made a great save to deny Abraham a hat-trick and Kepa Arrizabalaga
saved a longrange bullet from Ollie Norwood. But amid chaos in the Chelsea back
four, Zouma stumbled as he tried to defend a cross into the box and the
Frenchman poked the ball into his own net.

headline: Farke in rage at Zim foul
content_plain:
ANGRY Norwich boss Daniel Farke hit out at referee Paul Tierney after skipper
Christoph Zimmermann left West Ham on crutches.

The German defender suffered ankle damage from a late challenge by West Ham
striker Sebastien Haller, who then scored his team's opening goal.

Farke complained: "I am a big fan of VAR but this was a perfect example that it
does not always work.

"We were dominating but then there was a tackle against my centreback when the
ball was three yards away.

"But there was no card and not even a free-kick. Minutes later Zimmermann was
not able to sprint back because he was injured and their player scores the goal
which changed the whole game.

"The outcome was my player was on his way to hospital and their player was on
the shoulders of his team."

West Ham manager Manuel Pellegrini said: "It was a good performance. We could
have won by more but their keeper saved four or five clear chances.

"Haller is not just a striker. He is always working and supporting the midfield.
He will keep improving."

Pellegrini was unable to confirm reports that striker Javier Hernandez has made
a transfer request to rush through an £8million move to Sevilla before Monday's
European deadline.

He said: "We have rumours Sevilla want him and I expect the situation will be
best for the player and the club."

headline: Chris cross words cut Blades to bits
content_plain:
CHRIS WILDER revealed his half-time hairdryer shock tactic worked a treat in
earning Sheffield United a point.

The Blades boss (below) went for keeper Dean Henderson and striker Callum
Robinson over their first-half performances.

And it prompted the perfect response as 22-yearold Henderson pulled off a
brilliant save and Robinson scored the first goal which put United on their way
to a battling draw.

Wilder said: "I smashed Dean at half-time because he should have done better and
was kicking it all over the place. He's a young man learning his trade and we
feel he should have done better for the goal.

"And that is the character of the group  the two individuals. Dean kept us in
the game with an unbelievable save and for Callum to score just after half-time
shows what he is about.

"To come roaring back hopefully gives us an enormous amount of confidence and
belief going forward."

Henderson's instinctive save denied Tammy Abraham a hat-trick and acted as a
turning point in the game.

Chelsea defender Kurt Zouma's last-minute own goal put the seal on a gutsy
fightback.

Delighted Wilder said: "We deserved something from our second-half performance.

"The players need to believe more.

I understand their apprehension but we deserve to be in this division  the
coaching staff believe in the players more than they do at times."

headline: CONKED OUT
content_plain:
SOUTHAMPTON....1 Vestergaard 58 Man United.........1 James 10 IT is the first
day of autumn and Manchester United are out of the title race.

Not that they were ever in it, of course.

But with seven points dropped in the first four games, the reality of the
challenge facing boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has been laid bare while most of the
conkers are still on the trees.

It does not really matter that United probably deserved to beat ten-man
Southampton.

They created plenty of chances to score after Kevin Danso's sending off 17
minutes from time left Saints clinging on for a point.

In the end, though, United were just not good enough.

They failed to build on Daniel James' early goal, allowed the home side back
into the game before half-time and then conceded an equaliser to centrehalf
Jannik Vestergaard (left). A tactical switch which moved the infuriating Paul
Pogba into an advanced position, that he felt more worthy of his talents, might
have paid dividends on another day.

United did not have much luck, but how much do you deserve when you are asking a
17-year-old striker to save the day with eight minutes to go? Mason Greenwood
may go on to be a big player for United and his effort produced the best of a
number of decent saves by home keeper Angus Gunn.

But Solskjaer's side overall look short on quality and ideas, as well as goals.

That 4-0 romp against Chelsea just three weekends ago feels like an awfully long
time ago. Offloading your melu nter ment egy, uled two most senior strikers 
RomLukaku and Alexis Sanchez to InMilan  without signing a replacemalready
looked an interesting strateeven before a thigh injury ruAnthony Martial out of
this game.

alty atic, tive Not having a designated No 1 penataker was also proving
problemawith spot-kicks missed in consecutgames.

ving ning wed But one new United policy  givthe ball to £18million summer
signJames at every opportunity  showsigns of paying off early on.

The Welshman, 21, seemed to hrescued a point for United at home Crystal Palace
seven days earlier wave e to with an excellent late goal.

utes was His second strike in 11 minuof Premier League football wanother beauty.

SOUTHAMPTON had pressed hard their attacking third but were slow close James
down when he collectedsimple pass from Scott McTominay.

in w to d a. how firr of He still had a bit to do, but hwell he did it, cutting
inside and ing a fierce shot into the top corner Gunn's net after just ten
minutes. 'James, James will tear you apart again,' sang the away fans, which is
quite a tribute.

The chant, to the tune of the Joy Division hit 'Love Will Tear Us Apart', is
most associated with United legend Ryan Giggs, the most decorated player in
English football history.

James will not win anywhere near as much however long he stays at Old Trafford,
but he is the main reason to be cheerful so far this season.

Moments later the Southampton keeper easily gathered a tamer effort from the
Wales international.

But Gunn had to be alert to beat out a snapshot from James midway through the
half.

In that spell, James was very much the focal point, more so than England
centre-forward Marcus Rashford, but United's overall performance was also
promising.

The energy level was mostly high and Solskjaer's side showed purpose and
ambition whenever they had the ball, looking dangerous from almost every attack.
At the other end, the visiting defence was rarely troubled after Sofiane Boufal
had sent an eighth-minute shot just wide of David De Gea's right-hand post.

Southampton huffed and puffed but United's wall, with ten men retreating behind
the ball when necessary, was made of brick.

The home team were missing the in-form Nathan Redmond through injury and without
him they seemed to lack the guile to find a way through or around it.

United's only concern at that stage was how Pogba had seemed to start losing
interest, as well as possession, in the latter stages of the opening 45 minutes.

A big part of the reason Southampton gained the upper hand was Pogba's
carelessness with the ball.

Sure enough, within ten minutes of the restart Che Adams had fluffed Saints'
best chance of the game.

They need not have worried, the equaliser soon arrived.

De Gea had just kept out a Danny Ings header from a James Ward-Prowse cross.

But the United keeper was helpless when Danso swung the ball back in and 6ft 6in
Vestergaard outjumped Victor Lindelof to nod home on 58 minutes.

Something needed to change, so Solskjaer threw on Jesse Lingard, who had been
dropped to the bench, and asked Pogba to move forward.

When Danso was shown a second yellow card for a challenge on McTominay, United
had 17 minutes to save themselves from an earlyseason crisis.

Gunn saved from James and Rashford, Lingard went close and then Greenwood forced
the Saints No 1 into his best stop of the game.

The Saints survived four minutes of stoppage time pretty easily.

After three wins in his last 13 Premier League games, how long will even
fan-favourite Solskjaer last if things don't improve soon? Tweet @DanKing_1974

SHEFFIELD UNITED have won five points from their four Premier League games this
season. Only in 1993-94 (6) have the Blades had a better start in the division.

headline: LEICESTER'S Jamie Vardy has been [...]
content_plain:
LEICESTER'S Jamie Vardy has been directly involved in 14 goals in his 14 Premier
League games under Brendan Rodgers (12 goals, 2 assists).

headline: I'M confused as to why [...]
content_plain:
I'M confused as to why Fabian Schar's goal was allowed to stand.

I've said before Law 12 concerning handling the ball is an ass  but we want
consistency from VAR.

How was Isaac Hayden's use of the arm in the build-up to Schar's strike any
different from goals ruled out in other games? Four weeks into the season and
already we have inconsistency in decision-making by VAR on accidental handball
when a goal is scored.

headline: VARD 2 BEAT
content_plain:
LEICESTER........3 Vardy 12, 73; Tielemans 41 B'mouth..........1 C Wilson 15
VINTAGE Jamie Vardy magic left Leicester third in the table and unbeaten ahead
of the international break.

He grabbed a double as the Foxes underlined their credentials as serious
contenders to break up the top six this season.

Brendan Rodgers' side have won two and drawn two of their opening four games and
the elated boss gathered his players near the centre circle for a celebratory
huddle.

Bournemouth, meanwhile, were left in a muddle.

They dropped down to 15th as their defence imploded with a performance so
alarming that it will raise questions as to why England's latest recruit, Tyrone
Mings, was allowed to leave for Aston Villa during the summer.

At both ends of the park some of the defending bordered on farcical, if you were
being kind.

Take Leicester's opener after 12 minutes. If there is one thing everyone knows
about the Foxes it is that they have a useful striker. Name of Vardy  you may
have heard of him.

Legend has it he is so quick he can switch off his bedroom light and be tucked
up under the covers before it's dark.

Now fast forward to match day when he pumps himself up by swigging down a
minimum three cans of a well-known energy drink. Suddenly he is a whippet  with
wings!

So how could Bournemouth's dozy defenders fail to fathom it was a bad idea to
leave Vardy acres of space to run into behind them? Come to think of it, why did
Chris Mepham and Steve Cook fail to cut out the danger at source when they
watched Ben Chilwell's hoofed pass travel fully 50 yards towards them? Somehow
neither thought to apply the simple header required to defend their line and
suddenly Vardy was off haring past them.

Naturally, he arrived at the ball first. One bounce off the turf and then a
sublime lob with the outside of his right boot sent it sailing over Aaron
Ramsdale's head from 25 yards and into the corner of the net.

However, three minutes later Leicester were at it as they gifted the Cherries a
speedy equaliser.

Adam Smith found Harry Wilson with a throw-in and the winger moved the ball on
to Ryan Fraser.

The Scotland international ran at Ricardo Pereira, looked up and threaded a cute
ball behind Jonny Evans to Callum Wilson.

Caglar Soyuncu watched it happen  but somehow did not think to match the
England striker's bread-and-butter run into the channel. That gave Callum Wilson
the space he needed to dink the ball beyond Kasper Schmeichel and in off the
post for his first goal of the season  a decent way to mark his Three Lions
call-up.

Leicester responded as James Maddison flashed a header just wide from a Marc
Albrighton cross, before Soyuncu almost made amends for his howler by curling a
shot just over.

And the Foxes retook the lead just before half-time.

You guessed it, the Cherries' defence was caught napping when Vardy turned
provider, brushing past a powder-puff challenge from Cook to roll the ball
across the face of goal.

Youri Tielemans nipped in to flick it home off the inside of the far post.

After the break, VAR roared into action when Belgium midfielder Tielemans was
guilty of a horrific challenge on Callum Wilson, which saw him rake his studs
down the striker's ankle.

In fairness to Tielemans he had looked to be protecting the ball  and VAR
agreed that it was not a malicious challenge  although he was still a lucky boy
to stay on the park.

Ironically, he could not even be yellow carded, as VAR can only check for
red-card offences.

Callum Wilson's day was going from the sublime to the ridiculous and he was
booked for a dive in the box before Leicester put the game beyond his team with
a third.

Maddison tried a clever stepover in the box to set up Vardy  but Mepham read
the danger and intercepted.

In keeping with the day, he then dallied and Maddison poked the ball away from
his toes to Tielemans, who slipped a pass to Vardy on his left.

The hitman, 32, applied the finish, drilling the ball home from close range.

Job done and Bournemouth undone.

How boss Eddie Howe must now regret selling England new boy Mings to Villa.

headline: It's a Brucie (VAR) bonus
content_plain:
NEWCASTLE............1 Schar 41 Watford.................1 Hughes 2 STEVE BRUCE
was bemoaning bad luck all week after an injury crisis and penalty shootout
defeat.

Well, yesterday, the Newcastle boss was given a huge helping HAND to pick up his
first point at St James' Park.

Toon, beaten by Leicester on spotkicks in Wednesday's Carabao Cup, were behind
to Watford after 78 SECONDS.

Yet they levelled through Fabian Schar after an accidental handball by Isaac
Hayden  which VAR missed.

Under new laws, the goal should not have stood, like Gabriel Jesus' 'winner' for
Manchester City against Tottenham two weeks ago.

That was ruled out because Aymeric Laporte handled in the build-up.

So this was a Brucie bonus for Toon, even though they should have made it
back-to-back league wins following Sunday's shock victory at Tottenham.

The point lifts Newcastle out of the bottom three ahead of a tricky trip to
Liverpool in a fortnight's time.

Asked about their lucky break, boss Bruce said: "I haven't seen it but we are
going to have many VAR issues. I am not sure I am a big lover of it."

Winless Watford remain rock bottom  but are at least now off the mark.

Boss Javi Gracia was under fire following six league losses in a row, three of
which came at the end of last term.

And the Spaniard had a good moan at officials at the end, but even he was not
certain if VAR got the call wrong.

MATCH He said: "Maybe when the ball is falling it touched his hand. But I didn't
see it."

You fear for Gracia's men in their next two games against Arsenal and City.

NEWCASTLE 5/3.......Shots on/5................Blocked
49%.............466..................6.....................2/0..........Yellow/red
Yet they got off to the perfect start here when Tom Cleverley was given time to
fire off a 25-yard shot. It was blocked by Paul Dummett before taking a ricochet
off his teammate Jamaal Lascelles.

And the loose ball fell to Will Hughes to steer past Martin Dubravka for
Watford's second-fastest Prem goal.

Miguel Almiron should have levelled when Christian Kabasele misjudged Christian
Atsu's cross. But the Paraguayan, who has still not scored since his January
arrival, failed to control the bouncing ball.

Toon fans were restless, with one fan shouting, 'Where are your tactics,
Brucie?' Yet the hosts got their lucky equaliser four minutes before the break.

Emil Krafth crossed and, after an aerial battle between Craig Dawson and Hayden,
it fell to Schar to net.

Replays showed Hayden handled but VAR, for some reason, did not rule it out.

Schar could have had a second after half-time but headed off target from six
yards before Almiron scuffed another glorious chance.

Still, it was the visiting fans who were now getting impatient, as they chanted
for Gracia to make a change.

And when he did make one after 71 minutes, he almost had instant Success, as sub
Isaac Success went close with a header.

headline: Jor king of the Palace
content_plain:
CRYSTAL PALACE....1 Ayew 73 ASTON VILLA...........0 JORDAN AYEW broke Crystal
Palace's home duck to sink his old club.

The Ghana striker's stunning secondhalf strike was the Eagles' first goal at
Selhurst Park this season, after firing blanks in both of their previous games
on their own patch.

It was a sweet moment for Ayew, who scored seven goals in 30 Premier League
games for Villa in the 2015-16 campaign.

But the visitors, who were reduced to ten men on 54 minutes, were left fuming
after ref Kevin Friend disallowed sub Henri Lansbury's late 'goal' and booked
their skipper Jack Grealish for diving.

Whether Grealish intentionally went to ground after playing in Lansbury will be
debated long and hard.

The angry captain had to be held back from confronting Friend by his team-mates
as Palace celebrated only their third win in nine home games.

It must have been show-and-tell day again at Selhurst as on the half-hour mark
the 'Holmesdale Fanatics' unveiled three banners with messages slamming Bury
owner Steve Dale, the EFL and the FA for the Shakers' demise.

The Palace players were just as creative on the park in the first half, only for
their finishing touch to let them down.

James McArthur should have put them ahead on 22 minutes but he blazed Jeffrey
Schlupp's cross over the bar from eight yards.

MATCH C PALACE 5/10......Shots on/7................Blocked
53%.............384..................13....................2/0..........Yellow/red
Villa keeper Tom Heaton then plucked the ball out of the air after Schlupp's
shot zipped off the turf and up towards the roof of the net  before Ayew was
just inches away CRYSTAL PALACE RATINGS Guaita 7, Ward 7, Kelly 6, Cahill 7, Van
Aanholt 6, McArthur 7, STAR MAN MILIVOJEVIC 7, Kouyate 6, Zaha 7, Ayew 7,

from sliding in McArthur's cross. Just before the break Heaton superbly tipped
Luka Milivojevic's free-kick around a post before palming Cheikhou Kouyate's
header over the bar.

Villa had four players booked in the first half and it was no surprise when one
of them, Trezeguet, was sent off for a second yellow card after a foul on
Wilfried Zaha.

With a man advantage, Palace pressed in search of the breakthrough and
Milivojevic's 25-yard curler produced a superb stop from Heaton.

Just as the natives started to get a bit restless, up stepped Ayew to break the
deadlock with a stunning strike.

The frontman appeared to be in a cul-de-sac after running into the channel to
collect Schlupp's pass.

But he turned inside England newboy Tyrone Mings and Three Lions hopeful
Grealish before steering his shot past Heaton.

You could almost taste Palace's relief. But their celebrations were almost
spoilt when Lansbury fired a shot into the bottom corner near the end.

Ref Friend disallowed the goal and booked Grealish for diving in the build-up,
even though the Villa captain did not appeal for a foul under a challenge from
Gary Cahill.

STATS Villa fan Prince William  not at the game  would not have been happy.

headline: Callum's fuming over Youri tackle
content_plain:
CALLUM WILSON accused VAR of letting Youri Tielemans off the hook with a tackle
that almost broke his ankle.

The Foxes midfielder went over the top of the ball in an attempt to retain
possession and inadvertently brought his studs down on Wilson's ankle, which
buckled alarmingly.

England and Bournemouth striker Wilson was furious ref Peter Bankes failed to
reach for his red and stunned when VAR failed to overrule him.

Wilson said: "If that's not clear and obvious, then I don't know what is. He
went straight over the top and on to my shin. He almost broke my ankle  it
warranted a card."

Cherries chief Eddie Howe said: "It looked a bad one. It was a dangerous and
reckless challenge.

"I don't know what VAR is thinking in terms of why it hasn't acted."

Foxes boss Brendan Rodgers added: "When you slow them down they look worse than
they are."

headline:
Exeter.....................1 Mansfield.....................0 MATT TAYLOR warned
[...]
content_plain:
Exeter.....................1 Mansfield.....................0 MATT TAYLOR warned
his table-topping Exeter side: "Don't get carried away."

Ryan Bowman's winner after just five minutes sent the Grecians two points clear.

But boss Taylor said: "We know how difficult this league is and we are not
getting carried away.

"There are reasons to be cheerful but there is more to come from his side.

"Ryan's goal was one hell of a finish with his weaker foot. Then to go on and
get the clean sheet was really pleasing."

Bowman latched on to Dean Moxey's quick throw before smashing home.

Bowman almost added a second after his close-range header hit a post.

Jake Taylor's 20-yard volley also rattled the bar.

Mansfield failed to have a shot on target and had Ryan Sweeney sent off late on
for elbowing Bowman.

Boss John Dempster said: "You can't perform like that and expect to get
anything."

headline: SCOTT WISEMAN has assisted three [...]
content_plain:
SCOTT WISEMAN has assisted three goals in his first six league games for Salford
 as many assists as in his previous 74 appearances in the EFL during stints
with Scunthorpe, Chesterfield and Rochdale.

headline: LEAGUE TWO FASTEST & LATEST [...]
content_plain:
LEAGUE TWO FASTEST & LATEST GOALS FASTEST - Padraig Amond (Newport) 3m 51s
LATEST - Ryan Haynes (Newport) 91m 26s

headline:
Oldham..................0 Colchester..................1 FRANK NOUBLE completed
[...]
content_plain:
Oldham..................0 Colchester..................1 FRANK NOUBLE completed a
dream week for John McGreal's U's with a 45thminute winner.

Things could hardly be looking better for Colchester after back-to-back league
wins and a midweek giantkilling act on Crystal Palace. Next up in the Carabao
Cup is a glamour visit by Tottenham but McGreal is more interested in pushing
for promotion. He said: "We enjoyed ourselves at Palace but this was no case of
after the Lord Mayor's show."

It was a sharp contrast to Oldham's mood after Laurent Banide's men slumped to
third bottom on an afternoon which began with a demo by fans against owner
Abdallah Lemsagam.

Banide said: "We paid for missing chances especially in the first half, but you
can see the spirit of this team."

headline: NEWPORT'S Padraig Amond has scored [...]
content_plain:
NEWPORT'S Padraig Amond has scored in back-to-back League Two games for the
first time since December 2018  when he netted in four games in a row (5
goals).

headline: Walsall.................1 Grimsby.............3 GRIMSBY boss Michael [...]
content_plain:
Walsall.................1 Grimsby.............3 GRIMSBY boss Michael Jolley was
full of praise for two-goal match-winner James Hanson.

Walsall's Caolan Lavery and then Elliott Whitehouse netted as the sides went in
level at half-time.

But Hanson's double, one a bullet header on 68 minutes and one from the spot
with nine minutes left after Cameron Pring had barged over Max Wright, settled
things.

Jolley said: "Whenever you have a player like James Hanson in the team, you have
got a chance. He was terrific."

Walsall boss Darrell Clarke said: "Hanson was the difference."

headline: Northampton............3 Plymouth............1
content_plain:
KEITH CURLE hailed Andy Williams as the striker struck twice to sink Plymouth.

The Northampton boss said: "I thought Andy was superb. His first goal showed
great movement and the effort he put in was outstanding."

Ryan Watson gave Northampton a seventhminute lead from the spot after a Sam
Hoskins cross was handled by Callum McFadzean. Joe Riley levelled three minutes
later later from a free-kick.

Williams put Town ahead again on 21 minutes after sliding home a Hoskins pass
and he wrapped it up four minutes before the break after Hoskins again proved
too hot to handle.

Argyle boss Ryan Lowe admitted: "You cannot afford to get off to a bad start and
it's disappointing we chucked it away again after drawing level.

"We gave ourselves too much to do."

headline: Scunthorpe................0 Carlisle................1 SUPER SUB Ryan [...]
content_plain:
Scunthorpe................0 Carlisle................1 SUPER SUB Ryan Loft led
Carlisle's smash-andgrab raid at Scunthorpe. The visitors only had three efforts
at goal  compared to Scunny's 16.

But on-loan Leicester striker Loft fired home the winner with an hour gone.

It was the Cumbrians' first victory since the opening day.

Boss Steven Pressley said: "We have had lots of kicks of late, in terms of
playing well and not getting results we deserve. Today we were really poor but
got the breakthrough and dug in."

Yann Songo'o saw a header cleared off the line for the hosts, who could not beat
keeper Adam Collin.

It leaves basement boys Scunthorpe still searching for a first league victory.

Boss Paul Hurst said: "I must have done something wrong in a previous life! I
feel for the players as they put a lot in and couldn't have done much more."

headline: Crawley...............1 Cheltenham..... 0 OLLIE PALMER'S 90thminute [...]
content_plain:
Crawley...............1 Cheltenham..... 0 OLLIE PALMER'S 90thminute goal gave
Crawley a third win in a row.

The big striker, whose two goals in three minutes floored Leyton Orient a week
ago, finally broke a dreadful dreadlock.

Just 2,095 turned up  less than half of the crowd which saw the Reds knock
Premier League Norwich out of the Carabao Cup in midweek.

Crawley boss Gaby Cioffi said: "They had a plan to stop us and we had to win
ugly but it was also a victory for our mentality."

Cheltenham chief Michael Duff said: "The solution to us not scoring away is all
between the players' ears."

headline: Swindon............ 3 Morecambe......1 RICHIE WELLENS blasted [...]
content_plain:
Swindon............ 3 Morecambe......1 RICHIE WELLENS blasted his side after
they romped to victory courtesy of an Eoin Doyle double.

The Swindon boss said: "We were far too sloppy, it was the worst we've played by
a long stretch.

"We won't brush things under the carpet."

Doyle put the Robins ahead after five minutes when he pounced on Keshi
Anderson's deflected shot.

Lewis Alessandra equalised for Morecambe eight minutes later.

Jerry Yates made it 2-1 with a sharp turn in the box before Doyle nodded in
Lloyd Isgrove's cross.

Morecambe boss Jim Bentley said: "There were some good signs."

headline: Stevenage.........2 Macclesfield .... 2 JOE IRONSIDE'S late [...]
content_plain:
Stevenage.........2 Macclesfield .... 2 JOE IRONSIDE'S late spotkick snatched a
point for Macclesfield to deny the hosts a first win of the season.

The visitors led through Ben Stephens. But they were stunned when Kurtis Guthrie
bravely levelled and Luther James-Wildin's rocket put Boro ahead.

Ironside equalised from with four minutes left after Manu Osadebe was upended by
Kelland Watt.

Stevenage created 22 chances and boss Dino Maamria said: "We were fantastic but
obviously did not take enough chances."

Silkmen manager Daryl McMahon added: "It was a real roller-coaster."

headline: OH NO, JOE
byline: By JEFF TAPLIN Forest Green...0 Newport...........2
content_plain:
JOE WOLLACOTT had a day to forget as Newport moved into second place.

The Forest Green keeper's horror show started in the fourth minute of his fourth
senior start.

Wollacott dithered as he walked the ball from his box and Tristan Abrahams took
it off his toes before feeding strike partner Padraig Amond, who stroked it into
an empty net.

And the on-loan Bristol City man's day ended 24 minutes later when he was sold
short with a poor back pass from midfielder Ebou Adams before scything down
Abrahams and getting sent off.

Rovers were reduced to nine men in the 91st minute when defender Matt Mills
limped off with all their subs used.

Newport sealed the win a minute later  thanks in part to replacement keeper
Lewis Thomas.

Left-back Ryan Haynes opened his account for the club following a summer move
from Shrewsbury when he drilled in a shot from the edge of the box that Lewis
Thomas let through his hands.

Delighted County boss Michael Flynn said: "I thought we were excellent. Very
professional. Even with 11 men were the better team, although maybe we looked
for the killer pass too much.

"It's a big win. I've got a lot of time for Mark Cooper and the way his team
plays."

FGR came close to grabbing a point in the 75th minute when skipper Joseph Mills
curled a 25-yard freekick against the post. Manager Cooper sent goalkeeping
coach Dan Connor out to face the media. Connor said: "It's a defeat but we've
got to take the positives  apart from the two errors for the goals and the
sending off!

"We have no problems with that and would've been screaming for a red card if it
was us."

headline: Crewe................. 2 Bradford.............1 TOMMY LOWERY sealed [...]
content_plain:
Crewe................. 2 Bradford.............1 TOMMY LOWERY sealed Crewe's
fightback with a stunning strike.

The pocket rocket midfielder unleashed from 25 yards on the hour mark after
Charlie Kirk equalised just before half-time.

Alex boss Dave Artell said: "We came out of the traps in the second half and
played some great stuff and looked like a good team."

James Vaughan put promotion favourites Bradford ahead on 32 minutes.

But Bantams chief Gary Bowyer said: "We have got to realise that people want to
take our scalp and no team is going to give us anything."

headline: Port Vale.............1 Cambridge.......0 CAMBRIDGE boss [...]
content_plain:
Port Vale.............1 Cambridge.......0 CAMBRIDGE boss Colin Calderwood
admitted his side deserved NOTHING.

An 84th-minute own goal by Leon Davies gave Vale victory.

And Calderwood said: "The players had no courage and you don't deserve to get a
point after that.

"We didn't deserve anything whatsoever."

Former U's player David Amoo drove into the box and fizzed the ball across goal
for Davies to painfully put into his own net. Vale boss John Askey said: "I'm
delighted with the clean sheet and to win at home. If you win at home you give
yourself every chance."

headline: NON-LEAGUE YEOVIL beat NOTTS COUNTY [...]
content_plain:
NON-LEAGUE YEOVIL beat NOTTS COUNTY 3-1 in the battle of two teams relegated
last season from League Two.

Goals from Courtney Duffus, Luke Wilkinson and Myles Hippolyte moved the Glovers
up to 12th in the National League.

WOKING remain top after Jake Hyde's double helped them to a 3-2 win at home to
Barrow.

Tyreke Johnson bagged the other Woking goal.

headline: SWANSEA, Charlton and West Brom [...]
content_plain:
SWANSEA, Charlton and West Brom are the three teams still unbeaten after six
games in the second tier with Leeds losing their unbeaten tag vs the Swans
yesterday.

headline: Alex smarts
content_plain:
Salford................................ 1 Leyton Orient...................1
GRAHAM ALEXANDER was left fuming after Chris Neal's own goal saw Salford concede
a third late leveller in four games.

Ammies boss Alexander thought they had won it thanks to Richie Towell's
first-half effort.

But keeper Neal backheeled James Brophy's 87th-minute effort into his own net to
gift Orient a point.

Alexander said: "We haven't managed to see out a half when we are leading a game
and it is something we have to do quickly.

"Towards the end of last season, we took the lead in ten to 15 matches and
didn't relinquish it, so that is what we have to learn to do at this level.

"It is about game management and seeing out those last periods, both on and off
the ball."

A scrappy first-half saw few chances for either Salford or Orient, who were both
promoted from the National League last season.

But the home side had the better of the early exchanges and took the lead on 13
minutes.

Orient failed to clear a Scott Wiseman throw-in and Towell pounced to fire past
Dean Brill.

The O's keeper then tipped Mani Dieseruvwe's thunderous shot on to the bar as
Alexander's men hunted for a second goal.

Salford thought they had got it when Adam Rooney found the back of the net after
Brill fumbled.

But the skipper's effort was ruled offside by referee Marc Edwards.

The visitors went close several times after the break and got their reward when
Brophy forced Neal's howler.

O's interim head coach Ross Embleton said: "We deserved the goal in terms of how
we performed in the second-half."

headline: CHARLTON'S Lyle Taylor has been [...]
content_plain:
CHARLTON'S Lyle Taylor has been directly involved in 23 league goals in 2019 (17
goals, 6 assists), only Teemu Pukki has been involved in more this year (25).

headline: JON HAS A FRY-UP
content_plain:
Bristol City .................... 2 Middlesbrough...........2 JONATHAN WOODGATE
labelled Middlesbrough captain Dael Fry "a big lighthouse" on his longawaited
return to the side. On an afternoon of defensive blunders, Fry shone like a
beacon in his first game for six months after a serious hamstring injury.

Boro boss Woodgate called his side's display the "best performance all season."

And saluting Fry, who was 22 last Friday, he said: "Dael was absolutely
outstanding and deserved the captain's armband.

"I was proud when I captained Middlesbrough and he will be, too.

"That was his first game in six months against a team that has been unbeaten in
five games. He's not the loudest but he leads by example and in time will be the
full-time captain of this club."

Woodgate will have nightmares over the Bristol City's goals  both Kasey Palmer
and Tommy Rowe heading home when unmarked.

Boro's Ashley Fletcher poked a shot against a post while the Robins' Nathan
Baker also hit an upright with a flicked header.

But delightful wing work by Niclas Eliasson left Paddy McNair for dead and his
cross saw Palmer lose his marker to head City ahead.

Boro found their rhythm after the break and equalised when McNair's cross was
diverted into his own net by Taylor Moore.

Britt Assombalonga put the visitors ahead with his 100th league goal, and
Woodgate added: "I did think we were on our way to win."

Yet they fell asleep nine minutes from time and Rowe stooped to head home
substitute Callum O'Dowda's cross.

Robins head coach Lee Johnson said: "I didn't enjoy it at all. I didn't expect
it to be that open.

"We should have gone in 3-1 up.

We had some very good chances, but we didn't communicate."

6....................Corners....................10 1/0..........Yellow/red

headline: HUDDERSFIELD have failed to win [...]
content_plain:
HUDDERSFIELD have failed to win any of their last 16 matches in league
competition (D3 L13)  since beating Wolves in February.

headline: SHINNIE SHINES
content_plain:
Luton.......................................2
Huddersfield......................... 1 ANDREW SHINNIE'S wonder goal fired Luton
to their first home league win of the season.

The Scottish midfielder struck on 66 minutes and to add insult to injury
Huddersfield went home cursing after being denied an 80th-minute penalty.

And it looked nailed on as Sonny Bradley pulled back Elias Kachunga.

Luton's all-action attacking display made them well worth their third win in a
week after seeing off Barnsley in the league and Cardiff in the cup.

It also gave them their first home victory in the Championship since February
2007.

Hatters chief Graeme Jones said: "If you look around world football, three wins
in seven days doesn't happen very often. You have to be totally committed and
focused on each game, which is really demanding. Today was a show of character 
the boys have been magnificent."

Karlan Grant put the visitors ahead two minutes after the break when he
converted Terence Kongolo's low cross.

Luton stormed back when James Collins won and converted a 57thminute penalty
after Christopher Schindler was adjudged to have fouled him before Shinnie's
stunning winner.

Terriers caretaker boss Mark Hudson, who has seen his side go 18 games without a
win or a clean sheet, was unhappy with the decision that gave the hosts their
spot-kick He said: "Schindler didn't even see him and barely touches him anyway.
Collins actually apologises to him."

headline: LOVELEE JUBBLY
content_plain:
Reading................................. 0
Charlton................................. 2 LEE BOWYER warned Charlton's
promotion rivals: "We'll keep surprising teams."

A second-half curler from Jonathan Leko and Lyle Taylor's outrageous spot-kick
lifted the new boys into the automatic promotion places.

Boss Bowyer has the lowest playing budget in the division this term. But his
rag-tag red and white army, unbeaten in the league, keep marching on.

Reading striker George Puscas bundled close-range effort on to the bar.

Six minutes after the break, Leko made them pay as he picked his spot from 20
yards with a sweet left-footer which took a nick off Tom McIntyre, helping it
evade Rafael Cabral's grasp.

Taylor cheekily wrapped up the win ten minutes from time after Pele hauled down
Charlton sub Chuks Aneke in the box. Taylor looked as if he was going for a
country stroll instead of a run-up before coolly sending Cabral the wrong way
for his fifth goal this term.

Bowyer said: "Our gameplan worked, our defence again stood strong and the keeper
did his job when called upon.

"The midfield lads have worked really, really hard to do the dirty side of the
game and the front two caused problems all day."

Jose Gomes defended his substitutions despite his Royals falling apart after.

He said: "If you play games on the PlayStation, change the players and you lose,
but you can repeat the game. Here we can't."

headline: Top Bagg
content_plain:
West Brom.......................3 Blackburn........................ 2 SLAVEN
BILIC hailed brilliant Brazilian Matheus Pereira after he lit up The Hawthorns
in his first Championship start.

The midfielder, on loan from Sporting Lisbon, set up first-half goals for Matt
Phillips and Jake Livermore and showed top-notch quality on the ball.

Victory catapulted unbeaten West Brom into the top four.

Boss Bilic said: "I knew him from Germany last season when he was on loan at FC
Nuremberg.

"He's confident on the ball, he's happy to be in the pockets, he sees everything
 and he doesn't mind defending either.

"He's not a showman, he wants to penetrate. We expected this from him and he
gelled straight away."

But Rovers needed just 23 seconds to break the deadlock. Kyle Bartley tried to
play out of defence to Romaine Sawyers  but it was intercepted by Lewis Travis.

The ball broke to Dack and he curled home a 15-yarder. Albion turned the game
around with two goals in nine minutes, with Pereira involved in both.

His pass opened up a path for Phillips who shrugged off Greg Cunningham before
slotting past Christian Walton on 22 minutes.

Then Pereira teed up Livermore, who side-footed past Walton.

Grady Diangana made it 3-1 five minutes before half-time.

The visitors were then handed a lifeline in first-half injury time.

Baggies keeper Sam Johnstone failed to hold on to a header from Darragh Lenihan
 with Bradley Johnson gobbling up the loose ball.

Rovers boss Tony Mowbray felt Dack's second-half effort should not have been
KO'd for a foul on Johnstone. He said: "I'm not sure the ref could see it.

"He was looking through about nine players, he played it safe."

headline: Hey Jude
content_plain:
Birmingham.................... 2 Stoke...................................1 JUDE
BELLINGHAM celebrated a dream home debut by bagging Birmingham's winner  at the
age of just 16!

The England youth star came on as a first-half sub for crocked Jefferson
Montero.

And teen sensation Bellingham completed a superb late comeback to pile more
pressure on Stoke boss Nathan Jones.

He became the youngest player to appear for the Blues when he started against
Portsmouth in the Carabao Cup last month, at 16 years, 38 days.

That beat Trevor Francis' record of 16 years, 139 days.

And Birmingham boss Pep Clotet said: "I do hope he gives this club as many happy
days as possible.

"I know Trevor and know what a player he was  but it's difficult to judge them.

"Jude's goal should be to get established in this team and play as many games as
he can for the club he loves. As soon as the option was memorable day for him.
He's quiet but confident in his ability.

"It's difficult to say how far he can go when you have huge talent at such a
young age. My priority is to protect him."

Stoke took the lead on 58 minutes through defender Liam Lindsay after Lee
Gregory hit the post.

But Clotet's side turned it around in the space of three minutes.

First, Lukas Jutkiewicz met Maxime Colin's pinpoint cross to head the equaliser
at the far post.

And Bellingham fired the winner from the edge of the area, thanks to a big
deflection off Lindsay.

It left Stoke deflated and bottom of the table without a win.

Potters boss Jones said: "Nothing's going for us but we have to change our luck,
that's the frustrating thing.

"This cannot continue but I'm confident we can turn this around."
