headline: EastEnders HELL! WELCOME TO
content_plain:
WEDDING HEARTBREAK!DEATH AT THE VIC!

Emmerdale: Nate and Moira caught in bed!

Neighbours: The Alessi twins return!

BIANCA'S HOME!LISA'S BACK!

PLUS! 7-DAY TV LISTINGS

headline: EM's PEOPLE
content_plain:
FRIDAY 8.30PM 

Ham sarnies, crisps, polka-dot beakers - Steve's even got a tie on the
McDonalds are rolling out the red carpet to welcome Emma into the family. Sadly,
it's too much for the barmaid, who flees the delightful feast - before returning
to tell Steve he can't replace her dad, but she'd like to be friends. Aw! Also
this episode 

Sinead plans a wedding surprise for Daniel.

headline: 6 of the best
content_plain:
1.Best peeping Tom! 

EMMERDALE MONDAY 7PM

Or rather 'Peeping Thomasina', because it's Kerry who gets an eyeful when she
goes to Butlers Farm to talk to Nate and realises he has some Moira-shaped
company in the caravan of love. It's amazing those windows aren't too steamed up
to see through 

2.Best dilemma! EASTENDERS MONDAY 8PM

Callum's secret fling with Ben is a secret no more - and as Whitney prepares to
walk up the aisle as his bride, she must decide whether she's going to marry
Callum despite his indiscretions, or call the wedding of. f. If ever there was a
big, red, flashing neon sign saying 'Don't Do It!' this is it, Whit 

3.Best disaster! 

CORONATION STREET MONDAY 7.30PM

Aah, a child's eyes shining brightly - but that's not a Girl Guide's campfire
Hope is gazing at, it's a terrifying blaze at Underworld. Will she be found
before the flames engulf her? And did the troubled kid actually set the factory
alight? 

4.Best court case!

EMMERDALE THURSDAY 7PM

It's crunch time for Robert when he stands trial for attacking Lee. He's
sticking to his self-defence story, even though all his loved ones know it's a
lie. Victoria in particular is struggling between fibbing in court to protect
her brother and doing the right thing. Will Robert go down or walk away a free
man? 

5.Best shooting!

EASTENDERS FRIDAY 8PM

Mel may want Hunter to hide in the boot of her car - and Walford would have been
a whole lot safer if he'd just done as his mum asked. But Hunter is out for
revenge on Jack, and now he's got a gun. As events reach a crescendo, the gun is
fired in The Vic and someone will die.

6.Best 90s throwback!

NEIGHBOURS FRIDAY 1.45PM

& 5.30PM

Neighbours' blasts from Paul's past just keep getting better - look who's
returned now! Adding to the list of exes throwing a spanner in the works for
Paul and Terese come the Alessi twins, Caroline and Christina. If you're under
30, trust us - this is big news.

Email us! SPOTTED A SOAP FAUX PAS? SOMETHING TO GET OFF YOUR CHEST? EMAIL
tvsoap@the-sun.co.uk @TVSOAPMAG 03

headline: HOPE? A NEW
content_plain:
MONDAY 7.30PM 

Has Hope's stint at a school for badly behaved kids worked? Possibly not, as
while Ty and Fiz row about how to deal with her, she sneaks out and hides in the
factory. As Fiz calls in the police to search for her missing daughter, Ali
hears Hope calling for help - and finds her surrounded by burning cardboard
boxes. Can he save her? And who started the fire? Also this episode Geoff's
cancer lie spreads like wildfire.

Why didn't I bring some marshmallows?

headline: ROOM WITH A NEW (LODGER)
content_plain:
MONDAY 8.30PM What with Jan being shot by human traffickers last week, Eileen's
worried when she spots a dodgy-looking van in the street with Polish voices
coming from within. Seb goes to investigate and finds Mary inside, watching a
subtitled film. Obviously. Worried about his homeless friend, Seb invites her to
move into No.11. Eileen will be thrilled. Also this episode 

Ali saves Hope, but it doesn't help his drug addiction.

headline: NEAR KISS?
content_plain:
FRIDAY 7.30PM Bethany's upset when the Gazette rejects the grooming article, but
fear not, Daniel's here to save the day, wading in to give the paper's editor a
piece of his mind. Realising he really cares about her, Bethany gazes tenderly
into his eyes. What are you waiting for, girl, kiss him! Also this episode...
Michelle gets a business proposal from hotel boss Ray.

I call it strawberry blonde

headline: GATE CR ERS!
content_plain:
WEDNESDAY 8.30PM 

Steve, James and Michael agree to help Emma scatter her other dad's ashes at
Weatherfield football ground, but the security guard won't budge. Can Steve use
the negotiating skills that have seen him become, erm, a moderately successful
cabbie, to talk him round? 

Also this episode Fiz home-schools Hope.

I'm the club's new centre forward.

Obviously

headline: Star Interview
content_plain:
I was so scared to come back, I won't lie. I didn't know if I'd still be able to
do it. But it's just like riding a bike.

I think Evelyn most certainly hasn't missed Fiz. Tyrone insists he has, but I
don't know how convinced I am, because Fiz does nag him an awful lot.

We've been away for nine months, and in this time Fiz has supposedly been
working on Hope's bad behaviour, and allegedly it's improved.

Fiz keeps things under wraps after the fire as she has an inkling there's more
to find out. Tyrone becomes suspicious of Hope, and Fiz exhausts herself
emotionally by reassuring those closest to her that her daughter isn't capable
of anything like this. It then becomes apparent that Hope may be getting worse

headline: NO TIFFS NO BUTS
content_plain:
FRIDAY 8PM Whit's wedding has brought Bianca back to Walford, hurrah! And in
classic Bianca style, she gets up to some mischief as soon as she arrives, which
nearly holds the wedding up but anyway. Tiff is obviously thrilled that her
mum's back, but after some stern words from Sonia, Bianca realises all is not
well with her daughter. As the shot rings out in The Vic, Bianca must deal with
a bombshell of her own Also tonight... Someone will not make it to next week
alive, and the chaos causes one couple to admit their true feelings.

Fashion sense as classy as ever then, Mum

headline: ESCAPE JAN
content_plain:
WEDNESDAY 7.30PM 

As is now a regular occurrence, Eileen is planning to flee Weatherfield with a
slightly dodgy fella. But Sean's concerned, and urges Jan to think about whether
Eileen will ever be safe with a former police informer who's recently been shot.
So when Eileen shows up with her bags packed, will Jan do the right thing? 

 Also this episode Daniel reads Bethany's article on grooming.

I can switch on Pointless if you're really desperate

headline: HUNTED!
content_plain:
THURSDAY 7.30PM 

What do you get when you cross Hunter, a gun and Jack Branning? A shoot-em-up in
The Vic, that's what! Hunter wants revenge on Jack and steals Mel's gun. Having
failed to find Jack at the Brannings' he heads to the pub, which is packed with
people including Whitney, Callum and Ben. A shot is fired, and many of the
Square are caught in the crossfire but who will die? 

Also tonight sharon and Keanu finally come face to face, and Sonia tells Bianca
what's been going on with Tiffany.

headline: KEANU'S HELL BEN-T
content_plain:
TUESDAY 7.30PM 

With the Square in turmoil over Whitney's wedding and an escaped Hunter, Keanu
takes the opportunity to seek out Ben. He's determined to force him to withdraw
his incriminating statement - but of course, Ben's not about to do as he's told.
Louise, meanwhile, is desperately trying to find Keanu but must try to avoid
seeing Sharon in the process. 

Also tonight Whitney has to decide whether to marry Callum, and Hunter hides
with a gun

headline: WALT DISMALLY
content_plain:
FRIDAY 6.30PM 

Unimpressed with her welcome home, Lisa accuses her family of not caring about
Louis being murdered. She rebels and throws a full-on party, with Martine
inviting Scott to perform in drag. But when Walter sees Anita touch Mitchell,
the vicar hits the roof and kicks her out! 

Also tonight Sylver and Liberty concoct an upcycling business venture.

A coral rollneck? Count me in!

headline: WHIT SHE OR WON'T SHE?
content_plain:
MONDAY 8PM Ah, a wedding day.

The dress is ready. Your friends gather to help with your hair and make-up and
you try to forget your groom-to-be had a fling with a man.

I'm back!

That's what Whitney's dealing with, as well as Bianca causing a palaver with her
return to the Square. As Whitney arrives for her nuptials, she clocks Ben. Will
she put a brave face on things and wed Callum anyway? 

Also tonight Lisa returns, desperate to get Keanu and Louise out of danger.
Will they escape with Mel and Hunter? So am I!

headline: DON'T LUKE NOW
content_plain:
MONDAY 6.30PM 

Ollie's chuffed that his dad's returned to the village, but Darren is less happy
about Luke being back on the scene. Mandy tells her ex that he can stay with her
and the man she cheated on him with for as long as he wants (nice, that), but
when Luke prepares a candle-lit supper for her, Darren's left feeling very
insecure. If only they could find a new lady-friend for Luke 

Also tonight It's the big insemination day for Liberty and her surrogate
Sienna.

Three more members and our Steps tribute act is complete!

headline: BEANZ THERE, DONE THAT
content_plain:
THURSDAY 6.30PM 

It's Freshers' Week at Hollyoaks Community College, and the new intake of
students - which apparently consists of just Peri and Cleo - take part in a
'food forfeit quiz' at The Hutch (well, the old Student Union set is now the
hospital). However, recovering from bulimia, Cleo balks at pouring a bowl of
beans over her head - so Peri accepts the challenge instead! 

Also tonight Darren gives Luke and Cindy an ultimatum.

headline: ANITA KNOW HOW YOU FEEL, MITCHELL
content_plain:
TUESDAY 6.30PM 

Mitchell's developed a serious crush on Anita Tinkle, Scott's drag alter ego,
and it's coming between him and Cleo. To distract himself, he decides to spend
more time with his girlfriend by helping her prepare for her nursing studies,
but with his mind still on Anita, he gets all her medical questions wrong.
That's when Scott shows up in a sexy nurse outfit to save the day - can Mitchell
resist Anita? 

Also tonight Liberty tells Cindy she has doubts about the planned surrogacy.

I knew my RADA training would be worth it

headline: AN OPEN BROOKE?
content_plain:
WEDNESDAY 6.30PM 

Cindy's got a lot to answer for. While regaling Brooke with tales of her
terrible teens, she unwittingly gave the terrified youngster the idea of
concealing her pregnancy. But when she feels sick while at school, Brooke braces
herself to reveal all to Sally and seek the help she needs - well, until Nancy
interrupts their little chat. Will Brooke open up to her foster mum? 

Also tonight Goldie tags along to Freshers' Week with Cleo and Peri.

Have I overdone it on the accessories?

headline: ATTA BOY!
content_plain:
FRIDAY 7PM Ever since Billy and Nate arrived in the village they have been
swarmed by females. If they charged by the hour, they'd be millionaires by now.
Though Nate's currently busy juggling Amy and Moira, Billy's free. And there's a
certain young woman who is keen to make his acquaintance better. Dawn. We
knowwhat about Ryan? Seems he's no longer on her agenda when Billy agrees to a
lunchtime cappuccino with her.

Also tonight... Robert and his family are still digesting the court case.

headline: JOB LOT!
content_plain:
TUESDAY 7PM 

Is anyone entirely clear what Leyla actually does for a living these days? She
seems to spend most of her time in David's shop fretting about Jacob. But
apparently not only does she still have a business, she's also hiring. Andrea is
very keen on coming to work with her. Though, of course, when it comes to the
Tate family, if you employ one, you get the rest thrown in 

Also tonight Kerry uses her knowledge of Nate's affair with Moira to blackmail
him.

Are your hands massive, Kim, or is that a tiny cup?

headline: CHILD'S PLAY
content_plain:
This sideboard is too cluttered for another photograph THURSDAY 7PM & 8PM
Another week in the Dales and more scenes of a moody Jacob pining after Maya.
Which means we have to put up with whiny Leyla and squeaky David despairing at
pitches that only dogs can hear - and Jacob certainly tuned out months ago. Will
they ever get through to the boy, or should they just hope that when Maya is
released she'll be put off by Jacob's new hairstyle? Also tonight... Robert has
his day in court will his plea of self-defence get him off?

headline: GUILT TRIP WEDNESDAY 7PM Robert [...]
content_plain:
GUILT TRIP WEDNESDAY 7PM Robert has always been the kind of chap who lies so
convincingly that he ends up believing his own porkies. So when his solicitor
suggests he pleads guilty when his case comes to court tomorrow, Robert is
outraged by the suggestion. His sister Victoria, on the other hand, does have a
conscience, and hers is telling her that she should tell the truth when it's her
turn to take the stand. Will she drop Robert in it? Also tonight... Harriet and
Will arrange a date.

How many times?! It was a skinny latte with an extra shot.

And a biscuit

headline: BIG MAC AND LIES
content_plain:
Dean is refusing to have anything to do with Mackenzie - and as a result he has
no idea that his mate to see MONDAY Colby is in the process of getting it on
with her. So he's in for a big surprise when he decides to go and see Mac, to
talk to her about the mess with their dad, and finds her wearing Colby's police
shirt with Colby hastily pulling on his trousers

headline: Don't miss this!
content_plain:
CARAVAN OF LOVE

MONDAY 7PM 

Kerry is worried that Nate now knows her and Amy's secret, so she troops up to
Butlers Farm to persuade him to keep quiet. But as she nears his caravan, it's
quickly clear he's home, but not alone. Kerry peeks in the window and can't
believe her eyes when she sees Nate having a roll around with Moira! The moral
of the story? When the caravan's a-rocking, don't come a-knocking Also tonight
Amy thinks Nate talked to Tracy about the fire.

Bit of a tight squeeze in this caravan

headline: Star Interview
content_plain:
After discovering Amy confessed to Nate how the factory fire really started,
it's been niggling away at Kerry. So she decides to take the situation into her
own hands. And when she sees him in the caravan with Moira, she's not only
annoyed with him for betraying her daughter, she also sees it as a chance to
blackmail him. Kerry's now got information on him, just as he does on her and
Amy.

The talk Kerry has with Nate, when she tells him he has to end it with Amy, is
bittersweet. It solves her concerns about Nate blabbing, but at the same time
it's horrible for her because she knows she's behind her daughter getting hurt
when Nate dumps her. But it's got to be done.

headline: SHOUT OUT TO THE EX
content_plain:
Zara has found out about Becky and Daniel's dalliance, and she's not best
pleased. But before she confronts Becky, she's going to make her feel incredibly
uncomfortable. Zara invites Becky on a singles night, where they go to a local
bar - and the interrogation of Becky's love life begins. When Becky tries to
leave, Zara tells her she knows Becky has been sleeping with her ex, Daniel. As
Zara begins her verbal attack, Becky breaks down, but there's no stopping Zara
as she brands Becky "pathetic". Things are about to get very awkward at The
Mill.

headline: WE'RE BEING DOVERCOME
subheadline: CHANNEL CRISIS GROWING Scores of migrants storm coast
byline: EXCLUSIVE by NICK PARKER Chief Foreign Correspondent
content_plain:
1GM Sunday, September 1, 2019 ...............

BRITAIN'S coastline was stormed by scores of migrants yesterday.

More than 50, including kids, were seen in dinghies off Kent at first light.

Eight were detained after landing on Kingsdown beach.

Two Border Force cutters picked up another 48. In total five small boats were
intercepted in the Channel. The migrants were taken to Dover for processing. The
total number to reach British shores by sea in the past week is now more than
270.

It comes amid fears hundreds more will attempt the dangerous crossing as French
authorities clear a camp of 1,100 migrants near Dunkirk.

Josh Hallam, of Help Refugees, said: "It is possible there will be an increased
push of people trying to get across."

Home Secretary Priti Patel has vowed to crack down on the migrant armada.

Two are known to have died in the Channel during August.

Dover and Deal MP Charlie Elphicke said: "This is an ominous development. We
need immediate action."

Beached . . their small dinghy Detained . . migrants at Dover

headline: WHAT Ap-pAUL-ING LUCK!
content_plain:
Now look who's turned up! It's only another of Paul's ex-wives, Rebecca Napier.
He's beginning to wonder if the universe is trying to tell him something, what
with all these ghosts of relationships past suddenly arriving. After Paul and
Rebecca have a heated conversation about that night on that mexxanine, he and
Terese decide enough's enough and disappear off to Queensland. And who should he
bump into there? Yet another ex wife! And here's a small clue as to who that
might be

headline: ALESS IN WATERLAND
content_plain:
MODE swell MODEL Alessandra Ambrosio looks as she surfs in her sunglasses. The
Brazilian, 38, rode the waves on a boogie board before splashing at water's edge
in her red bikini. She is in Malibu, California, with Italian boyfriend Nicolo
Oddi.

bo the Sh Ital

headline: Death of 60 gulls
content_plain:
DOZENS of seagulls have been found dead at two seaside resorts.

At least sixty herring gulls are reported to have died across Weymouth and
Portland in Dorset.

They were killed by an outbreak of the avian botulism disease, nature experts
say.

Avian botulism is caused by ingestion of toxin produced by bacteria found in
rotting plant and animal material.

Weymouth wildlife conservationist Derek Davey believes litter may also cause
some of the deaths.

He said: "It could be from algae or caused by food being thrown away in hot
weather."

headline: Healthier with nuts
content_plain:
EATING nuts twice a week slashes the risk of heart death by a sixth, researchers
found.

They contain protective fats, vitamins, fibre and antioxidants, experts said.

A handful daily  preferably unsalted  was best, the European Society of
Cardiology conference in Paris was told. Researchers asked 5,400 healthy adults
about their diet every two years.

After 12 years, those who ate at least two portions of nuts a week had a 17 per
cent lower risk of heart disease death.

There are almost 170,000 UK deaths from heart attacks, strokes and circulatory
diseases a year.

headline: £53k win for hubby on fraud
content_plain:
A HUSBAND has won compensation after being "spoofed" out of £53,000.

John Williams, 65, was phoned by conmen who made the number appear as Santander
bank.

They stole savings set aside to buy a seaside apartment for wife Carol, 68, who
had been diagnosed with lung cancer. The bank had refused to refund money
because he handed out passwords.

It took 15 months to get the cash back after an ombudsman investigation.

Mr Williams, of Newbridge, South Wales, said: "Justice has been done."

The payout comes after his wife died last year.

The bank said it repaid the money with interest and offered condolences.

headline: Lad's sea swim hell
content_plain:
A TEENAGER was swept out to sea as winds buffeted a beach yesterday. Witnesses
watched in horror as the swimmer got in trouble at 1.50pm.

Coast guards were called and managed to pluck the boy to safety in Cleveleys,
Lancs.

One onlooker said: "It beggars belief what he was doing out there on a day like
this." He was treated by paramedics.

headline: To have and to Gould
subheadline:
Twitter: @LauraSunShowbiz T Hotline: 0207 782 4036 Email:
laura.armstrong@the-sun.co.ukHotlin biz on Sunday ELLIE WEDS CASPAR IN FRONT OF
STARS AND ROYALS
content_plain:
POP star ELLIE GOULDING and new husband Caspar Jopling looked a picture of
happiness yesterday as they sealed their marriage with a kiss.

The Love Me Like You Do singer looked stunning in a long-sleeved bespoke Chloe
wedding dress, designed by Natacha Ramsay-Levi.

And as she and art dealer Caspar tied the knot they were watched by a host of
showbiz pals, including KATY PERRY and ORLANDO BLOOM.

PRINCESS EUGENIE , who is believed to have introduced the newlyweds, was among
the guests, as well as sister BEATRICE and their mum SARAH FERGUSON.

SIENNA MILLER, JAMES BLUNT and JOE WICKS were also invited to the pair's
nuptials, which were held in York Minster  the largest gothic church in the UK.

After the ceremony, the couple laughed and chatted with guests on the outside
steps before making their way to a lavish evening reception at Grade IIlisted
Castle Howard.

Brit Award winner Ellie, who performed at the 2011 wedding of PRINCE WILLIAM and
KATE, was first linked to Old Etonian Caspar in March 2017. They announced their
engagement in The Times in August 2018.

The couple, who are said to have bonded over their love of jigsaw puzzles and
nights in, splurged £20,000 on flowers alone. But Ellie opted for a lowkey blue
Volkswagen campervan as her arrival car.

The reception, organised by PIPPA MIDDLETON 's wedding party planner Sarah
Haywood, was expected to deliver "designer vegan food", entertainment by
surprise guests and a DJ playing Nineties hits from the likes of the SPICE
GIRLS.

It is not known where the newlyweds will go on their honeymoon.

But I can reveal that in the run-up to their big day, Ellie and Caspar took time
out from wedding admin to relax in the wilderness of northern Norway.

A source told how they wanted to "get away from it all" on a trip to the back of
beyond with adventure guide Inge Solheim, who accompanied PRINCE HARRY on his
Arctic trek in 2011.

Inge took them into the heart of the Romsdalen national park, where they went
sea kayaking and swam under waterfalls.

If that was the warm-up act, imagine what Ellie and Caspar's honeymoon might
look like.

headline: EDDIE Holland is perhaps the [...]
content_plain:
EDDIE Holland is perhaps the most successful Motown artist you have never heard
of. He has written or co-written 80 hits in the UK and 143 in the US.

MAGIC

headline: AMANDA: I MADE A TOP ERROR
content_plain:
H alway AMANDA HOLDEN's outfits on Britain's Got Talent always grab people's
attention - including TV watchdog Ofcom, which received complaints about two of
her risque frocks.

But the telly judge says she is happy to have put her earlier fashion fails
behind her.

a te earli Bri la ser cr o I Before Britain's Got Talent: The Champions kicked
off last night, Amanda looked back on the first series of the hit talent show.

She cringed: "In one episode I've got my top on back to front.

"I'm wearing jeans, I've got brown hair, over-plucked eyebrows. I've made some
awful decisions, but I'd like to think I've come out the other side now.

"My outfits do still annoy some people, but I think they're better than they
were."

Amanda admitted she did not know back then if the show would be a success.

She said: "When we were making the first series, SIMON COWELL said, 'They don't
know whether this is going to work or not'.

"After day one, we all went, 'This is definitely going to work - this is
amazing'."

headline: Caught out
subheadline:
Twitter: @LauraSunShowbiz T Hotline: 0207 782 4036 Email:
laura.armstrong@the-sun.co.ukHotlin biz on Sunday
content_plain:
MOTSI MABUSE revealed top advice given to her is "have no fear". She said: "The
biggest things is fear of losing ." FRANK SKINNER recorded his Absolute Radio
show in just his pants yesterday, after vowing to strip off if the England
cricket team won last Sunday's game. DJ AMAZONICA rang her dad to reassure him
she was not part of #MeToo after she played at a Harvey Weinstein bash. She
said: "No one f***s with me." Ex-Geordie Shore star JOEL CORRY is not as big a
party animal as people think. He told me: "There's no way could DJ if I was
absolutely hanging."

headline: Jamie has too many maids in Chelsea
subheadline:
Twitter: @LauraSunShowbiz T Hotline: 0207 782 4036 Email:
laura.armstrong@the-sun.co.ukHotlin biz on Sunday
content_plain:
MADE In Chelsea star JAMIE LAING has been slammed for cheating on SOPHIE HABBOO
by his pal SOPHIE HERMANN.

Asked about Jamie and his girlfriend, left, ahead of the series' return, co-star
Sophie, right, told me: "He's cheated on her countless times.

"We all know Jamie's reputation. I love him, but... " Jamie, who got with his
Habbs during the last series, is on Strictly this year - and his moves will be
under scrutiny on Made In Chelsea, too, as viewers see ROSI MAI WALDON reveal
that she bedded him behind Sophie's back.

While fans must wait to see how it plays out when the E4 show returns tomorrow
at 9pm, castmates ELIZA BATTEN and VERITY BOWDITCH reckon it is a taste of
things to come.

Eliza told me: "The whole series is carnage.

Things no one would expect were happening."

Verity added: "There are bust-ups in every episode.

"Since I've been on the show I've got better at arguing."

headline: IT'S HOT WRITE NOW
subheadline:
Twitter: @LauraSunShowbiz T Hotline: 0207 782 4036 Email:
laura.armstrong@the-sun.co.ukHotlin biz on Sunday
content_plain:

would be, if she hadn't plastered it all over her stage outfit first. The Hot
Right Now pop star donned a bright pink cut-out jumpsuit emblazoned with her
hits as she performed in Zadar, Croatia yesterday. I suppose a get-up like this
could be pretty helpful if you thought you might forget your repertoire. But
Rita, who was all smiles as she performed, looks like she's read the book on
this one.

headline: BAND BOMB FURY
subheadline: Blast hell families' outrage at The 1975 vid stunt
content_plain:
FAMILIES of Manchester Arena bomb victims have slammed The 1975 for a pop video
showing their frontman exploding a fake suicide vest.

Singer Matt Healy, 30, whose band is based in the city, smiles as he presses the
detonator.

The sick stunt comes two years after a suicide bomber killed 22 people at an
Ariana Grande concert.

Alex Klis, 21, whose parents are among the dead, told The Sun on Sunday: "I
expect better, especially from somebody who is from Manchester.

"Putting yourself in a suicide vest is so insensitive.

Matt . . last week "Terrorist attacks are not something you use to make a music
video look 'cool'."

Figen Murray, whose son Martyn Hett, 29, was killed: added: "I can't believe
anybody could think this is in any way acceptable. It is disgusting."

Healy, 30  son of ex-Corrie star Denise Welch, 61  filmed the video with his
bandmates for their latest single People.

Last weekend, The 1975 were headlining Reading and Leeds festivals while Ariana,
26, performed at Manchester Pride. The band's management have been approached
for comment.

sarah.ridley@the-sun.co.uk

headline: Kids in ID app peril
content_plain:
NEARLY a third of children aged eight to 13 have given out personal details to
people they have only ever met online, a study has found.

YouTube, WhatsApp, Instagram, Snapchat and Roblox are the apps most used by the
kids.

But less than half said their parents understood YouTube and under ten per cent
get how Snapchat and Roblox work. And 29 per cent of kids had given out a mobile
number, home or email address, or school details.

The NSPCC, which carried out the poll with O2, said parents must warn children
to be wary of "strangers" online.

headline: BRUNO SETS UP CLINIC
content_plain:
BOXING legend Frank Bruno is opening his own mental health centre, saying: "I
don't want others to suffer like I did."

The former world heavyweight champ says he "lost three years of my life" after
being sectioned and put on high-strength drugs.

Frank, 57, says his experience inspired his new treatment centre. He told the
Sun on Sunday: "If you ask for help because you are depressed or feeling a bit
low, 99 times out of 100 a doctor will prescribe you pills and pack you off
home. That's not right for a lot of people."

Bruno was last sectioned in 2012. He said: "I was pumped full of drugs and left
like a zombie.

"Every day I begged them to let me out of hospital, saying it wasn't the right
place for me."

When he was eventually allowed to be treated at home, he was still given lots of
drugs. The Struggles . . Frank turning point came when he persuaded doctors to
cut his dose.

He says he has been medication-free since 2016 and has never felt better, thanks
to exercise, healthy living and mindfulness.

These are the tonics his centre  at Standens Barn, Northampton  will offer. He
said: "What we're going to do isn't rocket science but it will be
life-changing."

thea.jacobs@the-sun.co.uk

headline: Diabetes text boost
content_plain:
MOTIVATIONAL texts could save the lives of diabetes patients, according to
research.

Sending tips with fun rhymes about how to cope with the condition noticeably
helped several patients in a study.

Dr Xiqian Huo, of Beijing, said the effect could be "clinically relevant by
reducing risk of diabetic complications and death".

More than 500 patients were studied from 34 clinics across China.

Some were sent six messages per week at random times. At six months, those that
were sent texts had significantly lower blood sugar levels than those that did
not.

headline: As workplace bonds strengthen, you [...]
content_plain:
As workplace bonds strengthen, you take a place in a team - even if it doesn't
seem like the place you want to be. New sides of you begin to emerge and secret
skills are uncovered. In love? A partnership moon opens two hearts to big
changes. Single? You'll find a new love interest is an expert in healthy eating.

Make sure you find time for fun in the coming week. As your creativity revs up,
your unusual take on the world hits the right audience. Your work ideas are
genius - screens and dreams make a perfect match in more ways than one. As the
planets of passion and protection join, love finds a future-proof pattern.

Walking on the lighter side of life restores emotional balance, so you'll be
able to see who could be good for you. This week, power-planet bonds help you to
reboot tricky partnerships. Meanwhile, your moon path is part "just do it", part
dreamy, so people may not realise your strength until you end up in charge.

You will build brilliant bonds if you focus on communication. But be sure to
always stay true to yourself, so connections begin and stay genuine. Names that
share a special date are ready to start an important planning process. Your
memory zone is moon-intense and a significant journey is back on.

Hiding feelings, even for the best reasons, is not a solution to a problem.
Instead, follow your heart and find a way to speak about emotions to reset a key
relationship. In the next few days, so much of your chart is about finding and
rewarding value. This helps you overhaul everything, from love bonds to career
aims.

Your chart shows a contrast between high-profile planets in your sign and the
gentle moon lighting up how you feel and what to do about it - so you're the
centre of attention. A leading work role is perfect for you and you learn new
skills super-fast. In love, going with the flow sets some big feelings free.

Start September with clear decisions about cash, love or time. You have a new
sense of belief in yourself, and a fresh vision for the future can appear. Luck
sparkles around words, but you will also find it in how open you are to sharing
your dreams with others. In love, pure happiness links to an unexpected L name.

The people you surround yourself with matter so much right now, and instead of
waiting for a family member to call, you should make the first move. At work,
one group can become two and achieve more. A casual bond has the chance to
become serious - but only if you switch off that doubting inner voice.

Your success sector is shining with planet potential and you pursue goals with a
deep sense of purpose. Meanwhile, if you've been seeking approval in a
relationship, it's time to stop and set your own rules and limits for romance.
Your Jupiter prize sensors are super-sharp, so you will select contests well.

Your ability to learn in life and love tops all the zodiac signs in the coming
days. Intuition gives you a heads-up when making snap decisions or finalising
key documents, but best of all you find you won't be held back by the dreams or
opinions of others. Meanwhile, a name heard several times is your best love
clue.

When you allow yourself to cut loose from tight schedules or expectations, you
will make time for something special. And yes, you'll be ready. At the moment
your growth and personal change is powered by the planets, which makes you the
best version of yourself. Saturn helps you stick to a secret promise.

You are ready to transform a part-time connection into something that sits
firmly in your favour. What may first feel like a problem develops into an
exciting challenge. Numbers that start with seven and names that remind you of
holidays are very lucky. Elsewhere, a caring moon leads you to a local charity.

YOU CAN ALSO READ MYSTIC MEG IN FABULOUS

headline: Pet Vet
content_plain:
SEAN McCORMACK ea PET Vet SEAN McCORMACK, of the tailored food firm tails.com,
is on a mission to help the nation's pets.

QKATIE GASCOIGNE, from Lancaster, has a one-year-old chihuahua, Cornflake. She
writes: "I want to take Cornflake to France on holiday. Is it safe in the heat?
And what precautions would you recommend?" ASEAN SAYS: "Most dogs love to go on
holidays with their owners but you do need to be careful on your travels,
especially if it's hot.

"Ideally, have air con on in the car at all times, or windows rolled down for
airflow - but not so much that Cornflake might jump out.

"Never leave her unattended in a parked car as dogs can overheat really fast.
Offer her plenty of fresh, l t d i h ld cool water, and give her a cold, wet
towel to lie on, which will also help her keep cool. Ensure her passport is up
to date with your vet before you travel.

"It's no fun if she's denied entry or can't travel back to the UK because her
vaccinations and worming aren't up to date."

QGLENN TODD, from Coventry, is finally going to give in and let her son Sean
have a pet. She says: "He wants a snake - which I don't. He is seven and I know
I'll end up looking after it. Are snakes a good idea in a house? Are they easy
to look after?" ASEAN SAYS: "Snakes can be good pets but they need specialist
care, food, expensive housing and heating equipment and are very long lived - up
to 25 years for 'beginner' species.

"This is unusual but I'd suggest stick insects or giant African land snails.

"A pet mouse or hamster could also work, with plenty of adult supervision and
help. Pets are a great way to teach kids responsibility and empathy, but it's
vital to match difficulty level with the child's expectations and abilities.

"Maybe you'll allow him to have a snake when he's a teenager if he's still
fascinated by pets and animals and adamant he'll take care of one."

headline: Star of the week

The English bull terrier and finance writer Danny have been to more than 20
countries, including the US, Austria, Italy, France, Romania and Greece.

on trains or next to me in the car if I'm driving.

"Travelling with a dog is brilliant.

Rocky makes my adventures so much more interesting."

headline: A dog is for life...not just for summer
content_plain:
OWNERS who struggle to care for their dogs when the kids go back to school are
being urged NOT to hand them over to rescue centres.

Rehoming charity Dogs Trust says it has seen an alarming trend in young dogs
being abandoned in August and September, following the school holidays.

Last year, it saw a 12 per cent increase in pets being given up at the end of
the summer.

The average age was just three and a half.

Often, being around children for six weeks can lead to behaviour problems as
pets struggle to adapt to the change in their home environment.

A Dogs Trust spokeswoman says: "Sadly, in the past we have seen spikes in the
number of people returning their dogs to us after the summer holidays, when
their dog struggles to adjust to the new routine, or because they were only
purchased to keep children entertained over the summer break.

"Dogs can make a wonderful addition to a family, but it's a decision which
shouldn't be taken lightly. Having a pet is a lifetime commitment, and potential
owners should think carefully about the reality of dog ownership and whether it
is suitable for their lifestyle.

"We hope people thinking of adopting one will remember that a dog is for life,
not just the summer holidays."

The charity offers these tips: l CONSIDER how your dog's daily routine will
change when school starts. They may get less attention than they are used to, or
be left alone for longer.

Gradually introducing these changes in advance will help your dog adjust better
to their new routine.

l DOGS are social, intelligent and active animals, so it is important to
exercise their bod-ies and minds. Make sure your dog has plenty to keep it
occupied, such as interactive puzzlefeeders, safe chews and their own toys made
from a variety of materials.

l YOU might also want to consider asking a friend or dog walker to pop in if
your dog is going to be left by itself for longer periods.

l SOME dogs might find the school run overwhelming, as there are likely to be
lots of unfamiliar adults, children, noises and other dogs around.

Think about walking your dog at other times of the day, when it is a bit quieter
outside and there is less going on.

Owners who feel they need professional help can take part in Dog School, a
training programme set up by the charity in the hope that it will keep families
together and stop pets being handed in.

lFind out more at dogschool.org.uk

headline: Simply Devonly
content_plain:
WEREN'T those Victorians a clever lot, eh? Not only did they invent the electric
light bulb and the bicycle, they also discovered the joys of the British seaside
 ensuring their towels got prime spots before any German tourists could think
twice.

And you can see why.

There is so much to do on a holiday beside the sea.

Whether it be on the front surrounded by old-fashioned beach huts, piers
reaching out into the blue, crazy-golf courses, quaint little ports or modern
waterside parks.

We stayed at Hoburne Devon Bay caravan park, nestled on the hill above Paignton
in Torbay, on the stretch of coast known as the English Riviera.

Our two-room caravan was spotless and a good size for the four of us. There was
one en-suite, another bathroom and big kitchen diner living room with sofa bed,
with decking outdoors.

The park itself is medium-sized with a huge number of amenities  indoor pool
with waterslides, massive outdoor pool and sunbathing area, adventure
playground, cafe, restaurant, main entertainment area, shop, launderette and
football pitches.

A 15-minute stroll away is the charming beach of Goodrington Sands. As well as
the red-hued sands, there is the fabulous Splashdown Quaywest waterpark  and a
leisure centre with closed-circuit cycle track open to the public and bike hire
available.

There's also a steam train running along the coast, a local zoo, the English
Riviera Ferris wheel, gokarts, amusement arcades plus loads of walks and trails.

Delicious rewards Despite it being high season, the park never seemed too busy.

And you could spend your entire holiday on the park or use it as a base for
exploring the area.

My dance skills leave a lot to be desired so we gave the bingo and dancefloor a
swerve but there's a full programme of evening events.

Instead, we opted for busy days and cosy nights in on the sofa.

There was a lovely hike along the South West Coast Path to the nearby fishing
port of Brixham, discovering ancient woodlands and the almosthidden coves of
Elberry and Churston  where we went for a dip to cool down. The swim was
followed by the delicious fish and chips  and a bus back to base.

Next day our adventure took us back to Elberry Cove, where we spent the day on
the shingle dipping in and out of the clear water and getting up close and
personal with schools of fish and a friendly seal who happily bobbed about, just
15ft from the shore.

Although those Victorians were clever they couldn't master the weather. We had
three glorious days, one mediocre and one terrible.

But there is so much to do, both on the park and in the surrounding area, it
really is the Great British Holiday the weather cannot ruin.

ALEX COHEN GO: DEVON STAYING THERE: A three-night weekend break at Hoburne Devon
Bay in a holiday caravan or lodge is from £179, and seven nights is from £669.
Caravan touring pitches are from £105 for three nights. Dog friendly
accommodation is also available. See hoburne.com.

headline: Kids clueless in cashless UK
content_plain:
CHILDREN are heading back to school - but they are not learning the vital lesson
of how to manage their money. Youngsters are less familiar with cash due to
seeing their parents pay by card all the time, a study by University College
London's Institute of Education has found.

It has left them struggling with basic tasks such as working out how much they
should pay when at a shop checkout and how much change they should get.

Researcher Dr Jennie Golding, is "shocked" by the findings, and warns a lack of
financial knowhow could add to Britain's growing debt crisis.

Significant problem In one primary school, seven and eight-year-olds were using
plastic coins to work out their shopping total and change due.

Half of the class had "significant difficulty", as they were unfamiliar with the
use of coins, different combinations of values, or the notion of "change".

Her observations in a secondary school classroom found none of the teens were
getting pocket money or working part-time.

If they went shopping, they were given money or their parents would pay 
usually by card. When the teacher showed one class of 14 and 15-year-olds a
spreadsheet for her monthly budget, students showed no understanding of taxes or
loans such as mortgages  describing them as a "rip-off".

Dr Golding says: "There's already a significant problem with debt in this
country. And those struggling with it will have been brought up handling money h
th t much more than youngsters today do. My concern is that the problem will
escalate and we'll have more people not able to manage their money effectively 
and struggling with increased poverty as a result."

The same issues are continuing into later life.

A separate study by UCL Institute of Education and the University of Cambridge
found one in three adults in England and Northern Ireland is incapable of
working out the correct change when shopping. While four in ten struggle to
understand when a simple discount is applied to an everyday product.

Professor John Jerrim, also f th I tit t f of the UCL Institute of Education,
says: "The research highlighted how England is facing a crisis in terms of
adults' financial literacy skills."

Jamie Smith-Thompson, of pensions advice specialist Portafina, says: "The sooner
children start learning about money and the role it plays in our lives, the
better equipped they will be when it comes to managing their finances as an
adult."

To help get the kids thinking about money and how it works, here are some
talking points for each age group and a quiz for the teens and grown-ups.

lQuiz devised by Portafina, KickStart Money, MyBnk and Young Money

AT this stage it is about making the connection that the things we need and want
cost money. So to get these things, we need to earn money and save it, too. TALK
ABOUT l Where does money come from? l What do we use money for? l How do we get
more money? l What happens if you save money? GET them to understand that money
is precious and that is does not grow on trees. It is also about grasping the
fact that different things cost different amounts of money, which is why savings
are so important. TALK ABOUT l What type of things do parents and grown-ups have
to spend their money on each month? l On average, how much do people earn a
year? l Think of the one thing you really want - how much does it cost? l How
long would it take you to save up and buy it? THE crucial, final building block
- understanding some spending is essential and some isn't, and being able to
balance between your needs and wants. TALK ABOUT l How much does it cost your
parents to run your home? l Can you list all of the monthly essentials and guess
how much each of them cost? l You want something but can't afford it - what
should you do? l If you were paid £10 a week, what would you do with it? AGED 5
- 7 Understanding concept of money AGED 8 - 11 Understanding value of money AGED
16 - ADULT They should be ready BUT even adults struggle with basic concepts.
Here are grown-up questions to test your knowledge. (Answers below) QUIZ 1.
Explain the advantage of compound interest compared to simple interest. 2. Which
of these is better for a saver - an account which calculates interest daily,
monthly or yearly? 3. Do you know what your personal savings allowance is? 4.
Explain the difference between APR and AER. 5. What does the term PAYE stand
for? 6. Explain the difference between a standing order and a direct debit. 1.
Compound interest means you get interest on interest. 2. Daily calculation is
better for a saver. 3. The personal savings allowance means a basic-rate
taxpayer (20 per cent tax on income) can earn £1,000 interest on savings per tax
year without paying tax on it. 4. The interest rate you receive when you save
money in an account is known as the Annual Equivalent Rate (AER). The Annual
Percentage Rate (APR) is what you are charged for borrowing products. Both take
into account any fees and charges. 5. Pay As You Earn. This is how most
employees pay tax. It is deducted by the employer before you see it. 6. With a
standing order, you instruct your bank to pay the money to a particular person
or company. It is your responsibility to change the payment details (eg, the
date or amount) if they need to be changed. A direct debit is an instruction to
your bank to release money from your account to pay amounts automatically - the
billing company has control rather than you. AGED 12 - 15 Understanding money
management ANSWERS

headline: HOW APPLE ARE FIGHTING BACK
content_plain:
BEEFED-UP CAMERAS: For the first time, the iPhone will have three rear cameras.
If the rumours are true, the triangle of lenses will sit in a big square bulge
on the back of the iPhone.

It looks like Apple will have a new night mode for low light situations such as
outdoors at night. It is possible all three sensors will work together to
deliver high-resolution images. FRONT CAMERA IMPROVED: The selfie camera,
already good on the iPhone, will go from 7MP to 12MP. This will be on all the
new iPhone models.

NEW FACE ID: The facial recognition capability of the next iPhone will work
across a wider angle, so you can unlock it by looking at it even when it is
lying flat on the table, for instance. TWO-WAY CHARGING: The next iPhone will
feature, on some models, wireless charging that works in two directions. So if
your friend's phone is running low, holding it to the iPhone will recharge it.

FASTER CHIP: The A13 chip to be in the new iPhone will be even faster and more
powerful than current models. This will make more complicated apps possible,
such as advanced augmented reality effects where the camera's view is overlaid
with items from online. Think Pokémon Go on steroids. WHAT ELSE?: The price is
likely to be the same as last year's models (currently from £749 for the iPhone
XR, from £999 for the iPhone XS). And it looks like there'll be a more powerful
charger in the box, so recharging will be much faster. THE RIVALS Samsung Galaxy
S10+, from £799, samsung.com: This is a fast phone that is a real pleasure to
use. Solid software, gorgeous design and excellent cameras. It has two-way
charging and a fingerprint sensor buried in the screen itself.

Huawei P30 Pro, £899, john lewis.com: The best camera phone on the market, bar
none, thanks to its brilliant multiple Leica lenses and clever artificial
intelligence software that does a lot of work to make your shots look great.

Oppo Reno 10x Zoom, £699.99 from carphonewarehouse.com: Chinese brand Oppo is
the one that's nudged Apple out of the top three status with phones like this
handset with triple cameras. One of the cameras uses a periscope design where
the light is reflected along the inside of the phone for a telephoto effect.

headline: PAIR WERE FORCED TO HAVE SEX
byline: EXCLUSIVE by JAMES BEAL and NICK PISA
content_plain:
A BRITISH actress was forced into a lesbian encounter with Virginia Roberts as
Jeffrey Epstein watched, The Sun on Sunday can reveal.

The woman was trying to make a breakthrough in the US and had left the UK for
the Hollywood hills.

A source said: "Virginia and the actress were forced to have sex with each
other. It was definitely not something they wanted to do ... it was so that
Jeffrey could watch them. He forced them to do it."

The news comes as pictures taken in 2005 emerged, showing ex cabinet minister
Peter Mandelson out with Epstein in a Caribbean boutique. The pair were on the
luxury resort of St Barts close to private island Little St James, which Epstein
owned.

EVIL . . Epstein It was where he entertained the likes of Bill Clinton, Naomi
Campbell and Prince Andrew.

Paedophile Epstein, 66, was found dead on August 10 in his New York prison cell,
where he was facing charges of sex trafficking and conspiracy. Prince Andrew has
been under increasing pressure to face questions about his involvements with
Epstein since a photograph appeared of the royal with his arm around the
then-17-year-old Virginia. The snap was reportedly taken by Epstein in 2001.

headline: Superstar lawyer who is Andrew's worst nightmare
content_plain:
IN his department-store blazer, checking the time on his thirty-dollar watch,
David Boies looks like any other New York City businessman.

Yet this is the "superstar litigator" with Prince Andrew in his sights over
allegations linked to paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.

Those who know Boies told The Sun on Sunday the lawyer, 78, would make
"mincemeat" of Andrew if he gets to formally question the prince over the
Epstein scandal.

Boies, who charges £1,500 an HOUR for his services, is the man Epstein's alleged
"sex slave" Virginia Roberts Giuffre has turned to.

He has been nicknamed "the Michael Jordan of the courtroom" and "the Tiger Woods
of the legal world".

Boies represented former US Vice President Al Gore when he sued George W Bush
over the disputed 2000 presidential election.

The year before, he beat Microsoft in a landmark competition case in which the
judge ordered the IT giant split into two companies.

Boies' memory has been likened to a human hard drive as he can pluck obscure
facts from decades ago to bolster his legal arguments.

He is known to conduct multiple phone calls at the same time and his superhuman
work ethic is famous. He once asked a colleague: "Would you rather sleep ... or
win?" He is also known for his ego and has said: "I win virtually every case I
should win and I win a number of cases people think I shouldn't."

Boies was born in Illinois, to teacher parents. He would memorise stories read
to him by his mother as dyslexia meant Boies could not read them himself.

'If he says a case isn't going away, it isn't' Because of that dyslexia, he
speaks in court without notes. He has kept his Midwestern accent, and some say
juries relate better to him as a result.

He steers clear of using long words and legal jargon, giving him a disarming
style in court in even the most complex of cases.

He wears suits from department store Macy's and has a basic watch, but some of
his tastes are much more extravagant.

He is fond of Las Vegas and has blown £8,000 in a single weekend. But Boies
insists he never gambles "amounts of money that make any difference to me".

His wine collection is not humble, either. The cellar at his mansion north of
New York City is large enough for 8,000 bottles.

No wonder, given he owns a vineyard in California, the State where he had a
breakthrough win in court to back same-sex marriage. He owns a ranch and a
yacht.

Father to six children by three women, he loves to be seen on the Manhattan
social circuit with his third wife Mary, 69, a lawyer.

But he has experienced tragedy too. His son Jonathan  also a lawyer  died this
year, aged 50.

And his reputation took a battering when he represented shamed movie producer
Harvey Weinstein in 2017.

Now his firm is acting for Ms Roberts and a number of Epstein's other alleged
victims pro bono  meaning for free.

Some have even described this case as Boies' shot at redemption, though he has
laughed off the suggestion.

Boies has made "multiple requests" to interview Andrew and this week said he was
considering legal action pressing the royal to give evidence under oath.

US solicitor Daniel Bibb, who was a Manhattan prosecutor for 20 years, said
Andrew, 59, faces a daunting adversary.

He told The Sun on Sunday: "David leaves no stone unturned and has a legal team
who are about as good as he is. If David goes out there and tells Prince Andrew
this case isn't going away, you can take it to the bank it isn't going
anywhere."

Boies was seen outside Manhattan's federal court this week with Ms Roberts, 36.

She claims she was forced to have sex three times with Prince Andrew when she
was 17  at an "orgy in London", at Epstein's home and at an "orgy" on his
private island in the Caribbean.

Andrew was friends with the pervert for more than a decade. Epstein killed
himself in jail last month, while facing sex-trafficking charges.

The royal strenuously denied "having any form of sexual contact or relationship"
with Ms Roberts but questions remain about his behaviour and his frequent visits
to Epstein's questions homes. Now Andrew may be forced to answer those
questions. This week, 16 of Epstein's alleged victims were given the chance to
tell their harrowing stories in court.

Speaking after the hearing, Ms Roberts urged the prince to "come clean" and
said: "He knows what he's done."

Boies stuck the knife in, adding: "Anybody can deny things in a printed
statement.

"It's a different thing to come here and answer questions under oath, subject to
cross-examination.

"Those are the kinds of answers we are eventually going to get."

Mark Bederow, a New York defence lawyer, said: "Boies is dogged and known for
his brilliant legal acumen.

"He is an experienced, highly respected litigator. I would say he is in the top
tier of lawyers in America. He's top-notch, for sure."

Boies began his career at Cravath Swaine & Moore, arguably the most respected
law firm in America, with a raft of wealthy and powerful clients.

'Dyslexia forced him to work twice as hard' By 31, he had become the firm's
youngest partner.

In 1997, he left to set up his own firm, Boies Schiller Flexner.

Colleagues thought he was mad to leave such a good job.

But within an hour of the news breaking, he had his first client  DuPont, the
chemical giant.

He came into the public eye by representing Al Gore before the US Supreme Court
in the 2000 presidential recount controversy.

Boies  like Gore, a Democrat  suffered a rare reversal and would afterwards
admit: "I lost the whole f*****g country."

But he won a blockbuster antitrust case against Microsoft on behalf of the US
Department of Justice.

So confident was Boies that on the eve of taking a key deposition from Microsoft
founder Bill Gates, he threw aside his briefing notes and relaxed by watching
the Kevin Costner film Tombstone.

Boies still won the case. Boies fought off a libel suit brought against telly
network CBS by US Army general William Westmoreland, making himself a champion
of the free Press in the process.

And he has been feted in the pages of Time magazine and the New York Times.

Joe Patrice, a senior editor at legal mag Above The Law, has met Boies several
times and talks of his "stellar" reputation.

Patrice said: "He is very analytical and, due to his dyslexia, has had to work
twice as hard at things.

"That has contributed to his mindset where he works through things methodically.

"If David Boies sets his sights on you  especially in a case like this, where
money is not an object  you need to worry.

"Your hope is that the client stops paying. But here that's not going to happen,
s pursue it so he's going to doggedly it." Boies was criticised for defending
Harvey Weinstein, 67, over the abuse claims that sparked the #MeToo campaign.

He hit back by saying everyone had a right to be defended and has pointed out
that his firm had represented Weinstein for years before the claims surfaced.

He was even branded a "thug" for trying to shut down a story about a biotech
firm that collapsed amid allegations of massive fraud.

Either way, Boies' clients know one thing. He will give them his all.

As his fellow lawyer Mark Bederow said: "When an attorney like David Boies says
he's coming for you, you can assume he's coming for you."

l sundayfeatures@the-sun.co.uk

headline: Lousy air heart risk
content_plain:
PEOPLE with heart disease should avoid traffic jams and consider wearing face
masks, experts warn.

Air pollution and environmental noise increase the risk of heart attack and
stroke, they say.

The European Society of Cardiology says sufferers should use air purifiers
indoors and respirator masks in polluted areas.

A healthy diet, not smoking and exercise were also recommended.

headline: WHO GOT RUNS IN CRICKET PAVILION?
content_plain:
A VILLAGE cricket row exploded after poo was left on dressing-room benches.

Volunteers had to work "through the night" to clear up the mess, discovered
after a local derby.

Buckinghamshire side Chesham had cruised to a six-wicket home victory over
neighbours Burnham.

But sources say staff later walked into the away dressing room and discovered
the benches were used as a toilet. A source said: "They were covered in poo.
Chesham were due to host a big game the next day.

"Their poor staff had to work through the night to clean it up." The discovery
Foul play ...

on July 20 was reported to the Home Counties Premier Cricket League  and has
since caused uproar.

The source added: "It's just not village cricket. The Chesham boys were pretty
angry and rightfully so. Some even wanted to report it to police."

Burnham refused to comment on the claims but are understood to deny any
involvement. Chesham secretary Chris Royals last night said: "There is an
ongoing league investigation so we won't be able to say anything."

League chairman Martin Phillips said it was not "appropriate" to comment.

cricket club

headline: MADE UP FOR JOAN
content_plain:
I LOVED the photos of Dame Joan Collins, 86, lined up with the other stars of
the Charlotte Tilbury makeup campaign. What a lady. Joan, above, is classy,
funny and damn stylish. Or as my nan would've said, well turned out.

headline: LEARN THE LESSONS OF LATEST AID WASTE
content_plain:
ANOTHER day, another story about taxpayers' money being wasted in foreign aid.

This week it emerged that classrooms in nearly 800 schools in Pakistan - paid
for by us - have been closed because they were badly built and unsafe.

The buildings were erected as part of a £107million aid project and their
closure has left 115,000 children taking lessons outdoors or in overcrowded
rooms.

So, presumably, back where they were in the first place. On the upside, this has
prompted some MPs to call for an inquiry about how our annual foreign aid budget
- around £14billion - is spent.

On the downside, this is an example of yet more foreign aid money that has
fallen into the wrong hands and ended up being wasted.

In the meantime, British schools are crying out for investment.

So why are we spending money on Pakistani schools and not our own? Meanwhile, in
the UK, overseas patients have left the NHS with more than £150million in unpaid
bills for treatment, it emerged this week. That cash could pay for 6,000 nurses,
22,000 heart bypasses or nearly 5,500 junior doctors.

Two London hospitals are owed £28million each, including almost £500,000 from
one patient alone.

Apparently staff are reluctant to chase payments, with doctors' leaders saying
their obligation to charge overseas patients is "racist" and deters vulnerable
groups from seeking help.

To me, that sounds completely bonkers.

I don't understand why you are not asked to produce your NHS number - we all
have one - when you get to hospital.

Every other country asks, so why not us? It's a national service, not an
international one.

headline: FORMER Big Brother contestant Kate [...]
content_plain:
lFORMER Big Brother contestant Kate Lawler is campaigning to remove the taboo
facing women who don't want children.

She said she considers her two dogs, Baxter and Shirley, as her family and she's
very content with that.

She's right, of course. Whether or not you want children comes down to personal
choice and it should be fine for women not to want them.

The only problem with her situation, though, is that her fiancé is "desperate"
for children, which doesn't sound so good.

I think the most important thing when choosing whether or not to have kids with
someone is the pair of you both being on the same page.

headline: Real friends, not screen friends, are key to happy kids
content_plain:
GIVEN the alarming rise in mental health issues in young people, this week's
news that children are the unhappiest they have been for almost 25 years is no
surprise.

Almost a quarter of a million kids in the UK  around 219,000  report being
unhappy with their lives as a whole, according to The Children's Society.

This is partly due to increasing loneliness and turbulent friendships. And guess
what has been highlighted by charity experts as the main cause? "Excessive
social media use." Anyone surprised by that either? Thought not. Of course, not
all children are unhappy. But parents should take this news as a serious warning
shot. Because when it comes to our children's happiness, the trend is clearly
going in the wrong direction.

With social media, the problem is partly one of expectations.

Most grown-ups are seasoned enough to take the inevitable "my perfect life"
posts on Instagram with a pinch of salt.

But if you are new to these things, being bombarded with images on your mate's
Instagram page of the life you are "meant" to be living could make even the most
secure children begin to feel inadequate.

The other problem is that it's always "on"  and so are our kids.

It used to be that children could shut the front door on a day of school and
leave it on the outside until morning. Now, though, there is 24-hour access.

Another news story this week revealed that nine out of ten teens aren't getting
enough sleep or exercise. It doesn't take a genius to link the two issues.

Social media  and reality TV  also reveal a new emphasis on appearance that
has changed so much in the past 25 years, for adults as well as children. It's
just that children are more susceptible to that pressure.

Other things have changed too  not least our approach to parenting (which
wasn't even a word 25 years ago). We are much more child-focused, which isn't a
bad thing necessarily.

But telling our kids they are the best, no matter what they do, risks them
thinking they are the best without doing anything at all to be so.

Yes, we can help boost our children's self-esteem. But what we should really do
is help them boost their own self-esteem by doing things that make them feel
good about themselves.

Obviously, more families now have two parents in the workplace. That is a good
thing but perhaps some working parents feel the need to compensate for their
absence in ways  such as too many screens and "treats"  that aren't
necessarily brilliant for their children's mental health.

I write as a mother of two who worked more or less throughout my children's
young lives.

I'm proud to say we all made it through in one piece.

Obviously, I am no parenting expert. And I'm not claiming to have the answer to
the world's ills.

But over the years, I've identified three golden rules I believe build a
foundation for happy kids.

The first is sport. I passionately believe that being part of a team, having
regular exercise, being out and about and maintaining a routine offers kids
stability and boundaries.

It helps children feel good about their bodies and their abilities, boosting
their self-esteem.

The second is friendship. I am talking about proper friendship  not Facebook
"friends" you never meet. When kids leave their phones at home and develop real
friendships, they find people they can talk to and have fun with Never
underestimate the importance of fun.

The third golden rule is probably the most important.

Keep talking.

There are too many tragic examples recently of young people who felt it
necessary to take their own lives.

I believe a problem shared is a problem halved.

No matter how bad something is, talking always helps.

I don't remember ever reading about suicide when I was younger  especially not
suicide in young people. Now it is the biggest cause of death among people aged
20 to 34 and it affects three times more men than women.

That is a scary statistic. The causes are complicated but we need to keep
channels of communication open with our kids. That way, if they are unhappy, we
will know about it.

And if we know about it, we at least have the potential to help.

A problem shared is a problem halved

headline: TAKE OFF THE HEAT
content_plain:
WELL, I don't know about you but I am filled with relief that the heatwave - and
even summer - is over.

The cooler weather is perfect timing for going back to school and back to work,
so we can all concentrate again.

Hot weather is great when you are lying around in swimwear next to a pool ...
not if you are sitting in a classroom or office.

headline: FROM DAD TO WORSE FOR ALFIE
content_plain:
REMEMBER Alfie Patten? For a while, in 2009, he was known as the nation's
youngest father at the age of just 13.

Then he found out, later that year, that it was another boy who had made his
15-year-old girlfriend pregnant. So Alfie was off the hook.

That should have left him with the feeling that he had dodged a bullet.

It could have spurred him on towards getting a good education and a job, to
building himself a future.

The adults in his life should have encouraged him to do just that.

Instead, this week he turned up at Lewes Crown Court to be sentenced after being
convicted of criminal damage.

The court heard he is now a jobless alcoholic who lives at home with his mother
and has a history of criminal offences.

He already had a 24-month suspended prison sentence hanging over his head after
being convicted on June 14 of shoplifting, theft and possession of an imitation
firearm.

This is a good reminder that suspended sentences do not work. Alfie Patten
clearly needs a bigger wake-up call than a suspended sentence or he risks ending
up dead from alcohol and drugs.

I saw a bench in my local park the other day that said: "Die with memories ...
not dreams."

So true. But this guy, who is creating all the wrong sorts of memories, is a
nightmare.

headline: A Loro Loro fun
subheadline: TENERIFE'S TWIN PARKS MAKE FOR WILD FAMILY FROLICS
content_plain:
THUNDERING down a 28-metre tall chute, through a tank full of sharks, is like
something from a Bear Grylls special.

But the Tower Of Power is the star attraction at Tenerife's familyfriendly Siam
Park.

The Thailand-themed waterpark, and sister attraction Loro Parque zoo and
aquarium, are must-visits on the Canary Island.

Siam Park is on Costa Adeje, on the south of the Spanish isle, and has something
for everyone  from baby and toddler pools in The Lost City to two beaches and a
lazy river for those just out to relax.

There is also a bundle of highoctane rides for adrenaline junkies  Tower Of
Power being the absolute daddy.

And the park is easy to get to, thanks to its bus service which picks up
visitors from Siam Park bus stops located all over Adeje, Los Cristianos and
Playa de Americas. Fares are from £7pp.

Siam Park has benefited in recent years from huge investment, which has seen it
nearly double in size.

The new Coco Beach has a monster wave pool with hundreds of loungers, plus rides
such as Patong Rapids and the Singha water-rollercoaster, on which you can hit
speeds of up to 40mph while in a dinghy. The VIP experience has been ramped up,
too. Guests can now book their own private area with Balinese beds in the
Champagne Club  or a villa with jacuzzi, TV, minibar and hammocks.

No wonder so many people flock to the park every year to bask in the sun, which
shines year-round. Even in October and November temperatures average around 26C.

I took my wife and three young children and the hours of wet-andwild fun flew
by.

Tigers and pandas My two daughters, aged six and nine, were absorbed by The Lost
City  think kids' TV favourite Fun House on water, mercifully with no Pat
Sharp.

Meanwhile, my 11-month-old son played with the water guns and explored the
minislides in the baby pool. I shared in the excitement of the water rides, too.
Many have a minimum rider height of 1.1 metres so four of us could go on
together  like on the Naga Racer ride where we raced each other, face-first, on
mats.

Don't worry, family-friends looked after the baby.

Faster rides have a minimum rider height of 1.25 metres. If you fancy taking on
the Tower of Power you need to be at least 1.4 metres, aged 14 or over and not
too scared of heights.

You hit speeds of up to 50mph, while guides order you to keep your head down at
all times and arms crossed across your chest.

It is so fast you barely open your eyes, so you miss the sharks in the water
tank as they pass by in a flash  unlike those watching from the viewing balcony
below.

If waterparks are not your thing, head to the north of the island for the
beautiful Loro Parque, on the outskirts of Puerto de la Cruz, which has been
visited by more than 50million people since it opened in 1972.

Opposite steak restaurant Brunelli's  well worth a visit to break up your day 
the zoo is a real treat for nature lovers.

The 33-acre site is home to animals including chimps, lions, hippos, tigers and
red pandas, while also housing an impressive number of reptiles and birds.

Making your way through an ice tunnel, you can see four species of penguin in an
incredible replica of their Antarctic habitat.

Loro Parque is also famous for its sea-life shows, with dolphins regularly
soaking those sitting in the first few rows.

Whatever park you choose, you will leave sopping-wet ... but with a huge smile
on your face.

STUART PINK GO: TENERIFE GETTING THERE: Flights to from the UK to Tenerife are
from £30.99 one way. See easyJet.com.

OUT & ABOUT: Twin tickets to Siam Park & Loro Parque are from £41.27 for kids
and from £59.87 per adult. See tickets.siampark.net/gb.

content_plain:

of red wine? Resveratrol, a plant compound found in plonk, can help relieve
stress in the brain, scientists have found.

With the kids heading back to school, you can kick back and enjoy a drink at the
end of a hard day.
