headline: LIVE LIFE IN FAST LANE WITH F1 EXPERIENCES
content_plain:
THE closest I ever got to being a Formula One driver was thrashing 102mph out of
my old Peugeot 206 down a German autobahn. But there is a better way.

F1 Experiences offers fans track tours, pit and paddock access, hospitality and
driver meet-andgreets. Packages also include tickets for Saturday practice days
and races on Sunday.

I saw Lewis Hamilton win a record-breaking sixth British Grand Prix at
Silverstone in July.

With the Hero package, I got to ride around the circuit on the same flatbed
truck the drivers use for their pre-parade lap.

With expert guidance from former drivers, you learn the right line to take
through the famous Luffield and Brooklands corners.

It made for the perfect start to my weekend.

Back at the main grandstand, you get a photo with the trophy before enjoying a
guided tour of the pit lane.

It is incredible to see the mechanics working feverishly away at 10pm. They are
so dedicated to their work, F1 chiefs had to impose a 1am curfew so they would
get a few hours' kip.

After Friday's practice sessions, there were more unforgettable experiences
lined up.

First up was a reception in the magnificent Paddock Club on the top tier of
Silverstone's new main stand, which also included an entertaining Q&A session
with driver Lando Norris.

Still only 19, Lando has been handed another year's deal by his McLaren-Renault
team.

From there, we have a look inside the drivers' cooldown room, where the top
three are weighed before venturing out on to the podium.

We got to stand on the same step as Hamilton did 48 hours before he celebrated
in front of 141,000 delirious home fans.

It was back down to the pit lane again for a four-stop tour that included a
brilliant chat with famed safety-car driver Bernd Maylander, whose Mercedes AMG
GT road car manages to roar around at 150mph. (Well, you wouldn't want to hold
up the traffic behind and let their tyres get cold.) Much is made of tyres in
F1. So, in the Pirelli pit, an ex-driver gets you to touch the soft (red), the
yellow (medium) and the hard (white) tyres to feel the difference in smoothness
of the rubber, plus the unique tread on the wetweather version if there is a
downpour. You just cannot get your head around how those pit crew can get four
changed in around two seconds!

Saturday - qualifying day - was deservedly spent feet up being wined and dined
at The Champions Club, watching all the action from the terrace of Silverstone's
University Technical College plus a special-guest visit from McLaren chief Zac
Brown.

It was the perfect spot to see Hamilton battle it out for pole position with his
Mercedes teammate Valtteri Bottas as they hared out of Woodcote corner on to the
old pit, straight before taking on Copse corner as if they were on a high-speed
rail.

To cap it all, fans can also get an amazing walk down the paddock - access
usually reserved for the drivers, team officials and select VIPs. And it was a
great chance to spot celebrities. My list included Bond star Daniel Craig,
rapper Will.i.am and 2009 F1 world champion Jenson Button.

My outlook as a fan has changed for ever - and I will watch future F1 races in a
whole new light.

LEE SMITH

headline: BUGGY'S A TRAVEL BUDDY
content_plain:
essential Silver Cross Jet, £275, silvercross baby.com ANYTHING that makes
travelling with kids easier is a must for parents. Which is why we love this
buggy from Silver Cross.

It's so small you can take it on a plane as cabin baggage - meaning there's no
need to go buggy-free in transit. It's available in five colours, including
silver and spearmint, weighs just 5.9kg, and easily folds into a neat bundle.

There's a soft padded seat that's suitable from birth, and you can change the
position of recline for your pint-sized passenger.

It also has a protective hood for the sun and can be used with a Silver Cross
car seat for when you arrive at your destination.

If you want to take the buggy on board, just make sure you don't let anybody tag
it at the gate. Be sure to explain that it's part of your carry-on luggage.

headline: ANYONE UP FOR PINBALL?
content_plain:
news YOU can get the Club Med feel for a decent price when a new hotel opens in
East London tomorrow.

Mama Shelter, owned by the same family who run the luxury brand, will have rooms
from £99 a night.

The Hackney hotel is the first UK branch of the chain and its boutique design
and ethos are inspired by the Seventies, with retro artwork to greet guests.

The 195-room hotel also has two Japanese-styled karaoke rooms, as well as video
games, pinball machines and table football on offer.

The hotel's website says: "Mama Shelter is a living and meeting space, a true
urban refuge that's not just beautiful, modern and lively but also popular,
friendly and sexy."

See mamashelter.com.

headline: IT is 34C in Turkey [...]
content_plain:
IT is 34C in Turkey - and seven nights' allinclusive hot spot at the 5H Garcia
Resort & Spa is from £315pp, including flights from Gatwick on October 14. Find
out more or book now at teletextholidays.co.uk or call 020 30011 273.

headline: WIZZ AIR is to launch [...]
content_plain:
WIZZ AIR is to launch flights from London Southend Airport to Bucharest and
Vilnius from November this year.

The airline will fly five times a week to Bucharest from November 22 and twice a
week to Vilnius from November 23, with fares from £16.99pp one way.

The low-cost airline will also add twice-weekly flights to the Spanish city of
Castellon from December 9, with fares from £12.99pp one way and daily flights to
Vienna from Luton, starting in July next year from £16.99pp one way. See
wizzair.com lMARRIOTT will remove small plastic toiletry bottles from its 7,000
hotels by December 2020.

The hotel giant, which gets through 500million shampoo, conditioner and shower
gel bottles every year, will replace them with larger bottles that are easier to
recycle.

headline: SLOPE OFF WITH CHAMPS
content_plain:
CLUB Med is celebrating the launch of its newly renovated hotel in Alpe d'Huez -
with a snowsports week with British Winter Olympians Jenny Jones and Billy
Morgan.

The all-inclusive specialist's Masters Of The Mountain week - exclusively for
British customers - will take place between March 22 and 29, 2020, and see
slopestyle medallist Jenny and men's big air winner Billy host activities at the
new resort.

The pair will be offering riding sessions and technique tips on the slopes as
well as stretching and meditation classes apres ski.

Other activities on the special week include a sunset torch-lit descent and ski
slalom races. You will need to dig deep - prices start at £2,099pp - but include
all-inclusive premium accommodation, flights and transfers, gourmet food and
open bar as well as ski pass, lessons and mountain guides for all levels, plus
activities.

For details, see clubmed.

co.uk/masters-of-the-mountain.

headline: TEMPLE OF HORRORS
content_plain:
HORROR fans and chill seekers will love the latest round of monthly film
screenings at the Andaz London's Temple Cinema.

Sealed off for decades, a Masonic temple complete with majestic thrones, marble
columns and a golden zodiacadorned ceiling was discovered when the 5H East
London hotel was first renovated.

Now restored to its former glory, the unique gothic venue is the perfect place
for a horror movie screening. On September 26, the cinema will screen The Sixth
Sense. On October 31 it's the turn of Hitchcock classic Psycho.

Tickets are from £20 per head and include bottomless popcorn. See
andazlondonevents.com.

headline: FROZEN 2 MAGIC AT PARIS PARK
content_plain:
BE prepared to let it go at the Frozen Celebration at Disneyland Paris from
January 11 next year.

The long-awaited tribute to the popular film will feature a host of experiences
at the French theme park until May 3. A new show - Frozen 2: An Enchanted
Discovery - will star Anna, Elsa, Kristoff, Olaf and Sven and features new
floats and dancers bringing the second film, due out in November, to life.

In the Animation Celebration in the Walt Disney Studios park you can sing with
the reindeers, master Anna's magical moves and surprise Elsa in her ice palace.

Everyone's favourite snowman, Olaf, will be doing personal meet-and-greets for
the first time from November 17 this year - you will need to register on the
LineBerty app to reserve your hug.

The celebration will also feature a host of sweet and savoury bites inspired by
the world of Frozen's Arendelle and the nightly illuminations and fireworks will
get a frosty Frozen makeover, too.

Packages during the school holidays start from £329pp with Magic Breaks and
include return flights from Luton, Manchester and Birmingham, two nights' Disney
Hotel accommodation, three-day Disney Parks entry, free-half board meal plan and
free Magical Shuttle airport transfers, based on arrivals on February 16, 2020.

There is also a free call from Mickey Mouse to announce your stay, a free Disney
activity book and 15 per cent off dining at Planet Hollywood and Earl of
Sandwich.

Price based on two adults and two children under 12 sharing. Book before October
1 at magicbreaks.co.uk or call 0330 880 5092.

headline: GEORGE EX LIVING IN £49 TRAVELODGE
content_plain:
GEORGE Michael's ex Fadi Fawaz has been living in a £49-a-night Travelodge after
being accused of trashing the singer's £5million home.

Jobless Fadi has traded his life of five-star luxury for a low-budget central
London hotel described by one TripAdvisor reviewer as "shockingly dirty".

The ex-hairdresser has kept a low profile, only emerging from his tiny room when
housekeeping staff need to make his bed  or to pop outside for a cig.

Fadi, 46, checked in to the Covent Garden hotel after allegedly going berserk
and smashing up ex-lover George's luxury mews home last month.

He was arrested on suspicion of aggravated criminal damage after causing
"significant" damage inside the property. When The Sun caught up with Fadi at
his Travelodge hideaway, he bizarrely denied being the late Wham! star's ex.

Lebanese Fadi, whose pals have previously begged him to seek mental health
treatment, said: "I'm not Fadi. Sorry to disappoint you.

"It's so tragic what happened to George. It's a terrible loss. But I don't
really know him. In fact I've never met him."

Fadi also claimed he was not staying at the hotel, merely using its lobby to
charge his mobile. But sources confirmed he had been there for "several weeks"
and was checked in until September 9. It is a huge comedown for Fadi, who was
not left anything in George's £97.6million will following his December 2016
death. He had lived at George's home ever since, despite the star's family
wanting him out.

The Travelodge, with rooms as cheap as £49 a night, has received mixed reviews
online.

r cri la cleanlin Guests have criticised the size of rooms, the lack of
facilities and the cleanliness of carpets, bedding and towels. Hayrick wrote on
TripAdvisor: "There is a powerful stench of sewage when you use the sink or
shower. Cleaners left previous guests' wet towels hanging behind the door."

LEFTIES organising anti-Brexit demos want to launch a socialist propaganda TV

headline: Funding for world influence
content_plain:
BRITAIN is to pump millions of pounds into boosting its post-Brexit role on the
world stage.

Chancellor Sajid Javid will reveal a £200million package of measures to enhance
the nation's "soft power" in his spending round this week.

He said: "As we leave the EU, we are deeply committed to playing a leading role
on the global stage, bolstering alliances, celebrating our culture and building
new trading relationships."

Funding will include £90million to upgrade our diplomatic presence, £60million
to extend the "Great" tourism campaign and £13million to back our G7 presidency
in 2021.

A further £46million will support the 2022 Commonwealth Games in Birmingham.

Sun on Sunday Says  Page 16

headline: SWIPE OUT TRAITORS
subheadline: STOP THE BREXIT BLOCKERS Commons passes could be taken away
byline: EXCLUSIVE by DAVID WOODING Sunday Political Editor
content_plain:
MUTINOUS MPs face having their Commons passes deactivated to stop them staging a
sit-in to block Brexit.

It is among a range of measures open to security chiefs to stop this week's
debates descending into chaos. Officials fear some will resort to desperate
action as feelings run high over Boris Johnson's decision to suspend Parliament.

Some MPs have secretly discussed occupying the Commons in defiance of the
Queen's decision to halt sittings from next Monday temporarily.

Any votes taken would only be binding if the mace  symbol of the monarch's
authority and kept by pro-Remain Speaker John Bercow  is in the chamber. But
contingency plans have been drawn up by security officials to cover every
eventuality, including a threat to bust prorogation.

One option discussed was to deactivate the Parliamentary passes which MPs and
peers must swipe to gain entrance to the estate.

A source said: "There would be merry hell if we did it but senior officials have
a plan for every eventuality - including the craziest scenarios. There was a
febrile atmosphere about the place before the recess but we suspect many will be
fired up for a battle when they return on Tuesday."

MPs will try to seize control of the Parliamentary agenda on Tuesday  and then
ram through a new law forcing the PM to delay Brexit unless he can strike a deal
with the EU.

But Brexit-backers will attempt to talk out the move by staging long-winded
debates and raising points of order during its passage through the Commons and
the Lords. Their idea is to run down the clock before the five-week suspension
of proceedings begins.

Once Parliament has been prorogued, sittings can only resume in the event of the
monarch's death, war or a national emergency, such as an earthquake or disease
outbreak. A "rabble alliance" of anti-Brexit MPs have discussed holding sittings
outside of Parliament. Security teams have had extra briefings and staff advised
to remove passes as they leave to avoid being harangued by demonstrators.

Labour MP Hilary Benn has emerged as the latest choice by an all-party group of
Remainers to lead a new government of "national unity". But Jeremy Corbyn still
believes he should be the man to take charge if the PM is forced aside.

david.wooding@the-sun.co.uk The Sun on Sunday Says  Page 16

headline: Royal fall payouts
content_plain:
VISITORS who slipped during trips to royal palaces have been handed tens of
thousands of pounds in compensation.

Three Tower of London tourists received £12,600, £7,200 and £3,700 between 2016
and 2018.

At Hampton Court Palace, there were payouts of £40,000 and £17,600.

Historic Royal Palaces  the charity that manages the sites  said: "We strive
to make them safe within the constraints of their historic status."

headline: TEEN MURDER RAP A boy, [...]
content_plain:
TEEN MURDER RAP A boy, 16, faces JPs tomorrow over the strangle murder of
Lindsay Birbeck, 47  dumped in an Accrington graveyard.

headline: Summer a gin win
content_plain:
THE "perfect" mix of rain and sun this summer is making it a bumper year for
gin, experts say.

With the tipple back on trend in recent years, British distilleries are toasting
a record harvest.

Gin is mostly made from grain mixed with juniper berries.

Matthew Russell, from Copper Rivet Disillery in Chatham, Kent, said: "It needs
lots of sunshine but also plenty of water. The timing of the weather this year
has been perfect."

headline: Bishop's poll call
content_plain:
THE Archbishop of Canterbury has told Remainers to "stop whingeing" and accept
the result of the 2016 Brexit vote.

Most Rev Justin Welby said: "We may not like it, but that is democracy."

Last week it emerged he was in talks to chair a "citizens' forum" to help avoid
a No Deal exit from the EU. But two days earlier he said he did not back a
second poll.

headline: Wayne dropped 3 women showing trousers in front off tight blue boxers
subheadline:
EXCLUSIVE: LIFT GIRL ON 7HR BOOZE-UP WITH ACE 'HIS WIFE WOULD NOT BE HAPPY WITH
JACUZZI STRIP'
content_plain:
htes A BRUNETTE pictured with Wayne Rooney in a hotel at 5.30am has told how he
earlier stripped to his pants in front of three women at a boozy Jacuzzi party.

t tl erl gse Karra Granados, seen in last week's Sun getting in a hotel lift
with Rooney, said the ex-England skipper and four DC United team-mates all
stripped to their skivvies during a wild seven-hour night out.

e Karra, 27, said: "Wayne took off his jeans and was dipping his feet in the
water. He joined in with everyone else. He had tight boxers on  they were blue
and I think they were Calvin Klein.'' She also told how Rooney and one team-mate
took her back to their hotel at 5.30am after the Jacuzzi party ended  where the
Manchester United legend fell asleep and she romped with his friend.

Karra added: "It was a crazy night  Wayne partied so hard with the others. It
was very intense. Everyone was going for it and Wayne was definitely letting his
hair down, joining in with everybody. He was in very good spirits.

"I think Wayne just wanted to feel like a normal guy on a night out, not a
famous person."

Karra told how she hooked up with Rooney, 33, and team-mates following a DC
United match in Vancouver on August 17.

She was with friends at nightclub Twelve West when they were given a VIP table
next to Rooney's group.

She said she poked fun at Rooney because he looked scruffy in a grey hoodie and
baseball cap.

Karra said: "I wasn't really paying attention to his party. But I almost spilled
a drink on one of them and we began chatting.

"I had no idea who Wayne Rooney was but someone mentioned that he was a famous
footballer."

While in the club Rooney, believed to be drinking rum and cokes, was pictured
deep in conversation with a second woman  a brunette wearing black leather
trousers. Pictures showed him putting his arms around her waist and her leaning
in closely to whisper in his ear.

Rooney later insisted the woman was "simply one of many who innocently asked for
autographs".

Karra, who did not know the woman, said: "They looked like they were quite
close, she was flirtatious.

"I didn't see her getting his autograph." Karra's account of that night fills in
a few details that Rooney omitted when he responded angrily on social media to
The Sun's story.

She told how the woman in the a te an Pierre's Champ picture was asked to join
her, Rooney and team-mates as they headed to another club, called Champagne
Lounge. After they all clambered into a limo, Rooney turned his attention
towards lawyer's assistant Karra.

She said: "Wayne's team-mate grabbed me by the hand and put me in the limo.

"He was pushing everyone in but there wasn't much room. Wayne said 'Come and sit
here next to me'.

"He put his arm around me.

The other girl was on the other side of the limo."

Once in Pierre's the other woman disappeared  and Karra found herself as the
only girl on Rooney's table as waiters brought them drinks.

After about an hour Karra, Rooney, two other women and four team-mates were
invited back to a barman's apartment.

It had a shared swimming pool and a Jacuzzi  which the group ended up using in
the early hours of the morning. Karra told how Rooney whipped off his jeans,
revealing blue Calvin Klein underpants, and dipped his legs into the water of
the Jacuzzi.

His team-mates also stripped to their underwear.

The two other women, friends of the barman, swam in the adjacent pool. Karra
said: "Wayne joined in with everyone else. He had tight boxers on.

"He kept his shirt on but his jeans got wet when they were laid out beside the
hot tub.

"When he put them back on it looked like he had p***** him-himself. I was making
fun of him about it."

At about 5.30am Rooney and one of his team-mates invited Karra with them back to
their hotel, the Hyatt Regency.

She said: "We went up in the lift together and all chatted for a bit. Then
Wayne, who just seemed absolutely exhausted, went to sleep."

Karra said she ended up kissing and cuddling the team-mate. She added: "I moved
over to his bed and we kissed.

"I was really tired so later I called a cab and went home."

Karra said she was devastated when she discovered the player she kissed was
married.

She added: "Nothing would have happened between us if I had known.

"Wayne was such a gentleman the whole time.

"But I'm not sure his wife would be happy to hear he stripped to his underpants
in a hot tub in front of women."

james.beal@the-sun.co.uk

headline: 1 killed & 9 hurt in bus stop knife fury
byline: By NICK PARKER Chief Foreign Correspondent
content_plain:
A TEENAGER was killed yesterday and nine other people injured in a knife attack
at a bus stop.

Three of the hurt are fighting for their lives.

Afghan asylum seeker Sultan Marmed Niazi allegedly slashed at the crowd with a
knife and a spit used to roast meat.

Brave bus workers pounced on him and disarmed him near a metro station in
Villeurbanne, in eastern France.

A 19-year-old man, on his way to a music festival, was the first attacked and
died at the scene.

A source said: "There were about 30 people in the crowd. He launched the attack
in broad daylight while people were waiting for a bus.

Niazi was in custody last night. He is said to have given "three conflicting"
reasons for the attack, none terror-related.

ROONEY'S antics with women have caused wife Coleen plenty of sleepless nights.

He also visited a Liverpool brothel and slept with granny Patricia Tierney, 48,

In July 2009, call girl Jenny Thompson claims Rooney slept with her just a month
before Coleen had their first son, Kai.

In 2011 it was reported that Rooney had a threesome with Jenny and prostitute
Helen Wood and in September 2017 he was seen in a car with Laura Simpson. Rooney

headline: Dear Deidre OUR housemate's boyfriend [...]
content_plain:
Dear Deidre OUR housemate's boyfriend is treating our home like his own and
sponging off us but she can't see it.

We are four girls in our early 20s. One girl got a new boyfriend two months ago.
Their relationship is intense. She spent the whole of one day crying because she
could not see him till the next morning. Her changing moods affect us all.

He doesn't work and he sleeps and farts on the sofa all day. He constantly
cadges our cigarettes. He eats our food and takes our housemate's credit card to
buy stuff but only ever for himself. He uses our washing machine and watches TV
without contributing to any bills. Our flatmate used to be highly motivated and
energetic but now she is a lazy couch potato like him.

Their relationship is very unhealthy but she does not seem to care.

0 Deidre SAYS: It is her choice to see him but you do not have to accept a
housemate being forced on you all.

Tell them together that he must start to pay his way. Refuse to give him
cigarettes and demand bills are split five ways.

If they argue, say they will have to find somewhere else to live. My e-leaflet
on Standing Up For Yourself will help you stick to your guns.

headline: NEVER HAD TO MATURE
content_plain:
WHAT is a married 33-year-old man doing taking off his trousers in a Jacuzzi
with young girls? You might say he's just having fun but no woman wants her man
larking around late at night with another woman.

Jumping in a hot tub is inappropriate and s nine out of ten times something will
happen, even if it didn't here.

Wayne has behaved so badly in the past he needs to be squeaky clean for his wife
to move on.

His problem is that he keeps getting into trouble when he has a drink. He simply
can't behave.

He's not matured because he's never had to worry about paying the bills. Coleen
is fiercely loyal and she will probably never leave him  but he needs to stop
disappointing her like this.

headline: I'M BIG BELOW SO PASSION IS A PAIN
content_plain:
Dear Deidre I AM big down below and my girlfriend can't cope.

She's 19 and I'm 21. She's my first proper girlfriend and I like her loads.

I have done sexual stuff with girls before, but not had full sex and I didn't
realise I was so wellendowed. I thought I was run of the mill.

My girlfriend had never had sex before and she stopped me the first time we
tried, because she said it was too painful.

We have tried since then but she struggles when we want to have sex. This is
really affecting our sex life and I don't want our relationship to end. What can
I do to make this better for her? 0 Deidre SAYS: I wonder if you are really
extra-large down below - or whether lack of experience means you just don't give
sufficient time to foreplay.

If your girlfriend isn't properly aroused before intercourse, then it's going to
hurt.

Experiment together to find out what kind of touches work for her.

My e-leaflets How To Thrill A Woman In Bed and Too Large? can help.

headline: Topic of the day
content_plain:
Topic of the day HALF of women in the UK are unhappy about the size or shape of
their breasts and most have an unrealistic notion of what breasts look like due
to celebs taking the silicone route. My e-leaflet Unhappy With Your Breasts?
will help you decide what's right for you. For a copy, email me or private
message me on Facebook.

headline: Dear Deidre I HAVE made [...]
content_plain:
Dear Deidre I HAVE made a fool of myself over a younger woman.

My mum was admitted to hospital last month and will be there for a while. I
noticed a very attractive nurse. I was wary of asking her out because I am 42
and she looks half my age.

I gave her a long letter telling her how much I admired her. I said I realised I
was too old for her but hoped we could be friends. She thanked me afterwards and
said it was lovely.

I suspect that she then showed some of her colleagues, because the atmosphere
has deteriorated. I overheard her telling another nurse I'm a creep. It has got
to the point where I am relieved now if she is off duty when I visit my mum. I
have always treated women with respect but I never seem to have any luck.

0 Deidre SAYS: Nurses often have to be wary of men falling for their caring role
and not understanding the professional boundaries, but this nurse has been
insensitive.

Let it go, as the atmosphere will ease, but focus on building up a social life
that includes women so you can get to know them as friends to start with. A
relationship can then develop naturally.

My e-leaflet Finding The Love Of Your Life will help you get started.

headline: I'D RATHER CHEAT ON DREAM GIRL
content_plain:
Dear Deidre I LASH out at strangers in the shopping centre and worry I'll get
arrested.

I'm 25 and pregnant with my third child. I've always had anxiety and depression
but the pregnancy seems to make it worse. Most days I take my boys to school
then go home and sleep all day. I never answer the door.

When I must go out, I go mental if someone looks at me oddly. A security guard
was called in a shop yesterday and I had to leave. My husband just says it's
because I'm pregnant. He's 26 and I wish he was more understanding. I've never
felt so alone.

0 Deidre SAYS: You are not well and need urgent help. Hormonal changes may be
the problem or perhaps anxieties about how this child will affect your life and
family.

See your GP, preferably with your husband. To help the doctor understand, write
down your symptoms and explain clearly how you're feeling. Tell your midwife,
too.

The PANDAS Foundation offers understanding support to help with pre/ antenatal
depression (pandasfoundation.org.uk).

headline: FAMILY FORUM
content_plain:
Dear Deidre MY fiancée's father wants to come and stay - but he hates pets of
all kinds and kicks our two dogs whenever he gets the chance.

He is a difficult man and drinks too much. When my fiancée was little, they
found a litter of kittens in the garden and he drowned them all.

I am 24. My girlfriend is 23 and is expecting our first child soon. I think this
is why her dad wants to stay, because we haven't seen him for two years.

I want to get on well with my fiancée's family. Her parents are divorced, so her
mum won't be visiting with him. Otherwise, I could ask her to keep watch on him.

I don't lose my temper easily but I love our two dogs. They are well behaved and
I don't know if I could hold myself back from belting this man if he tried to
hurt them.

? DEIDRE SAYS: Does your girlfriend actually want her dad to come to stay? She
has a choice, especially if he is a difficult drunk. You can say no together.

If she truly does want to see him, tell him beforehand that he must not upset
your dogs - or you. Watch carefully and, whenever possible, keep a closed door
between her dad and your dogs.

If he really has a drink problem, though, alcohol may undo everyone's best
intentions - and then you'd best insist he leave.

Dear Deidre I AM at the end of my tether. I have two sons and a daughter. The
boys hate one another.

There is never a moment's peace in our home. They have to share a room but
otherwise I have to separate them all the time. They are 12 and 13. My daughter
is just nine.

Both the boys have had problems at school. I'm 37 and have to deal with this
myself, as my husband and I live apart. He sees the children when he can.

The eldest one seems angry with the world just about all the time. He can be
aggressive and rude to adults and to his teachers. When he is annoyed about
something, he cannot let it go. I also worry that my daughter is being affected
by the turmoil - but I don't know how to keep them happy.

0 Deidre SAYS: Children tend to learn about adult relationships from their own
parents' behaviour - especially the same-sex parent. How was your break-up? Why
isn't their dad making the effort to see the children regularly? Unless there is
some reason why he shouldn't see more of the children, especially his sons, talk
to your husband.

Say he needs to see more of the boys so they feel valued and important to him.
It could make so much difference to how they value themselves.

My e-leaflet Stressed With The Kids? should help.

headline: Amazing lover's gay secret has left me broken
content_plain:
Dear Deidre SEX with my lover is wildly adventurous and satisfying as I enjoy
being submissive, but I think he may be cheating on me - with guys.

I have been in a dead-end marriage for 12 years. My husband is a good person but
does not give me what I truly need and does not make me happy.

We have come to realise that we are not well matched and we lead pretty separate
lives but still live in the same house.

I am 34, he is 35 and we have a daughter of 11 and a son of nine. They are
unaware of our troubles because we don't argue and we do a lot as a family.

I realised that part of finding myself was to understand what I need in a
relationship. I started to explore the idea that I might be submissive, in all
aspects of a relationship including sexually.

I met a man online who swept me off my feet. He is 39 and in a hollow marriage
rather like mine. I felt I'd met my soulmate.

Never before had I enjoyed so much variety in the bedroom and had so much fun
socially. He may have taken me a bit out of my comfort zone but he is just
perfect for me. We manage to meet in a hotel most weeks.

But today while he was in the shower I saw that he was still logged in to his
email on my laptop. I didn't plan to snoop but saw he had signed up to a gay sex
site, looking to meet men.

I have asked him before whether he is bisexual and he said no, but I am broken.
I thought he was perfect but he is not the man I thought I knew.

I haven't said anything to him yet. If I speak to him about it I know he will
say that it does not affect his feelings for me, and I do not need to know about
it.

This man has given me the most amazing, exciting months of my life but can I
accept that? He is very open-minded sexually and thinks it is normal to involve
other people in your sex life so he probably doesn't think that would be
cheating. I'm still married anyway, so how can I complain about cheating? 0
Deidre SAYS: This has been an exciting adventure for you, but this man doesn't
care for you in any meaningful, lasting way.

He is using you to pursue his own agenda of pushing the sexual boundaries and
will always put his wants before your needs.

Truth is, your self-esteem will be pushed lower and lower the longer you keep
seeing him, quite apart from the risk to your sexual health.

I know you say your marriage is hollow but better settle it one way or the other
than let your children think your lack of deep love for each other is normal.
You may not argue but they will pick up on the lack of passion.

Stop seeing your lover, organise a sexual health check and tell your husband
it's crunch time - either you rebuild your love for one another or separate so
you're both free to find genuinely caring partners.

My e-leaflet Your Relationship MOT can help you give your marriage the best
chance.

headline: SAT NAV CHAOS HITS AMBULANCE DRIVERS
content_plain:
AMBULANCE crews have been told to shun sat navs after dozens on 999 calls were
diverted to slower routes.

Some were described as serious incidents which "potentially led to harm".

Crews have been told to "look at road signs" instead as part of a shake-up.
Those using sat navs in some of the country's most heavily populated areas
reported problems on call-outs last year.

It led to a probe by the South East Coast Ambulance Service Foundation Trust
(SECAmb), which covers Surrey, East and West Sussex and Kent. It found 36
incidents alone happened on the Isle of Thanet in Kent. There were also 41
others elsewhere.

A report said: "By February 2019 multiple incidents had been recorded. Two were
declared serious incidents as they potentially led to harm."

One potential cause was setting the sat nav to "lorry mode" which sent them on
"incompatible" routes. Crews have since been advised to use local knowledge,
follow road signs and only use sat navs for the last part of a journey.

A SECAmb spokesman said of the serious incidents: "While GPS was a contributory
factor, it has been judged no harm occurred as a result."

They added: "The occurrence of GPS incidents has started to reduce and we are
closely monitoring the issue."

headline: Give me a tinkle

BRITS log on to dating sites while sitting on the loo  with six per cent
chatting online.

headline: Shoe are ya?
subheadline: MATCH THE CELEBS TO THEIR TRAINERS
content_plain:
IF you have ever wanted to step into a celeb's shoes, it has never been easier -
with the likes of Rihanna, David Beckham and Kanye West designing their own
footwear.

Last week Liam Gallagher launched a limited-edition trainer costing £99.95 that
was so popular it crashed the Adidas website.

GRAEME CULLIFORD thought it would be fun to see if you can match the star to
their shoe. Take his fun quiz to find out. Answers are below.

headline: 5-job ma dole con
content_plain:
A BENEFITS cheat fiddled nearly £63,000 by claiming to be housebound despite
holding down several jobs.

Mum of eight Andrea Blackburn, 40, "got a taste" for handouts after a valid
payment in 2008.

She fleeced benefits for five years after claiming she could barely walk.

But she was waitressing and worked in Tesco, M&S, Greggs and Sainsbury's.
Blackburn, of Middlesbrough, was caught when she was seen driving, which she
claimed she could not.

She got a ten-month suspended jail sentence after admitting fraud at Teesside
crown court.

headline: Hospital TVs theft
content_plain:
THIEVES have stolen televisions from three wards at a hospital.

Staff at Royal Derby Hospital branded the raiders "scumbags" for the thefts from
wards 205, 302 and 309.

The exact number taken is not known, but police are investigating.

Kayleigh Watts posted on Facebook: "If anyone would like to donate a television
we would be extremely grateful.

"Our poor patients have no television to watch!"

headline: MOTOWN chief Berry Gordy Jr [...]
content_plain:
MOTOWN chief Berry Gordy Jr took the label's name from "motor" and "town" as a
homage to Detroit city, where he used to work in the Ford Motor factory.

MAGIC

headline: IT TAKES 2 TO TANGO
content_plain:
STACEY Dooley and her pro dance partner Kevin Clifton are not the first Strictly
duo to add some extra magic to the mix with their sizzling chemistry ...

SOAP star Kara Tointon, 36, and dancer Artem Chigvintsev, 37, won the
Glitterball Trophy after falling for each other on the show in 2010. They stayed
together for three years.

ENGLAND rugby ace Ben Cohen, 40, lasted to week nine in 2013 thanks to dance ace
Kristina Rihanoff, 41. He later got divorced and now has a daughter, aged three,
with Kristina.

CORRIE actress Georgia May Foote, 28, was swayed by 28-year-old Giovanni
Pernice's charms in 2015, and the pair made the final. They went on to date for
almost a year.

YOUTUBER Joe Sugg, 27, and dancer Dianne Buswell, 30, narrowly lost out to
Stacey and Kevin in last year's final. They also became a couple and are
planning to move in together.

headline: Workers on booze
content_plain:
A FIFTH of home workers admit to boozing while doing their job, a study found.

They enjoy a bottle of wine or a pint or two at least once a week.

A third do a spot of vacuuming or cleaning when they're meant to be working at
home, while a fifth invite a friend over.

More than half said dodging the horror of commuting was the main benefit of home
working, the poll of 2,000 by accounting software firm FreeAgent found.

headline: CRAIG GROVEL HORWOOD Backstage . . Kevin, Di & Stacey with your [...]
subheadline:
EXCLUSIVE: STRICTLY STAR APOLOGY OVER SEX JIBE lTV judge admits: I made huge
error "I'm deeply sorry for cruel comments
byline: By LAURA ARMSTRONG Sunday Showbiz Editor
content_plain:
STRICTLY'S Craig Revel Horwood issued a grovelling apology last night after
saying celebs should sleep with their pro partners like Stacey Dooley to win.

The acid-tongued judge, 54, admitted he had made a "huge error" and he deeply
regretted his "hurtful" jibe, made during filming on Friday night.

Last year's champ Stacey  now dating former dance partner Kevin Clifton  was
sitting in the audience with her family at the time. Filming was halted as aides
rushed over to them, but her mum Di stormed from the Strictly studio.

BBC sources said Craig was savaged by bosses for the "totally unacceptable"
remark  and ordered to apologise.

Craig said last night: "I'm deeply sorry for the offence caused to Kevin and
Stacey and everyone who works on the show.

"I recognise that what I said was hurtful, cruel and incredibly disrespectful.
It was a huge error of judgment that I very much regret."

It came after reigning champions Stacey and Kevin took to the ballroom floor
during filming for the pre-recorded launch show, which will be aired next
weekend.

Following their performance, host Tess Daly asked the panel  Craig, Bruno
Tonioli, Shirley Ballas and newcomer Motsi Mabuse  for their advice to this
year's contestants.

Craig initially told her the wannabes should be inspired by documentary-maker
Stacey, 32.

He said she had been "dragged up from the dance gutter" before winning the show.

But he then added spitefully: "Of course, if you sleep with your dance partner
that helps..."

Sources said the snide remark sent shockwaves around the studio, and horrified
bosses immediately called for filming to be halted.

Worried aides flocked to Stacey and her family while executive producers
immediately decided to scrap the footage.

The hosts, panel and audience were then asked to return to their places to
refilm the sequence.

One source said: "It was an awful moment. Craig was obviously trying to be
funny, but realised as soon as he said it that he had gone too far.

"The audience was visibly shocked, as was Tess Daly and the other judges.

"Immediately after he made the comment, 'cut' was called, and chaos broke out.

"Several aides rushed over to Stacey and her family to check if they were OK.
They were all stunned, and Stacey's mum obviously wasn't OK at all.

"She looked very upset, and soon after that she left the studio.

"The bosses were absolutely furious with Craig and wasted no time in taking him
to one side afterwards and telling him the remark was totally unacceptable.

"They encouraged him to make a full apology to Stacey and Kevin, which he was
happy to do.

"He knows that what he said was completely out of line."

The launch show for this year's series will be screened on BBC1 next Saturday.

Days before filming, Stacey had shared her excitement about returning to
Strictly on social media with a series of photographs backstage. One, showing
her having her hair done, was retweeted by proud mum Di.

And boyfriend Kevin, 36, posted a heart emoji underneath the shot.

The Sun on Sunday revealed in April how Stacey was secretly dating him after
ditching longterm boyfriend Sam Tucknott. The pair were said to have grown close
while filming the show, with their on-screen chemistry helping them sail through
to the final last December.

After winning the trophy, Stacey gushed about her partner: "I should say
something quite poignant, shouldn't I? You know how highly I think of you. I
think you are the biggest gem. It's no surprise you have been in the final as
many times as you have.

"It's daunting doing something you haven't done before. But he's so patient and
he walks you through. You so deserve this."

Kevin replied: "Thank you so much, not just for being so amazing and for dancing
so well, but for being the most wonderful person to work with, to spend every
day training with.

"You've worked so hard. You are so lovely and I think the absolute world of
you."

Kevin supported Stacey as she performed on the Strictly Come Dancing Live tour 
despite not taking part himself. In January they were seen apparently sharing a
hotel date in Birmingham.

Stacey and personal trainer Sam, 30, ended their five-year relationship in
March.

But Sam got a shock when the pair cleared out their Brighton flat on April 1. He
spotted a text from Kevin on Stacey's phone which read: "I love you."

Stacey, who has a £250,000-ayear golden handcuffs deal with the BBC, later
texted Sam to insist she had only fallen for Kevin once the couple had
separated.

But her explanation failed to reassure Sam, who branded Kevin a "rat" and a
"snake".

Stacey and Kevin's relationship has since gone from strength to strength. In
July, Stacey broke her silence on the romance to gush about "amazing" Kevin 
who was previously married to Strictly pro Karen Clifton.

She told a newspaper: "What I am happy to say is, 'Kev's amazing, I'm happy,
life happens, I've got an amazing career and I'm very lucky.'" A BBC source said
last night of the judge's comment: "Craig was told in no uncertain terms that
this was completely unacceptable.

"It goes against everything the show stands for and it's right that he's issued
a full apology."

laura.armstrong@the-sun.co.uk The Sun on Sunday Says  Page 16 WHAT HE SAID TO
TESS 6Stacey was dragged up from the dance gutter..of course, if you sleep with
your dance partner that helps7

headline: Wiggins: I'd rather talk bikes than ride
content_plain:
CYCLING great Sir Bradley Wiggins says he does not miss the sport "at all".

Wiggo, 39, turned professional in 2001 and won a hatful of awards including
Olympic golds and the Tour de France.

He spent 15 gruelling years as a professional, starting on the track before
moving to road.

The star eventually quit in 2016 and gave a terse reply when asked if he would
enjoy a comeback.

He said: "No, I don't miss it at all. It doesn't leave room for many other
aspects in your life.

"I am fortunate that I can make a career talking and commentating about it now,
which I love doing as well.

"I've got the best of both worlds. I will always love cycling and the fans but I
don't miss the elite side of it because it's a very tough sport."

headline: 600 hours of training to thank for victory
content_plain:
BY the time Stacey Dooley lifted the trophy last year she had endured almost 600
hours of gruelling training.

Weeks before the final she was taken to hospital after tearing an intercostal
muscle behind her rib, and almost vomited from the pain.

Two days later she was back rehearsing and scored 36 out of 40 that week.

Stacey was not what you would call a natural dancer.

She even considered quitting after a disastrous score for her cha cha cha in
week two, before doggedly deciding to carry on.

So how frustrated she must have been on Friday to hear her triumph apparently
put down to her "sleeping with her dance partner" rather than her work ethic.

Craig Revel Horwood's snide remark will have also cut deep for Kevin Clifton -
who put in just as many hours alongside Stacey.

He had reached no fewer than four finals before finally being crowned.

So the suggestion that he too slept his way to the top will add a bitter taste.

There's no doubt that the pair's chemistry helped them along their path to
glory.

But as an experienced judge, Craig should know better than to brush away the
blood, sweat and tears that really won the trophy.

headline: If you sleep with partner like Stacey it helps you win
subheadline: EXCLUSIVE: JUDGE CRAIG SHOCKS STARS AND AUDIENCE ON STRICTLY TV SHOW
content_plain:
CRAIG Revel Horwood stunned Strictly's studio audience by saying contestants
should sleep with their dance partners like Stacey Dooley if they want to win.

Stacey's mum Di stormed out from the TV recording after the judge's shocking
remarks. Last night he said: "I'm deeply sorry for the offence."

I m offence.

dee l sorr offence " Stacey 32 " Journalist Stacey, 32, won last year with pro
partner Kevin Clifton, 36  who she is now in a relationship with

Full Story  Pages Six and Seven

headline: Rory just two hot to handle
content_plain:
Georgia.............10 Scotland..........44 RORY HUTCHINSON scored two tries to
force himself into World Cup contention as Scotland ran riot.

With coach Gregor Townsend set to reveal his squad on Tuesday the centre made
the most of his first Test start.

Hutchinson went over on 19 minutes after Finn Russell opened up the Georgia
defence in Tbilisi.

Then he underlined his pace and power by scything through for his second after
the break.

Ben Toolis had earlier finished off a superb move involving Russell and Greig
Laidlaw, who also kicked three penalties and three conversions.

Georgia enjoyed their best spell straight after the restart.

And Karlen Asieshvili burrowed his way over from scrum close to the line on 59
minutes.

But any prospect of a meaningful fightback was dashed when Darcy Graham dived on
a Russell chip for a clever try.

Lock Scott Cummings bullocked over for his first Scotland score to complete the
rout.

Townsend will expect another emphatic win when the teams clash at Murrayfield on
Friday.

headline: Roo dropped his trousers LIFT [...]
content_plain: Roo dropped his trousers LIFT GIRL in front of 3 women EXCLUSIVE PAGES 12 AND 13

headline: COLE FIRE
subheadline: RUGBY UNION WORLD CUP COUNTDOWN Dan desperate for final fling
content_plain:
By ADAM HATHAWAY in Sapporo then in the second game against the USA four days
later in Kobe.

DAN COLE knows he has one final shot at World Cup glory in Japan after England
fired blanks in the last two global tournaments.

When you are young you do not worry too much because you will get another one.

But Cole, capped 88 times by England and three times by the British & Irish
Lions, insists the lack of rest is nothing to lose sleep about.

"But as one of the senior guys I have to make sure that everyone pushes because
there is no tomorrow in some regard.

Prop Cole was part of the 2011 fiasco in New Zealand that ended in a
quarter-final exit to France after a campaign dogged by dwarf throwing and
nights on the sauce.

"This is the best squad I have been with in terms of tightness.

He added: "We have a four-day turnaround and then a longer one. You want to
play, not sit back and make up the numbers.

And in 2015 he was in the England side who became the only host team ever not to
make the knockout stages after defeats by Wales and Australia.

"In the last World Cup it was too individual, but now everyone is pushing each
other and working hard. There is a togetherness. "The squad was announced early,
which gives you some confidence, but there is still a lot of work to do ahead of
Japan."

"I have done it with the Lions. You go with it and everything is prepped. As a
player you have to trust and go with it. It is a four-day turnaround but nothing
to be worried about.

Cole, who turned 32 in May, will not make the finals in France in 2023 but
reckons this England side are a step up from the last two.

Head coach Eddie Jones has gambled by picking only two tight-head props  Cole
and Kyle Sinckler  in his 31-man squad.

The Leicester forward said: "I am 32 now. I doubt I will get there at 36. It
would be nice but I do not think it will happen.

"With two it's good because, I hope, you are involved in all the games."

That means both must play some part in England's opener against Tonga on

after England fired blanks in the last two global tournaments.

headline: Sad farewell as Warren loses it
content_plain:
Wales..................... 17 Ireland...................22 WALES coach Warren
Gatland had to endure a frustrating farewell to the Principality Stadium.

The final home game of his 12-year reign ended in defeat by Ireland  and he was
left with a World Cup selection headache from second-half scorers Owen Lane and
Rhys Patchell.

The Wales head coach is ready for a night of showdown talks to decide the final
squad after overcoming the emotion of his final Cardiff clash.

He said: "It will take a few hours to finalise the squad and there's probably
half a dozen positions that are probably up for debate.

"I was a bit lost for words and choked up. It was emotional.

"Even coming off the pitch I was emotional, thinking it will be my last time
here and the last time going down Westgate Street to the stadium.

"It's a special nation with special people who are very passionate and very
kind."

Jack Carty booted Ireland into a ninth-minute lead after new Wales skipper Josh
Navidi handled the ball on the floor at a ruck before Jarrod Evans levelled with
a simple penalty.

Then Ireland's flyers combined to give their side lift-off.

Will Addison soared to claim a high ball before Andrew Conway went racing away
on a mazy cross-field run to give the scoring pass for Jacob Stockdale to stroll
over in the corner.

Stockdale made it a double after 28 minutes when he pounced to scoop up Aaron
Shingler's loose offload and race to the line to make it 15-3. Ireland's pack
were smashing Wales in the scrum and were eventually rewarded with a penalty try
after Leon Brown was sent to the sin-bin for repeat offending.

But Wales' debut star Lane showed shades of George North as he powered past the
covering defence to score at the corner and narrow the gap to 12 points. The
comeback was on when Patchell sidestepped his way over with five minutes to go
but it was too little too late as Ireland held on to claim victory.

headline: DEATH SMASH AT SPA See [...]
content_plain: DEATH SMASH AT SPA See Page 55

headline: PAINE KILLER
subheadline: 4TH ASHES TEST: 3 DAYS TO GO Aussie doubts after incredible Stokes knock
content_plain:
BEN STOKES' Headingley heroics are still sending shock waves through the
Australian camp.

The Durham all-rounder's astonishing 135 not out has transformed the summer.

And the Aussies still cannot believe they are 1-1 in the series  rather than
2-0 ahead. Tim Paine (left) and Co know they should be walking out in
Wednesday's Fourth Test at Old Trafford with The Ashes already retained.
Momentum is all with England and the Aussies are unsure of their line-up, or the
sort of cricket they want to play. Even England losing James Anderson for the
final two Tests does not alter the fact Australia face many more questions than
the hosts.

England's only real issue is whether to bring in Sam Curran for Chris Woakes.

Dilemma No 1 for the Aussies, who beat Derbyshire by an innings and 54 runs in a
warm-up match yesterday, is who to drop to accommodate the returning Steve
Smith.

Marcus Harris, Usman Khawaja and Matthew Wade are in the firing line as Marnus
Labuschagne  Smith's initial concussion sub  boasts three half-centuries in
three innings, so will keep his place.

And Smith, wearing a stem guard neck protector for the first time, scored 23
against Derbyshire on Friday. It was his first innings since being KO'd by a
Jofra Archer bouncer.

One Aussie option is to include big-hitting all-rounder Mitchell Marsh  the
closest they have to a Stokes.

But the tourists also have a bowling dilemma having so far overlooked Mitchell
Starc, leading wicket-taker at the World Cup.

The Aussie paceman will surely play at Old Trafford now. Put it this way, Stokes
and Co will be delighted if he does not ...

headline: Workington class heroes
subheadline: HOW RL CLUB PAVED THE WAY FOR BEN'S HEROICS
content_plain:
IT was the stab-in-the-dark trip nearly 20 years ago which ultimately paved the
way to England finding its latest Ashes hero.

The journey which eventually was to lead to those incredible scenes at
Headingley a week ago.

On the face of it, a rugby league game between Keighley Cougars and the New
Zealand A team would appear to have little link to the England cricket side. But
coaching the tourists was a New Zealander called Ged Stokes  father of a
certain Ben  who spent one season in 1982 playing for Workington.

So, in 2002, with the Cumbrian club on the lookout for a new coach, director
Dave Smith and pal Vic Semple  who did the strapping for the team  decided to
take a punt.

Jumping in the car, they headed 120 miles south for the meeting which, two
decades later, has had such far-reaching consequences.

Semple, who is now nearly 75 but still doing the strapping at Whitehaven rugby
league club, looked back on that fateful day.

He said: "I'm not even sure if Ged knew we were coming, quite possibly not. We
just decided to sound him out because he'd had a season over here as a player.

"We wanted to ask him if he ever planned to come back.

"Sometimes you just have to be cheeky  and he took to us straightaway as
Cumbrians.

"He was keen and that was that. They came over just before Christmas, it's
unbelievable how it all turned out."

Semple grew so close to Stokes that when his time at Workington came to an end
after four years, he quit to work with him at Whitehaven.

Indeed, the families remain such good pals that Semple was a guest at Ben's
wedding and his children's christenings. And as the nation was gripped by that
sensational match-winning innings in last week's Third Test, there were few
prouder people around  even if Semple could not get to TV to see it!

He added: "Last Sunday we were all at Cockermouth Rugby Union club for a
fund-raising day, so we couldn't see the television coverage.

"Everyone had their phones out, keeping up with what was happening at
Headingley. It was an incredible day and there were quite a few drinks taken,
everyone was so delighted for him. "Ben had actually played a bit of rugby
league as a kid for a club called Broughton Rose  but there was obviously
always cricket, he was so good.

"He was up here a couple of months ago and he is exactly the same. He's still
the Ben we've known and loved all those years."

headline: Pressing on-Ward
content_plain:
DANNY WARD feels that London defying the odds does have a downside.

The Broncos host Leeds today chasing a tenth win in their fight for survival.

But the uncertainty of where they will be playing next year is causing havoc to
coach Ward's recruitment and retention plans. He said: "It's a bit of a
nightmare. If teams come in who have Super League rugby guaranteed, then I
understand why players would sign elsewhere.

"We have two scenarios so are putting together a squad capable of competing in
Super League but we've got to work with the worst case scenario as well."

headline: Wake-up call Chris
content_plain:
CHRIS CHESTER thought about quitting as Wakefield boss due to his increasing
work load.

Trinity's win over drop rivals Hull KR last time out has boosted their bid for
Super League survival.

Chester, 40, whose side host high-flying Wigan today, said: "I sat down with the
wife and really contemplated maybe just stepping away.

"I always said that if I got to the point where I was bringing my work home and
taking it out on the kids, I'd walk away.

"I felt I'd got to that point. The pressure got the better of me but she told me
not to be stupid."

headline: Don't get bowled over Joff!
content_plain:
ENGLAND bowling ace Jofra Archer stumps fans by hitting the road on an electric
scooter.

They feared for his safety in Hove, East Sussex, after a spate of accidents.

The fourth Ashes test is on Wednesday and Jofra, 24, left, is crucial. One fan
said: "We should wrap him in cotton wool."

headline: BANK OF MUM & DAD IS SUING ITS OWN KIDS
content_plain:
PARENTS who lend kids money to buy a home are increasingly going to court to get
it back.

The Bank of Mum and Dad is now the country's tenth biggest lender.

The average loan is £24,100 and one in five property deals is completed with
parents' help following house price rises.

But courts now see up to 15 cases a month of parents suing their adult children
 or the child's spouse  up from three a month in 2014. Divorce between a child
and their spouse is the most common cause of dispute  while fallouts when the
home is sold for a profit are also a factor.

Barrister Greg Williams, a family property specialist, said many disputes centre
on whether the money was "a gift, a loan, or an investment leading to a
beneficial interest".

He said: "The Bank of Mum and Dad can face an uphill struggle if there isn't
anything in writing." Research by Legal & General, meanwhile, says millions of
parents are "digging ever deeper" to lend and risk running out of cash in later
life.

robin.perrie@the-sun.co.uk 15 court cases a month in which parents sue their
children

headline: Lust for 69 plates
content_plain:
A THIRD of Brits are more likely to buy a new car next month due to the sexually
suggestive 69 number plate.

Just over half of drivers had realised the lewd number was being rolled out from
September.

Motorists in the North-West are most likely to get a car with personalised 69
plate, the poll found. Naughty private plates for sale include ORG4SM for
£150,000, CUM 2 for £8,700 and PEN I55S for £7,990.

headline: Tony feels so special
byline: By GARY CARTER Catalans.............6 Hull KR..............24
content_plain:
TONY SMITH wants to build "something special" at Hull KR  as special as Danny
McGuire's try and Ryan Shaw's 20-point haul that shoved them to the brink of
safety.

The former England boss signed a three-year deal at Rovers yesterday.

Now it is a case of beat London on Friday and they will be pretty much safe.

Smith said: "I initially came on a short-term basis with an open mind.

"I'm committed to building something special." Shaw's early try double, which
added to six goals, put the Robins in control.

But McGuire's 38thminute score, which saw brilliant play from Jez Litten, Mose
Masoe and Josh Drinkwater, stole the show.

David Mead's try, converted by Tony Gigot, was a rare show of quality from the
Dragons.

headline: Yob cake rage rap
content_plain:
A DAD-to-be threw his pregnant girlfriend over a garden fence in a row about
baking a cake.

Matthew Reynolds, 26, got angry when plans to celebrate the pregnancy at his
mum's house did not work out.

The thug's girlfriend suffered a cut eyebrow.

He also smashed panes of glass and pushed his mum to the ground.

Reynolds, of Swindon, Wilts, admitted assault and criminal damage.

Town JPs gave him a community order.

headline: FOUNDER Berry Gordy Jr refused [...]
content_plain:
FOUNDER Berry Gordy Jr refused to sign The Jackson Five in 1966 because they
were kids. Gladys Knight got him to change his mind a year later.

MAGIC

headline: CLUBBERS APP ALERT
content_plain:
CLUBBERS worried about drunk pals going missing can be reassured by a new app
which uses GPS technology to alert them if they don't make it home.

The app  Wingman  will automatically notify revellers if a pal doesn't get
back to their designated "safe place".

Creators Michael Kelly, 24, and Douglas McCrae, 25, said it is aimed at students
but can be used by anyone.

The pair plan to roll the app out in Southampton in January before taking it
nationwide in September 2020.

They hope to raise up to £150,000 start-up costs by crowdfunding. The city's
Solent University donated £5,000.

headline: £75M NEW TICKNOLOGY
subheadline:
GADGET OP IS FIRST IN BRITAIN lComputer inside heart saves gran lImplant beams
data to doctors
byline: By NICK McDERMOTT Health Editor EXCLUSIIVE
content_plain:
A GRAN is the first person in Britain to get a revolutionary in-heart computer.

The wireless implant  which is set to save the NHS £75million a year  then
beams data back to medics telling them how Margaret McDermott's ticker is
coping.

The monitor, on trial in the UK, sends doctors real-time readings  allowing
them to intervene before patients' health deteriorates further.

The makers claim that if it is rolled out across Britain it could drastically
reduce hospital admissions.

Margaret, of Birmingham, had the gadget implanted in her heart's left atrium
during an hour-long operation and says it has already changed her life for the
better.

The 75-year-old said: "It's wonderful. Every day I wake up and I can breathe,
I'm not out of breath.

"Before I was really struggling and relying on inhalers. It really feels like a
miracle."

Margaret is among ten patients taking part in trials.

Around a million people in Britain suffer heart failure  a condition in which
the heart becomes too weak to pump blood around the body properly. It is the
leading cause of hospital admissions for over-65s.

The device, the world's first in-heart microcomputer, is made by Israeli firm
Vectorious. It claims if the device was rolled out nationally here it could help
keep thousands out of hospital.

Currently, NHS treatment for heart patients only changes once they suffer from
worsening symptoms.

The trial of the device was announced ahead of the European Society of
Cardiology conference in Paris.

Experts said the "batteryless" technology should last a lifetime. It is said to
be the most accurate form of home heart monitoring yet available.

Each day patients place a strap across their chest for five minutes.

It sends the results to a hospital team, flagging any problems to medics so they
can intervene much earlier.

Currently, if doctors want to check changes to heart signs patients must first
be admitted to hospital.

Researcher Prof Francisco Leyva, consultant cardiologist at Queen Elizabeth
Hospital in Birmingham, said: "This new device has the potential to combat three
of the biggest problems relating to heart failure disease  low patient quality
of life, repeat admissions to hospital and the astronomical cost to the system
of readmissions." Nearly half of heart failure patients end up back in hospital
after initial treatment. Oren Goldshtien, head of Vectorious, said: "We believe
the monitor is a game changer in helping the million people living with heart
failure in the UK take control and manage their disease."

nick.mcdermott @the-sun.co.uk

headline: 4-drink boozing novice drowned
content_plain:
A UNI student not used to booze drowned in a freezing lake after downing four
Jagerbombs, an inquest heard.

Daniel Williams, 19, rarely drank and usually helped others to get home after a
night out.

But he was like a "zombie" after consuming 2½ times the drink-drive limit at a
student bar, the coroner was told.

The student from Sutton, South London, tried to make his way back to his
house-share alone through five inches of fresh snow in January.

He had been separated from his friends and plunged into a lake near Reading
University, Berks.

His body was found after an extensive search.

Coroner Heidi Connor said: "Drinking when you are not used to alcohol can have a
more dramatic effect."

Verdict: Accident.

headline: FORMER boxer turned songwriter Berry [...]
content_plain:
FORMER boxer turned songwriter Berry Gordy Jr borrowed $800 from his dad to
start the Motown Records label in his US hometown Detroit in 1959.

MAGIC

headline: 'Gang hit' Brit in car bombing
content_plain:
A BRIT was fighting for life last night after a suspected underworld car bombing
in South Africa.

John Burns, 48, suffered horrific injuries to his bottom and back after a blast
beneath his seat.

The businessman was driving his £50,000 Range Rover through Cape Town where he
moved from Liverpool in 2010.

Trucker Greg Muller  one of the first at the scene  said: "He told me: 'I've
been bombed.' He was losing lots of blood."

Mr Burns was under armed guard in hospital last night. Police were treating
Friday's attack as attempted murder.

Sources claim it was linked to an Australian police seizure of £76million of
cocaine shipped via South Africa by an East European drug gang.

headline: Security for 500k
content_plain:
NEARLY 500,000 Brits living in Europe get a UK state pension because they've
helped make our country the success it is.

The Prime Minister and I agreed we will continue to increase their pension for
another three years, just like those in the UK.

This move will make a real difference to people living in the EU, helping to
reassure them they have a financially secure retirement.

headline: HMS FISH 'DISASTER'
content_plain:
FISHERMEN say the dredging of a harbour to berth the aircraft carrier HMS Queen
Elizabeth has created an "ecological and economic" disaster.

In the past five years, ten million tons of material from Portsmouth, home of
the ship, and Southampton has been dumped in the Solent. Fisherman John Kennett,
of Freshwater, Isle of Wight, said: "There have been no small lobster since last
August, which indicates they are not strong enough to survive in the silt now
lying on the sea bed.

"This is an environmental disaster and an economic disaster for fishing
businesses."

headline: £200 EXPAT JOY
subheadline: Pensions will rise even with a No Deal Brexit
content_plain:
RETIRED Brits living in Europe will get a £200 annual Brexit boost to their
pensions.

Eat at q5o The promised raise quashes scare stories that 500,000 expats would
lose out under a No Deal.

Today Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd guarantees to increase payments Sa
by using the triple lock. Her staff will text OAPs in countries including Spain,
France, Portugal and Cyprus to reassure them their rights will be protected.

The move was signed off after being blocked by previous Chancellor Philip
Hammond.

A senior Whitehall source said: "Philip sat on every decision he could, even if
it meant hard-working pensioners lost out." The current state pension is worth
£168 a week.

A triple lock, guaranteed for the next three years, ensures it rises each year
either by 2.5 per cent, the rate of inflation or average earnings.

This means that pensioners at home and abroad will get a rise of a minimum of
£200 a year.

Ms Rudd was inspired by Love Island, where contestants often shouted: "I've got
a text!" She told the Sun on Sunday: "Over the coming weeks pensioners living in
the EU will receive a text message with a simple, important message.

"You will continue to receive your UK state pension when we leave on October 31.

"And they don't need to do anything to make this happen  it will carry on
automatically."

david.wooding@the-sun.co.uk 500,000 British expats living in Europe collect a UK
pension

headline: THE first Motown hit was [...]
content_plain:
THE first Motown hit was Barrett Strong's Money (That's What I Want), which got
to No2 on the Billboard R&B charts in 1959 and was covered by The Beatles in
1963.

MAGIC

headline: Bar bash Ben sign
content_plain:
A SIGN saying "It was here that Ben Stokes lamped an oik" has appeared outside
the club where the cricketer was filmed punching a man.

The blue plaque refers to an altercation outside Mbargo in Bristol in September
2017, which England's Ashes hero Stokes was involved in.

It is not known who erected the plaque on Friday. Stokes, 28, was found not
guilty of affray in August 2018.

headline: DIANA Ross's mum wanted to [...]
content_plain:
DIANA Ross's mum wanted to call her Diane but there was a clerical error on her
birth certificate. Now 75, Diana is known for her 12 No1 hits with The Supremes.

MAGIC

headline: Biker hit kills two
content_plain:
TWO people died when a motorcyclist crashed into a pedestrian.

Cops are appealing for witnesses after the 40-year-old male biker hit a woman,
34, in Battersea, South West London, on Friday night. The woman died at the
scene. The biker was taken to hospital but did not survive.

The Met Police said the next of kin were being notified and asked for any
dashcam footage that could help their investigation.

headline: Lags get cafe after hot water whinge
content_plain:
KILLERS and rapists at a high-security prison have been given a Starbucks-style
coffee shop. Lags moaned the hot water boilers on wings kept breaking down.

Now cons such as black cab rapist John Worboys can sip 50p barista-type lattes
at the new cafe at Wakefield Prison.

A source said: "All hell broke loose when they couldn't get hot water."

One prisoner asked: "Who knows how much this has cost?" But another called Tony
K defended it in a prison mag. He said: "Equipment was donated free and the
counter was made in the prison workshops. We were assured no money was diverted
from other areas."

A RECORD number of lags  34,395  are allowed Freeview TV, up four per cent,
stats reveal.

headline: STUDENTS' GRANT
byline: By DAVID WOODING Sunday Political Editor
content_plain:
SCHOOLS and colleges are to get £400million to spend on boosting the life
chances of over-16s.

Chancellor Sajid Javid will announce the biggest cash injection for higher
education in a decade this week.

The move, part of his Spending Round, will fund the launch of T-levels, a
two-year qualification being introduced in England in September 2020.

Teachers say 16 to 19-year-olds are often neglected as money is poured into
primary schools, GCSE courses and universities.

But Mr Javid last night vowed to treat sixth-form and FE col-leges "with the
seriousness they deserve". He said: "Further education is a lifeline of
opportunity for our young people.

"I want this investment to start to end the snobbishness in some quarters about
the quality and importance of a vocational education. An FE college equipped me
with the qualifications to pursue my ambitions." T-levels will give 16 to
19-yearolds a mix of classroom learning and "on the job" experience.

Details emerged yesterday after the Government announced billions of pounds in
extra funding for schools in England.

Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said the money would help young people "get
the skills to get the right jobs".

The qualifications have been developed in collaboration with industry. Teachers,
nurses and police will also be "looked after" in the Spending Round.

david.wooding@the-sun.co.uk

headline: Rest up? no Ken do
content_plain:
SUPERMODEL Kendall Jenner is bot to trot  and swim and stretch  while
holidaying with the girls.

The 23-year-old sister of Kim Kardashian seemed reluctant to leave her exercise
regime behind despite being on the sunshine break to Jamaica.

Talk about putting the rest in the shade ...

headline: SOMEONE LIKE FEUD
subheadline:
RUMOUR HAS IT SI'S UPSET lCowell fury at Adele's Grenfell record snub lNow he's
blocked her songs from his shows
byline: EXCLUSIVE by CLEMMIE MOODIE Associate Showbiz Editor
content_plain:
SIMON Cowell has vetoed all Adele tracks from his shows after the star snubbed
his Grenfell charity single, the Sun on Sunday can reveal.

Cowell, 59, does not want the Grammy-winner or any of her songs on The X Factor
or Britain's Got Talent: The Champions, which started last night. Tellingly, the
last time one of her records featured on BGT was in May 2017  a month before
the Grenfell Tower fire.

On The X Factor, her songs  previously a staple of the show  have not featured
since the blaze.

The Tottenham-born singer famously showed up to the tower block wreckage in West
London 24 hours after the tragedy.

But she refused to appear on Cowell's star-studded charity single, a re-working
of Simon and Garfunkel's Bridge Over Troubled Water. Last night a source told
The Sun on Sunday: "Simon put his heart and soul into that recording, and used
up a lot of favours getting so many big names to lend their voices and give up
their time for free.

"He saw Adele down at Grenfell and assumed she'd leap at the chance to help
raise more funds.

"Unfortunately negotiations came to a grinding halt, and she declined to take
part.

"Understandably Simon was frustrated, and as a result currently refuses to play
any of her songs on his shows.

"Say what you like about Simon, he's a genuine guy. If Adele wouldn't help him
out, then he's not going to boost her album sales by playing her tracks.

"The stats speak for themselves  whilst pre-2017 Adele was a staple on The X
Factor, her tunes haven't appeared post-Grenfell.

"Clearly Adele is no longer in vogue with Simon or his creative team."

Songs penned by Adele used to be a popular choice among contestants on Cowell's
ITV shows.

In 2011 then-judge Louis Walsh tried to ban X Factor wannabes from singing Adele
tracks at auditions because so many were doing them.

Past winners James Arthur, 31, and Sam Bailey, 42, were among those to perform
her songs.

But the last person to sing one was Ryan Lawrie in October 2016.

Adele herself has not appeared on it since December 2015.

In May 2017, BGT hopeful Kyle Tomlinson belted out Rolling In The Deep  the
last time one of her songs has featured on the show.

Industry experts previously claimed Adele's chart success has been helped by The
X Factor.

Stars including Robbie Williams, Liam Payne, Rita Ora, James Blunt and Stormzy
all appeared on Cowell's single, released a week after the devastating fire
killed 72 people.

clementine.moodie@thesun.co.uk

headline: 155mph racer rap
content_plain:
A POSTIE who raced another driver at speeds up to 155mph has avoided a jail
sentence.

Daniel Grantham 28, was "goaded" by the stranger, a court heard.

He only pulled up in his BMW after a fourmile police chase on the A610 near
Nottingham.

The second driver was never caught.

Grantham, of Giltbrook, Notts, admitted dangerous driving. He got a suspended
ten-month jail sentence and was banned from the road for a year.

headline: Saved by his boots
content_plain:
A MAN unconscious in a ditch was saved when council binmen spotted his boots
poking up.

They raised the alarm and medics took the "well-dressed" victim to hospital for
treatment.

He may have lain by the road in Wymondham, Norfolk, all night.

Bin driver Jonathan Osborne, 61, said: "I was up high and could see into the
ditch. I saw a pair of boots. The man was still breathing."

headline: THE UK's biggestselling Motown single [...]
content_plain:
THE UK's biggestselling Motown single is I Just Called To Say I Love You by
Stevie Wonder, which sold 1.8million copies. Lionel Richie's Hello is second at
964,000.

MAGIC

headline: Race jibe comp for white guy
content_plain:
A STEELWORKER has won a payout for suffering racial abuse  even though he is
white.

Wayne Hoch, 35, was called a n***er, w** and kaffir, an insult used in South
Africa.

His face was superimposed on to the photos of black bodies.

s

And owners joined in the torment at Thor Anderson Steel Fabrications in
Ulverston, Cumbria, a tribunal heard. Wayne, who is white with blond hair, has
been awarded £54,686 for constructive unfair dismissal and racial harassment at
the Carlisle hearing.

Hoch, who was born in South Africa but lived in England since he was 18, said:
"I almost ended my life from the stress."

The firm has been approached for comment.

headline: Schools aid vow
content_plain:
TOUGH new measures to tackle under-performing and coasting schools will be
revealed by Education Secretary Gavin Williamson this week.

Outstanding schools will no longer be exempt from routine Ofsted inspections.

And spot checks will ensure parents have up-to-date information about the
quality of their kids' education.

Mr Williamson, right, will unveil more support for struggling schools and
funding for a trust to turn around those with longterm problems.

headline: Konta can Jo all the way says Martina
content_plain:
MARTINA NAVRATILOVA says Jo Konta is playing at the peak of her powers as she
aims for a first Major crown.

Brit Konta who reached the French Open semis and Wimbledon last eight this year,
faces world No 3 Karolina Pliskova today in the US Open last 16.

Her performances here in New York have been top notch, impressing 18-time Slam
winner Navratilova.

The all-time great was particularly blown away by her third-round straight-sets
destruction of China's Zhang Shuai on Friday and said: "She looked great.

"Everything was working  I think she had a very specific game plan.

"She knew what she wanted to do so she had that clarity and she played with
clarity.

"She made a few more unforced errors in that second set but overall the ratio
was fantastic.

"She really went for the right shots at the right time and mixed things up. It
was an A-plus performance.

"When you have more variety yourself, you can handle the variety of opponents
because you have different options on different shots.

"It seems like she's playing more on instinct now  she knows what she wants to
do and doesn't have to think about it.

"Because of that I think she's cut out the unforced errors."

Pliskova, like Konta, is a big hitter and their fourth-round clash promises to
be explosive. The last time they met was in the final of the Italian Open in
Rome in May. The big-serving Czech, 27, was triumphant on that occasion but
Konta reckons she has improved since then.

The world No 16 has looked great at Flushing Meadows and fears no one as the
28-year-old aims to reach the last eight in the Big Apple for the first time.

Konta, who failed to get past the second round of any Major in 2018, said: "I'd
like to think that I've even grown as a player since Rome, as well.

"I am actually looking forward to seeing how I can do a bit better, how I can
just maybe ask some better questions this time around.

"I don't think there's any specific magic click or pill or anything.

"But I feel I've been giving myself every opportunity possible to get better and
grow.

"From a big-picture perspective, I've played a lot of matches this year but I
feel good."

headline: Heat bills food fast
content_plain:
A QUARTER of Brits will eat less to pay heating bills, a study found.

And more than a third, 38 per cent, are worried about winter bills  up from 21
per cent last year.

Two thirds said they would wear extra layers, a quarter will use hot water
bottles and one in seven plan on moving more to stay warm.

Norwich, London and Belfast residents were the most likely to economise, the
poll of 2,000 folk by comparison website moneysupermarket found. A spokesman
said: "Many people are already worried about being able to heat their homes
through the winter."
